Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot



Chapter 1



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Fifteen [categories of] women<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> requires that the widow of any man who died without legitimate or illegitimate issue be married by the man’s brother. If, however, that brother is forbidden one of the deceased’s wives by the incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a> or the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-10" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-10"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–10</a>, she may not be married by the brother to whom she is forbidden.</i> free their co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Hillel hold that if one widow is forbidden, all co-widows are forbidden. This is not accepted by the House of Shammai, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.6.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i> and the co-wives of their co-wives from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate forever<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">If one of three brothers had married the second brother’s daughter and another woman, died childless, the other wife was married by the third brother who already had another wife, if the third also dies childless both of his widows are forbidden because one of them is forbidden. This scenario can be extended to <i>n</i> polygamous brothers; <i>n</i> arbitrary.</i>. They are the following: one’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">This statement seems to be needed only for an illegitimate daughter, except the daughter from a gentile or a slave woman who are not legally his relatives (Rashi <i>ad loc</i>.). Legitimate children are covered by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>. However, the Yerushalmi (Note 135) does not make any distinction between legitimate and illegitimate daughters.<br>Sadducees (followed by Karaites and Christians) did forbid marriage with a niece since marriage with an aunt is a biblical prohibition and they held that the incest prohibitions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a> are gender symmetric. Pharisaic opinion is that “one does not introduce punishable offence by argument;” what is written is forbidden, what is not written is not (biblically) forbidden.</i>, his daughter’s daughter and his son’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a>.</i>, his wife’s daughter and her daughter‘s daughter and her son’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>: “The genitals of a women and her daughter (including mother-in-law and wife) you may not [both] uncover, her son’s daughter (wife’s granddaughter or wife as paternal grandmother’s daughter) or her daughter’s daughter (this forbids the wife’s maternal grandmother) you may not marry to uncover her genitals; they are relatives, it is tabu.”</i>, his mother-in-law and his mother-in-law’s mother and his father-in-law’s mother, his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">This is needed only for the maternal halfsister (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:9" href="/Leviticus.18.9"><i>Lev</i>. 18:9</a>) married to a paternal halfbrother. It will be established that the levirate applies only to paternal brothers; the first marriage of the halfsister was legitimate.</i> and his maternat aunt<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:13" href="/Leviticus.18.13"><i>Lev</i>. 18:13</a>.</i> and his wife’s sister<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>.</i>, his maternal halfbrother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>. It is assumed that the halfbrother died or divorced his wife who then married a paternal halfbrother of the man in question to whom she was not related. The earlier marriage to the maternal halfbrother forbade her permanently to the levir, the brother-in-law on the husband’s side.<br>Since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25" href="/Deuteronomy.25"><i>Deut</i>. 25</a>, “brother” is assumed to mean “paternal brother”, it needs some discussion in the Halakhah why in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a> “brother” may mean “maternal or paternal brother” since the usual stance is that in legal texts one word can have only one meaning.</i>, the wife of his brother who did not live in his world<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> introduces the rules of the levirate with the statement “If brothers live together”. This means that a brother born after the death of another cannot marry the widow of the deceased, i. e., the childless widow does not have to wait until the newborn baby grows up to marry her but, if there is no other brother, she may immediately marry outside the family.</i>, and his daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This is obvious (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:15" href="/Leviticus.18.15"><i>Lev</i>. 18:15</a>) except for the case that the son had died and his widow married a brother of her father-in-law unrelated to her. The prohibition of 18:15 is permanent; the earlier marriage to the son forbade her permanently to the father-in-law.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Fifteen [categories of] women free their co-wives”, etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifra Ṣaw Parashah</i> 2(9–10); another version of 2(10) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 39b" href="/Yevamot.39b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 39b</a>. The basis of the argument is the 12th exegetical rule of R. Ismael [Introduction to <i>Sifra</i> (2)]: If anything was in some set and was removed from it for another purpose, you cannot return it to that set unless the verse returns it explicitly. See <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 85:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.85.6"><i>Midraš</i> <i>Gen</i>.<i>rabba</i> 85(6</a>) for a formulation of 2(10) referring more directly to the rule. (For an introduction to these rules, see H. Guggenheimer, <i>Logical Problems in Jewish Tradition</i>, in: Confrontations with Judaism, Ph. Longworth, ed., London 1966, pp. 171–196; <i>Über ein bemerkenswertes logisches System aus der Antike</i>, Methodos 1951, pp. 150–161.) What exactly was permitted, became forbidden, and is now commanded is a matter of interpretation in the next paragraphs.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:9" href="/Leviticus.6.9"><i>Lev</i>. 6:9</a>, speaking of the leftovers of cereal offerings in the Tabernacle. These leftovers must be eaten by priests, in the holy precinct, and unleavened, after the prescribed rites were performed.</i> “unleavened it must be eaten”. Since it was permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Before dedication as offering, the flour was profane and permitted to everybody. It is in the set of unrestricted permitted food.</i> and then forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">After dedication and before the prescribed rites were performed, the flour is forbidden to everybody, including priests. It is no longer in any set of permitted food.</i>, when it became permitted again<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">After the prescribed rites were performed, it cannot return to the set of unrestricted permitted food.</i> should one think it returned to its prior permission? The verse states “unleavened it should be eaten” as commandment. Similarly, “her levir shall come upon her” as a commandment. Since she was permitted and then forbidden, when she became permitted again should one think she returned to her prior permission<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A rhetorical question; this is impossible by rule 12.</i>? The verse states “her levir shall come upon her” as commandment.
Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 40a" href="/Yevamot.40a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 40a</a>, the parallel arguments, in inverse order, are attributed to Rava, a preeminent authority. He is known sometimes to represent Yerushalmi positions, cf. צבי דוֹר, תוֹרת ארץ ישׂראל 1971. בבבל, דביר, תל אביב</i> explains the <i>baraita</i>: “Unleavened it must be eaten”. Since it was permitted before it was dedicated, if one wants to eat it, he eats, not to eat, he does not eat. When he dedicated it became forbidden. When the fistful<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">A fistful of the offering with all the incense, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:8" href="/Leviticus.6.8"><i>Lev</i>. 6:8</a>, brought to the altar to be burned. Once the offering starts to burn, the remainder is permitted to the priests.</i> was brought it became permitted again; should one think it returned to its prior permission? If he wants to eat it, he eats, not to eat, he does not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This is also Rava’s argument in the Babli. The Babli corrects the statement since the obligation to eat the remainders of the offering is repeated several times in <i>Ex</i>. and <i>Lev</i>.</i>? The verse states “unleavened it must be eaten” as commandment. Similarly, “her levir shall come upon her” as a commandment. Since she was permitted before she was married to his brother, if he wanted to bring her into his house<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">As his bride.</i>, he could bring her, not to bring her into his house, he would not bring her. When she was married to his brother she became forbidden. When his brother died childless she became permitted again. Should one think she returned to her prior permission, if he wanted to bring her into his house, he could bring her, not to bring her into his house, he would not bring her? The verse states “her levir shall come upon her” as commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">He <i>has</i> to marry her whether he likes her or not.</i>.
Rebbi Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (<i>l</i>. <i>c</i>. 39b) this is the opinion of Rav Isaac ben Eudaimon, a minor figure. Here also, the author R. Huna of this paragraph does not have the authority of R. Yose of the preceding paragraph.</i> explains the <i>baraita</i>: “Unleavened it must be eaten”. Since it was permitted before it was dedicated, if one wants to eat it leavened, he eats it, unleavened, he eats it. <sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The argument of the preceding paragraph has to be inserted here. Since the corrector of the ms. did not insert anything here, it probably was not in the ms. before the copyist; the lacuna can be replaced by three dots.</i> The verse states “unleavened it should be eaten” as commandment. Similarly, “her brother-in-law shall come upon her” as commandment. Since she was permitted before she was married to his brother, if he wanted to bring her into his house because of her shapeliness, he could bring her, because of her money, he could bring her. When she was married to his brother she became forbidden. When his brother died childless she became permitted again. Should one think she returned to her prior permission, if he wanted to bring her into his house because of her shapeliness, he could bring her, because of her money, he could bring her? The verse states “her levir shall come upon her” as commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">She remains forbidden if the levir has any intention other than to fulfill the commandment. This means that in practice the brother has to refrain from marrying the sister-in-law to avoid enjoying her sexually.</i>.
It turns out that Rebbi Ḥuna follows Abba Shaul, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A different formulation, stressing the opposition of the anonymous majority, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 39b" href="/Yevamot.39b">Babli 39b</a>.</i>: “Abba Shaul says, one who brings his sister-in-law into his house because of beauty or another reason<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Other than fulfilling the biblical commandment.</i> commits intercourse of prostitution and the child is close to be a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Who is forbidden to marry a Jewish partner, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3"><i>Deut</i>. 23:3</a>.</i>.”
Does Abba Shaul hold with Rebbi Aqiba? Since Rebbi Aqiba said, there exists a bastard from a sister-in-law! What Rebbi Aqiba said refers to a sister-in-law who whored<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">R. Aqiba holds that any child born of any forbidden union is a bastard; the majority opinion is that bastards are created only by incestuous relations that either are capital crimes or sanctioned by extirpation (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhot 4:15</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.2-13">11:1</a>). Since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>) “the wife of the deceased may not belong to any outside unrelated man” he holds that any marriage of a widow not released from levirate duty to another man is invalid and her relationship is one of whoring.<br>A parallel, but more differentiated, statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a">Babli 92a</a>.</i>. What Abba Shaul said refers to his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">In a completely legal situation.</i>. It comes like Rebbi Yose ben Ḥalaphta<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The Tanna, who is a much more important authority than the older Abba Shaul. The formulation as a story implies that R. Yose followed Abba Shaul as a matter of personal piety but did not impose his discipline on others.</i> since Rebbi Yose ben Ḥalaphta contracted a levirate marriage with his brother’s wife. He ploughed five times and planted five saplings and had intercourse using a bedsheet<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">He avoided direct contact with his levirate wife following Abba Shaul. In a regular marriage, such behavior permits the wife to force a divorce (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 48a" href="/Ketubot.48a">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 48a</a>). The story contradicts <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnah 4:4</a> which states that once married, the sister-in-law becomes a wife <i>in all respects</i>, including the husband’s duty to satisfy her sexual needs. Tosaphot (Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 118b) discuss the Yerushalmi versions but they read that R. Yose contracted levirate marriages <i>with the widows of his brothers</i> implying that he married five widows, had with each of them only the one biblically required intercourse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>) and then divorced them. This custom was followed by some Jewish Berber groups in the Atlas mountains to modern times. (R. Moses Margalit restricts the avoidance of direct contact to the first intercourse in fulfillment of the biblical command. R. David Fraenckel concludes that R. Yose rejects <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnah 4:4</a> except that he agrees that the wife acquired in levirate can be divorced by the rules applying to any other wife.)<br>The parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 118b" href="/Shabbat.118b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 118b</a>, formulated as personal statement of R. Yose does not mention either the sheet or levirate marriage, and appears in a completely different context.</i>. These are they: Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose, Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Only the first two are renowned; R. Ismael ben R. Yose was the teacher of R. Yehudah the Prince.</i>, Rebbi Menaḥem ben Rebbi Yose, and Rebbi Ḥalaphta ben Rebbi Yose, Rebbi Eudaimon ben Rebbi Yose.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>.</i>: “The genitals of your brother’s wife you may not uncover.” One understands both his paternal and his maternal brothers’ wives, both the wife of a brother who lived concurrently with him or onewho did not live concurrently with him, whether he had children or did not have children<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 55a" href="/Yevamot.55a">Babli, 55a</a>, independently from the verse quoted next. Therefore, the Babli engages in a series of arguments to indicate that “brother” in this verse has a wider meaning than “brothers” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>; among them a reference to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:9" href="/Leviticus.18.9"><i>Lev</i>. 18:9</a>, where “sister” is expressly defined as at least a halfsister from any side. [A tannaitic source, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 11 8" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_11.8"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 11(8</a>), restricts the meaning of “brother” in this verse to that in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. Cf. R. Abraham ben David’s commentary ad loc.] The Yerushalmi has no need for an additional argument since this paragraph is still a continuation of the first one in this Halakhah, an application of the 12th exegetical rule (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.2">Note 13</a>), only that the argument is inverted. Since we know that if something was permitted, forbidden, and permitted again, the set of second permissions must be a proper subset of that of first permissions, it is necessary that the restrictions applied to the meaning of “brother” in the second set cannot apply to the prohibition. {The Babli avoids using rules 7–13 of R. Ismael and never has systematic comparisons between arguments following R. Ismael and those following R. Aqiba.}</i>. She became permitted, excluded from this set, by levirate. Should I think unconditionally? It is said here<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>.</i>: “When brothers live together”; and it is said there<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 42:13" href="/Genesis.42.13"><i>Gen</i>. 42:13</a>. להלן is a Babylonism; in true Galilean style it would be תמן. The parallel argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli 17b</a>; because the constructive framework of the Yerushalmi is missing in the Babli, the latter has a lengthy discussion why the definition of “brother” for levirate is narrower than that for incest prohibitions.</i>: “We, your servants, are twelve brothers.” Since the “brothers” mentioned there are paternal brothers, so the “brothers” mentioned here must be paternal brothers.
<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli, 17b</a>, follows <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. #288 in inferring from “together” not only to exclude the wife of a predeceased brother but also the wife of the maternal halfbrother who in a patriarchal world would not live in their clan.</i>“Together”, this excludes the wife of his brother who did not live in his world. “And one of them died”, of those who lived. Even if he divorced her and then died? This one is exempted<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Exempted from the rules of the levirate.</i>. “Without child”. Therefore, if he has a child she is exempted.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev.</i> 18:29</a>. The verse is not quoted exactly. The argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 10 10" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_10.10"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 10(10</a>). A similar version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 3b" href="/Yevamot.3b">Babli 3b</a>.</i>: “For anyone who is acting out any of these abominations will be extirpated”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is made explicit (in the name of the 5th generation Galilean Amora R. Jonah) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 8a" href="/Yevamot.8a">Babli 8a</a>: The verse considers all incest prohibitions as equivalent.</i>. Was not the brother’s wife in the set of all incest prohibitions and was removed from this set by the levirate? Could one say that all other incest prohibitions were removed from this set by levirate? Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: “upon her<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister to be ‘bundle’ together, to uncover her genitals in addition [to the sister’s] in her lifetime.” Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.11">Note 51</a>.</i>”, “upon her<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5">Deut. 25:5</a>.</i></i>”: “her levir shall come upon her.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5">Deut. 25:5</a>.</i></i>” Since with respect to “upon her” which was said there, the verse speaks about paternal brothers, so with respect to “upon her” which was said here<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister to be ‘bundle’ together, to uncover her genitals in addition [to the sister’s] in her lifetime.” Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.11">Note 51</a>.</i>, the verse speaks about paternal brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">This implies (a) that a sister which also is a sister-in-law cannot be subject to the levirate and (b) no woman subject to an incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18</a> can be subject to the levirate, as spelled out in the Mishnah.</i>.
Rebbi Benjamin ben Gidal and Rebbi Aḥa were sitting together. Rebbi Aḥa mentioned the statement of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina. Rebbi Benjamin bar Gidal said to him: Or maybe: Since with respect to “in addition” which was said there<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister to be ‘bundle’ together, to uncover her genitals in addition [to the sister’s] in her lifetime.” Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.11">Note 51</a>.</i>, the verse speaks about one who is not a sister-in-law, so with respect to “in addition” which was said here<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5">Deut. 25:5</a>.</i></i>, does the verse speak about one who is not a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Since an argument based on the invariable meaning of words in legal texts must work both ways and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i>18:18</a> obviously includes the prohibition of a sister-in-law who is not a brother’s wife, R. Yose ben Ḥanina’s argument seems illogical.</i>? Rebbi Aḥa said to him: The Torah mentions<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5">Deut. 25:5</a>.</i></i> the brother’s wife and you say, the verse speaks about one who is not a sister-in-law! Rebbi Benjamin bar Gidal said to him: The Torah mentions<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister to be ‘bundle’ together, to uncover her genitals in addition [to the sister’s] in her lifetime.” Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.11">Note 51</a>.</i> one who is not a sister-in-law and you say a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The implication from <i>Deut.</i> to <i>Lev.</i> would restrict the prohibition of the sister-in-law to a brother’s widow!</i>! Rebbi Aḥa was offended by him. Rebbi Yose said, not that Rebbi Aḥa disagreed but he insisted on the formulation he had heard from his teacher. What about it? Since “in addition” mentioned there<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5">Deut. 25:5</a>.</i></i> is about a brother’s widow, so “in addition” here<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister to be ‘bundle’ together, to uncover her genitals in addition [to the sister’s] in her lifetime.” Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.11">Note 51</a>.</i> is even about a brother’s widow<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The correct implication, parallel to the argument of R. Yose ben Ḥanina, is that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a> applies even to the widow of the childless brother as claimed in the Mishnah.</i>.
The Torah said<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>.</i>: “Do not take a woman in addition to her sister”. Not only her, her co-wife from where? The verse says “to ‘bundle’ together”, not her co-wife nor her co-wife’s co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The problem is the verb form לִצְרוֹר which has been translated as “to ‘bundle’ together” (from צרר II, Arabic صرّ) but which might also be taken as “to be a co-wife” (from צרה II, Arabic ضرّ). The Yerushalmi opts for the first version. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 13a" href="/Yevamot.13a">Babli, 13a</a>, the argument is that the verb appears in two forms, צרר here and צור in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:25" href="/Deuteronomy.14.25"><i>Deut.</i> 14:25</a>. The duplication of consonants is taken to imply “many bundlings together”, to exclude the co-wives’ co-wives. That argument is more in the line of R. Aqiba’s teaching than the bare argument here.</i>. Not only his wife’s sister, all other incest prohibition from where? Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: A conclusion <i>de minore ad majus</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The first of R. Ismael’s rules (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.2">Note 13</a>) which is universally accepted, also by R. Aqiba.</i><i>.</i> Since his wife’s sister, who is under an incest prohibition which may be lifted after being imposed<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">After the wife’s death.</i>, nevertheless is prohibited from the levirate, all other women under incest prohibitions which cannot be lifted after being imposed not much more so! Since in the first case the incest prohibition exempts the prohibited co-wife, all other incest prohibitions also exempt their co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Since there is no argument pointing to the opposite conclusion.</i>. This follows Rebbi Aqiba.
Following Rebbi Ismael? <sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 11 10" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_11.10"><i>Sifra Qedošim</i> <i>Pereq</i>11(10</a>); a version combining the argument with the argument excluding the co-wives in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 3b" href="/Yevamot.3b">Babli 3b</a>. Both sources are anonymous.</i> Rebbi Ismael stated an argument <i>de minore ad majus.</i> Since his wife’s sister is particular being under incest prohibition for whose violation one is punished if intentional by extirpation, if in error by an obligation to bring a purification offering, and is barred from the levirate, all other women under incest prohibitions for whose violation one is sanctioned if intentional by extirpation, if in error by the obligation to bring a purification offering, should be barred from the levirate.
What is the difference between them? A widow for the High Priest. For him who says, a woman under an incest prohibition which may be lifted after being imposed, this one, not being permitted after being prohibited<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A widow is forbidden for the High Priest as a new wife, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i>21:14</a>. No sanction in mentioned in this case, in contrast to violations of incest prohibitions whose punishment is detailed in Chapter 20. On the other hand, following the principle that “one ascends in holiness but does not descend”, a High Priest may become inactive but he cannot return to the status of common priest permitted to marry a widow.</i>, should be barred from the levirate. For him who says, a woman under an incest prohibition for which one is punished if intentional by extirpation, if in error by the obligation to bring a purification offering, is barred from the levirate, in this case since one is not sanctioned if intentional by extirpation, if in error by the obligation of a purification offering, should be permitted for the levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This conclusion has to be shown to be faulty.</i>.
Rebbi Ayvu bar Naggari, Crispus, in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. “The dead man’s wife should not be outside, to a strange man<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>. “To be” referring to a woman means “to be married”, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:2" href="/Deuteronomy.24.2"><i>Deut.</i>24:2</a>. זר “strange” means “outside the clan”, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 17:5" href="/Numbers.17.5"><i>Num.</i> 17:5</a>. This is interpreted here to mean “outside her marriage group”, e. g., the High Priest for the widow.</i>.” That is a wife who is a stranger to him. The Torah said, she should not be his wife even in case of a commandment. That being, she should not need <i>ḥalîṣah!</i> Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In the differently formulated Babli parallel, 20a, the author is Rav. It seems therefore that one should read “Rav Jeremiah” (first generation Babylonian) rather than “Rebbi Jeremiah” (fifth generation Galilean).</i> said: “his sister-in-law, his sister-in-law”, the Torah increased the cases of <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut.</i> 25:7</a> reads: “If the man does not want to take his sister-in-law, then his sister-in-law shall go to the elders at the gate and she shall say: My levir refuses to sustain his brother’s name in Israel, my levir does not agree.” The second “sister-in-law” seems unnecessary; if it were written “then she shall go” it would have the same meaning. Since we hold that no word in the Torah is unnecessary, R. Jeremiah concludes that there is a sister-in-law who goes even though the levir did not refuse but Heaven refused for him. This is the subject of the next paragraph.</i>! If from “his sister-in-law, his sister-in-law”, did the Torah not increase the cases of levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut.</i> 25:7</a> also repeats “levir”, should there not be a levir who marries his sister-in-law even though the union otherwise would be forbidden?</i>? Rebbi Ismael stated<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Deut.</i> #289. There, the second “levir” is used to express what R. Jeremiah concluded from the first part of the verse: “My <i>levir</i> does not agree,” to exclude the case that the Omnipresent does not agree.</i>: “My levir refuses”. That is, my levir refused, not that Heaven refused for him. In that case, she should not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>! That means, the statement of Rebbi Jeremiah is needed, “his sister-in-law, his sister-in-law”, the Torah increased the cases of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>!
Rebbi Bun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: Does a widow need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? He said to him, is it possible to say that her <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">A Jewish marriage is performed in two stages. The first, <i>qiddushin</i>, requires the groom to hand over to the bride an object of value (today, a gold ring) or a written promise of marriage and to declare before two witnesses that the woman is betrothed to him. From that moment on they are married as far as penal law is concerned. In antiquity, the prospective bride (who probably was in her early teens) did not prepare any trousseau. Hence, after <i>qiddushin</i> she was given adequate time to prepare and then was married to live with her husband in a second public ceremony, <i>nissuïn,</i> the execution of the <i>ketubah</i> document, in which the groom mortgages all his possessions and earnings for the upkeep of his wife and the care of his children, followed by the public recitation of seven benedictions (in the presence of 10 adult males). From that moment on, the couple is required to live in intimacy. Today, the two ceremonies are separated only by the reading of the <i>ketubah</i> and, sometimes, by a rabbi’s sermon. The period between <i>qiddushin</i> and <i>nissuïn</i> is one in which the groom is legally married, but as he is forbidden marital relations with his wife, as yet has no financial responsibility. After <i>nissuïn,</i> since the wife has a claim on his property enforceable in court, he receives administration of her estate. The “preliminary marriage” contracted by <i>qiddushin</i>, in Greek speaking communities called πρωτογαμία (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 6:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.6.1.6"><i>Demay</i> 6, Note 19</a>), can be dissolved only by a valid bill of divorce.</i> are legally recognized<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Incestual <i>qiddushin</i> (where the relationship is punished by extirpation by the Heavenly court or as a capital crime by the earthly court) are null and void. Forbidden marriages for which no particular penalties are indicated, such as marriages of priests with unsuitable women or marriages of bastards, are sinful but valid. Since the marriage of a High Priest with a widow would be valid, it is clear that a levirate union would be sinful but valid and, therefore, the widow needs <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i> and you say she may not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? He answered him: But <i>qiddushin</i> of a she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A woman lacking secondary feminine sex characteristics held to be infertile.</i> are legally recognized and one says that she does not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>! He said to him, the she-ram was removed because of another reason: “she will bear<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Deut.</i> #289, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 12a" href="/Yevamot.12a">Babli 12a</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.6"><i>Deut.</i> 25:6</a>: “It shall be that the firstborn <i>she will bear</i> should replace the name of his dead brother”.</i>”, this excludes the one who cannot have children.
Instead of inferring from his wife’s sister that all women under incest prohibitions remain prohibited<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">For levirate; see above, Notes 50–55.</i>, deduce from his brother’s wife that all women under incest prohibitions become permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">That the prohibitions are eliminated by the duty of levirate. The argument is repeated in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 8a" href="/Yevamot.8a">Babli, 8a</a>, by Amoriam of the last Babylonian generation who add an additional argument.</i>! Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Since the authors quoted in the following are of early generations, this must be R. Mana I.</i> said,one infers two prohibitions from two prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">One pre-existing prohibition to which was added the additional prohibition of adultery when she married the brother.</i> but one does not infer two prohibitions from one prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of an unrelated woman, the prohibition of adultery and that of marrying the brother’s wife are one and the same.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Abun: For anything induced by a cause, if the cause is removed the prohibition is removed. But for anything not induced by a cause, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains. What is that? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Bun said, e. g., those fifteen categories of women. That you should not say that his daughter is forbidden to him before she is married to his brother; once she is married to his brother she is permitted to him.
<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 9a" href="/Yevamot.9a">Babli 9a</a>. There, many other interpretations are given and the discussion extends up to fol. 10b.</i> Levi bar Sisi asked before Rebbi: Should we not state “sixteen women”? One’s mother who was raped by his father married to his paternal halfbrother<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">According to the majority interpretation, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1"><i>Deut.</i> 23:1</a> does not forbid the unmarried mother of a son to his paternal halfbrothers. R. Jehudah disagrees but even he must hold that the prohibition of the unwed mother to the halfbrothers of her son is not severely penalized and therefore, a marriage would be legally valid. The incest prohibitions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18</a> all speak of the “father’s wife”.</i>. He said to him, it is evident that this person has no brain in his head. And why? He said to him, because of Rebbi Jehudah, because Rebbi Jehudah forbids the one who was raped or seduced by his father. Does Rebbi Jehudah not agree that if [the halfbrother] gave her <i>qiddushin,</i> the preliminary marriage is legally recognized? But because we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.5.1">Mishnah 1:5</a>.</i>: “Six incest prohibitions more severe than these; because they are married to others their co-wives are free.” And Rebbi Ḥiyya stated thereupon: <sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta <i>Yebamot</i> 1:7</a>. In that case, the marriage is valid and the co-wives are freed as co-wives of a forbidden one. But if the “marriage” of the brother was in sin, it was in deadly sin and the marriage was not legally recognized. In that case, the brother was not married to the forbidden woman and the so-called co-wife was in fact the only wife and subject to the laws of the levirate.</i>“If they may marry his brother without sin their co-wives are freed from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate.” And among all of them there is only his mother who was raped by his father married to his paternal halfbrother. Why did we not state this? Because Rebbi Ḥiyya stated it, should we not state it? Certainly we should state it! But because we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 9b" href="/Yevamot.9b">Babli 9b</a>, in the name of R. Ḥiyya.</i>: “Her sister who also is her sister-in-law either takes <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or accepts the levirate.” We find in all cases<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The complicated scenario for all 15 cases of the Mishnah is given in detail by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Yevamot 9b" href="/Rashi_on_Yevamot.9b">Rashi in his Commentary to <i>Yebamot</i> 9b</a>. In the 16th case, if the raped woman married a son of the man who raped her, her sister cannot marry her son since the maternal aunt is forbidden in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:13" href="/Leviticus.18.13"><i>Lev.</i> 18:13</a>. Therefore, her sister cannot be her sister-in-law in a case involving prohibited levirate.</i> that her sister who also is her sister-in-law accepts the levirate except for his mother who was raped by his father married to his paternal halfbrother.
Isaac, the son of the isatis grower<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">His name appears only here.</i>, said that Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish asked, should we state sixteen women? <i>Ḥalîṣah</i> frees her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">This cryptic argument is explicit in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 10b" href="/Yevamot.10b">Babli 10b</a> in the form of a discussion between R. Joḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish. It is generally agreed that when a levir freed his brother’s widow from the levirate by the ceremony of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, she is forbidden to him and all other brothers. The majority opinion is that she is forbidden not as his brother’s wife since that prohibition was eliminated when levirate became possible but because it is written in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יִבְנֶה אֶת־בֶּית אָחִיו which is interpreted not as “who <i>would</i> not build his brother’s house but as “who <i>will</i> not build”; if he refused once he will not build in the future. If the brother who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nevertheless afterwards marries his sister-in-law, that marriage is recognized since no special penalties are attached to this prohibition. If he then dies childless, according to R. Simeon ben Laqish she is forbidden to any remaining brothers as wife of the first brother since for them that prohibition was never lifted. Since she is severely forbidden, the co-wife is free without ceremony.</i>! Rebbi Jacob the Southerner said before Rebbi Yose, why was this not stated? Because of Rebbi Aqiba, since Rebbi Aqiba said there is a bastard from a woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">R. Aqiba, who denies any difference between severely or simply forbidden marriages, declares all children born from all kinds of forbidden marriages as bastards forbidden to marry untainted Jewish partners.</i>. One should have stated it for the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Who disagree with R. Aqiba.</i>! We came to state only things everybody agreed to. It turns out that Isaac, the son of the isatis grower, holds with Rebbi Immi. Rebbi Yasa said, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagreed<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli quotes only the tradition here attributed to R. Immi.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he is not guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">“Guilty” of the severe sin of incest with the brother’s wife.</i> for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, but the brothers are guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Both he and the brothers are guilty for the co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Since she was not selected for the ceremony, her status vis-à-vis the brother performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is not different from that vis-à-vis the other brothers.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, neither he nor the brothers are guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or for the co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Since any of the brothers could have performed the ceremony, the severe prohibition was lifted for all of them and was never re-instituted.</i>. Rebbi Immi switches the attributions<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Since the position of R. Simeon as quoted by R. Yasa contradicts the position of R. Simeon quoted by R. Isaac the isatis grower’s.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said before Rebbi Yasa, does not Rebbi Immi switch the attributions? But Rebbi Joḥanan had several opinions<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">He taught different positions to different students (R. Immi and R. Yasa).</i>. Did Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish have several opinions<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Should he have changed his position just to oppose R. Joḥanan?</i>? The statement of Isaac, the son of the isatis grower, supports Rebbi Immi and the statements of the rabbis support Rebbi Yasa, as both Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Abba, said in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Everybody agrees about the co-wife that one is guilty. Where do they disagree? About the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he is not guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, but the brothers are guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.2-10">Halakhah 3:1</a> where the main discussion is whether <i>ḥalîṣah</i> gives the widow the additional status of divorcee, a position endorsed by Rebbi. Samuel holds that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is simply the removal of an impediment for the widow to remarry and does not create new marriage restrictions.</i> The words of the rabbis mean that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. Simeon bar Abba asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: What is the difference between having <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and divorcing<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Since in relation to a Cohen the woman freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is at least rabbinically treated as a divorcee.</i>? He said to him: You think that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, but it is only freeing. The brothers are not guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">If they would engage in sexual relations with her.</i> for her under the category of “wife of the one acting in <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but they are guilty under the category of “wife of the deceased.”
Rebbi Yudan asked: Following him who says, neither he nor the brothers are guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but are guilty for the co-wife. It is fine that he is not guilty about the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since he was cleared to have her freely<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Since he could have married her in levirate. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 9a" href="/Yevamot.9a">Babli, 9a</a>, rejects this kind of argument since any one of the brothers could have acted as levir of any of the widows which, therefore, were potentially available to all brothers and none of them could be accused of incest with any of the women.</i>. He is guilty about the co-wife since he was never cleared to have her freely. What is the difference for one of the brothers between the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and the co-wife? He turned around and said, you do not know under which head to declare him guilty, whether as wife of the one performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or wife of the deceased. Rebbi Yose said, do you think <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton? But it is only freeing. The brothers are not guilty for her under the category of “wife of the one acting in <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but they are guilty under the category of “wife of the deceased”.
Rebbi Yudan asked: Following him who says that everybody agrees about the co-wife that he is guilty, if somebody from the market gave <i>qiddushin</i> to one of them and then the levir came and performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her or had intercourse with her, did the <i>qiddushin</i> become invalid? If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her companion but then had intercourse with her, were <i>qiddushin</i> validated retroactively? Rebbi Shammai said, did not Rebbi Yannai say the following: More than 30 elders voted, from where that <i>qiddushin</i> have no legal effect on a sister-in-law? The verse says, <sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>.</i>“the wife of the deceased may not belong to any outside unrelated man”, that she cannot have any existence with another man<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">This is the unquestioned doctrine of the Yerushalmi. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92b" href="/Yevamot.92b">Babli, 92b</a>, it is the position only of Rav; Samuel doubts whether the verse invalidates <i>qiddushin</i> or simply makes them sinful like other non-incestuous forbidden unions. The editors of the Babli explicitly follow Samuel and reject the opinion of the Yerushalmi. That a transgression which is not a capital crime either before the human or the heavenly court is invalid is a very exceptional statement.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said to him, is that not a Mishnah? <sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:5:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.5.2-7"><i>Qiddušin</i> 3:5</a>. The Mishnah enumerates situations in which consummation of the marriage is impossible at the moment but may become possible later on. If consummation of the marriage is impossible then <i>qiddushin</i> are impossible since they make the bride a wife for all aspects of criminal law. She becomes a wife for matters of civil law only by entering the husband’s house in <i>nissuïn</i>, the marriage ceremony. (R. Meїr disagrees and acknowledges inoperative <i>qiddushin</i> which become activated once the impediment to marriage is removed. The second question of R. Yudan must refer to R. Meїr’s position.)</i>“Or after your levir will have performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with you, she is not preliminarily married.” And Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The text here reads “R. Joḥanan”. This has been changed in the translation following the parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 2:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.2.1.2-11"><i>Soṭah</i> 2:1</a> and a similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 8:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.8.1.2-11"><i>Kilaim</i> 8:1</a> (p. 258).</i> praised him “those who pour out gold from the wallet<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 46:6" href="/Isaiah.46.6"><i>Is</i>. 46:6</a>.</i>,” “my son, they should not be removed from your eyes,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 3:21" href="/Proverbs.3.21"><i>Prov</i>. 3:21</a>.</i>” “get wise, my son, and make me happy<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 27:11" href="/Proverbs.27.11"><i>Prov</i>. 27:11</a>.</i>”, “give to the wise that he shall become wiser<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:9" href="/Proverbs.9.9"><i>Prov</i>. 9:9</a>.</i>,” “let the wise listen that he increase in knowledge.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 1:5" href="/Proverbs.1.5"><i>Prov</i>. 1:5</a>.</i>” Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, after all these praises I can explain it following Rebbi Aqiba since Rebbi Aqiba said that there exists a bastard from a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">R. Aqiba holds that any child born of any forbidden union is a bastard; the majority opinion is that bastards are created only by incestuous relations that either are capital crimes or sanctioned by extirpation (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhot 4:15</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.2-13">11:1</a>). Since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>) “the wife of the deceased may not belong to any outside unrelated man” he holds that any marriage of a widow not released from levirate duty to another man is invalid and her relationship is one of whoring.<br>A parallel, but more differentiated, statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a">Babli 92a</a>.</i>! But there<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i>.</i> is one sister-in-law, here are two sisters-in-law. The prohibition of a single sister-in-law is different from that of two sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">The biblical argument of R. Yannai does not imply anything about the status of a co-wife; cf. Note 92 for the opposition of the Babli.</i>!
Rebbi Yudan asked: Following him who said, a man is not guilty for the woman who got <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but he is guilty for the co-wife, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing; is intercourse freeing<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Intercourse is the only way a sister-in-law can be married, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. The act not only is one of binding the woman to him but also of freeing him from the incest prohibition of the brother’s wife.</i>? As you say, if he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her, she became forbidden to the brothers. Similarly, if he had intercourse with her, she became forbidden to the brothers. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: If the first husband died, the second brother shall take her in levirate. If the second dies, the third shall take her in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">How can the third man marry her if she is forbidden to him by the levirate of the second?</i>! Rebbi Yose said, what do you think? That <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is the same as intercourse? Once he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the claim of the dead is removed from her retroactively. Retroactively fell on her the prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The incest prohibition.</i> of the dead man regarding the brothers. But if he had intercourse with her, she is his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">“In every respect”, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnah 4:4</a>. Her relationship with the first husband is legally dissolved.</i>. On that did Rebbi Ḥiyya state: If the first husband died, the second brother shall take her in levirate. If the second dies, the third shall take her in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">But if two husbands die (except in war or during an epidemic) she is considered a danger to a husband’s life and must have <i>ḥalṣîah.</i></i>.
“His maternal halfsister,” married to his paternal halfbrother. “His mother’s sister,” a man and his son married two sisters. “His wife’s sister,” two brothers being married to two sisters<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah one constructs cases in which the prohibitions of levirate can actually apply.</i>.
“His maternal halfbrother’s wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">One explains why the scenario described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Note 10</a> is intended, that there is no levirate among maternal halfbrothers.</i>” It mentions here brotherhood and it is said there: “We, your servants, are twelve brothers.” Since the “brothers” mentioned there are paternal brothers, so the “brothers” mentioned here must be paternal brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">See above, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.7">Note 37</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jonathan said, it is said here dwelling and it says there dwelling. “You will inherit and dwell there<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:13" href="/Deuteronomy.17.13"><i>Deut.</i> 17:13</a>.</i>.” Since with “dwelling” mentioned there, inheritance is connected. so with “dwelling” mentioned here, inheritance is connected. Rebbi Abun bar Bisna in the name of Rebbi Jonathan from Bet Gubrin: “they dwell<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>. The argument is based on the expression “dwell <i>together</i>”. Cf. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. #288, first paragraph. The argument is hinted at in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli, 17b</a>, as a side remark.</i>”. Those whose dwelling is in one house. This excludes maternal halfbrothers where one goes to his own father’s house and the other one goes to his own father’s house.
“Together”, this excludes the wife of his brother who did not live in his world<sup class="footnote-marker">11,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> introduces the rules of the levirate with the statement “If brothers live together”. This means that a brother born after the death of another cannot marry the widow of the deceased, i. e., the childless widow does not have to wait until the newborn baby grows up to marry her but, if there is no other brother, she may immediately marry outside the family.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli, 17b</a>, follows <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. #288 in inferring from “together” not only to exclude the wife of a predeceased brother but also the wife of the maternal halfbrother who in a patriarchal world would not live in their clan.</i>. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said, Rebbi Abba bar Mamal asked: The she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A woman lacking secondary feminine sex characteristics held to be infertile.</i> and the wife of his brother who did not live in his world were in the paragraph. Why do you see fit to say that the co-wife of the she-ram is permitted but the co-wife of the wife of his brother who did not live in his world is forbidden? He said to him, the she-ram was removed because of another reason: “she will bear”, this excludes the one who cannot have children<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Deut.</i> #289, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 12a" href="/Yevamot.12a">Babli 12a</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.6"><i>Deut.</i> 25:6</a>: “It shall be that the firstborn <i>she will bear</i> should replace the name of his dead brother”.</i>. Is it not enough that she cannot be eligible for the levirate but you also want to forbid her co-wife? But the wife of his brother who did not live in his world is under an incest prohibition and any incest prohibition frees the co-wife. Assi<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rav Assi; his statement is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 12b" href="/Yevamot.12b">Babli 12b</a>. Since he is Babylonian and slightly older than Rav for whom the title of “Rav” was invented, it seems correct to leave him without title.</i> said, the co-wife of a she-ram is forbidden. The Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.1">Mishnah 1:2</a>.</i> disagrees with Assi: “All of these, if they died, or refused, or were divorced, or turned out to be she-rams, their co-wives are permitted.” Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Mamal: Assi follows Rebbi Meїr since Rebbi Meїr said, in any case where you cannot take me in levirate you cannot take my co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli holds that the Mishnah speaks about a girl whose first husband never realized that she was congenitally sterile. Therefore, we assume that had he known this, he would not have married her; the marriage act was in error and she is not his widow. But if he knowingly married a sterile woman she is his wife and her co-wife is forbidden (accepting R. Meiir’s reasoning without quoting him.)</i>.
“And his daughter-in-law.” Rebbi Yose said, this implies that a man is permitted to marry his brother’s son’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">A daughter-in-law becomes a sister-in-law only if the son dies or divorces her and she marries a brother. The statement is attributed to R. Ḥaggai in Halakhah 11:4.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> All these free their co-wives and the co-wives of their co-wives from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate forever<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">If one of three brothers had married the second brother’s daughter and another woman, died childless, the other wife was married by the third brother who already had another wife, if the third also dies childless both of his widows are forbidden because one of them is forbidden. This scenario can be extended to <i>n</i> polygamous brothers; <i>n</i> arbitrary.</i>. And all of these, if they died, or repudiated<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Only a father can give his minor daughter in marriage. If the father died, mother or brother can marry her off, but this marriage is rabbinic only and the girl can walk out of the marriage as long as she is a minor by a simple declaration that she refuses to be married to this man.</i>, or were divorced, or found to be she-rams, their co-wives are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">An impediment to levirate must exist at the moment of death of the childless brother. If the relationship with the brother was dissolved before his death, it no longer has any influence.</i>. But you cannot say about his mother-in-law or his mother-in-law’s mother that they were found to be she-rams or that they had repudiated<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">If they had a daughter they must have had marital relations when adult.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “All these free their co-wives and the co-wives of their co-wives from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate, etc.” <sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The main place of this Halakhah is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:1:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.1.2-15">Halakhah 13:1</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, she may repudiate the levir to invalidate the claim of the dead brother, to permit the co-wife to her father, and the daughter-in-law to her father-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">If the girl walks out of the marriage, the marriage did never exist. The co-wife after <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is permitted to the girl’s father in case the father had lost his guardianship over the daughter (see below). She herself is permitted to her non-husband’s father.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 12a" href="/Yevamot.12a">Babli, 12a</a>, agrees that repudiation of the levir invalidates the marriage to the dead brother but nevertheless in this case forbids the girl to the father-in-law (a Babylonian <i>baraita</i>).</i>. Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, she may not repudiate the levir to invalidate the claim of the dead brother, to permit the co-wife to her father, and the daughter-in-law to her father-in-law. Do Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish follow the house of Shammai, since the House of Shammai say “the husband”<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:1:1-2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.1.1-2.9">Mishnah 13:1</a>; the House of Shammai limit repudiation strictly to the husband even if the widow is a minor. It would be very unusual if practice were to follow the House of Shammai against the declared opinion of the House of Hillel.</i>? Where do we hold? If she says, I can stand neither the marriage with your brother nor with you, everybody agrees that she invalidates<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Reading of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:1:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.1.2-15">Halakhah 13:1</a>. The ms. here reads “does not invalidate”. The practice is that of the House of Hillel.</i>. But we hold in case she says “I cannot stand marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Without spelling out which marriage.</i>”. Rebbi Joḥanan said, I can stand neither the marriage with your brother nor with you. Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, she says I cannot stand marriage with you but marriage with your brother I want. The Mishnah disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “And all of these, if they died, or repudiated, or were divorced, or found to be she-rams, their co-wives are permitted.” Was she not divorced from him? Similarly, she repudiated him<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The first husband in his lifetime.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: If they repudiated or were divorced in the husband’s lifetime, their co-wives are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">To the brothers in levirate. The marriage of a minor except through the father is only rabbinic and cannot eliminate the biblical requirement of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But levirate cannot be tolerated since that would show that the rabbinically valid marriage is a sham.</i>. After the husband’s death their co-wives perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.
Rebbi Yudan, the father of Rebbi Mattaniah said: Explain it when they died without having repudiated since there is a Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.4.1">Mishnah 1:4</a>.</i>: “If a woman could repudiate but did not do so, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">To the brothers in levirate. The marriage of a minor except through the father is only rabbinic and cannot eliminate the biblical requirement of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But levirate cannot be tolerated since that would show that the rabbinically valid marriage is a sham.</i>.” So is the Mishnah: “If a woman could repudiate but did not dies, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate.” Rebbi Abba Mari said, you may even say if she still lives; explain it if her father is the only levir<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Since at the moment of the husband’s death the rabbinic marriage of the daughter was still presumed to be valid and the daughter cannot repudiate her father, there is no way to circumvent the prohibition of levirate.</i>.
Rebbi Jonah said, only after <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the she-ram married to the dead brother. R. Jonah holds that after consummation of the marriage the husband would recognize that his wife had no secondary sex characteristics and that she was congenitally sterile. If he did not claim that the marriage was in error (since usually people marry with a view to have children), the marriage was valid and it is not clear why an incest prohibition for the she-ram should be irrelevant for the co-wife.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, even after final marriage. In the second repetition<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The second time R. Yose taught <i>Yebamot</i>.</i>, Rebbi Yose changed his mind. Rebbi Phineas said to him, did the Rabbi not teach us “after final marriage”? He answered him, is that fixed in you like a nail<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">He refused to be bound by his prior opinion.</i>?
Rebbi Ze‘ira said before Rebbi Mana, did not Rebbi Yose say correctly before he changed his mind? Once a man’s daughter is married without being a she-ram, her co-wife is forbidden. If in addition she is a she-ram, does her co-wife become permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter married to a brother is forbidden to her father. A she-ram is forbidden to all brothers (cf. Notes 65, 66). Since when do two prohibitions add up to a permission?</i>? He said to him, the she-ram is as if non-existent. If there are two sisters-in-law, one a she-ram and one not a she-ram, if the levir comes and performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or has intercourse with the first<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Who is forbidden for levirate.</i>, did he free her companion of anything? That shows that the she-ram is as if non-existent.
“His daughter”. How can his daughter repudiate, is she not married by Torah standards, “my daughter I gave to this man<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:16" href="/Deuteronomy.22.16"><i>Deut</i>. 22:16</a>. From the text it is clear that the marriage is valid in all respects. The verse implies that the father has the right to marry off his daughter, but only the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 23b" href="/Sotah.23b">Babli (<i>Soṭah</i> 23b</a>) infers from it that the mother does not have this right, even though the Yerushalmi accepts that ruling in practice.</i>”? Rebbi Huna in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Explain it by a minor, who was married off by her father<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">She is emancipated from her father by the marriage but not able to validly contract while under age. This is quoted cryptically in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 44b" href="/Kiddushin.44b">Babli <i>Qiddušin</i> 44b</a>.</i> and divorced, who is like an orphan while her father is alive.
Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥanina, in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: This means<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The statement that the mother-in-law could not have repudiated her husband since she had a daughter from him.</i> that a minor cannot give birth; because otherwise she could wait until she grew up, repudiate her husband, and permit her co-wife to her son-in-law. The daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 52a" href="/Niddah.52a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 52a</a>, the daughter.</i> of Rebbi Ismael repudiated while her son was on her shoulder. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Rebbi Jehudah, Rebbi Simeon, and Rebbi Ismael<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>loc. cit</i>., R. Ismael is quoted to hold that no biblically invalid marriage bars the woman from walking out. It is also stated that the action of the daughter was in accordance with her deceased father’s opinion. Since according to the Yerushalmi that opinion is nowhere recorded formally, the Babli’s explanation is one of the possibilities mentioned in the paragraph after the next as R. Ismael’s.</i> said the same. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different version is in Babli <i>loc. cit</i>. and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 6:8" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.6.8">Tosephta <i>Niddah</i> 6:11</a>.</i>: Until when may the daughter repudiate? Until she grows two pubic hairs<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Alternatively, the breasts as indicators of puberty are described in Mishnaiot <i>Niddah</i> 5:7–8, 6:1.</i>, the words of Rebbi Meїr. Rebbi Judah says until the black covers most. Rebbi Simeon says until the hill of Venus expands. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba.</i> in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Until the mons Veneris enlarges and the black be more than the white<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Corrected version of R. Simeon’s opinion.</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Eleazar, in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 52a" href="/Niddah.52a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 52a</a>, the statement is Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar and includes that of the colleagues below.</i>. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, practice follows Rebbi Jehudah. A case came before Rebbi Yasa; he said, go to Rebbi Abbahu since he has learned that practice follows Rebbi Jehudah; we did not learn that practice follows Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Ḥanina said, practice follows Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Joḥanan said to the Sepphoreans, you say in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina that practice follows Rebbi Jehudah, but it is not so. How is it? The colleagues<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Ḥanania and his brother Rav Oshaia.</i> in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Rebbi Jehudah agrees that if she had intercourse after she grew two hairs, she cannot repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">He agrees that the criterion of R. Meїr is valid to give her the right to contract marriage but if she is not forced to make a decision her right to repudiation remains in force; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Niddah 52a" href="/Rashi_on_Niddah.52a">Rashi in <i>Niddah</i> 52a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Rebbi Jehudah agrees that if she received <i>qiddushin</i> after she grew two hairs, she cannot repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion, the more important one in the Yerushalmi, is ignored in the Babli.</i>. According to Rebbi Ze‘ira who said “she received <i>qiddushin</i> after she grew two hairs”, it follows that if she received <i>qiddushin</i> before she grew two hairs and had intercourse after she grew two hairs, she can repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 46a" href="/Niddah.46a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 46a</a>, disagrees.</i>. That fits<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the next paragraph, one holds with R. Simeon that the rabbinic marriage of the minor becomes biblically valid only by a conscious act, for example intercourse to confirm the marriage. Since people usually think that a rabbinic marriage is all they need, simple intercourse does not satisfy the requirement. Therefore, R. Ismael’s daughter-in-law could repudiate even as an adult.</i>. According to the colleagues who say “she had intercourse after she grew two hairs”, it follows that if she had intercourse before she grew two hairs, she can repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">By the same reason as given in the previous paragraph. But for them, if she was married as a minor and the marriage was not consummated until she produced two pubic hairs, she cannot repudiate.</i>.
When was it<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter-in-law of R. Ismael who had a child and wanted to repudiate her husband following her father’s rules.</i>? She became pregnant and gave birth before she grew two hairs. Could she have lived? Did not Rebbi Redifa, Rebbi Jonah, say in the name of Rebbi Hila<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 12b" href="/Yevamot.12b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 12b</a>, rejects a similar (Galilean) statement; the Babylonian Rav Saphra declares that pregnancy is a sign of puberty.</i>: If a woman became pregnant and gave birth before she grew two hairs, she and her son will die. After she grew two hairs, she and her son will live. If she became pregnant before she grew two hairs and gave birth after she grew two hairs, she will live but her son will die. How is the situation? Rebbi Ismael follows RebbiJehudah, until the black covers most<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">In all these criteria, he will replace “two hairs” with “most of the mons Veneris is black”.</i> [and] Rebbi Simeon, that intercourse occurred with the idea of the prior <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the next paragraph, one holds with R. Simeon that the rabbinic marriage of the minor becomes biblically valid only by a conscious act, for example intercourse to confirm the marriage. Since people usually think that a rabbinic marriage is all they need, simple intercourse does not satisfy the requirement. Therefore, R. Ismael’s daughter-in-law could repudiate even as an adult.</i>.
