Following the opinions of Rebbi Meїr and Rebbi Jehudah who say that her status depends on the signs of development, it fits<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">As explained above, the daughter-in-law could have had a baby and still be a minor according to R. Jehudah [not according to R. Meїr; he is mentioned here only to reject the implied opinion of R. Saphra (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.9">Note 152</a>).]</i>. Following the opinion of Rebbi Simeon who says, if he adds another act of acquisition, then even if she is an adult! Rebbi Isaac said, that is so<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter-in-law of R. Ismael could have been an adult if no conscious validation of the marriage took place after her reaching adulthood (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.9">Note 150</a>).</i>. Only that the daughters of Israel should not be unbridled in breaking tabus<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The rejection of this interpretation in practice is rabbinic; the Babli (cf. Note 140) takes this as a reason to reject R. Ismael’s position.</i>.
There came a case before Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Of a girl repudiating when it was doubtful whether or not she was an adult.</i>. He said: One should examine her breasts<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:7–8 explains the progress of puberty from minority to adulthood through the state called נערוּת “maidenhood” when she is an adult and legally responsible for her actions but still under the authority of her father. This paragraph identifies the beginning of maidenhood with the growing of two pubic hairs and adulthood with the covering of the mons Veneris by hair. This means that R. Meїr permits repudiation only during minority and R. Jehudah during minority and maidenhood.</i>. How? Following Rebbi Jehudah! Since Rebbi Jehudah said, until the black covers most. Is not that what Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, between maidenhood and adulthood thare are only six months<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 65a" href="/Niddah.65a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 65a</a>, this is a statement of the contemporary Babylonian Samuel.</i>, and Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, one does not act on this<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">How can Rebbi Yose follow R. Jehudah when according to R. Meїr any marriage contracted by the repudiating girl would be adultery and R. Joḥanan forbids to follow R. Jehudah (even if in the abstract R. Jehudah might be correct).</i>? This means during that period<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">When she is no longer a minor but not an adult, the court does not act either to permit repudiation or to deny it, as explained later.</i>. But after that period one acts<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Six months after the first signs of puberty one forbids repudiation without checking for signs of adulthood. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 46a" href="/Niddah.46a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 46a</a>, which disregards R. Jehudah’s opinion and forbids repudiation by maidens, holds that after the age of 12 full years no examination is necessary to establish the fact of maidenhood.</i>. But in this case where there was a doubt whether the black covered most or the black did not cover most, I force him to give a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Since one cannot deny repudiation according to R. Jehudah and cannot permit it following R. Meїr, the court forces the husband to confirm the repudiation by a formal divorce. Then the girl can remarry without problems. But once she is an adult, she cannot force a divorce in court (except for infertility or serious misbehavior of the husband.)</i>. When the black covers most one does not touch a bill of divorce.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How do they free their co-wives? If a man’s daughter or one of the incest-prohibited women<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Forbidden to him but not to his brother.</i> was married to his brother who has another wife and dies, just as his daughter is free so her co-wife is free<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">If the man is the only brother of the deceased.</i>. If his daughter’s co-wife went and was married to a second brother<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Since the daughter is not forbidden to his brother, her co-wife is also permitted. The brother could have married his niece in levirate.</i> who then died, just as his daughter’s co-wife is freed, so the co-wife’s co-wife is freed; even if this is repeated a hundred times.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How do they free their co-wives? If a man’s daughter or one of the incest-prohibited women,”, etc. That is the baraita<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">This is not the text of the next Mishnah since here the daughter is still alive. A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:2" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.2">Tosephta 1:2</a>. It refers to the second case in the Mishnah, if there are at least three brothers. If there is only one brother and the daughter is still a minor one might teach her to repudiate the former marriage (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:6:1-8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.6.1-8.2">Mishnah 13:7</a>) and her co-wife will be permitted to her father.</i>: “If a woman could repudiate but did not do so, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">To the brothers in levirate. The marriage of a minor except through the father is only rabbinic and cannot eliminate the biblical requirement of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But levirate cannot be tolerated since that would show that the rabbinically valid marriage is a sham.</i>.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How are their co-wives permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">To the levir in Levirate.</i> if they die? If his daughter or one of the incest-prohibited women was married to his brother who has another wife, if his daughter died and then his brother died her co-wife is permitted. And if a woman could repudiate but did not do so, when she died her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">To the brothers in levirate. The marriage of a minor except through the father is only rabbinic and cannot eliminate the biblical requirement of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But levirate cannot be tolerated since that would show that the rabbinically valid marriage is a sham.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How are their co-wives permitted if they die,” etc. That is the Mishnah: “If a woman could repudiate but did not do so, when she died her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Mishnah text “when she died”, in contrast to the <i>baraita</i> text of the preceding Halakhah which presumes the daughter to be a widow.</i>.”

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Six incest prohibitions are more stringent than these<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Than the 15 mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i> since they [concern women who] must be married to others<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">They are equally forbidden to all paternal brothers and never can be parties to levirate.</i>, their co-wives are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">If they were widowed or divorced and married an unrelated husband, their co-wives from this marriage are unrelated to the brothers since co-wives can become forbidden only in cases of levirate.</i>: A man’s mother, his father’s wife, his father’s sister, his paternal sister, his paternal aunt, and his paternal brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Who had children or was divorced.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Six incest prohibitions are more stringent than these since they [concern women who] must be married to others”, etc. In what are they more stringent? Here there is extirpation, there is extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Incest with some of the women is a capital crime. Even these are subject to divine extirpation if there are no two witnesses to the act.</i>. Here there is bastardy, there there is bastardy<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The child of any of the forbidden unions is a bastard excluded from marriage with natural-born Jews.</i>. What is more stringent? That they cannot be married to the brothers without transgression. And Rebbi Ḥiyya stated thus: For all women who may be married to the brothers without transgression, their co-wives are free from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta 1:7</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.7">Tosephta 1:7</a>.</i>: “A co-wife is only from a brother”. Rebbi Yose said, our Mishnah says the same: “Since they must be married to others<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Others than the brothers.</i>, their co-wives are permitted.” Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Why can there not be a co-wife from the market place<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">If an incest-prohibited woman is married to a total stranger, why should her co-wife, if divorced or widowed, not be forbidden also to the family of the other wife?</i>? Rebbi Yose said, did Rebbi Jeremiah not hear what Rebbi Ḥiyya said, did he not hear our Mishnah, “since they must be married to others, their co-wives are permitted”<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">It is impossible to become an ordained rabbi without knowing the Mishnah.</i>? He turned around and said, certainly did he hear. But he is a person who hears something and questions it<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">The Yerushalmi leaves this without an answer. Two different answers are given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 11 12" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_11.12"><i>Sifra</i> <i>Qedošim</i> <i>Pereq</i>11(12</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 8" href="/Yevamot.8">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 8a/b</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: If one has intercourse with a co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Widow of his brother whom he cannot marry because of the incest prohibition regarding the other wife.</i>, is he guilty because of his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">In general, the brother’s wife is forbidden under penalty of divine extirpation. But if levirate is possible, the widows of the dead brother become potentially permitted. If one of them is married by a brother, the others are forbidden since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–9</a> speaks only of one sister-in-law and one house to build. The question is, does the brother who sleeps with the excluded co-wife infringe on the prescription (regarding a single levirate) of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25" href="/Deuteronomy.25"><i>Deut</i>. 25</a> or the incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a>? The problem does not appear in the Babli since it derives all prohibitions directly from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a>.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, if a co-wife were possible without a brother’s wife, that would be a valid question<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">In the sense of R. Jeremiah’s first question.</i>. It is possible to be a brother’s wife without a co-wife. It is impossible to be a co-wife without a brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">As R. Ḥiyya stated. Therefore, the prohibition of the co-wife is no separate prohibition, but only that one of the dead brother’s wives gets a special dispensation from the incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>.</i>.
Is the brother’s wife not his sister-in-law? Rebbi Yose bar Abun said, explain it if she had children from a brother<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Who had children or was divorced.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai permit the co-wives to the brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">They dispute the validity of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.4.1">Mishnaiot 1–4</a>. The schools of Hillel and Shammai existed for about 100 years in the first Century C. E. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17a" href="/Yevamot.17a">Babli (17a</a>) dates the public permission of the co-wives to the brothers to the short time of ascendancy of the House of Shammai shortly before the outbreak of the revolt against the Romans.</i>, but the House of Hillel forbid. If they took <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the House of Shammai disqualify them for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">A divorcee is forbidden to a Cohen (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>) and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is the equivalent of a divorce (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Mishnah 2:4</a>).</i> but the House of Hillel declare them qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage is impossible, so is the corresponding divorce. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a> prohibits the marriage of a Cohen with “a woman divorced from her husband”, but not a woman divorced from a non-husband.</i>. If they entered levirate, the House of Shammai declare them qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">The children are legitimate. For the House of Hillel the children are bastards and excluded from endogamous marriage.</i> but the House of Hillel as disqualified. Even though these forbid and those permit, these declare disqualified and those qualified, the House of Shammai did not refrain from marrying women from the House of Hillel nor the House of Hillel from the House of Shammai. Regarding all purities and impurities which these were declaring as pure and those as impure<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">The differences in the interpretation of laws of purity are noted in the sixth order of the Mishnah.</i>, these did not refrain to process pure foods with the help of those<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">They lent one another pure vessels.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The House of Shammai permit the co-wives to the brothers,” etc. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Yose in the name ofNehorai: The reason of the House of Shammai, “the outside wife of the deceased shall not belong to a strange man<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>. The verse reads לֹא־תִהְיָה אֵשֶׁת הַמֵּת הַחוּצָה לְאִישׁ זָר. In the masoretic text, הַחוּצָה is adverbial לֹא־תִהְיֶה אֵשֶׁת הַמֵּת הַחוּצָה לְאִישׁ זָר and therefore is stressed on the penultimate syllable. The House of Shammai read an unlikely adjective לֹא־תִהְיֶה אֵשֶׁת הַמֵּת הַחוּצָה לְאִישׁ זָר. Following masoretic grammar, הַחוּצָה then should be stressed on the last syllable. As E. Y. Kutscher has shown in his study of the Isaiah scroll, one may assume that in the last century of the Jewish state the stress was penultimate irrespective of meaning. Therefore, in Mishnaic times there may not have been an audible difference between the two versions.<br>The House of Shammai would translate: “The deceased man’s wife who is outside [the family of the levir] shall not be to a strange man,” implying that only the widow who already belongs to the levir’s family is free from the obligations of the levirate. The argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 13b" href="/Yevamot.13b">Babli, 13b</a>.</i>,” the “outer one” should not be another man’s. It turns out that the House of Shammai hold like those Samaritans who perform levirate with the betrothed but remove the married, for they explain “outside” as “the outer one<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Having received <i>qiddushin</i> but not yet finally married, she is not yet part of the family. This interpretation avoids any appearance of conflict between <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>, declaring relations with the brother’s wife incestuous, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>, requiring marriage to the brother’s wife.<br>In rabbinic Hebrew, ארוסה “the betrothed one”, is a seldom used synonym of מקודשת “who had received <i>qiddushin</i>”.</i>.” How do the House of Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The commentators want to replace “House of Shammai” by “Samaritans”, but it was stated before that the House of Shammai accepts the reading of the Samaritans while giving it another interpretation.</i> confirm “when he has no child<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. You do not expect a man to have a child before marriage.</i>”? Rebbi Jacob the Southerner said before Rebbi Yose, “when he has no child” from the married one, “the outer one shall not belong outside to a strange man.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">In this interpretation, the “outside” wife is the woman betrothed, legally a wife, but not married to live in her husband’s family. For them, a woman widowed after marriage is never subject to levirate, only one becoming a widow from betrothal to a childless man. This eliminates any conflict between <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>. The practice of the Samaritans is confirmed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 75b-76a" href="/Kiddushin.75b-76a">Babli, <i>Qiddušin</i> 75b–76a</a>.</i>” He said to him, will not the Samaritans love you that you confirm their interpretations! Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar stated: I told the learned Samaritans, what did cause you to err? That you did not explain following Rebbi Neḥemiah, since it was stated in the name of Rebbi Neḥemiah: Anything which needs a ל as a prefix but did not get it, we give it a ה at the end, e. g., to the outside חוּצָה, to Se‘ir<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 33:16" href="/Genesis.33.16"><i>Gen</i>. 33:16</a>.</i> שְׂעִירָה, to Succoth<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 33:17" href="/Genesis.33.17"><i>Gen</i>. 33:17</a>.</i> סוּכּוֹתָה. They objected to Rebbi Neḥemiah, is it not written: “The wicked shall return to the pit לִשְׁאוֹלָה<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 9:18" href="/Psalms.9.18"><i>Ps</i>. 9:18</a>; one of the two signs of direction is superfluous.</i>.” Rabba bar Zabda said, to the lowest living space<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δίαιτα.</i> in Sheol.
<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:9-10" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.9-10">Tosephta 1:9–10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 14b" href="/Yevamot.14b">Babli 14b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27a" href="/Yevamot.27a">27a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 13b" href="/Yevamot.13b">13b</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said, look how this practice is widespread in Israel! If one upholds the words of the House of Shammai, the child is a bastard following the words of the House of Hillel<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">For them the co-wife is forbidden because of the incest prohibition.</i>. If one upholds the words of the House of Hillel, the child is a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">In Tosephta and Babli: “damaged”; of questionable origin and unfit for the priesthood but not a bastard. The co-wife who married outside the husband’s family did breach a simple prohibition, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>, which only R. Aqiba declares to result in bastards. The <i>baraita</i> of the Yerushalmi must come from R. Aqiba’s school and cannot represent practice.</i> following the words of the House of Shammai. Come and let us institute that the co-wife perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not be admitted to levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ḥalîṣah</i> would let the co-wife marry outside the family for the House of Shammai and be ineffective for the House of Hillel.</i>. It was stated: They did not manage to institute this before the time became unsuitable<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">The revolt of Bar Kokhba and its aftermath intervened.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, if it were so, what would one have done with the earlier co-wives who married<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">After the restitution of the patriarchate, R. Simeon ben Gamliel refused to follow R. Joḥanan ben Nuri since he would characterize women who had married following the House of Shammai as lawbreakers. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27a" href="/Yevamot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>, asserts that later generations followed R. Joḥanan ben Nuri. This is not the position of the Yerushalmi.</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1">Tosephta 1</a>:10 (which proves that R. Eleazar ben Shamua, the Tanna, is the author); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 14a" href="/Yevamot.14a">Babli 14a</a>.</i> Rebbi Eleazar said, even though the House of Hillel and the House of Shammai disagreed about co-wives, they agree that the child is not a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Shammai agree with the House of Hillel, against R. Aqiba and R. Joḥanan ben Nuri, that the child of a co-wife married according to the House of Hillel is not a bastard since even for the House of Shammai only a simple prohibition is involved. In the shortened version of the Babli it is easy to read into the text a one-sided version, implying that the children according to the House of Shammai are indeed bastards. It is difficult to read this into the Yerushalmi and the Tosephta text.</i>, since a bastard is only from a woman which is forbidden to [a man] by an incest prohibition and one is subject to extirpation for [sinning with] her<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">This extends even to incestuous relationships that are capital crimes since in absence of two witnesses to the forbidden act, when there can be no prosecution, the guilty pair still faces divine retribution in the form of extirpation.</i>. Rebbi Tarphon said, I would love to have a daughter’s co-wife to marry her into priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, “that I would marry her”, being a Cohen, to invalidate the position of the House of Shammai.</i>. They asked Rebbi Joshua, what are children of a daughter’s co-wife? He said to them, you bring my head between two large mountains, between the words of the House of Shammai and those of the House of Hillel, that they should smash my brain. But I testify about the family ‘Anubai from Bet Ṣeba‘im and the family Neqipai from Bet Meqošeš<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:10" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.10">Tosephta (1:10</a>): בית עלובי (עליבאי) מבית צבאים (צביים), בית קיפאי (קיפא) מבית מקושש. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 15b" href="/Yevamot.15b">Babli (15b</a>): משפחת בית צבועים מבן עכמאי ומשפחת בית קופאי מבן מקושש. The town of צבעים is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 11:34" href="/Nehemiah.11.34"><i>Neh.</i> 11:34</a> as settled by the returnees from the tribe ofBenjamin; cf. B. Z. Luria, ערי הכהנים בימי בית שני, HUCA 44 (1973) א-יח.</i> that they were sons of co-wives and their grandchildren were High Priests officiating on top of the altar<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Even though he did not want to express any opinion of the co-wives themselves, he was adamant that the children were untainted.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">A different version of the entire paragraph in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 16a" href="/Yevamot.16a">Babli, 16a</a>.</i> Rebbi Jacob bar Idi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: It happened that the Sages visited Rebbi Dosa ben Hyrkanos<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">A contemporary of Rabban Joḥanan ben Zakkai, already old at the time of the destruction of the Temple. He was almost blind in his old age.</i> to ask him about the daughter’s co-wife. They said to him, are you the one who permits co-wives? He said to them, what did you hear? Dosa ben Hyrkanos? They said to him, ben Hyrkanos. He said to them, my brother Jonathan is exceedingly sharpminded<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Interpretation of Rashi.</i> and of the students of the House of Shammai. Be careful with him, he has three hundred arguments about the daughter’s co-wife. They went to him. He sent and wrote to him<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">R. Dosa to Jonathan.</i>, be careful because the Sages of Israel will visit you. They came and he placed them before him. He lectured<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">About his 300 reasons to permit the co-wives to the brothers.</i> but they did not understand, repeatedly. They started to get drowsy. He said to them, why are you getting drowsy? He started pelting them with pebbles. But some people said, they entered in one door and left in three<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Defeated.</i>. He sent to say to him<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Jonathan to Dosa.</i>, why did you send to me, the people want to learn and you said to me, these are the Sages of Israel? They came to him<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">R. Dosa.</i> and said to him, what do you say in the matter? He said, on this stone<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">A stone used to crush spices.</i> sat the prophet Ḥaggai and testified to three things: On the daughter’s co-wife that she can be married into priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Following the House of Hillel.</i>, on Ammon and Moab that they tithe for the poor in a Sabbatical year<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Yadayim 3:3" href="/Mishnah_Yadayim.3.3">Mishnah <i>Yadayim</i> 3:3</a>.</i>, and on proselytes of Palmyra that they are acceptable to marry into the congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">They are reputedly the children of Gentiles from Jewish women. The statement objects to the opinion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.6.2">Halakhah 7:6</a>) that the child of a Gentile and a Jewish woman, who certainly has to be counted as Jewish, is a bastard. It is known from the Babli that the soldiers of Odenathus of Palmyra in his campaigns in Babylonia abducted Jewish women for their own use.</i>. He said, lift my eyelids so I can see the Sages of Israel. He saw Rebbi Joshua and said to him: “To whom will one teach knowledge<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 28:9" href="/Isaiah.28.9"><i>Is.</i> 28:9</a>. “To whom will one teach knowledge, to whom impart understanding, to those weaned from milk, removed from the breasts.” This determines the start of school for outstanding scholars at age 2. As usual, the part of the verse not quoted is the one intended.</i>?” I remember that his mother brought his crib to the Synagogue that his ears should cling to the words of the Torah. [He saw] Rebbi Aqiba, and said to him: “Lion cubs will be poor and hungry<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 34:11" href="/Psalms.34.11"><i>Ps.</i> 34:11</a>: “Lion cubs will be poor and hungry, but those who seek the Lord will not lack any good thing.” R. Aqiba at the outset was an ignorant seeker of the Lord.</i>.” I know of him that he is a man strong in Torah. He saw Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah and said to him: “I was a youth but became an elder<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 37:25" href="/Psalms.37.25"><i>Ps.</i> 37:25</a>. A pun is intended; זָקַנְתִּי “I grew old” is turned into “I was appointed as an elder” at age 16, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:1:33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.4.1.33"><i>Berakhot</i> 4:1, Note 118</a>.</i>.” I know of him that he is the tenth generation from Ezra and their eyes are similar. Rebbi Ḥanina from Sepphoris said, Rebbi Tarphon also was with them and he addressed him as he did Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah.
<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 16" href="/Yevamot.16">Babli <i>Yebamot</i>16a/b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 56b" href="/Niddah.56b"><i>Niddah</i> 56b</a>.</i> Rav Naḥman bar Jacob said, one accepts proselytes from Kurds<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">From Corduene. Again, the problem exists only for those who hold that the child of a Gentile from a Jewish mother is a bastard.</i> and Palmyrenians. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: A Mishnah said that the proselytes from Palmyra are acceptable<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">As marriage partners for Jews.</i>. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 7:6, 56b. If a stain is found on a garment, it might be from menstrual blood and therefore would be impure. As a precaution, any stain on a garment from Jewish sources is considered impure. Gentiles are unable to be impure in biblical law; their impurity is only rabbinical. Considering stains of Gentile origin to be impure would be superimposing one rabbinical decree over another, which is inadmissible.</i>: “All stains coming from Petra are pure.” Therefore<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">This looks like a <i>non sequitur.</i> One has to admit the version, tentatively offered in the Babli, “from Petra and Palmyra”. This would either clear the inhabitants of Palmyra from any suspicion of Jewishness (Rashi’s opinion) or make it clear that the descendents of Jewish mothers were raised as Jews but that a Jewish woman would not give away an unwashed cloth (opinion of Tosaphot, R. Elieser from Tuchheim). Therefore, even following Tosaphot, a proselyte will never be a bastard.</i>, the proselytes from Palmyra are acceptable.
Text of the parallel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.2-16"><i>Qiddušin</i>4:1</a>:<br><sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">A parallel to the paragraph in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 71b" href="/Kiddushin.71b">Babli <i>Qiddušin</i> 71b</a>. The origin of the paragraph is in <i>Qiddušin,</i> the readings of the parallel from there seem to be slightly better. Since the canals of Antiquity all decayed after the Arab conquest, the names cannot be reconstructed.</i> Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa presented traditions: Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, one declares permissible and the other admits. He who declares permissible admits. But he who admits does not declare admissible<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Anybody can become a proselyte. But only a person not descendent from Jews is sure not to be really Jewish and, according to the earlier opinion, a bastard. This problem is most urgent in Media, place of exile of the Ten Tribes, but also in Palmyra, part of Solomon’s empire.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Naḥman bar Jacob: Babylonia, as far as family pedigree is concerned, extends up to the <i>zrvq</i><sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: עזק.</i> canal. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, Rav and Samuel, one said up to the <i>zrvq</i> canal, the other said up to the <i>Wani</i> canal. Rav Jehudah said, between the rivers is like Nahardea<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">The place of exile of King Jojachin and the nobles of Jerusalem, usually called “exile”. The rivers are Euphrates and Tigris.</i> as far as family pedigree is concerned. Rebbi Ḥanina ben Beroqa in the name of Rav Jehudah: The people of Mesene<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">The province of the confluence of Tigris and Euphrates.</i> are questionable only because of doubts of desecrated women<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Women desecrated by a forbidden union with Cohanim: Divorcees, harlots, and daughters of such marriages.</i>. The Cohanim amongst them did not care about divorcees. There<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. There seems to be a pun involved if מתה and מישא both are pronounced <i>mēsā.</i> Neubauer (<i>La Géographie du Talmud,</i> Paris 1868, p. 325) thinks that the pun about Media connects the name of Media with the root דוה “to be unwell”.</i>, they called Mesene dead, Media sick, Elam and <i>gbby</i> dying. The maritime district<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">It might be “the Western district”, but the West of Babylonia is desert. Neubauer conjectures that it might be the lake region of upper Mesopotamia. Since the meaning and location is unknown, the places cannot be determined. Purple-blue is the most costly of colors.</i> is the purple-blue of Babylonia. <i>Šny’</i>, <i>gbby’, and ṣrry</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 72b" href="/Kiddushin.72b">Babli, <i>Qiddušin</i> 72b</a>, שוניא גוביא, ציצורא.</i> are purple-blue of the maritime district.
<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 1:10, Babli 14b.</i>“Even though the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel disagreed about co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Discussed in the Mishnah here.</i>, and sisters<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>, about two sisters married to two brothers who both die childless at the same time.</i>, and an old bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Hillel hold that if a man divorces his wife and then spends time with her under circumstances that permit sexual relations, the bill of divorce is invalidated and the woman needs a new one to marry again. The House of Shammai disagree and hold that if they sleep with one another they do it in intended promiscuity. What the Tosephta calls “an old bill of divorce”, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 8:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.8.7.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 8:8</a> calls “he who divorces his wife and spends the night with her in a hostelry.”</i>, and a woman doubtfully married<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">There are several cases of disagreement about the status of a woman in the Mishnah, and Rashi, R. Ḥananel, and S. Lieberman all have their own preferences. Probably this refers to all instances.</i>, and one who gives <i>qiddushin</i> in the value of a <i>peruṭa,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1</a>. In <i>qiddushin,</i> the man has to give the woman something of value to make the act legally binding. The value according to the House of Hillel must be at least a <i>peruṭah,</i> the smallest copper coin in Hasmonean times, long out of circulation in Mishnaic times. The House of Shammai require a <i>denar,</i> the larger Roman silver coin in the early Empire.</i> i. e., he who divorces his wife and spends the night with her in a hostelry, and that a woman receives <i>qiddushin</i> for at least a <i>denar</i> or the value of a <i>denar,</i> the House of Shammai did not refrain from marrying women from the House of Hillel or the House of Hillel from the House of Shammai but they behave truthfully and in peace, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 8:19" href="/Zechariah.8.19"><i>Zach.</i> 8:19</a>.</i>: ‘Love truth and peace.’ ” Bastardy is between them and you say so? How is that? If a first man gives her <i>qiddushin</i> for a <i>peruṭa</i> and a second for a <i>denar,</i> in the opinion of the House of Shammai she is betrothed to the second and the child of the first is a bastard. In the opinion of the House of Hillel she is betrothed to the first and the child of the second is a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the discussion is about the more realistic case of the daughter’s co-wife, where the child is a bastard for the House of Hillel in a levirate following the House of Shammai but only damaged (unfit for a Cohen) for the House of Shammai if married outside following the House of Hillel.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The House of Shammai concede to the House of Hillel as a restriction<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">They would never permit a new marriage if an existing one is valid for the House of Hillel. There remains the difference that, if it happened, the <i>qiddushin</i> of the second are invalid, the woman remains permitted to the first, but for the House of Shammai the court would have to force the second to write a bill of divorce.</i>. In that case, the House of Shammai should marry women from the House of Hillel since they concede to them. But the House of Hillel should not marry women from the House of Shammai since they do not concede to them. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: They all followed the same practice<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Following the House of Hillel.</i>. If they followed the same practice, in this case we stated<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Miqwa’ot</i> 4:5. If there is a trough in a rock too small to be a <i>miqweh</i> (40 <i>seah</i>), one may drill holes in the rock to lead the water to a <i>miqweh.</i> The House of Hillel require that the hole be slightly more than 2 fingers in diameter; the House of Shammai require that most of the bottom be removed. In a case in Jerusalem known as “trough of Jehu”, the House of Shammai actually did enlarge the hole even though practice should follow the House of Hillel.</i>: “The House of Shammai sent and diminished it, since the House of Shammai says unless most of it is missing?” Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, the House of Shammai acted before the question came before the House of Hillel. After a question came before the House of Hillel, the House of Shammai were not touching it. Rebbi Abba Mari said, that is correct. Did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">It is unknown where this is stated.</i>: “They declared impure all purities from before”, but not in the future. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, Rav and Samuel, one said both acted according to valid practice<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Following the House of Hillel.</i>; the other said, each party followed its own practice. Bastardy is between them and you say so? The Omnipresent watched and no case ever happened<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 14a" href="/Yevamot.14a">Babli, 14a</a>, disagrees and holds that they informed one another in case the child of a family should not be married by a person of the other House. Since the ascendancy of the House of Shammai was so shortlived, the position of the Yerushalmi seems justified. One has to wonder what the rules were for marriages between Sadducees and Pharisees in late Temple times.</i>.
In this matter<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">As R. Moses Margalit points out, this kind of reference fits the style of the Yerushalmi. Those who want to delete כהדא ד are lead astray by the style of the Babli.</i>, it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sukkah (Lieberman) 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Sukkah_(Lieberman).2.3">Tosephta <i>Sukkah</i> 2:3</a>, <i>Yebamot</i>1:13, <i>Idiut</i> 2:3. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 6b" href="/Eruvin.6b">Babli <i>Eruvin</i> 6b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 14b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.14b"><i>Roš Haššanah</i> 14b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 43b" href="/Chullin.43b"><i>Ḥulin</i> 43b</a>.</i>: “About anybody who wants to take upon himself the stringencies both of the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel it was said<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 2:14" href="/Ecclesiastes.2.14"><i>Eccl.</i> 2:14</a>.</i>: ‘The silly one walks in darkness’. The leniencies of both of them, he is called wicked. Only either following the words of the House of Shammai in their leniencies and stringencies, or following the words of the House of Hillel in their leniencies and stringencies.” That is, before there came the disembodied voice<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">The collective agreement of the people, over the heads of the rabbinic establishment.</i>. But after the disembodied voice was heard, “practice follows the House of Hillel forever<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sukkah (Lieberman) 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Sukkah_(Lieberman).2.3">Tosephta <i>Sukkah</i> 2:3</a>, <i>Yebamot</i>1:13, <i>Idiut</i> 2:3. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 6b" href="/Eruvin.6b">Babli <i>Eruvin</i> 6b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 14b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.14b"><i>Roš Haššanah</i> 14b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 43b" href="/Chullin.43b"><i>Ḥulin</i> 43b</a>.</i>.” And any who transgresses the words of the House of Hillel is deserving of death<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.4.1">Mishnah <i>Berakhot</i> 1:7</a>.</i>. It was stated: There came the disembodied voice and said: Both of them are the words of the Living God, but practice follows the House of Hillel forever. Where was the disembodied voice heard? Rav Bebai in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The disembodied voice was heard at Yabneh<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Between the two wars against the Romans.</i>.

Chapter 2



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In which way<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In which way does the wife of his brother who did not live in his world free her co-wife?, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>.</i> “the wife of his brother who did not live in his world”? There were two brothers, one of them died, then a brother was born to them<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">To whom the widow now is forbidden. She remains forbidden.</i>, and after that the second brother took his brother’s wife in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Having already another wife. He then died childless.</i>, and died. The first woman<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The widow taken in levirate.</i> leaves as widow of his brother who did not live in his world and the second one<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The original wife of the second brother.</i> because she is her co-wife. If he had “bespoken” her<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In biblical law, only cohabitation makes the sister-in-law the wife of the levir (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>). Since it was felt that having sex without prior ceremony was unbecoming, there is a requirement (rabbinic for the Babli, possibly biblical for the Yerushalmi) to go through the formalities of <i>qiddushin</i>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>. <i>Qiddushin</i> make a free woman a wife for the purposes of criminal law. But for the sister-in-law, the act is invalid by biblical standards (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:21" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.21">Chapter 1, Note 94</a>); the wife of the second brother does not become co-wife of the sister-in-law through the latter’s <i>qiddushin</i> by the standards of criminal law. Therefore, the act is not called <i>qiddushin</i> but מאמר “bespeaking”: she is reserved for the brother claiming her; all other brothers are excluded from levirate with her. “Bespeaking” is not preliminary marriage since it is voided not by a bill of divorce but by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>(but it needs a rabbinic bill of divorce).<br>The other woman is not freed as co-wife but, rabbinically, one does not admit levirate since she is almost a co-wife.</i>, the second performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Why “the wife of his brother who did not live in his world”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>. In contrast to all other cases enumerated there, this is not based on a direct incest prohibition.</i>? “Together”, this excludes the wife of his brother who did not live in his world<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.8">Chapter 1, Note 39</a>.</i>. Because if it were not so, what would we say? If he died childless, his widow would be forbidden to remarry, for maybe his father would have another son and his widow would then be a candidate<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The one under obligation of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is always called זקוּקה, the fact of obligation זיקה. It does not seem reasonable to connect this meaning to biblical זקק “to refine, purify”; maybe the root is related to Arabic زقّ، زقق “to feed (a bird his young)”, that she is fodder for the levirate, or even Akkadic <i>zāqiqum</i>“ghost; necromancer”. {Jewish Berber tribes held that a brother who rejects levirate will be punished by the ghost of his dead brother.}</i> for the levirate! Even if [the deceased’s] mother had died, his widow would be forbidden to remarry, [because] maybe the father would go and marry a new wife who could have a son and the widow would then be a candidate for the levirate! Then the verse would have to read<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">To free her for remarriage.</i>: “He has neither father nor son”! One would compare this to the case that he left his widow pregnant; does she not have to wait to know whether the child is viable or not<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">A posthumous child who does not survive for 30 days does not free its mother from levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i>? Here also, should she not have to wait to know whether the child is viable or not? Therefore it was necessary to say “together”; this excludes the wife of his brother who did not live in his world.
“Her levir shall come upon her<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>.</i>”, that is cohabitation. “And take her as wife for himself”, that is “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">A better translation, if one identifies biblical and rabbinic Hebrew, would be: “Acquires her as a wife for himself”, by giving her some valuables as for legally valid <i>qiddushin.</i></i>. I might think that just as cohabitation is final so “bespeaking” is final<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Cohabitation makes the widow his wife; her marriage to him can be terminated only by death or by a bill of divorce. “Bespeaking” does not remove the obligation of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if the levir changes his mind, in contrast to <i>qiddushin</i> which can be undone only by a bill of divorce.<br><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).3.1">Tosephta 3:1</a>: “<i>Qiddushin</i> are final, ‘bespeaking’ is not final”.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 54a" href="/Yevamot.54a">Babli, 54a</a>, formulates: “Cohabitation is final, money or a document are not final.” Cohabitation is final even if in error or unintentional (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>); money or a document are not final even if given as <i>qiddushin</i> and not as “bespeaking”.</i>; the verse says “and act as levir towards her.” This directs the entire paragraph towards levirate. Cohabitation is final, “bespeaking” is not final. Then what is “bespeaking” good for? To forbid her to the brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">After “bespeaking”, she remains forbidden to the other brothers even if the “bespeaker” changes his mind.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon says, “bespeaking” either acquires<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">As a biblically required act. This is the opinion of the House of Shammai, cf. Halakhah 3:5, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 18a" href="/Yevamot.18a">Babli 18a</a>.</i> or does not acquire<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">As a rabbinic institution. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 18b-19b" href="/Yevamot.18b-19b">Babli, 18b–19b</a>, the question whether R. Simeon’s problem is rabbinic or biblical is only marginally hinted at.</i>. What is the argument of Rebbi Simeon? “Her levir shall come upon her”, that is cohabitation. “And take her as wife for himself”, that is “bespeaking”. Just as cohabitation is final so “bespeaking” is final. Or “her levir shall come upon her”, then she has been acquired by him and “bespeaking” was of no use to her<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the interpretation given above, “bespeaking” is mentioned in the verse after intercourse. This is incomprehensible since everybody agrees that cohabitation makes the widow the full wife of the levir without any “bespeaking”. If “bespeaking” is not needed, it cannot be a biblical requirement and “take her as wife for himself” does not refer to “bespeaking” but that “she is his wife in every respect” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnah 4:4</a>).</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh says, “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely. What is the argument of Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh? “And take her as wife for himself”, the same expression is used as for <i>qiddushin</i> of a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:13" href="/Deuteronomy.22.13"><i>Deut.</i>22:13</a>, “If a man takes a wife”.</i>. Just as <i>qiddushin</i> acquire completely, so “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely. What is the formula for “bespeaking” a sister-in-law? “You are betrothed to me by money or money’s worth.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The same formula as for <i>qiddushin</i>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 52a" href="/Yevamot.52a">Babli 52a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta 1:1</a> (the latter also has the formula for “bespeaking” by document).</i>”
Both the rabbis and Rebbi Simeon agree to the following<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Two different reasonings lead to the same practical result.</i>. According to the rabbis, the aspect which “bespeaking” acquires is forbidden in the co-wife, the aspect which “bespeaking” does not acquire is permitted in the co-wife; therefore, the latter has to have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Since “bespeaking” is neither final nor useless, the wife of the brother becomes possibly a co-wife of his sister-in-law; if he dies she is excluded from levirate since that is possible only for a woman certainly permitted to the (newly born) levir. She cannot leave the family without <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since she was not a full co-wife of the forbidden woman.</i>. According to Rebbi Simeon, if “bespeaking” acquires, both are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">If “bespeaking” preceded the birth of the next brother, the widow of the first brother already was the wife of the second and after his death will be permitted to the third. If the birth of the next brother preceded bespeaking, both are forbidden: the first as widow of a brother who did not live in his world, the second as her co-widow. Whether one wants to emend the text here, from “permitted” to “forbidden”, depends on which case one chooses.</i>. If “bespeaking” does not acquire, the first one is forbidden but the second one permitted. Out of doubt, she has to have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate. What is the difference between them<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Is there any case where there is a practical difference between the rabbis and Rebbi Simeon?</i>? If he slept with the second one<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">If the third brother sleeps with the woman to whom he should give <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, this is to some degree incestuous intercourse, he cannot acquire her in levirate, and a child from this union is a bastard.</i>. In the opinion of the rabbis, an incestuous intercourse because he<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The second brother.</i> had “bespoken”. Therefore, if he had not “bespoken” she may have levirate and there is no candidacy at all<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The simple fact that the widow may not marry outside the family without <i>ḥalîṣah</i> does not establish a relationship with any one of the brothers. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli, 17b</a>, this is the minority opinion ascribed to Rav Huna in the name of Rav.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, I explained that following what Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If a woman waiting for her levir died, her mother is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted many times affirmatively in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:8:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.8.2-4">Yerushalmi (<i>Yebamot</i> 4:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:16:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.16.2">4:16</a>; <i>Soṭah</i> 2:5), rejected in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 17b" href="/Yevamot.17b">Babli, 17b</a>.<br>The position of R. Simeon is not explained but is clear: The relationship is possibly incestuous, the child is only possibly a bastard and cannot be forbidden by the court to marry inside the congregation.</i>. He had in her an interest of candidacy. When she died, the candidacy was eliminated. And here, when he died, the candidacy was eliminated<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Rejected in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 18a" href="/Yevamot.18a">Babli, 18a</a>: “Candidacy cannot disappear without action.”</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> There were two brothers, one of them died and the second<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Who already has a wife. If he has no wife, the rules for the widow of the first brother do not change.</i> took his brother’s widow in levirate; afterwards a brother was born to them, and he died. The first woman<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The widow. The author of this Mishnah holds that the widow does not lose her status as widow of the first by her marriage to the second brother. She leaves the family of her dead husbands and is free to marry any outsider without further ceremony.</i> leaves as wife of his brother who did not live in his world and the second one as her co-wife. If [the second brother] had bespoken [the widow of the first] when he died, the second performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the preceding paragraph.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, he may take in levirate any one he wants or performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with any one he wants<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">As shown in the next paragraph, this must refer to the first case and R. Simeon must hold that the marriage to the second brother erases her status as widow of the first.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If there were two brothers, one of them died”, etc. Rebbi Simeon says, “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire, and you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Could R. Simeon refer to the woman “bespoken” when the second brother died?</i>? May one permit levirate with the “bespoken” woman? One should suspect that “bespeaking” does not acquire; then he<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The youngest brother born after the death of the first.</i> would be guilty because of “wife of his brother who did not live in his world.” Can the “bespoken” one perform <i>ḥalîṣah?</i> Should one not suspect that “bespeaking” does acquire; then the second {widow] is a candidate for [the third brother]<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">According to R. Simeon, see <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.2.1">Note 33</a>. Another argument with the same result is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 18b" href="/Yevamot.18b">Babli, 18b</a>.</i>. It must be that Rebbi Simeon refers to the first case.
Rebbi Joḥanan said, Rebbi Simeon agrees in the first case<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The case of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>, when the third brother was born after the death of the first and before the second brother married the widow in levirate.</i>. It was found stated, that also is in disagreement. What is the difference between the first and second cases? In the first case he came and found her forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">“He” is the newly born brother, “she” is the widow of the first brother. The argument shows that R. Simeon could not possibly disagree with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i>, in the second he came and found her permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">As wife of a living brother. The text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).3.1">Tosephta 3:1</a>; the same argument is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 19b" href="/Yevamot.19b">Babli, 19b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan asked, if he found his father’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">A man with two wives dies, leaving one of them pregnant while the other is already married to an outsider when the pregnant widow gives birth to a boy. Is the remarried one still “his father’s wife” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8"><i>Lev.</i> 18:8</a>)?</i> married to an outsider, what does Rebbi Simeon say about her? Because he came and found her permitted, is she permitted? Rebbi Simeon said that only relative to paternal brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The answer is readily understood but not the question. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a> cancels the prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev.</i> 18:16</a> but no other prohibition from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18</a>; the same conclusion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 20a" href="/Yevamot.20a">Babli, 20a</a>.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 20a" href="/Yevamot.20a">Babli, 20a</a>, the impossible question is about a maternal halfsister married to a paternal halfbrother when the new baby was born.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish asked: His maternal halfbrother’s wife which he found married to an outsider, what does Rebbi Simeon say about her? Because he came and found her permitted, is she permitted? Rebbi Simeon said that only relative to paternal brothers. Rebbi Yudan asked, a co-wife of his maternal aunt which he found married to an outsider? Because he came and found her permitted, is she permitted? Rebbi Abin asked, if a divorcee became a widow<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">This is a different case altogether. A Cohen is forbidden to marry a divorcee (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev.</i> 21:7</a>). If a Cohen was born when a certain woman who had been divorced had remarried and now was a widow, is she a widow or a divorcee for him? No answer is given since she is both a divorcee and a widow.</i>? You have to say that Rebbi Simeon referred to the first case.
What does Rebbi Simeon say about the “bespoken” woman<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The second case in the Mishnah, when the additional brother was born after the second brother bespoke his brother’s widow and before his death.</i>? Let us hear from the following: “Rebbi Simeon says, the cohabitation or the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly confusing wording. “One of them” means “a certain one of them”, viz., the brother’s original wife.</i> frees her co-wife but if he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the “bespoken” woman, her colleague also needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is doubtful whether the “bespoken” one was his wife it is doubtful whether her <i>ḥalîṣah</i> means anything.</i>. You say, the cohabitation or the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one of them frees her co-wife. However one argues, if “bespeaking” acquires, both are his wives and any one of them becomes free by her colleague’s <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. If “bespeaking” does not acquire, the first one does not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, but if he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the “bespoken” one, the second one also needs <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> Maybe “bespeaking” does not acquire, then <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate do not apply to her. Maybe “bespeaking” does acquire; then she is freed by her colleague’s <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. What is the difference between them<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Are there additional practical differences between the theories of the rabbis as given in the Mishnah and R. Simeon?</i>? If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the first and cohabited with the second<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Again, “the first” is the widow of the first brother, “the second” the wife of the second brother. “He” is the third brother born after the death of the first.</i>. In the opinion of the rabbis it was an incestuous cohabitation<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">“If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the first” means “even if” since for the rabbis <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of the first is legally impossible and therefore irrelevant. The relation with the second was certainly partially incestuous.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon it was not an incestuous cohabitation<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since the second one is permitted, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.2.4">Note 44</a>.</i>. If he cohabited both with the first and the second widow, in the opinion of the rabbis with the first it was incest<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly confusing wording. “One of them” means “a certain one of them”, viz., the brother’s original wife.</i> and the second needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">With the sister-in-law in a case not covered by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon, both need a bill of divorce. The first one needs a bill of divorce; perhaps the “bespeaking” did acquire. The second one needs a bill of divorce; perhaps levirate did acquire; if “bespeaking” did acquire, she was freed by her colleague’s <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Since for the rabbis “bespeaking” is partial acquisition of the widow as a wife, the second, the original wife of the second brother, was partially co-wife of the widow of the first brother. That aspect of her which was not that of co-wife is acquired by the third brother in levirate and needs a divorce; then she also needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for that aspect which was not acquired. In no case can she be permitted to stay with the third brother.</i>.
Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Sheshet: There<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. No similar statement is found in the Babli. In the discussion there, whether candidacy has any legal consequences other than preventing the widow to marry outside the clan, the name of R. Simeon is not mentioned.</i>, one stated: The words of Rebbi Simeon are that both are forbidden. This is difficult. If “bespeaking” acquires, are not both permitted? This is a question of acquiring not by “bespeaking” but by candidacy. This is difficult. If candidacy acquires, both are permitted. If candidacy does not acquire, the first one is forbidden but the second permitted. Maybe candidacy for Rebbi Simeon is like “bespeaking” for the rabbis. Just as the rabbis say, “bespeaking” acquires but leaves a remainder, so Rebbi Simeon says, candidacy acquires but leaves a remainder. This is difficult. That aspect which is acquired by candidacy implies a prohibition of an equal part of the co-wife, that part which is not acquired by candidacy implies permission of an equal aspect of the co-wife! Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Shammai, the late Amora.</i> said, is this kind of argument applicable to incest prohibitions? What does he mean? As Rebbi Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya, the aspect acquired in any sister-in-law which is not totally inside [the family] is considered to be under the incest prohibition and an incest prohibition frees her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is stronger than that ascribed to the Sages about “bespeaking”. The lifting of the incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev.</i> 18:16</a> applies only to a brother who can marry the widow without doubt. If any condition of the levirate is not fully met, there can be no levirate and the co-wife is freed without <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> They formulated a principle about a sister-in-law: Any woman forbidden by an incest prohibition has neither <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nor levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a> do not apply to her.</i>. If she is forbidden by a commandment prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Simple biblical prohibition as well as rabbinic prohibitions, explained in the next Mishnah.</i> or one of sanctity<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">A woman prohibited to a Cohen by the laws of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-14" href="/Leviticus.21.1-14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:1–14</a>. In these two cases, while marriage is sinful, the act of marriage is not void.</i>, she has <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate. Her sister who is also her sister-in-law has either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">If two sisters married to two brothers become widows and there is a third brother to whom one of the sisters is forbidden by one of the incest prohibitions, her sister may be married in levirate since the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a> do not apply to the forbidden one; an example is given in the Halakhah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “They formulated a principle about a sister-in-law: Any woman forbidden,” etc. Rebbi Ze‘ira said: When I was still there<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia.</i>, we extracted fourteen cases from “her sister which is also her sister-in-law has levirate”, except his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">From the 15 cases of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>, excluded from the laws of levirate.</i>. When we came up here, we heard what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated, since Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: His daughter from a woman he raped was married to a paternal halfbrother; she<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">לו read as לה, as in Tosephta, Chap. 2. The use of the masculine for the feminine is not uncommen in the Yerushalmi; the substitution is most likely <i>not</i> a scribal error.</i> also has a maternal sister from a different father married to a second brother who died childless. His daughter is forbidden to him but her sister, who is her sister-in-law, is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Since he never was married to her mother and the prohibition of a woman and her daughter is formulated in terms of “taking”, i. e., marriage. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 2" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).2">Tosephta, Chapter 2</a>, “she either has <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or is taken in levirate”.</i>. That is, “her sister which is also her sister-in-law has levirate”.
It is obvious that if somebody had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a woman forbidden by a commandment or because of sanctity, the co-widow was freed<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Since marriage would be valid, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> must be valid.</i>. When he had intercourse with her? Rebbi Yose said, Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Joḥanan disagree; they say the co-widow was not freed<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In this interpretation, Rebbis Eleazar and Joḥanan agree with one another but disagree with everybody else (interpretation of פני משה). Another way would be to postulate a lacuna: “R. Eleazar and R. Joḥanan disagree, <i>R. Joḥanan said, the co-widow was freed, R. Eleazar said,</i> the co-widow was not freed” (קרבן העדה). The Babli is no help; the Venice text (20b) asserts that R. Joḥanan and R. Eleazar disagree in the matter but it is unsure who said what (parallel the Yerushalmi, supporting קרבן העדה), but Tosaphot (fol. 5a, s. v. ואכתי) reads “Rebbi Aḥa and Rebbi Eleazar”, supporting פני משה.<br>The people denying that the co-widow was freed must hold that this is a rabbinic ordinance since “commandments” and “sanctity” are treated together. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 20b-21a" href="/Yevamot.20b-21a">Babli, 20b/21a</a>, treats only the prohibition of a widow to the High Priest which is simultaneously a prohibition and the transgression of a positive commandment (to marry a virgin) and therefore in a different category.</i>. Rebbi Shammai switches the [names] of this tradition. The position of Rebbi Shammai is reasonable since everywhere Rebbi Eleazar seeks support from the great Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Ḥiyya stated for women forbidden by a commandment or because of sanctity, if he had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or intercourse with her, the co-widow was freed<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Statement not found in Tosephta.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Commandment prohibition: Secondary prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">For any biblical incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18</a>, one more generation is forbidden by common law, a tradition ascribed to the “Sopherim”, the colleagues and successors of Ezra in reconstituting Judaism in Israel after the Babylonian exile.</i> instituted by the Sopherim. Holiness prohibiton: A widow for the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:14</a>.</i>, a divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev.</i> 21:7</a>.</i> or one who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The identification of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with divorce is rabbinic for the majority, possibly biblical for R. Simeon; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.4">Note 17</a>.</i> for a simple priest, a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3"><i>Deut.</i> 23:3</a>.</i> or a Gibeoness<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">A popular tradition ascribes the exclusion of Gibeonites from the Jewish marriage community to their cruel behavior towards the family of Saul when it was decided that “the Gibeonites are not part of Israel” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:2" href="/II_Samuel.21.2"><i>2S.</i>21:2</a>). They are called “given” for Joshua “gave” them as hewers of wood and drawers of water (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 9:27" href="/Joshua.9.27"><i>Jos.</i> 9:27</a>).</i> to an Israel, a Jewish woman to a Gibeonite or a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Both of them could be illegitimate paternal halfbrothers of the deceased obligated by the laws of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25" href="/Deuteronomy.25"><i>Deut.</i>25</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Commandment prohibition: Incest prohibitions instituted by the Sopherim; it is a biblical commandment to listen to the words of the Sopherim. And Holiness prohibition: A widow for the High Priest, a divorcee or one who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a simple priest. “These are the commandments,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Lev.</i> 27:35. The last verse of <i>Lev.</i> includes all commandments contained in the book. This sentence is redundant here; it belongs to the argument of those who switch the attributions.</i>” all commandments are one. “<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:8" href="/Leviticus.21.8"><i>Lev.</i> 21:8</a>; this explains the expression “holiness prohibitions”.</i> You should sanctify him, for he brings the bread of your God.” But some<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 20a" href="/Yevamot.20a">Babli, 20a</a>, the first interpretation is that of the rabbis, the second that of Rebbi Jehudah.</i> do switch: A widow for the High Priest, a divorcee or one who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a simple priest, “you should sanctify him, for he brings the bread of your God.” “These are the commandments,” all commandments are one<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The special rules for priests are called “commandment prohibitions”.</i>. And holiness prohibitions, incest prohibitions instituted by the Sopherim<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:2" href="/Leviticus.19.2"><i>Lev.</i> 19:2</a>, “you shall be holy”, is taken as general injunction to the religious leadership to institute “fences around the law” to which the secondary prohibitions belong.</i>.
Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said, why did Scripture put the incest chapter next to the holiness chapter<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19" href="/Leviticus.19"><i>Lev.</i> 19</a>.</i>? To teach you that every one who shies away from incest<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">“Incest” always includes adultery.</i> is called “holy”. In this sense, the woman of Shunem said to her husband: “<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:9" href="/II_Kings.4.9"><i>2K.</i> 4:9</a>. The parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 10b" href="/Berakhot.10b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 10b</a>, mostly in the name of R.
