Yose ben Ḥanina.</i> Lo, I know that he is a holy man of God”. Rebbi Jonah said, “he is holy”, but not his student. Rebbi Abin said, that he never looked at her. But the rabbis say that he he never had an involuntary emission. {The slave girl of Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, I never saw a bad thing on my master’s garments.}<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The statement is added to explain how the Sunamite could know that Elisa was holy..</i> It is written “Geḥazi drew near to push her away<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:27" href="/II_Kings.4.27"><i>2K.</i> 4:27</a>.</i>”. What is לְהָדְפָהּ<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">A poetic contraction of לַהֲדוֹף אוֹתָהּ, somewhat out of place in a prose text.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, he put his hand on her beauty spot<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, בְּהוֹד יופְיָהּ, better suited as expansion of הוֹדפה.</i>, between her breasts.
How can one prove secondary prohibitions? Rebbi Ḥuna said: “These<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:27" href="/Leviticus.18.27"><i>Lev.</i> 18:27</a>, כִּי אֶת־כָּל־הַתּוֹעֵבוֹת הָאֵל “all these abominations”, <i>these</i> should have been written הָאֵלֶּה; the short form is taken as a hint of the root אל “power” (the meaning of the word commonly but wrongly translated as “God”).</i>”, the strong ones. This implies that there are weaker ones<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli, 21a</a>, the argument is in the name of Rava.</i>. The following are the secondary prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli 21a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).3.1">Tosephta 3:1</a> (parallels the Babli in content and the Yerushalmi in language), <i>Derekh Ereṣ Rabba</i> 1, extended to contain most of the next paragraph.</i>: His paternal grandmother and his maternal grandmother, his paternal grandfather’s wife and his maternal grandfathers wife, his grandson’s wife whether from son or daughter, the wife of his mother’s brother and the wife of his father’s maternal brother.
It was stated: Rebbi Ḥanin said, all of them have no limit<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence has no formal equivalent in the Babli but is understood there since the exceptions to the rule are discussed at length, 21a–22a.<br>“No limit” means no limit to the number of generations to which it applies. Not only the grandmother is forbidden but also the great-grandmother and all her female ancestors. Daughter and granddaughter are biblically forbidden, the great-granddaughter and all her descendants are rabbinically forbidden.</i> except for the wife of his maternal grandfather<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The text reads “the mother of his maternal father.” This makes no sense. The translation follows the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli (21a</a>), where Ze‘iri tentatively interprets a statement of Rav that the wife of his maternal grandfather is the last in her line but her female ancestors are permitted.</i>. Bar Qappara said, all of them have a limit, since Bar Qappara added the mother of his maternal grandfather and the mother of his paternal grandfather<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">It is not claimed that Bar Qappara made a formal statement to this effect but, since he found it necessary to include an extra generation in some cases, it is clear that he assumes that only the cases enumerated are forbidden. The statement is also in <i>Derekh Ereṣ Rabba</i> 1.</i>. Rav said, his son’s daughter-in-law is the limit<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli, 21a</a>, Rav declares a limit in the number of generations to exist only in 3 or four cases: the wives of any maternal uncle (whether maternal or paternal (half)brother of his mother), his daughterin-law (per mitting her daughter who is not his granddaughter), and possibly the case quoted by R. Ḥanin.</i>. Why does he disagree? His son’s daughter-in-law comes under a different category<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">She is no blood relative.</i>. Rav said, his [grandson’s] issue from her is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The great-granddaughter and all her descendants are rabbinically prohibited since the granddaughter is biblically prohibited (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>).</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, the reason of Rav is that all Jewish women are forbidden for Abraham and all Jewish men are forbidden for Sarah.
Rav said<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21b" href="/Yevamot.21b">Babli, 21b</a>, this is reported as a Galilean statement which is rejected because it is not valid in all cases.</i>: In all cases where the female is forbidden by the Torah, the wife of the corresponding male is forbidden. The father’s sister is forbidden as female; the wife of the father’s brother, the corresponding male, is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Both cases are biblical, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:12" href="/Leviticus.18.12"><i>Lev</i>. 18:12</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:14" href="/Leviticus.18.14">14</a>. It seems that Rav claims biblical status for his statement.</i>. The mother’s sister is forbidden as female<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:13" href="/Leviticus.18.13"><i>Lev</i>. 18:13</a>. The second case is a secondary prohibition.</i>; the wife of the mother’s brother, the corresponding male, is forbidden His son’s daughter is forbidden as female<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>.</i>; the wife of his son’s son, the corresponding male, is forbidden His daughter’s daughter is forbidden as female<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>.</i>; the wife of his daughter’s son, the corresponding male, is forbidden Rebbi Jacob the Southerner said before Rebbi Yose, there are another two. His mother is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a>.</i>. His mother’s mother is secondary to her. They forbade his father’s mother because of his mother’s mother<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">She is in the list of secondary prohibitions. As the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21b" href="/Yevamot.21b">Babli notes, 21b</a>, in general one does not admit fences around fences of the law (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Note 72</a>), so without Rav’s rule, she should be permitted. The Babli has a special explanation for the prohibitions, because grandmother and grandfather are called grand <i>mother</i> and grand <i>father</i> by the grandchildren, which gives them status of father and mother. The Yerushalmi disagrees and holds that there is never a fence for a fence of the law. In the next paragraph one proves the biblical prohibition of some so-called secondaries.</i>. His son’s wife is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:15" href="/Leviticus.18.15"><i>Lev</i>. 18:15</a>.</i>. His son’s son’s wife is secondary to her. They forbade his daughter’s son’s wife because of his son’s son’s wife. Rebbi Mattaniah said, there are another two. His father’s wife is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8"><i>Lev</i>. 18:8</a>.</i>. His paternal grandfather’s wife is secondary to her. They forbade his maternal grandfather’s wife because of his paternal grandfather’s wife. His father’s paternal brother’s wife is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:14" href="/Leviticus.18.14"><i>Lev</i>. 18:14</a>. It was stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:2-26" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.2-26">Halakhah 1:1</a> that “brother” means “paternal brother”.</i>. His father’s maternal brother’s wife is secondary to her. They forbade his mother’s maternal halfbrother’s wife because of his father’s maternal brother’s wife.
Rebbi Ḥuna understood all of them from this verse<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>. “The genitals of a woman and her daughter you should not uncover; her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter you should not <i>take</i> to uncover her genitals, they are relatives, this is <i>taboo</i>.” <i>Take</i> means “to marry”.</i>: “The genitals of a woman and her daughter you should not uncover; her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter.” Taboo - taboo, for an equal cut<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14">v. 20:14</a> one reads: “If a man <i>take</i> a woman and her mother, it is taboo, in fire they should burn him and them, so that there be no taboo amongst you.” In contrast to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17">v. 18:17</a> which speaks “downwards” of future generations, that verse speaks “upwards” of preceding generations. They are connected by the word <i>taboo</i> {Accadic <i>zamū</i> “to exclude from something, to refuse something to somebody”} which must “cut” the same way in both cases. The argument is refuted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 75" href="/Sanhedrin.75">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 75a/b</a> since it contradicts verses dealing with earlier generations which seem to insist that the kinds of sin and their punishments are not comparable.</i>. Since there are three generations downwards, so there are three generations upwards<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Wife, her mother, and grandmothers as well as himself, his mother and grandmothers.</i>. Since there is a prohibition downwards, so there is a prohibition upwards. Since upwards one requires marriage, so downwards one requires marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">To make it a capital crime.</i>. Since upwards they are burned, so downwards they are burned. Since downwards, He<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The Lawgiver.</i> gave the male’s daughter the same status as the female’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>. “The genitals of a woman and her daughter you should not uncover; her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter you should not <i>take</i> to uncover her genitals, they are relatives, this is <i>taboo</i>.” <i>Take</i> means “to marry”.</i>, so upwards He gave the male’s mother the same status as the female’s mother. What is this about? His father-in-law’s mother and his mother-in-law’s mother. Should not his father’s mother be like his father-in-law’s mother<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">His mother-in-law’s mother is under a biblical prohibition since his wife is her granddaughter. Since the verse puts the daughter’s daughter on the same level as the son’s daughter, the paternal grandmother also must be forbidden.</i>? Should not his mother’s mother be like his mother-in-law’s mother<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">So there is only one fence, not two. The same argument holds for all the rhetorical questions; all the prohibitions are reduced to single fences.</i>? They forbade his father’s father’s wife because of his father’s mother. They forbade his mother’s father’s wife because of his mother’s mother. Should not his son’s son’s wife be like his wife’s son’s daughter? Should not his daughter’s son’s wife be like his wife’s daughter’s daughter?
Rebbi Ḥaggai objected before Rebbi Yose: Does not a <i>baraita</i> contradict Rav? “A person’s stepson’s wife is permitted to him but the latter’s daughter is forbidden.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).3">Tosephta 3</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli 21a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Acharei Mot" href="/Sifra,_Acharei_Mot"><i>Sifra Aḥare Mot Pereq</i> 13 (15</a>).</i>” Is his stepdaughter not forbidden to him<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli 21a</a>. A biblical prohibition; she is his wife’s daughter.</i>? The stepson is the corresponding male but his wife is permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21b" href="/Yevamot.21b">Babli 21b</a>.</i>!
Rebbi Zeriqan in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: His father-in-law’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Who is not his wife’s mother. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21a" href="/Yevamot.21a">Babli disagrees, 21a</a>. Tosaphot report that Rabbenu Tam did follow the Yerushalmi in a case at Provins (Champagne), but his contemporaries objected.</i> is forbidden because of the bad impression. If<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The word was missing in the text; it was inserted by the corrector. It probably should have been אִין since אִי meaning “if” is Babylonian.</i> you want to say it is biblical, did not David marry Riṣpah bat Ayyah<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">His father-in-law Saul’s concubine.</i>? As it was said<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 12:8" href="/II_Samuel.12.8"><i>2S</i>. 12:8</a>.</i>: “I gave you your master’s house and your master’s wives in your bosom.” Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Two stepchildren who grow up in the same house<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">And are not related.</i> are forbidden to marry because of the bad impression. A case came before Rebbi Ḥanina ben Rebbi Abbahu. He said, they should marry in a place where they are not known<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">In line with the general attitude of the Yerushalmi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.1.9"><i>Kilaim</i> 9, Notes 34ff</a>.</i>.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 3:5" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.3.5"><i>Keritut</i> Mishnah 3:5</a>. The Mishnah speaks of the grandfather’s grandson’s daughter’s daughter who was married to his brother. If that brother dies without issue, the widow is forbidden to her great-grandfather by a secondary prohibition. If the old man marries her in levirate instead of having <i>ḥalîṣah</i> as required, since the prohibition is rabbinic she is married and, if the son sleeps with her, Rebbi Yose the Tanna declares him guilty both for his granddaughter and his father’s wife, committing two sins in one act.</i>: “Rebbi Yose says, if the grandfather transgressed and married her.” What did he transgress? He transgressed the words of the Sopherim<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Three generations are biblically forbidden. She would be secondarily forbidden to the father. Since the Mishnah does not mention the father but “the old man”, generally interpreted as “grandfather”, this is one generation more than that spelled out in the Tosephta. Does this support R. Ḥanin that these prohibitions are unlimited in the number of generations?</i>. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Abbahu, he asked Rebbi Joḥanan: Does this mean that secondary prohibitions have no limit? He said to him, did we learn “secondaries to secondaries”? No. Secondaries to the words of the Torah, and all of them because of his son’s daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Yose the Tanna does not refer to the first part of the Mishnah speaking of a granddaughter but has a new case where the woman was the son’s daughter-in-law before marrying the father’s brother who is permitted to her.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Jonah, Rebbi Abbahu did not say so, but Rebbi Eleazar asked Rebbi Joḥanan, did we not learn of eight secondaries, and here they are nine! But all of them because of his son’s daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Since this case is the root of all secondary prohibitions it was not spelled out before; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 21b" href="/Yevamot.21b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 21b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Any [male] who has a brother anywhere<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Even illegitimate or bastard.</i> makes his brother’s wife a candidate<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The one under obligation of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is always called זקוּקה, the fact of obligation זיקה. It does not seem reasonable to connect this meaning to biblical זקק “to refine, purify”; maybe the root is related to Arabic زقّ، زقق “to feed (a bird his young)”, that she is fodder for the levirate, or even Akkadic <i>zāqiqum</i>“ghost; necromancer”. {Jewish Berber tribes held that a brother who rejects levirate will be punished by the ghost of his dead brother.}</i> for levirate and he is his brother in every respect<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Including inheritance.</i>, except if he were from a slave woman<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">If she is not his own property. In the latter case, one might assume that he freed the mother of his child. She is a semi-Jew who upon manumission and immersion in a <i>miqweh</i> becomes a full Jew. Therefore, she is not in the same category as a non-Jewish woman.</i> or a non-Jew.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Any person who has a child<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Even illegitimate or bastard.</i> anywhere frees [the child’s] father’s wife from levirate; [the child] would be guilty for wounding or cursing [the father]<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:15" href="/Exodus.21.15"><i>Ex</i>. 21:15</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:17" href="/Exodus.21.17">17</a>.</i>; he is his child in every respect<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Including inheritance.</i> except if he were from a slave woman<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">If she is not his own property. In the latter case, one might assume that he freed the mother of his child. She is a semi-Jew who upon manumission and immersion in a <i>miqweh</i> becomes a full Jew. Therefore, she is not in the same category as a non-Jewish woman.</i> or a non-Jew.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Any person who has a child anywhere”, etc. Rebbi Avin asked: “His child in every respect”, even for being fruitful and multiplying<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.6.1">Mishnah 6:6</a>. Since no answer is given, it seems obvious that a bastard counts as a child. This is the interpretation of R. Mose Isserls.</i>? Is there no difference<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The Spanish tradition, from Nachmanides to R. Nissim, reads לפריה וּלרביה ולשניות “for being fruitful and multiplying and secondary prohibitions”.</i> between a Gentile who came to a Jewish woman and she gave birth and a Jew who came to a Gentile woman and she gave birth<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">In both cases, of the three partners in the creation of a child, father, mother, and God (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:27" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.27"><i>Peah</i>, Chapter 1, Note 116</a>), the child has only two since legally it has no father.</i>? “When she became Jewish and gave birth it is a first-born for inheritance but not a first-born for the Cohen.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 8:1" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.8.1">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 8:1</a>. If the Gentile first has a child as a Gentile, then converts and marries the father of her child, the next child, if male, will be the father’s firstborn (since he is no relative of the other child) but does not have to be redeemed (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:20" href="/Exodus.34.20"><i>Ex</i>. 34:20</a>) since he is not the first child of the mother.</i>”
A Gentile came to a Gentile woman and she gave birth. Rebbi Joḥanan said, Gentiles have family relationships<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The verse <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 2:24" href="/Genesis.2.24"><i>Gen</i>. 2:24</a>: “Therefore, a man abandons his father and his mother and clings to his wife so they will be one flesh” is interpreted to mean that, by the laws of Creation, incest between parents and children, adultery (with a wife not his own) and possibly homosexuality are forbidden. The question is whether a court can enforce the incest prohibition between father and daughter. If there is no recognized legal relationship, that cannot be enforced. R. Joḥanan holds that any court on earth, even a Jewish one, can punish incest between Gentile father and daughter. R. Simeon ben Laqish disagrees.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 62a" href="/Yevamot.62a">Babli, 62a</a>, the parallel discussion is on a completely different topic, whether the firstborn of a proselyte who converted together with his father is entitled to the customary double portion of the inheritance. R. Joḥanan answers in the affermative, R. Simeon ben Laqish in the negative.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, Gentiles have no family relationships. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 39:1" href="/Isaiah.39.1"><i>Is</i>. 39:1</a>.</i>: “At that time, Merodakh-Baladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Ḥizqiah.” Since he honored his elder<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 96a" href="/Sanhedrin.96a">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 96a</a> reports that Baladan was incapacitated and Merodakh added his father’s name to his own so that all acts of his regency should also be in his father’s name.</i>, he was honored with a family relationship. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 15:18" href="/I_Kings.15.18"><i>1K.</i> 15:18</a>. The text is contaminated with <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 16:2" href="/II_Chronicles.16.2"><i>2Chr</i>. 16:2</a>.</i>: “At that time, king Asa sent to Ben-Hadad, son of Tabrimon, son of Ḥezayon, king of Damascus, as follows.” Destroyer son of a destroyer. As you say<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 9:24" href="/Esther.9.24"><i>Esth</i>. 9:24</a>. In <i>Targum Šeni</i> 3:1, the family tree of Haman is given up to his ancestor Esaw. It is not clear there whether “Hamedata the Agagite” is intended as a name or a title. In the latter case, Haman’s father’s name was Seraḥ.</i>: “For Haman ben Hamedata was”. Was he the son of Hamedata? That means, oppressor son of an oppressor. So here also, destroyer son of a destroyer. Rebbi Tanḥuma said, so did Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish answer Rebbi Joḥanan, but is there not written<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 9:10" href="/II_Samuel.9.10"><i>2S</i>. 9:10</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 9:2" href="/II_Samuel.9.2">v. 2</a>, Ṣiba is called “ ‘ebed of the House of Saul”. Since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 9:9" href="/II_Samuel.9.9">v. 9</a> he is called “esquire of Saul”, it seems that <i>‘ebed</i> represents the usage of the time the book was finally edited, the later kingdom of Judah, when <i>‘ebed</i> was the recognized title of officials directly responsible to the king.</i>: “Ṣiba had sixteen sons and twenty slaves.” Do slaves have family relationships<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Not being able to legally marry, they are empowered to be promiscuous without guilt.</i>? It is to enumerate those who served Mephiboshet together.
A slave woman: “The woman and her children shall belong to her owner.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:4" href="/Exodus.18.4"><i>Ex</i>. 18:4</a>, speaking of the Jewish indentured servant who has to serve for six years. If the children he had during that time with a slave woman were his, they would have to be freed with him at the end of his servitude.</i>” A Gentile woman. Rebbi Joḥanan said in the name of Rebbi Sineon ben Ioḥai, it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 7:3-4" href="/Deuteronomy.7.3-4"><i>Deut</i>. 7:3–4</a>. Since only the masculine is used, “he will divert”, but not the feminine, it is concluded that the verse speaks only about the Gentile husband. Therefore, the child of the Jewish husband and the Gentile wife is not the husband’s child.<br>The parallel to this paragraph is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 23a" href="/Yevamot.23a">Babli 23a</a>.</i>: “You shall not conclude marriage with them”. And it is written: “For he will divert your son from after Me.” Your son from a Jewish woman is called your son; but your son from a Gentile woman is not called your son but her son.
<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Parallels in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.2-13"><i>Qiddušin</i> 3:14</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 7:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.7.3"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 7(3</a>); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 7:26" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.7.26"><i>Eccl. rabba</i> 7:26</a>; <i>Bemidbar rabba, Tanḥuma</i>, both <i>Pesiqtot</i>, to <i>Ḥuqqat</i> (<i>Parah</i>).</i> Jacob from Kefar Naboraia went to Tyre. They came to ask him, may one circumcise the son of a Gentile woman<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">The son of a Jewish father born on the Sabbath, converted at birth.</i> on the Sabbath? He wanted to permit it from the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 1:18" href="/Numbers.1.18"><i>Num</i>. 1:18</a>, which determines the clan by patrilinear descent. The principle is expressed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.10.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:12</a>: “If there is a possibility of marriage without sin, the child follows its father”, even if the parents are not married.</i>: “They determined their genealogies for their families according to their fathers’ houses.” Rebbi Ḥaggai heard it and said, he shall come. They brought him in order to be whipped. He said to him, for what reason do you whip me? He said, from what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 10:3" href="/Ezra.10.3"><i>Ezra</i> 10:3</a>: “Now we shall make a covenant for our God to expel all these [foreign] women and what was born to them, as counseled by the Lord, by those who fear the commandments of our God; it should be done according to the Torah”. As usual, the main point is the part not quoted.</i>: “Now we shall make a covenant for our God”. He said, you want to whip me based on tradition<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">“Tradition” is the name for the books of Prophets and Hagiographs which are not books of law. The most one can infer from a text of tradition is how Torah laws were handled in later times.</i>? He said, “and it should be done according to the Torah.” He said to him, from which teaching? He said, from that which Rebbi Joḥanan said in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai, it is written: “You shall not conclude marriage with them”. And it is written: “For he will divert your son from after Me.” Your son from a Jewish woman is called your son; but your son from a Gentile woman is not called your son but her son. He said to him, whip your whipping, because it is good to impress<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">To impress upon him the lesson he should not forget.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody gave <i>qiddushin</i> to one of two sisters but he does not know to which one of them, he gives a bill of divorce to each<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Both are forbidden to him since each one is possibly hi his sister-in-law’s sister.</i>. If he died and has one brother, that one has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both sisters. If he had two [brothers], one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one may marry in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">If the one who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> had received <i>qiddushin</i> from the deceased, the other one is free to marry his brother. If she did not get <i>qiddushin</i>, then the levirate is valid.</i>. If both married without asking, one<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The court does not intervene since one has correctly married in levirate and the other is free to marry his brother since she had no <i>qiddushin</i>.</i> does not remove [the women] from them.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody gave <i>qiddushin</i> to one of two sisters but he does not know to which one of them, he gives a bill of divorce to each. If he died and has one brother, that one has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both sisters.” Everywhere else you say<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.1.1">Mishnah 5:1</a>.</i> “there cannot be <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but here you say so? There if it is certain, here one is in doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">It is impossible to do otherwise.</i>. “If he had two [brothers], one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one may marry in levirate.” Everywhere else you say, in any case one asks him to perform the levirate one does not say perform <i>ḥalîṣah;</i> but here you say so? There if it is certain, here one is in doubt. “If both married without asking, one does not remove [the women] from them.”

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If two<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Unrelated.</i> [men] gave <i>qiddushin</i> to two sisters and neither of them knows to which one he gave his, each one of them gives two bills of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Both sisters are forbidden to both men since each relation would possibly be adultery. Of the two bills each of the women gets, one is valid and the other, given by a man not her husband, is as if it had not been written; only they do not know which is which.</i>. If they died and each one had a brother, each [brother] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both [sisters]<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">They are forbidden to both of them for each one is possibly a candidate for levirate with the other man’s brother.</i>. If one had one [brother] but the other had two, the single one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both [sisters], but of the two brothers one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and the other may marry in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The second sister which did not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his brother since she either is his sister-in-law or an unrelated person.</i>. If both married without asking, one does not remove [the women] from them<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The court does not intervene since one has correctly married in levirate and the other is free to marry his brother since she had no <i>qiddushin</i>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If two [men] gave <i>qiddushin</i> to two sisters,” etc. It was stated: These rules apply both for Israel and for Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 24a" href="/Yevamot.24a">Babli 24a</a>, with an explanation: Since for priests, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is treated like divorce, one should assume that both sisters are forbidden to priests. But since this treatment is only a rabbinic enhancement of the priest’s status, it is not applied to cases of doubt.</i>. That is, if <i>ḥalîṣah</i> was performed first and the levirate afterwards. But to perform levirate first is forbidden; maybe his brother will die and it will turn out that he cohabited with the sister of his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Who still is bound to him as a candidate for levirate. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 23b" href="/Yevamot.23b">Babli 23b</a>.</i>. Rav Ḥisda said, that means that having relations with the sister of his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Who is not known certainly to be his sister-in-law. The conclusion is reached since all parts of this Mishnah are approved if one of the men is a Cohen.</i> does not make her unfit for [marriage into] priesthood. Rebbi Yose bar Abba said, Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: He who cohabited with the sister of a woman for whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> did not make her unfit for [marriage into] priesthood.
“If they died and each one had a brother, each [brother] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both [sisters]. Everywhere else you say “there cannot be <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but here you say so? There if it is certain, here one is in doubt. “If one had one [brother] but the other had two, the single one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both [sisters], but of the two brothers one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and the other may marry in levirate. Everywhere else you say, in any case one asks him to perform the levirate one does not say perform <i>ḥalîṣah;</i> but here you say so? There if it is certain, here one is in doubt. “If both married without asking, one does not remove [the women] from them.”

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If each [of the deceased] had two brothers, one brother of each [of the deceased] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with one [of the sisters] and the other brother takes the other [sister] in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of his brother was correct, then the other brother marries an unrelated widow. If it was incorrect then he enters a valid levirate marriage.</i>. If two [brothers] both performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Each of them for another woman.</i>, the other two should not [both] marry in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Since one of them might marry the sister of a candidate of levirate with him. But if they married without asking, one of them certainly executed a valid levirate and the other married an unrelated woman.</i> but one of them performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and the other one may take in levirate. If both married without asking, one does not remove [the women] from them.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If each [of the deceased] had two brothers”. That is, for Israel, but for Cohanim they are forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">If the first pair of brothers both performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and the second are Cohanim then one of the second pair certainly will marry a woman freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, who is considered a rabbinic divorcee. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 24a" href="/Yevamot.24a">Babli, 24a</a>, seems to extend the permission given to Cohanim (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.8.2">Note 159</a>) even to this case since for each single person there is only a 50/50 chance that he married a woman with a legally valid <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The obligation of levirate is on the oldest [brother] but if a younger one got the start on him, he acquired. If somebody is accused in matters of a slave woman<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">That he has an affair with the slave.</i> and she was manumitted, or of a Gentile and she converted, he should not marry her but if he married her one does not remove her from him. If somebody is accused in matters of a married woman and she was forcibly divorced from [her husband], even if he married her he must divorce her<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">An adulteress is permanently forbidden both to the husband and the adulterer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The obligation of levirate is on the oldest [brother] but if a younger one got the start on him, he acquired, etc.” “The obligation of levirate is on the oldest,” since it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.6"><i>Deut</i>. 25:6</a>: “The firstborn she will bear shall rise in the name of his dead brother.” This seems to imply that the child should be called X son of Y, where Y is not the biological father but the dead first husband.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 24a" href="/Yevamot.24a">Babli, 24a</a>, discusses the same verse in a different manner, based on <i>Sifry Deut</i>. #289.</i>, “the firstborn she will bear shall …”. How do we hold? If about the newborn, the verse should read “he should rise in the name of his dead father.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">The first hand in the ms. had יקוּם על שם אחיו המת which is exactly the biblical text and therefore cannot have been meant. The corrector changed this into יקוּם על שם אחיו המת as given in the text. Ms. A reads יקוּם על שם אחיו אביו המת “shall rise on the name of his dead brother-father” and this seems to be the superior reading; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.10.2">Note 168</a>.</i>” But it must be that the newborn is a firstborn. In that case, even if he had children and they died before he died, his widow should not be a candidate for levirate! Then the verse should have said, “he never had children<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Since one of them might marry the sister of a candidate of levirate with him. But if they married without asking, one of them certainly executed a valid levirate and the other married an unrelated woman.</i>”. But if it cannot refer to the newborn; let it refer to the levir, “the obligation of levirate is on the oldest.”
“If somebody is accused in matters of a slave woman and she was manumitted, or of a Gentile and she converted, he should not marry her but if he married her one does not remove her from him.” If he agreed lawfully not to marry her and [nevertheless] married her, she is forcibly removed from him<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">But without a confession of guilt by the husband, the rabbinic authority cannot interfere.</i>. If he divorced her, may he take her back? If you would say that, would you not defame her children<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">If she was divorced and one would prohibit remarriage (as long as she had no other husband in between), at the same time one would declare her children from that man as bastards. This is unacceptable.</i>? “If somebody is accused in matters of a married woman,” Rav said, that is, he was accused by witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Only for adultery proven in court is the marriage with the presumed adulterer forbidden. A parallel statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 24b" href="/Yevamot.24b">Babli, 24b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose asked, if he was accused by witnesses, is that what was stated: If <i>he</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The husband. He may divorce her for suspected adultery and refuse to pay her anything. If she goes to court for the money, he can defend himself by circumstantial evidence permitted in civil law.</i> divorced her, even if he<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The adulterer.</i> married her, he must divorce her? If somebody else divorced her<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">After her divorce, she married a party other than the presumed adulterer.</i>, he can keep her! If he was accused by witnesses, even if somebody else divorced her, he must divorce her<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">An adulteress is permanently forbidden both to the husband and the adulterer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>).</i>! But that is what we deal with: If he was accused not by witnesses, if somebody else divorced her, he may keep her<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta 4:5</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody brings a bill of divorce from overseas and says “it was written and signed in my presence”, he shall not marry the wife<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">A bill of divorce brought from another country is valid only if the person who delivers the document can testify to the circumstances in which it was executed (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:1</a>). If the witness would marry the divorcee, his testimony would be suspect because of his interest in the validity of the divorce.</i>. “He died<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died far from home and somebody testifies to his death to free the widow for another marriage, he cannot marry her because of conflict of interests. The same holds for the other cases.</i>”, “I killed him”, or “we killed him”, he shall not marry the wife. Rebbi Jehudah said, “I killed him”, the wife cannot be married<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The killer cannot testify since he declares himself to be wicked and persons officially declared wicked cannot be witnesses (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:1" href="/Exodus.23.1"><i>Ex</i>. 23:1</a>). Therefore, there is no evidence of the death and the wife cannot claim to be a widow.</i>, “we killed him”, the wife can be married<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">The witness only says that he was with a group containing a killer, not that he himself is a killer. His testimony is valid; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:4:1-5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.4.1-5.4">Mishnah 15:4</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is a copy of the parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.7.2"><i>Qiddušin</i> 3:7</a> on the Mishnah quoted later, “I betrothed one of my daughters but I do not remember to whom I betrothed her. If someone comes and says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>, he is trustworthy.”</i>“If somebody brings a bill of divorce from overseas and says”, etc. About what is he trustworthy? Samuel says, he is trusted to give a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">But without further evidence he is not allowed to marry the girl since he is testifying in his own behalf. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 63b" href="/Kiddushin.63b">Babli, <i>Qiddušin</i> 63b</a>, this is the opinion of Rav; Samuel is not mentioned there.</i>. Assi said, he is trusted to marry<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Without evidence to the contrary, we do not accuse him of attempted adultery.</i>. Rav Huna said in the name of Rav: He is trusted to marry. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he is trusted to marry but one does not infer from this ruling anything for another case. What means, one does not infer from this ruling anything for another case? I sold one of my fields but I do not remember to whom I sold it. If someone comes and says, I bought it, he is not trusted in any way. In <i>qiddushin</i>, the same holds. “<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.8">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:7</a>.</i> I betrothed one of my daughters but I do not remember to whom I betrothed her. If someone comes and says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>,” he is not trusted in any way<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">To marry her; this is the point made by Samuel. The text in <i>Qiddušin</i> reads לא הכל ממנו “is not everything from him?”; the father’s evidence is nothing and everything depends on the word of the suitor. This seems to be the correct version even though the two mss. agree in <i>Yebamot</i>.</i>. The Mishnah disagrees with Rav: “If somebody brings a bill of divorce from overseas and says, it was written and signed in my presence, he shall not marry the wife<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">The person on whose word the woman becomes free to marry may not marry her; why should a person whose word frees the girl from being unable to marry anybody in the world be allowed to marry her?</i>.” There, she is considered by everybody to be a married woman. Here, she is considered to be a married woman only by two persons<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The two witnesses without whom any <i>qiddushin</i> are invalid. If they come and testify, there will be no doubt; the testimony of the suitor is verifiable. In the case of the divorce, everybody knows that the woman is married and the testimony is unverifiable.</i>. One waits until these two come and say, this is the man who gave her <i>qiddushin</i>. The Mishnah disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Qiddušin</i>: Samuel. This is the correct version even though the two mss. agree in <i>Yebamot</i>. If one of the two suitors is permitted to marry the girl, the rest of the world is excluded and both are trustworthy even for marriage.</i>: “<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.8">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:7</a>.</i> This one says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>, and that one says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>. Both of them give a bill of divorce, but if they agree, one gives a bill of divorce and the other one marries.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">End of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.8">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:7</a>, about the father who btrothed his daughter to an unknown suitor.</i>” He explains this, if [the father] says, I did betroth her to one of these two but I do not remember which one it was. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Yasa, in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If one of them jumped the gun and married her, one does remove her from him. That is, if this one says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>, and that one says. I gave her <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">They both came at the same time, or at least the existence of both of them was known when one of them married the girl.</i> and one of them jumped the gun and married her. But if he said, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i> and married her, and another one comes<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">He comes later; his identity was not known at the time of marriage.</i> and says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>, he is not trusted in any way. It was stated thus: If after the marriage another man comes and says, I gave her <i>qiddushin</i>, he is not trusted in any way.
<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">In both mss. the reference to the Mishnah is missing, that R. Jehudah bars the one who says, I killed the husband, from marrying the widow. It is explained here that such testimony is always invalid.</i> As you take it, if he killed him, a suspect in a case can neither judge nor testify in it. If he did not kill him, the person is alive.
“We killed him,” she should be married to others but not to him<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Even though R. Jehudah says only that the woman can remarry; he will agree that she cannot marry the person upon whose testimony she becomes a widow.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 4:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).4.5">Tosephta 4:5</a>; a somewhat different version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 25b" href="/Yevamot.25b">Babli, 25b</a>. The Babli insists that the robber explicitly dissociated himself from the killers. This is not the position of the Yerushalmi; a possibility that he was not the killer is enough, given all the leniencies admitted in testimonies concerning women whose husbands had disappeared.</i>“They said before Rebbi Jehudah, it happened that a robber was caught in Kappadokian Caesarea<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Today Kaisarie.</i>. When he went out to be executed, he said to them, go and tell the wife of Simeon ben Cahana that I killed him when he was coming into Lydda. The case came before the Sages and they confirmed his words. Rebbi Jehudah said to them: Is that a proof? He only said, we killed him.”

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A rabbi who forbade a woman to her husband because of a vow<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">A woman made a vow that she will have no usufruct from her husband. This is a vow the husband cannot dissolve since it is not a “vow of deprivation” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 30:2-17" href="/Numbers.30.2-17"><i>Num</i>. 30:2–17</a>). She can go to a competent rabbi who may find a way to relieve her from her vow if she sincerely repents. If he did not find a way to repeal the vow, the husband will divorce her (obviously, he need not pay her anything.) Since the refusal of the rabbi to annul the vow forces the divorce, he cannot profit from his act or people will suspect him of bending the law for his own profit.</i> cannot marry her. If she repudiated or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> before him he may marry her since he acts as a court<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, he does not act alone since a repudiation needs 3 and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> 5 judges. In the other cases of the Mishnah, the availability of the woman for marriage depends on unforseeable circumstances.</i>. And all who had wives who [subsequently] died may marry them<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbi who forces the divorce or the witnesses who testified that she was a widow. If they were married at the time of the action, they may marry the woman after the death of their wives since death is an unpredictable event. In this case, it is presumed that the marriage contract of the rabbi or any member of the court forbade the husband to take an additional wife without the first wife’s consent. Then the members of the court are truly disinterested parties. <i>Ketubot</i> of this kind are known from the Cairo <i>Genizah</i>.</i>. And to all who were married to others and were divorced or widowed, they can be married. All are permitted to their sons or brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Nobody sins for the profit of others; see the Halakhah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A rabbi who forbade a woman to her husband because of a vow”, etc. “A rabbi who forbade a woman to her husband because of a vow cannot marry her.” I would say, that was his intention from the start. “If she repudiated or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> before him he may marry her since he acts as a court”, because two will not usually sin for the benefit of a third. There<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.3.4.1"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i>, Mishnah 3:7</a>.</i>, we have stated: “If somebody deposits fruit with another person, that one should not touch it even if it spoils. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, he shall sell it under the supervision of a court because one is obliged to return a find to its owners.” Rebbi Abba bar Jacob said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 39b" href="/Bava_Metzia.39b">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 39b</a> (R. Abba ben R. Jacob in the name of R. Joḥanan). In the Babli, the circumstances of this ruling are very much in dispute.</i>. What does one do with the money? Rav Jehudah said, the disagreement of Rebbi Aqiba and Rebbi Ṭarphon<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 2:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.2.6.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 2:7</a>. If somebody finds perishables (with characteristics that might allow the indentification of the lawful owner), he sells them under the supervision of a court. R. Tarphon holds that he uses the money in his own business; therefore he is totally responsible for it. R. Aqiba says, he may not touch the money; therefore, he is not responsible if it is stolen.</i>. It is a condition that the members of the court cannot buy. Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">A woman made a vow that she will have no usufruct from her husband. This is a vow the husband cannot dissolve since it is not a “vow of deprivation” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 30:2-17" href="/Numbers.30.2-17"><i>Num</i>. 30:2–17</a>). She can go to a competent rabbi who may find a way to relieve her from her vow if she sincerely repents. If he did not find a way to repeal the vow, the husband will divorce her (obviously, he need not pay her anything.) Since the refusal of the rabbi to annul the vow forces the divorce, he cannot profit from his act or people will suspect him of bending the law for his own profit.</i> said, Rebbi Ḥiyya ben Rebbi Sabbatai<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown Amora.</i> asked: Here, you say, “if she repudiated or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> before him he may marry her since he acts as a court,” and here, you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Why are the members of the court forbidden to buy the produce to be sold under their supervision?</i>? Rebbi Yose said, there, the buy could be in thirds<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Every judge could profit from the transaction.</i>, but here, two will not usually sin for the benefit of a third.
“ “And all who had wives who [subsequently] died may marry them.” It only says “who died”; therefore, not if they were divorced. “And to all who were married to others and were divorced or widowed, they can be married”, since usually nobody sins for an uncertain future. “All are permitted to their sons or brothers,” since usually nobody sins for the benefit of either his son ot his brother.

Chapter 3



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> There are four brothers, two of whom are married to two sisters. If those married to the sisters died<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">One possible explanation is that they died childless at the same time; then each of the sisters is a candidate for levirate for either one of the surviving brothers, i. e., each is a sister of a sister-in-law and potentially forbidden.</i>, [the sisters] have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate. If [the remaining brothers] jumped the gun and married, they must divorce them. Rebbi Eliezer said, the House of Shammai say, they shall keep them<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">According to him the House of Shammai must hold that candidacy has no other legal consequences (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.4">Note 19</a>). Therefore, if they married the sisters against the rules, no biblical precept has been violated. In contrast, cf. Halakhah 5.</i>, but the House of Hillel say, they have to divorce.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Four brothers, two of whom are married to two sisters,” etc. If there were four brothers, two of whom are married to unrelatedwomen, would they not be subject to levirate? There is a difference, since here there is the prohibition of sisters. In that case, they should not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i> from them! Rebbi Mattaniah said, it is because of candidacy and the prohibition of sisters is not clear<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether the fact that the sisters become candidates for levirate at the same time makes them forbidden; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.6">Chapter 2, Notes 27–29</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>.</i> There, we have stated: “If a brother gave <i>qiddushin</i> to the sister of a woman waiting for the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">After the death of the brother, when the sister-in-law’s sister was prohibited to him since the widow is a candidate for levirate with any one of the brothers.</i>, they said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra: One says to him, wait until your brother has acted. If [one of the] brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or married her, he may marry his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Since the candidacy obstacle to marriage was removed. The same holds if the widow dies.</i>. If the sister-in-law died, he may marry his wife. If the levir died, he has to send away his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s widow by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Only if he is the only remaining brother. Then he is forbidden to marry his betrothed and has to divorce her. The widow becomes the sister of a woman divorced by him and cannot be married.</i>” It says only: If the sister-in-law died, his wife is permitted to him. But if his wife died, his sister-in-law is forbidden to him. Rebbi Joḥanan said, these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The source of the argument is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:6:1-7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.6.1-7.4">Mishnah 13:6</a>. In the tradition of the Babli, the author is R. Eleazar (ben Arakh, the Tanna). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 41a" href="/Yevamot.41a">Babli disagrees (41a</a>) and holds that both opinions are compatible with the position of the Sages who in this case might agree with R. Eleazar that a woman whom a brother could not marry for one moment is permanently forbidden to him.</i>. But the Sages say, if his sister-in-law died, his wife is permitted to him, if his wife died, his sister-in-law is permitted to him. Rebbi Joḥanan said<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.16">Chapter 1 (Note 71</a>), this is a statement of R. Eleazar (the Amora) in the name of R. Abun. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27b" href="/Yevamot.27b">Babli, 27b</a>, R. Joḥanan disagrees and holds that any sister-in-law who cannot be married in levirate at the moment of death of her husband can never be a party to levirate.</i>, the Sages hold that for anything induced by a cause, if the cause is removed the prohibition is removed. But for Rebbi Eliezer, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains.
Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: Here<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>.</i>, you say, if his sister-in-law died, his wife is permitted to him, if his wife died, his sister-in-law is permitted to him, and here<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>. If one of the brothers performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the woman who became a widow later, the sister who first became a widow should be permitted to the other brother by the rule spelled out by R. Joḥanan; see below.</i> you say so? He said to him, I do not know the reason for [the rule regarding] sisters<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27b" href="/Yevamot.27b">Babli, 27b</a>, R. Joḥanan is quoted as saying that he does not know the author of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>. This means he is unable to analyze the hidden premisses on which the ruling is based.</i>. Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Ḥiyya, in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: I do not know the reason for [the rule regarding] sisters who are sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">He spelled out that his criticism refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>, not 4:10.</i>. Rebbi Hila, Rebbi Yasa, in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The prohibition of sisters who are sisters-in-law cannot be compared to the prohibition of sisters who are not sisters-in-law. Rebbi Jeremiah said, explain it that the house fell on both [brothers] at the same time<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Note 1</a>. In that case, we do not know which of the two brothers died first; there are no discernible first and second widows to apply the rule of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>. A similar argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28a" href="/Yevamot.28a">Babli, 28a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose asked, did Rebbi Joḥanan say, I do not know the reason for [the rule regarding] sisters who are sisters-in-law if the house fell on both [brothers] at the same time? Only if they died one after the other. They wanted to say, what was the problem of Rebbi Joḥanan? If the second one died, why should the first one not be permitted to him? But if the first one died, the second should be forbidden to him. Rebbi Yudan said, both cases are the same problem for him. And candidacy counts for nothing since if there are three brothers,two of them paternal but not maternal halfbrothers, and two maternal but not paternal halfbrothers. If the paternal halfbrother died first<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Brother 2 is paternal halfbrother of brother 1 and maternal halfbrother of brother 3. There is no relationship between 1 and 3. If 1 dies childless, his widow becomes a candidate for levirate with 2.</i> and the second brother had no time to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate before he died, and she became eligible for his maternal halfbrother, may he not take her<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">If candidacy had given her some status comparable a wife of 2, she would be forbidden to 3. Since this case is never mentioned, one has to conclude that for 3 she is the widow of an unrelated man. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 74a" href="/Nedarim.74a">Babli, <i>Nedarim</i> 74a</a>, this position is ascribed to R. Aqiba, but not accepted by the other Sages.</i>? This shows that candidacy is nothing, [otherwise] she should be forbidden as the maternal halfbrother’s wife.
What if there is a co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since none of the sisters can be married (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>), could any co-wife of one of them be married?</i>? Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Avina: It is an inference <i>de minore ad majus</i>. If the Sages gave a co-wife to the sister of a woman with whom one performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, which is rabbinic<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The imputation of the status of divorcee to any woman having performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is purely rabbinic. Therefore, the prohibition of the sister of a woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and her co-wives is not biblical.</i>, here, where there is the prohibition of sisters<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>.</i>, not so much more? It is obvious that the rule of co-wives applies to his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is a case of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>, the sentence is superfluous. It is missing in ms. A.</i>. Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Avina: One has stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>baraita</i> referring to the case of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.1">Mishnah 3:1</a>, partially quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27a" href="/Yevamot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>.</i>, “if the co-wives performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the sisters were freed; if the sisters performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the co-wives were not freed.” But as you say, if the co-wives performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the sisters were freed, so it should be that even if the sisters performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the co-wives should be freed<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Since the House of Hillel hold that a woman forbidden for levirate gives the same status to her co-wives, it seems illogical to give the co-wives a status different from that of the sisters.</i>. But it must follow Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri, since Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said, come and let us institute that the co-wife perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> without being admitted to levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:6:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.6.2-3">Chapter 1, Notes 200–204</a>.</i>. Did they institute that? Was it not stated: They did not manage to institute this before the time became unsuitable. But it must follow the House of Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Same conclusion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 27a" href="/Yevamot.27a">Babli, 27a</a>.</i> since the House of Shammai permit the co-wives to the brothers. Rebbi Phineas said to Rebbi Yose: If it follows the House of Shammai, even if the co-wives performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the sistersshould not be freed<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of the sisters is worthless for the co-wives then <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of the co-wives should be worthless for the sisters since the House of Shammai validate a marriage of the sisters.</i>! But we have stated: Rebbi Eliezer said, the House of Shammai say, they shall keep them, but the House of Hillel say, they have to divorce. There are two Tannaïm interpreting the House of Shammai, one said if the co-wives performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the sisters were freed, the other one said if the co-wives performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the sisters were not freed.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28a" href="/Yevamot.28a">Babli 28a</a>.</i>: “Abba Shaul says, the House of Hillel made this easy<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In his opinion, the House of Hillel permit the sisters to the brothers without problems, not only if they married without asking; they are more lenient than the House of Shammai.</i>.” Is that a criticism? It is a praise, since people were saying, what is the prohibition here<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">If candidacy without “bespeaking” has no influence, there is no reason why the two brothers should not marry the two sisters in levirate since no biblical precept could be violated.</i>? It was found stated in the name of Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28a" href="/Yevamot.28a">Babli 28a</a>.</i>: “If they jumped the gun and married, they should keep them.” But that is only if they had intercourse at the same time<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Since levirate is valid only through intercourse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>), and R. Simeon has doubts whether “bespeaking” makes the woman a wife (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.2-6">Halakhah 2:1</a>), he will require to do away with “bespeaking” and marriage ceremony. If each brother has intercourse with the corresponding sister at the same time, they both become wives of the respective brothers and neither of them is an impediment to the other’s marriage.</i>. In the opinion of Abba Shaul it is permitted to have intercourse without asking. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon only if he transgressed and had intercourse. If the first [brother] married and had intercourse, he tells the second also to have intercourse. If that one did not have intercourse, the first [brother] is forbidden to have intercourse a second time<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Which does not fulfill the biblical requirement to marry the widow of the childless brother.</i>; maybe one of them will die and it turns out that he had intercourse with the sister of <i>his</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The one who from the start was a candidate to be taken by him in levirate. Then both of them are forbidden to him.</i> sister-in-law. It was stated: If the second [brother] died, the first one had to divorce his wife with a bill of divorce and his brother’s wife by <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The wife of the first brother becomes forbidden as the sister of a woman who is a candidate for levirate with him. This Tanna holds that since the levirate of the first sister was illegal, it does not exclude the second sister from becoming a candidate. The expression “his brother’s wife” means “his brother’s potential wife”. If the second brother had taken the second sister in levirate, the problems would have disappeared and when he died childless, his widow would be free of levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> without problems.</i>. Even if the second one died? Does this not follow Rebbi Simeon? But Rebbi Simeon frees the second [sister] from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>. The second sister should be able to marry outside the family without any formality.</i>! Rebbi Ze‘ira said, I confirmed this: Any sister-in-law who was to be freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> will never be permitted without <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Since both sisters did require <i>ḥalîṣah</i> when they became widows, the intervening incomplete action by one of the brothers cannot remove that requirement.</i>.
If the first [sister] had a co-wife, one [of the brothers] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the co-wife is freed. If then he had intercourse with her<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The sister who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>, this is forbidden intercourse and the co-wife is not freed<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Even for R. Simeon.</i>. If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and then had intercourse with her, as you look at it, either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> should free or intercourse should free<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ḥalîṣah</i> was valid, then the intercourse is sinful but otherwise without consequence; if <i>ḥalîṣah</i> was not valid, then the intercourse makes the sister a wife and the co-wife is automatically freed.</i>! Rebbi Yudan said, I confirmed it following “If somebody married his sister-in-law and she turns out to be pregnant<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.1">Mishnah 4:2</a>.</i>”, as you say there, the co-wife should not marry until she knows by which means she is permitted, whether through the fetus or through intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement appears in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.1.2-6">Halakhah 4:1</a>. The only parallel is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta 6:3</a>: If somebody “bespeaks” his sister-in-law and she turns out to have been pregnant (from the deceased husband), her co-wife should not marry until it will be known that the fetus has developed into a viable child since no child frees unless it came into the air. That version must be Babylonian since it does not support R. Yudan.</i>; so here also the co-wife should not marry until she knows by which means she is permitted, whether through <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or through intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">That would require the decision of a court of law.</i>.
If the first [sister] had a co-wife, he can marry the co-wife, keep his wife, but the second [sister] is forbidden to him<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This still refers to the case of the Mishnah where the first brother performed levirate with the first sister but the second brother did nothing with respect to the second sister.</i>. That is “the sister of the co-wife of one for whom he performed <i>ḥalîah</i> is permitted to a person.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.7.1">Mishnah 4:7</a>: “The relative of the co-wife of one for whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>”.</i>” Should the co-wife not be forbidden to him as co-wife of the sister<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">In ms. A: “relative”, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.3.3">Note 50</a>.</i> of one for whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? Rebbi Yudan said, if he wanted to have intercourse with the co-wife before he married<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Take her in levirate. This would be the easiest solution since then the second sister is eliminated as co-wife of one married in levirate and the first sister is permitted to the remaining brother.</i>, would he not have been permitted? At the start, he is permitted; at the end, he is prohibited? If you say so, you are making a co-wife after death<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">By treating candidacy as equivalent of marriage, the co-wife of the second sister would become co-wife of the first, an impossible proposition.</i> and there can be no co-wife after death.
If there were five brothers of whom three married three sisters and died<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">All childless. The text here and the parallel one in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 26b" href="/Yevamot.26b">Babli, 26b</a>, are totally incompatible (as noted by Rashba, חידוּשי יבמוֹת, מוֹסד הרב קוק, ירוּשלים תשמט, ע׳ קסז) since the Babli attributes to Rav the statement given here to Samuel and then bases everything on candidacy which has been proven to be irrelevant (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.4">Note 19</a>).</i>: Rav said, each one [of the remaining brothers] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for one of them, and the third [sister] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with whom she wants<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">As explained here, Rav holds that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisition, i. e., it is as if the brother had married the sister-in-law and immediately divorced her. The third sister should be freed automatically were it not for the argument that no obligation of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> can vanish into thin air.</i>. Samuel says, each one [of the remaining brothers] performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for one of them, and the third performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel holds that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing; the third sister has to obtain <i>ḥalîṣah</i> from both brothers since she is equally forbidden to both of them. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 26b" href="/Yevamot.26b">Babli (26b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 51b" href="/Yevamot.51b">51b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 53a" href="/Yevamot.53a">53a</a>) states that an impossible <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, like that of the third sister, necessitates <i>ḥalîṣah</i> from all brothers.
