This is not found in the Yerushalmi.</i>. Rav said that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisition. Samuel said that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. Rebbi Ze‘ira said that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisition. Rebbi Hila said that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. <sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph was explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.19">Chapter 1, Notes 89–91</a>.</i> The words of the rabbis mean that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. Simeon bar Abba asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: What is the difference between having <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and divorcing? He said to him: You think that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, but it is only freeing. The brothers are not guilty for her under the category of “wife of the one acting in <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but they are guilty under the category of “wife of the deceased”. Levi said, candidacy is acquisition and each [sister] has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with both [brothers]<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Levi holds that each sister became a forbidden quasi-wife of each of the surviving brothers at the death of each husband and therefore needs freeing from each of them. This statement is not discussed since its premiss had been rejected.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is missing in ms. A and in the text reproduced by Rashba (Note 55).</i> A Mishnah disagrees with Samuel: <sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.7.1">Mishnah 4:7</a>.</i>“If somebody performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law, her relatives are forbidden to him and his relatives are forbidden to her.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">All relatives of his wife forbidden to a husband are forbidden to the levir who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Therefore, it seems that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> turns the widow into an ex-wife.</i>” There is a difference here, since he already is available to free himself from her<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is unintelligible and none of the commentators has an acceptable explanation. The only sensible way is to translate שכבר נראה not in the singular, “since he already is available”, but “since they (both brothers) are available” and neither has an advantage over the other as participant in <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. The question raised by the text is not answered since the prohibition is clearly rabbinic and independent of the nature of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav: <sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.8.1">Mishnah 4:8</a>. The widow is biblically permitted to her levir but rabbinically forbidden; therefore, she needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. If <i>ḥalîṣah</i> were acquisition, she would be freed without ceremony.</i>“If somebody performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law, then his brother marries her sister and dies, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate.” This supports him who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. But according to him who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, is there anybody who wants to acquire two sisters together<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Since everybody knows that one cannot be married to two sisters simultaneously.</i>? Explain it, after her<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">If the first sister died, the second one is permited. Then one does not understand why she cannot have levirate.</i> death. Is there no levirate after death? Explain it following Rebbi Eleazar, since Rebbi Eleazar said, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">If the first widow was alive when the second husband died, the second widow cannot have levirate. If then the first widow died, the situation is not changed for R. Eleazar.</i>. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav: <sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.5.1">Mishnah 3:5</a>.</i>“Three brothers, two of them are married to two sisters and the third is free. One of the sisters’ husbands died, the free [brother] “bespoke” her, then the second brother died. The House of Shammai say, his wife is with him<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Shammai hold that “bespeaking” acquires like a betrothal; parallel the opinion of R. Eleazar ben Arakh (Halakhah 5, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.2-10">Halakhah 1</a>). Therefore, the first widow is his wife; the second is forbidden to him biblically and leaves the family without formality.</i> and the other one should leave as the wife’s sister. The House of Hillel say, he divorces his wife with a bill of divorce (and <i>ḥalîṣah</i>), and his wife’s sister with <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Hillel hold that “bespeaking” is purely rabbinical and that the only legal consequence of “bespeaking” is to forbid the sister-in-law to the other brothers. Therefore, now the “bespoken” and the new widow have conflicting claims on him; he has to give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to both of them and in addition a rabbinic bill of divorce for the rabbinic betrothal to the first widow.</i>. This supports him who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is (acquisiton) [freeing]<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that one must read פטור instead of קיניין. The next sentence is missing in ms. L; it is clear that the scribe of ms. L already had the error before him since ms. A also reproduces it. The sentence in brackets is only in ms. A, it is missing in ms. L since its scribe left out a sentence from קיניין to קיניין. It is unlikely that the insertion in A is a deliberate correction.</i>. But according to him who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, is there anybody who wants to acquire two sisters together? Explain it, after her death. Is there no levirate after death? Explain it following Rebbi Eleazar, since Rebbi Eleazar said, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav: <sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.9.1">Mishnah 4:9</a>, explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.3">Notes 7–9</a>.</i>“If a brother gives <i>qiddushin</i> to the sister of a woman waiting for the levir, they said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra: One says to him, wait until your brother has acted. If one of the brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or married her, he may marry his wife. If the sister-in-law died, he may marry his wife. If the levir died, he has to remove his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s widow by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.”. This supports him who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. But according to him who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, is there anybody who wants to acquire two sisters together? Explain it following Rebbi Eleazar, since Rebbi Eleazar said, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav: <sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.4.1">Mishnah 6:4</a>. The High Priest may marry only a virgin. The verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>) reads: “A widow, a divorcee, a harlot, and a desecrated one he shall not acquire …”. Since marriage is formulated in terms of acquisition, if <i>ḥalîṣah</i> were acquisition, the widow of the High Priest’s brother either should be free without <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or never could be freed.</i>“If a brother of the High Priest dies, he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.” This supports him who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. But according to him who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, does one say to him, transgress the words of the Torah? Rebbi Ḥama, the colleague of the rabbis, objected: Does not a Mishnah disagree with Rav? <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>. The second widow has to have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if the first widow did. If the first was married in levirate, the second goes free without ceremony.</i>“Three brothers, two of them married to two sisters or a woman and her daughter or a woman and her daughter’s or her son’s daughter. These perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.” There is a difference since the prohibition of a woman and her daughter applies both when she is alive as also after her death. These last two disagree with Rav and one cannot explain them away.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one of them was forbidden to one of them by an incest prohibition, that one is forbidden for him but her sister is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Since one of the sisters is not available to him, the other is not the sister of a candidate for levirate. If they both become candidates at the same time (or at least before the other brother had married one in levirate), they both are sisters of a candidate and therefore forbidden to the second brother.</i>. Both are forbidden to the second [brother]. In case of a commandment prohibition or a holiness prohibition, they have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>. Since a marriage would not be void, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is necessary.</i>. If one of [the sisters] was forbidden to that one [brother] by an incest prohition and the other [sister] was forbidden to the [other brother] by an incest prohition, the one who is forbidden for one might be permitted to the other and vice-versa. That is what they said, “Her sister who is her sister-in-law can have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or be married in levirate.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If one of them was forbidden,” etc. If a man raped a woman and she had a daughter who married one of his brothers while [the daughter’s] half-sister from another man is married to a second brother: When they died without children, his daughter is forbidden to him but her sister is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is not his wife’s daughter.</i>. This exemplifies: “Her sister who is her sister-in-law can be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">That case never can happen if he is married to the mother of the girl (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28b" href="/Yevamot.28b">Babli 28b</a>). All these rules are valid only for cases which probably never occur.</i>.”
“If one of them was forbidden,” etc. If one of them raped a woman and she had a daughter, [the woman] in turn was raped by his brother and also had a daughter and both [daughters] married [these]brothers who were paternal but not maternal halfbrothers: Each one of them is forbidden his own daughter but permitted her sister. That exemplifies: The one forbidden for one is permitted to the other and vice-versa<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">That case never can happen if he is married to the mother of the girl (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28b" href="/Yevamot.28b">Babli 28b</a>). All these rules are valid only for cases which probably never occur.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>. The second widow has to have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if the first widow did. If the first was married in levirate, the second goes free without ceremony.</i> Three brothers, two of them married to two sisters or a woman and her daughter or a woman and her daughter’s or her son’s daughter: These perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate, but Rebbi Simeon frees them<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">If both women become widows before one of them is married in levirate or performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.<br>According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28b-29a" href="/Yevamot.28b-29a">Babli, 28b–29a</a>, R. Simeon reads <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>: “Do not take a wife together with her sister to tie into one bundle” that the common candidacy of a woman and her sister destroys both candidacies so that even the one who was widowed first would be freed by her sister. This is not the position of the Yerushalmi which holds that the candidacy of the first widow excludes the second from candidacy, as explained in the Halakhah.</i>. If one of them was forbidden to one of them by an incest prohibition, that one is forbidden for him but her sister is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Since one of the sisters is not available to him, the other is not the sister of a candidate for levirate. If they both become candidates at the same time (or at least before the other brother had married one in levirate), they both are sisters of a candidate and therefore forbidden to the second brother.</i>. In case of a commandment prohibition or a holiness prohibition, they have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.1">Mishnah 3:4</a>. Since a marriage would not be void, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is necessary.</i>. But Rebbi Simeon frees them<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is not in the Mishnah of the Babli; the Babli holds that in this case, R. Simeon agrees with the majority.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Three brothers, two of them married to two sisters,” etc. Ulla bar Ismael said, so explained Rebbi Hoshaia, the father of the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, he and the elder R. Ḥiyya are given as the source of reliable <i>baraitot</i>.</i>: Rebbi Simeon frees the second one from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">If both women become widows before one of them is married in levirate or performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.<br>According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28b-29a" href="/Yevamot.28b-29a">Babli, 28b–29a</a>, R. Simeon reads <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>: “Do not take a wife together with her sister to tie into one bundle” that the common candidacy of a woman and her sister destroys both candidacies so that even the one who was widowed first would be freed by her sister. This is not the position of the Yerushalmi which holds that the candidacy of the first widow excludes the second from candidacy, as explained in the Halakhah.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the group asked, would anybody think that a man could acquire two sisters together<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">They held that any <i>ḥalîṣah</i> mentioned in the Mishnah is only rabbinic (a view also held in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 28b-29a" href="/Yevamot.28b-29a">Babli, 28b/29a</a>). Since nobody assumes that anyone might contract incestuous marriages, that rabbinic institution seems superfluous.</i>? Rebbi Ḥanina said before Rebbi Mana and disagreed: Why does Rebbi Simeon free the second one from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate? He said to him, because nobody thinks that a man could acquire two sisters together. There they said, the words of Rebbi Simeon imply that no candidacy can come after another candidacy<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This statement, attributed to Babylonian sources, is not found in the Babli. Here it is referred to as “the opinion of the rabbis” in the interpretation of R. Simeon.</i>. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Only if he sinned and had intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar holds that R. Simeon considers candidacy only as tentative (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.2.4">Chapter 2, Note 47</a>). Therefore, the second widow is freed only if the first becomes unquestionably the wife of the third brother; this she can become only by having intercourse which under the circumstances is sinful.</i>. What is the difference? If somebody from the market gave <i>qiddushin</i> to the second sister. Following the rabbis, perfect <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Since the second widow leaves the family without ceremony.</i>. Following Rebbi Eleazar, suspended <i>qiddushin.</i> When he<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The third brother.</i> has intercourse with the first, the <i>qiddushin</i> become valid for the second. If he had intercourse with the second, following the rabbis it is an incestuous act. Following Rebbi Eleazar, it is not an incestuous act<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">At least not an act which certainly would be incestuous.</i>. If the first one died, following the rabbis the second is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">To the third brother, but only in the case of two sisters.</i>.
If the first [sister] had a co-wife, he can marry the co-wife, keep his wife, but the second [sister] is forbidden to him<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This still refers to the case of the Mishnah where the first brother performed levirate with the first sister but the second brother did nothing with respect to the second sister.</i>. That is “the sister of the co-wife of one with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is permitted to a person.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.7.1">Mishnah 4:7</a>: “The relative of the co-wife of one for whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>”.</i>” Should the co-wife not be forbidden to him as co-wife of a relative of one with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? Rebbi Yudan said, if he wanted to have intercourse with the co-wife before he married<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Take her in levirate. This would be the easiest solution since then the second sister is eliminated as co-wife of one married in levirate and the first sister is permitted to the remaining brother.</i>, would he not have been permitted? At the start, he is permitted; at the end, he is prohibited? If you say so, you are creating a co-wife after death<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">By treating candidacy as equivalent of marriage, the co-wife of the second sister would become co-wife of the first, an impossible proposition.</i> and there can be no co-wife after death.
The argument of Rebbi Simeon seems to be inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.1">Mishnah 3:10</a> where R. Simeon completely disregards “bespeaking” while here he even considers candidacy as obstacle.</i>, he says, “he marries in levirate the one he wants and performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other,” and here, he says so? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, when I was still there<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 31b" href="/Yevamot.31b">Babli, 31b</a>, this argument is labelled rabbinic, not biblical.</i>, I learned the reason: There, the candidacy for two brothers-in-law does not interfere and one candidacy can be added to another, but here it is candidacy for one levir and no candidacy can come after a “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">A comparison with the earlier quote (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.3.2">Note 85</a>) shows that candidacy and “bespeaking” are put on one and the same level.</i>. Rebbi Mattania said, are not sisters different from unrelated women? If you want a difficulty, find it in what Rebbi Ze‘ira said in the name of RavSheshet: They stated there that Rebbi Simeon forbade both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.2.4">Halakhah 2:2, Note 47</a>. In that case, Rebbi Simeon accepts “bespeaking” as marriage.</i>. The argument of Rebbi Simeon seems to be inverted. There he says, both are forbidden, and here<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.1">Mishnah 3:10</a> where R. Simeon completely disregards “bespeaking” while here he even considers candidacy as obstacle.</i> you says, both are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">No answer is given since the earlier explanation of R. Ze‘ira is also valid here.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three brothers, two of whom are married to two sisters and the third is a bachelor. One of the sisters’ husbands died; the bachelor “bespoke” her; then the second brother died. The House of Shammai say, his wife is with him<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Shammai hold that “bespeaking” acquires like a betrothal; parallel the opinion of R. Eleazar ben Arakh (Halakhah 5, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.2-10">Halakhah 1</a>). Therefore, the first widow is his wife; the second is forbidden to him biblically and leaves the family without formality.</i> and the other one should leave as the wife’s sister. The House of Hillel say, he divorces his wife with a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The word is missing in the Mishnah and is deleted in ms. L by the corrector; therefore it is missing in the <i>editio princeps</i>. It is found in ms. A. From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:3:2-4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.3.2-4.3">Halakhah 3:4</a> it is clear that the word was omitted from the Mishnah by a scribal error (cf. א. שכטר, המשנה בבבלי וּבירושלמי, מוֹסד הרב קוּק, י-ם תשיט) and was wrongly eliminated from the text.</i>, and his wife’s sister with <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Hillel hold that “bespeaking” is purely rabbinical and that the only legal consequence of “bespeaking” is to forbid the sister-in-law to the other brothers. Therefore, now the “bespoken” and the new widow have conflicting claims on him; he has to give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to both of them and in addition a rabbinic bill of divorce for the rabbinic betrothal to the first widow.</i>. That is what people say, he is unlucky with his wife and with his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">A popular saying about somebody who loses everything without having done anything wrong.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Three brothers, two of whom are married to two sisters,” etc. Do the House of Shammai follow Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The positions of Rebbis Eleazar ben Arakh and Simeon are explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.2">Halakhah 2:1, Notes 10–13</a>; their agreement is asserted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 29b" href="/Yevamot.29b">Babli, 29b</a>.</i>, since Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh says, “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely? If they would follow Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh, in case he had divorced the “bespoken” widow, she would not need <i>ḥalîṣah</i>! But Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora, who lived about 150 years after the disappearance of the House of Shammai. His opinion is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 29a" href="/Yevamot.29a">Babli, 29a</a>.</i>, the House of Shammai agree that if he divorced the “bespoken”, she needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>! It must be they follow Rebbi Simeon, since Rebbi Simeon says, “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire. If they would follow Rebbi Simeon, in any case, if “bespeaking” acquires, nothing follows it<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">She is his wife as if there were <i>qiddushin</i>; there is no question that the sister is free without ceremony.</i>. If “bespeaking” does not acquire, why “his wife is with him and the other one should leave as the wife’s sister”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">They would have to agree to the position of the House of Hillel.</i>? Maybe “bespeaking” for the House of Shammai is like candidacy for Rebbi Simeon in the interpretation of the rabbis there. As the rabbis there<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.2.4">Chapter 2, Note 47</a> ff.</i> say, “bespeaking” acquires and leaves a remainder, so Rebbi Simeon says, [candidacy] acquires and leaves a remainder. Rebbi Simeon says, no candidacy can come after a candidacy, so the House of Shammai say here, no candidacy can come after a “bespeaking”.
Rebbi Yudan asked: If somebody gave <i>qiddushin</i> to a woman “from now and after thirty days”<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:1</a>. If somebody gives something of value to a woman and says, “be betrothed to me after thirty days”, if another man comes in the meantime and gives her <i>qiddushin</i>, she is the wife of the second man and after 30 days, when she should become the wife of the first, she already is married and betrothal with a married man is void. But if the first had said, “from now after thirty days”, he reserved his rights to her from the moment of the transaction but she becomes his wife in civil and criminal law only after 30 days. If anybody else gives her <i>qiddushin</i> in that period, she is tentatively betrothed to both of them and both have to divorce her.</i> and her sister became a candidate for levirate with him during these thirty days, is even in this “his wife with him and the other one should leave as the wife’s sister”<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Following the House of Shammai.</i>? He said, the House of Shammai said that only after candidacy and “bespeaking”. But that what Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, even a hundred <i>qiddushin</i> are valid for her<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 60a" href="/Kiddushin.60a">Babli <i>Qiddušin</i> 60a</a>, Yerushalmi <i>Qiddušin</i> fol. 63c, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:1:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.1.2-13">3:1</a>. It is a little difficult to accomodate 100 <i>qiddushin</i>. The general idea is that the first man says, from now in 30 days, the next day another says, from now in 29 days, etc.</i>, does not follow the House of Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Since the House of Shammai hold that “bespeaking”, which is a very weak imitation of <i>qiddushin</i>, suffices to make the woman a wife in relation to female competitors, they should hold that <i>qiddushin</i> “from now to 30 days” also are enough to eliminate male competitors.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Of three brothers, two are married to two sisters and one to an unrelated woman. One of the sisters’ husbands died, the husband of the unrelated married his widow, and died. [The dead brother’s] second [wife] leaves as his wife’s sister, the first one as her co-wife. If he had “bespoken” her, the unrelated woman performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Of three brothers, two are married to two sisters,” etc. Both the rabbis and Rebbi Simeon will agree in this case. For the rabbis, the part of the co-wife parallel to that which “bespeaking” acquired [in the widow] is forbidden. Also, the part of the co-wife parallel to that which “bespeaking” did not acquire [in the widow] is [still] forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Since no woman can be the wife of two men; since she cannot have partial levirate, she cannot have levirate at all.<br>In this Mishnah and the next, the only question is why the unrelated woman has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. These Mishnaiot require the third brother to be married.</i>. Therefore, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate. Following Rebbi Simeon, if “bespeaking” acquires, both are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">To marry outside the family without formalities.</i>. If “bespeaking” does not acquire, the first is forbidden but the second permitted. Because of the doubt, she<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The first, unrelated, wife is forbidden for outsiders without <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. {The Mishnah in the Babli switches the places of “first” and “second” in the Mishnah; students of the Babli consider this paragraph corrupt.}</i> performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Of three brothers, two are married to two sisters and one to an unrelated woman. The husband of the unrelated died, one of the sisters’ husbands married his widow, and died. His first [wife] leaves as his wife’s sister, the second one as her co-wife. If he had “bespoken” her, the unrelated woman performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Of three brothers, two are married to two sisters,” etc. Both the rabbis and Rebbi Simeon will agree in this case.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three brothers, two of them are married to two sisters and one to an unrelated woman. One of the sisters’ husbands died, the husband of the unrelated married his widow, the wife of the secondbrother died and then the husband of the unrelated died. She<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The widow of the first brother is forbidden to the second even though in general the deceased wife’s sister is permitted to her husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>). The reason is that when her first husband died, she was forbidden to the second brother as sister of his wife and, as will be explained later, any brother who cannot “build his brother’s house” at the first opportunity can never build after that.</i> is permanently forbidden to him<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The only surviving brother.</i> since she was forbidden one moment.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Of three brothers,” etc. Rebbi Avina said, that is what Rebbi Yose said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The prohibition of sisters who are sisters-in-law does not compare with the prohibition of sisters who not are sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">These are always permitted to the widower of the sister.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Of three brothers, two are married to two sisters and one to an unrelated woman. If one of the sisters’ husbands divorced his wife, when the one married to an unrelated woman died and the divorcer married her<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">The unrelated woman, now his brother’s widow.</i> and then died, that is what they said: Of all of these, if they died, or repudiated, or were divorced, or turned out to be she-rams, the co-wives are permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">If at the moment of the husband’s death there is no impediment to levirate, anything that happened before is unimportant. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25">Chapter 1, Note 115</a>.<br>In the Babli and most Mishnah mss., the text is short “if they died or were divorced” as in the quote in the Halakhah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Of three brothers,” etc. Rebbi Ḥaggai said in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira, not only if he divorced and after that married, but even if he married and after that divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 30" href="/Yevamot.30">Babli, 30a/b</a>, considers this only as a possibilty, to be disregarded. That Talmud requires that the two women never were potential co-wives, i. e., if the first brother divorced his wife only after the third brother had died and the unrelated woman was a potential co-wife of the first’s wife, she is permanently forbidden to the second brother.</i>. That is what we had stated: “Of all of these, if they died or were divorced, their co-wives are permitted.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">A shortened version, possibly due to Babylonian influence, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.8.1">Note 114</a>.</i>”
Rebbi Yudan said, even Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Who holds in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Halakhah 1 (Note 10</a>) that a prohibition remains even if its cause has disappeared.</i> agrees. Rebbi Yose said, that is correct. Because, if somebody had children but they died before he died, is his widow not a candidate for levirate? There, if he had children at the moment of death. Here, if they were co-wives after his death<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Only the status at the moment of the husband’s death counts in matters of levirate. Everybody reads in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>: “one of them died while he left no child.” Only the status at the moment of death counts; the prior history is irrelevant.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In all cases<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">If the relationship with any one of the 15 categories of prohibited women enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a> was predicated on a marriage whose validity or dissolution was questionable, the co-wife cannot automatically be freed since the relationship might be nonexistent but she cannot have levirate since the relationship might be valid.</i> in which there were questionable <i>qiddushin</i> or divorces, the [co-wives] must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate. What are questionable <i>qiddushin</i>? If he threw the betrothal gift to her and there is a doubt whether it fell closer to him or to her, that are questionable <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Qiddushin</i> have two parts: Delivery of a gift to the prospective bride and a declaration by the groom that the gift is intended to make the woman his bride. If a person stands in the public domain, it is assumed that any object within a circle of radius of 4 cubits with her in the center is acquired by that person upon expression of her will to receive that object. If now both stand in the public domain exactly 8 cubits apart and he throws the gift to her in the presence of two witnesses and it lands in the middle, it is impossible to determine up to the last micron whether most of it landed within her domain. {If both stand on his property, the gift must be properly delivered; if on her property, her property will acquire for her if she wants it. If they are more than 8 cubits apart and the gift is not completely inside her circle of acquisition, there are no <i>qiddushin</i>.}<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 5:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).5.7">Tosephta, 5:7</a>, <i>qiddushin</i> are questionable because it was not established that the gift had the monetary value of at least a <i>peruṭa</i>.</i>. What is a questionable divorce? If [the divorce document] was written in his handwriting but without witnesses, or there are witnesses but no date, or there is a date but only one witness, these are questionable divorces<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">These are all cases of illegal divorces which can be validated only in urgent cases (if the woman remarried on the basis of the document and is now pregnant.)</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Halakhah is copied in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.3.2-4"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:2</a>.</i>“In all cases in which there were questionable <i>qiddushin</i> or divorces, the [co-wives] must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot have levirate,” etc. There really is no questionable divorce here<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">As noted, the divorce documents are formally defective but can be validated in hardship cases. Therefore, if the forbidden woman has remarried based on such a document and now has children from another man, there is no reason why <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.8.1">Mishnah 8</a> should not be invoked by the former co-wife. Therefore, for matters of levirate such a divorce is valid under all circumstances. The corresponding text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.3.2-4"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:2</a> (fol. 50b) reads: “There really is no questionable divorce but a real divorce.” See the next paragraph.</i>. What are questionable <i>qiddushin</i>? If he threw the betrothal gift to her and there is a doubt whether it fell closer to him or to her, that are questionable <i>qiddushin</i>. And here, if he threw the divorce document to her<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">A divorce document can be valid by biblical standards only when delivered to the woman (or her duly appointed representative), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1"><i>Deut</i>. 24:1</a>. This is a condition which cannot be waived.</i> and there is a doubt whether it fell closer to him or to her, that is a questionable divorce.
Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Ḥalaphta from Haifa<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The place name is corrupt in most sources. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 86" href="/Gittin.86">Babli, <i>Giṭṭin</i> 86 b</a>, the statement appears in very abbreviated form.</i>: Any who were married on the basis of such a document should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Her marriage based on the flawed document should not be terminated to avoid tainting her children from the second husband as bastards.</i> in order not to give a bad reputation to her children. His daughter who was married outside on the basis of such a document should not leave in order to damage her co-wife to her father<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">If his daughter was married to his brother and divorced by one of these questionable documents, if later her ex-husband dies childless, her co-wife is permitted to her father in levirate. If the rabbinical establishment would force the termination of a second marriage, the co-wife would have to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> as possible co-wife of his daughter.</i>. Her co-wife who was married outside on the basis of such a document has to leave<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">If his daughter was married to his brother and divorced by one of these questionable documents, if later her ex-husband dies childless, her former co-wife is permitted to her father and any outside marriage she contracts without <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is null and void.</i>. His daughter who married his brother on the basis of such a document has to leave<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">If his daughter was married to his brother and divorced by one of these questionable documents, if later her ex-husband dies childless, any marriage of this daughter to one of the other paternal uncles is incestuous.</i>. Her co-wife who was married to his brother on the basis of such a document, or even to her father, should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">If his daughter was married to his brother and divorced by one of these questionable documents, if later her ex-husband dies childless, her co-wife is permitted to her father in levirate. If the rabbinical establishment would force the termination of a second marriage, the co-wife would have to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> as possible co-wife of his daughter.</i>.
It was stated: [A claim based on] any of these three types of documents<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">A bill of debt executed in the manner of any of the three types of bills of divorce declared questionable in the Mishnah. In talmudic practice, mortgages were usually not executed for specified pieces of real estate but were liens on all real estate of the debtor (in his possession at the date of the document) to be satisfied in the order of execution (except for the money due to a wife at the dissolution of a marriage by divorce or death of the husband, which always takes precedence). Therefore, the date of a bill of debt determines its rank as a mortgage.<br>The problem is touched on very lightly in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 176a" href="/Bava_Batra.176a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 176a</a>.</i> can be collected only from unincumbered property<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Real estate acquired after any other bill of debt was executed.</i>, not from mortgaged property. Rebbi Abba said, that means, if the document in the hand of the lender has not been confirmed. But if the document in the hand of the lender has been confirmed, he may collect<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">No mortgage can be foreclosed unless the document and its signatures have been found to be genuine by a competent court.</i>. Rebbi Yose asked: If the document in the hand of the lender has not been confirmed, he should not be able to collect even from unincumbered property! But one must deal with a document confirmed in the hand of the lender. And why can he not collect? Rebbi Bisna said, because of action in partnership<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοινωνία, used by LXX as translation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:21" href="/Leviticus.5.21"><i>Lev</i>. 5:21</a>) of Hebrew תְשׂוּמֶת יָד, derived from the verb κοινωνέω, one of whose meanings is “to act in partnership”. In talmudic literature, the word always has a pejorative meaning, “a criminal conspiracy”. The lender and the borrower might conspire to defraud an earlier mortgage holder by predating the document. A sale of real estate cannot invalidate mortgage liens executed before the time of the sale. The lender and the borrower might also conspire to defraud any buyer of unincumbered real estate by pretending that the later loan predates the earlier sale. Since they would not find witnesses in good standing to sign a predated document (and to testify before a court), they take their chance with an undated bill in the borrower’s hand.</i>. Rebbi Abun said, because it is invalid. So far, if the old man took the loan and [later] the old man mortgaged<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">There might be a conspiracy if the borrower and the writer of the bill of debt are one and the same person. But if the borrower was the parent and the writer an heir, the <i>baraita</i> should have validated the document in this exceptional case just as the defective divorce document is validated in an exceptional case.</i>. But if the old man took the loan and [later] the son mortgaged, can you say because of a conspiracy? No, because it is invalid. And here, because it is invalid. Rebbi Abun said, and was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted in slightly different form in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 176a" href="/Bava_Batra.176a">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 176a</a>. This is all part of R. Abun’s argument.</i>: The same holds for bills of divorce. Can you say there, because of action in partnership? No, because it is invalid. And here<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of a bill of debt.</i>, because it is invalid.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three brothers are married to three unrelated women. If one of them died, his second brother “bespeaks” her and then dies, these<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The two widows who now are candidates for levirate with the third brother. If the second brother had not “bespoken” the first widow, he would have been free to marry both of the widows. Now that the first widow is quasi-married to the second brother, she cannot be married by the third brother; therefore the quasi-co-wife also is barred. But since the first widow is only partially forbidden, both require <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i> perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate, as it is said: “Her levir shall come to her<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. The Mishnah in the Babli and most Mishnah mss. also quote the beginning of the verse: “If brothers live together and <i>one</i> of them dies, …”</i>,” if on her is the candidacy from one brother but not from two. Rebbi Simeon says, he takes in levirate the one he prefers and performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Simeon holds that bespeaking either acquires completely or not at all (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.2-6">Halakhah 2:1</a>). If it acquires completely, both widows are widows of the second brother, and the influence of the first is eliminated; the third may marry one in levirate and then the other would be freed without ceremony. If “bespeaking” does not acquire, the two women are widows of different brothers and both are permitted to the third in levirate. Because of the doubt, the third can marry only one of the widows and has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Three brothers married to three women,” etc. Can a woman waiting for a levir who became available to several brothers-in-law not be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse also speak of the levir in the singular, one might infer that the laws of levirate apply only to a single levir. But this is certainly not the case.</i>? Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: The wife of one [dead husband] is married in levirate, not the wife of two dead<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The two widows who now are candidates for levirate with the third brother. If the second brother had not “bespoken” the first widow, he would have been free to marry both of the widows. Now that the first widow is quasi-married to the second brother, she cannot be married by the third brother; therefore the quasi-co-wife also is barred. But since the first widow is only partially forbidden, both require <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. One understands that he has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the “bespoken” because the wife of one [dead husband] is married in levirate, not the wife of two dead. Why can the other one not be married in levirate? Rebbi Eleazar said, this follows Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr said, of any one you cannot marry in levirate, you cannot marry the co-wife in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25">Chapter 1, cf. Note 116</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if Rebbi Eleazar formulated this, he formulated what he had heard from me<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:1:16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.1.16">Berakhot 2, Note 53</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, a Mishnah said so: “<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.1">Mishnah 10:9</a>.<br>The sex act of a minor less than 9 years old has no legal consequences. If the boy is at 9 years and one day old, his sex act counts (if a married woman sleeps with him, she is criminally liable for adultery but he is not responsible since he is a minor.) A minor cannot acquire in general; therefore, his sex act corresponds to “bespeaking” for adults and the disagreement between the rabbis and Rebbi Simeon about the legal consequences of “bespeaking” extends to those of the sex act by a minor close to puberty.</i> A boy at least nine years and one day old who had intercourse with his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Widow of an older brother who had died childless.</i> and when he grew up he married another wife; if he never had intercourse with the first again after he became an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">For the rabbis, she is partially his wife; for R. Simeon, she either is his wife or she is not his wife.</i>, the second [wife] may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or be married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">With a third brother, if the second brother also dies childless.</i>. The first one must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and cannot be married in levirate.” Here you say, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; there you say, she is married in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.1">Mishnah 3:10</a>, neither woman can be married. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.1">Mishnah 10:9</a>, one of them can be married even though the legal situation is the same!</i>! Where you say she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Simeon; where you say, she is married in levirate, Rebbi Simeon and the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">In both Mishnaiot, R. Simeon holds that the third brother may marry one of the widows without restriction. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.1">Mishnah 3:10</a>, the anonymous Tanna is Rebbi Meïr; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.1">Mishnah 10:9</a> he is another Tanna who admits the possibility that only one of the widows may be a candidate for levirate. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 5:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).5.7">Tosephta 5:7</a>, R. Yose (ben Ḥalaphta) holds that in the situation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.1">Mishnah 3:10</a>, the second widow may be married, parallel to the opinion of the Tanna of 10:9.</i>. Rebbi Abun bar Bisna in the name of Rebbi Aḥa, but only if first he<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The third brother. In the Tosephta, this is a tannaitic statement attributed to R. Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon, following his father’s doctrine. The <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one of the widows frees the other; the marriage of the second has no influence on the status of the first.</i> married in levirate and then performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But if he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> first, it is forbidden; perhaps “bespeaking” acquired and she was freed by her co-wife’s <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two brothers are married to two sisters. If one of them died and then the wife of the other died, she<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">The wife of the first brother who had died childless. Since at the time of death of the first the wife of the second was alive, there could not have been any levirate. If levirate is forbidden at the time of death of the husband, it is permanently forbidden (since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> both the death of one and the marriage of the other are mentioned.)</i> is eternally forbidden to him since she was forbidden one moment.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two brothers married to two sisters,” etc. Rebbi Avina said, that is what Rebbi Hila, Rebbi Yose, said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The prohibition of sisters who are sisters-in-law does not compare with the prohibition of sisters who not are sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">These are always permitted to the widower of the sister.</i>.

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If two men gave <i>qiddushin</i> to two women and when they entered the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The act of marriage itself which was preceded by a public ceremony and which validates the marriage in terms of civil law. The meaning of “bridal canopy” given today to the word חוּפָּה is comparatively recent, not older than about 1000 years. In terms of criminal law, the couple are married from the time of qiddushin; therefore, the marriage with the wrong wife constitutes adultery.</i> they switched each of them to the other<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Inadvertently, maybe because they never had seen their brides beforehand.</i>, they are guilty of [adultery with] a married woman. If they were brothers, they also are guilty because of [the prohibition of] the brother’s wife. If they were sisters, they are guilty also because of [the prohibition of] “a woman in addition to her sister”. If they were menstruating, they are guilty also because of [the prohibition of] menstruating women<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible to commit 4 deadly sins in one act; this would require 8 purification offerings per pair.</i>. And all of these one separates for three months to see whether they are pregnant. If they were minors not able yet to have children one returns them at once. If they were from priestly families they are disabled for heave<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a> states that the daughter of a Cohen married to a non-Cohen who becomes a widow may return to her family to eat from holy food only is she is “as in her maidenhood”, that she could be married by a Cohen. But a woman who had illicit sex, even as a rape victim, is forbidden to a Cohen.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> If he had intercourse with the second he is two times guilty, for the brother’s wife and for “a woman in addition to her sister”<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The formulation is elliptic. It is asserted (1) that entering the bridal chamber is not sinful, only the intercourse is; (2) that prohibited acts can be added together. The Babli has great difficulties with multiple guilt for one act; that problem is not mentioned in the Yerushalmi except for procedural problems in criminal law.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 5:8-9" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).5.8-9">Tosephta 5:8–9</a>, in a slightly different wording. A very short quote of the Tosephta in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 33b" href="/Yevamot.33b">Babli, 33b</a>.</i>: Sometimes four times, sometimes eight times, sometimes twelve times, sometimes sixteen times<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Since four persons are involved, each transgression implies punishment for four people. The total number of crimes (or purification sacrifices) must be a multiple of four.</i>. They are guilty under the heading of adultery with a married woman, each couple for two. If they were brothers, under the heading of “brother’s wife”, each couple for four. If they were sisters, under the heading of “a wife together with her sister”, each couple six. If they were menstruating, under the heading of “menstruating”, each couple eight. If the men are minors and the women adults, they are free<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">The minors cannot legally marry; it is impossible to commit adultery with their wives.</i>. If the men are adults and the women minors, they are obligated two by two because of menstruation<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Since a minor girl cannot legally marry except if given in marriage by her father, in the absence of a father the only inadvertent crime possible is that of intercourse with a menstruating woman. But if the father married the girls off, they are legally married and all four sins are possible.</i>. If their father married them off, for all eight. If one of the men was an adult and the other a minor, the one who had intercourse with the minor is guilty as wife of the adult but the one who had intercourse with the adult is free as wife of the minor.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: A rape victim does not have to wait three months<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">That statement is tannaitic in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 35a" href="/Yevamot.35a">Babli, 35a</a>, and ascribed to the Tanna R. Yose. R. Jehudah is reported to require separation of a raped wife from her husband for three months. R. Yose, in the interpretation of Abbai, is confident that the rape victim will know how to rid herself of the unwanted semen. That argument seems so obvious to the Yerushalmi that it is not necessary to mention it.</i>. But did we not state: “One separates them for three month to see whether they are pregnant. If they were minors not yet able to have children one returns them at once.” That is different, it is for the benefit of the child<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">If the woman is pregnant from the unintended adultery, the child is a bastard and permitted to marry another bastard. If she were allowed immediately to return to her husband, any child would be a possible bastard and forbidden to marry either a regular person or a bastard.</i>.
“If they were from priestly families they are disabled for heave.” Rebbi Yose said, this implies that rape disables in priestly families like adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.1">Mishnah 6:5</a> quotes the opinion of the anonymous majority that the “harlot” forbidden to a Cohen in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a> is either a libertine or a woman “subject to illegitimate sexual relations” without any consideration of intent. While a non-priestly husband keeps his raped wife, the Cohen is forced to divorce her, even against his will.</i>.

Chapter 4



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law but she turns out to have been pregnant and gives birth, if it is a live birth<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Even though usually וולד של קיימא denotes a child surviving more than 30 days; in case of levirate, Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:3 states that a one-day old baby causes levirate (if the husband died childless one day after a brother was born to him) and frees from levirate (if the pregnant widow gave birth to a live baby). Then her late husband potentially had a child when he died, there can be no levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and, legally, the ceremony never happened.</i> her relatives are permitted to him and his relatives are permitted to her; he has not disabled her [from marrying into] priesthood. If it is a still birth, her relatives are forbidden to him and his relatives are forbidden to her; he has disabled her [from marrying into] priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The ceremony is valid; she is (rabbinically) under all rules of a divorcee from the brother.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law but she turns out to have been pregnant,” etc. If he transgressed, but not from the start<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah is formulated “if it happened”, not that it should be the rule.</i>. That follows the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah 4:11. To ascertain that the widow is not pregnant. Before that time, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is not needed since she could not remarry even if she had children, for the same reason.</i>: “The widow should not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or have levirate until after three months.” Why can she not have <i>ḥalîṣah</i> immediately? As you take it, if she has a live birth, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> did not affect her<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Even though usually וולד של קיימא denotes a child surviving more than 30 days; in case of levirate, Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:3 states that a one day old baby causes levirate (if the husband died childless one day after a brother was born to him) and frees from levirate (if the pregnant widow gave birth to a live baby). Then her late husband potentially had a child when he died, there can be no levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and, legally, the ceremony never happened.</i>. If she has a still birth, she holds <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in her hand. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Ḥiyya, Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, that she should not need a proclamation for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>ḥalîṣah</i> prevents a woman from marrying a priest, an invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> demands public proclamations by the town crier (a herald, Greek κῆρυξ), to make sure people would not think that her children from a Cohen are desecrated. The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 41b" href="/Yevamot.41b">Babli 41b</a>. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 16:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.16.1.2">Chapter 16, Note 11</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Jacob bar Idi, in the name of Rebbi Hoshaiah, that she should not need a proclamation for the priesthood. Rebbi Hoshaiah stated: “My levir refuses<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut</i>. 25:7</a>. As long as the levir is not required to marry her, she cannot claim that he refused. The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 41b" href="/Yevamot.41b">Babli 41b</a>.</i>.” To the one to whom one says: perform levirate, to him one says: perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; but to the one to whom one cannot say: perform levirate, to him one cannot say: perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>! What is the difference between them? If she had been acceptable and was desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">By a marriage contracted in violation of the holiness prohibitions, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14">14</a>.</i>, e. g., a widow for the High Priest or a divorcee or one who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a common priest. According to him who says that she should not need a proclamation for the priesthood; that one, who does not need a proclamation for the priesthood, should have <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. According to him who says that to the one to whom one says: perform levirate, to him does one say: perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>?<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The answer, that still even a desecrated woman cannot remarry for 90 days after her husband’s death, is missing. This is either a scribal omission or it is assumed that everybody will be able to supply the rest of the argument.</i>
If there was <i>ḥalîṣah</i> during these three months, does she need another one after three months? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:4:1-5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.4.1-5.2">Mishnah 12:5</a>.</i>: “A minor who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> should perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after she grows up; if she performed [only one] <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> she performed is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In a plurality of mss. of the Babylonian Mishnah, “not valid”. A minor cannot perform acts that are legally valid, but the essence of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is the declaration of the levir, by necessity an adult, that he refuses to marry the widow.</i>.” Rebbi Mana said it anonymously, Rebbi Isaac the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya brought it in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel in Chapter 12, R. Jonah instead of R. Joḥanan.</i>; this is Rebbi Meïr‘s, since Rebbi Meïr says one does neither perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nor levirate with a minor: maybe she would turn out to be a she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">R. Meïr is known in many cases to require attention to possibilities that are seldom realities. For a she-ram, levirate is forbidden and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> unnecessary. The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 19b" href="/Bekhorot.19b">Babli <i>Bekhorot</i> 19b</a>; a detailed discussion in Tosaphot <i>ad. loc., s. v</i>. איש.</i>. As you say there, even though she already performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, she again performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; so here also though she did perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">If <i>ḥalîṣah</i> was performed early, against the rules, it has to be performed again after the three months have passed but, in case this was not done, the first <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid.</i>.
Rebbi Yudan asked: If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a pregnant woman and she had a miscarriage<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Is the procedure valid if intended as a precaution in case the woman had a miscarriage?</i>? Let us hear from the following: If somebody died and left a pregnant widow, should I think that she must have recourse to her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">At the moment of death, the husband was childless.</i>? The verse says, “that his name should not be extinguished from Israel,” only one whose name is extinguished<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">But not one who had the potential of offspring at the time of his death.</i>. The verse says, “to establish a name in Israel for his brother,” until you know whether there is a live child or not<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The early <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is of no legal value.</i>. I could think that the wife of an eunuch should need levirate, the verse says “that his name should not be extinguished from Israel,” only one whose name is not extinguished; this excludes this one whose name was already extinguished<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Before his death.</i>.
Could I say, her<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The pregnant woman who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i> co-wife may remarry? “<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Similar <i>baraitot</i> are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 36a" href="/Yevamot.36a">Babli, 36a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta 6:3</a>.</i> He who marries his sister-in-law and she turns out to be pregnant,” as you say, “her co-wife cannot marry until you know by which means she is permitted, whether by pregnancy or by intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Whether the deceased finally had a posthumous child and the rules of levirate do not apply or whether she is freed by the levirate of her co-wife, which is justified after the fact if the widow has a miscarriage or a still birth.</i>” The same is valid for the one who performed <i>ḥalîṣah. Ḥalîṣah</i> frees and intercourse frees<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The co-wife.</i>. As you said it for intercourse so it was said for <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.
Samuel said, one can transfer benefits to fetuses; Rebbi Eleazar said, one cannot transfer benefits to fetuses<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The question whether an unborn child can inherit and receive gifts is discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 141b-142a" href="/Bava_Batra.141b-142a">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i>141b/142a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 9:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.9.1.2-7">Yerushalmi <i>Baba Batra</i> 9:1</a> in a similar way. The opinion of R. Eleazar is attributed to (the slightly older) Rav Huna in the Babli.</i>. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose, the fifth generation Amora, colleague of R. Jonah. In ms. A, the name appears as ר׳ יונסה, a confluence of both names.</i> said, even though Samuel said, one can transfer benefits to fetuses, he agrees that most of [the fetus’s] head and body must come out alive<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 142a" href="/Bava_Batra.142a">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i> 142a</a>, that a gift to a minor is acquired only at the time of birth is the opinion of Rav Naḥman, Samuel’s foremost student in matters of civil law.</i>. That is the Mishnah, “if somebody performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law but she turns out to have been pregnant,” as you say here, retroactively <i>ḥalîṣah</i> did not touch her, so retroactively the child is a son and receives the benefit<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">After birth, the gift is valid from the time it was given but it is not acquired (and cannot be invested by the baby’s trustees) before birth.</i>. There, we have stated: “If somebody says, if my wife gives birth to a male, he shall take a mina<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">100 drachmae. In the parallel, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 141b" href="/Bava_Batra.141b"><i>Baba batra</i> 141b</a>, only the male baby is mentioned. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 9:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.9.2.2">Yerushalmi <i>Baba batra</i>9:2</a>, edited by a different group, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Batra (Lieberman) 9:5" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Batra_(Lieberman).9.5">Tosephta <i>Baba batra</i> 9:5</a>, a different text, the male gets double the amount of the female.</i>, if she gave birth to a male, [the male baby] will take a mina. If a female, 200 [drachmae], if she gave birth to a female, that one will take 200.” Rebbi Eleazar said, this is only for his son, but not for any other. Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">It seems here that instead of ר׳ יוסה (in both mss.) one should read ר׳ יסה; he is R. Yasa (Assi), contemporary of R. Eleazar.</i> said, even any other. In the opinion of Rebbi Eleazar, only from a sick person, but not a healthy one; only movables but not real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The rules of emergency wills, which are much more lenient than those of standard wills, are detailed in tractates <i>Giṭṭin</i> and <i>Baba batra</i>. Real estate can be acquired only if all rules are followed; since the fetus cannot perform the act of acquisition, no real estate can be transferred to him on the death bed.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Eleazar. “<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 142a" href="/Bava_Batra.142a">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 142a</a>. If a proselyte has no children after he became Jewish, his estate has no heirs; so anybody who wants to may take it. It is assumed here that if the deceased had a wife, he died without a will and she was not present since either way she immediately could lay claim to the entire property. Therefore, it is stated that only later it became known that the widow was pregnant.</i> If a proselyte died and Jews plundered his estate, then it became known that he had a son overseas or that [his wife] was pregnant, everybody is required to return [what he took].” What does Rebbi Eleazar do with this<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The unborn baby inherits his father’s estate. This is a biblical decree (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:8" href="/Numbers.27.8"><i>Num</i>. 27:8</a>).</i>? There is a difference because it is his child. The second part [of the Mishnah] disagrees with Samuel in the interpretation of Rebbi Yose: “If they returned everything and then the son died<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">And again there are no legal heirs.</i> or she had a miscarriage<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If a fetus cannot acquire, then the first group of people who had returned what they had taken, simply should be given back what they had returned. If a fetus can acquire, then the first group took the possession illegally and they should not be considered as owners.</i>, anybody who takes first <i>after that</i> acquires it.” The first group did not acquire. Even at the beginning they should not have acquired! Did not Rebbi Yose say, even though Samuel said, one can transfer benefits to fetuses, he agrees that most of [the fetus’s] head and body must come out alive. He was not living<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">In the interpretation of R. Yose, the return was in error and the people who took first should take their property back.</i>! Rebbi Isaac bar Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 9:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.9.1.2-7"><i>Baba batra</i> 9:1</a> this is an anonymous statement of the editors. In ms A: R. Eleazar. Cf. <i>Berakhot</i> 7:117.</i> said, because of abandoning<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The owners had given up hope to recover their property. Then they had given up ownership. Loss of ownership by giving up hope of recovery is the topic of <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 2.</i>. The rabbis of Caesarea, R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, Rebbi Abba bar Natan<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian in Galilee, older than R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, student of Rav Huna. The next name, R. Nathan, seems to be corrupt; possibly one should read “R. Eleazar”. Unfortunately, two lines are missing here in ms. A.</i>: Rebbi Natan changed his mind because of that Mishnah: “If a male, a mina, if a female, 200.” Is a female in this situation not like an outsider<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the presence of sons she does not inherit (but can claim support from the estate and a dowry).</i>? Bar Qappara stated: “On transfers benefit to a one day old.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">He denies that an unborn child can inherit or receive gifts; cf. Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:3.</i>”

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody marries his sister-in-law but she turned out to have been pregnant and gave birth. If the child is alive, [the levir] has to divorce her and they must bring a sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">His marriage to her is incestuous; she is forbidden to him as sister-in-law with children. The sacrifice is a purification sacrifice, חַטָּאת (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4" href="/Leviticus.4"><i>Lev</i>. 4</a>). One has to assume that the marriage was entered into without any suspicion of pregnancy.</i>. If the child is not alive, he may keep her. If it is doubtful whether [the child is] a nine-month child of the first [brother] or a seven-month of the second, he has to divorce her, the child is legitimate, and they are obligated to bring a reparation offering for an uncertain case<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">His marriage to her is possibly incestuous; he must divorce her. A child is either a bastard or not a bastard; legally no children exist that <i>possibly</i> are bastards. The reparation offering is the אָשָּׁם required if it is uncertain whether a sin was committed or not (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:17-19" href="/Leviticus.5.17-19"><i>Lev</i>. 5:17–19</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot be either the late Amora or the Tanna; it seems that he is the Babylonian who in the Babli is called Rav Assi. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 17b" href="/Keritot.17b">Babli (<i>Keritut</i>17b</a>) by implication attributes to Rav Assi the opinion that a reparation offering is due if the true situation cannot be ascertained.</i> said, in any case where the true fact can be ascertained, one does not have to bring a reparation offering because of doubt. How is that? If there were before him two olive-sized pieces, one of suet<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">From the back part of a domestic animal. Since suet of a sacrifice has to be burned on the altar, it is forbidden as food from all animals that can be sacrifices (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:27" href="/Leviticus.7.27"><i>Lev</i>. 7:27</a>). Eating an olive-sized piece of suet inadvertently requires a purification offering.</i> and one of fat<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Fat permitted as food.</i>, he ate one of them and the other is locked up.He says, since I could determine the true fact if I would find the key, does one have to bring a reparation offering in this case of doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Theoretically, the true situation could be ascertained, whether a purification offering is due or no sin has been committed, but practically it cannot. Does one follow theory or practice?</i>?
