Let us hear from the following: “If somebody marries his sister-in-law but she turned out to have been pregnant”, as long as it is not known whether the child lives or does not live, does he have to bring a reparation offering because of the doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">No, the Mishnah requires them to wait until the eventual necessity for a purification offering is decided.</i>? This means that he does not bring.
Rav said, in any case where the true fact can never be established, one does not have to bring a reparation offering for the doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 2:6:4-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.2.6.4-6"><i>Bikkurim</i>2:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 17b" href="/Keritot.17b">Babli <i>Keritut</i> 17b</a>. {The commentators who did not recognize that Yerushalmi אֵיפשר = Babli אי אפשר had to rewrite the text; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 7:7:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.7.7.3"><i>Peah</i>, Chapter 7, Note 170</a>.}</i>. How is that? If there were before him two olive-sized pieces, one of suet<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">From the back part of a domestic animal. Since suet of a sacrifice has to be burned on the altar, it is forbidden as food from all animals that can be sacrifices (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:27" href="/Leviticus.7.27"><i>Lev</i>. 7:27</a>). Eating an olive-sized piece of suet inadvertently requires a purification offering.</i> and one of fat<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Fat permitted as food.</i>, he ate one of them, and then a raven ate the other. Since he cannot ascertain the true fact, one does not have to bring a reparation offering for this doubt. But if the raven ate first and then he ate, since he could have ascertained the true fact<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">By having the piece analyzed by a competent butcher.</i>, one has to bring a reparation offering for the doubt. But did not Rav say, only if he made sure that it certainly was suet<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 17b" href="/Keritot.17b">Babli, <i>Keritut</i> 17b</a>, quotes a similar statement in the name of Ḥiyya bar Rav, that the offering for a doubt is due only if there were two pieces, one permitted, one forbidden, whose history can be traced and their true status ascertained. But if there is only one piece whose status is indeterminate (the case of Rebbi Yose, Rav Assi), the offering for a doubt does not apply.</i>? Even though Rav said, only if he made sure that it certainly was suet, he agrees here that he could have ascertained the true fact. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rav: “As Rebbi Eleazar says, one must bring a reparation offering for the doubt of suet<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 2:6:4-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.2.6.4-6"><i>Bikkurim</i> 2:8</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 17b" href="/Keritot.17b">Babli <i>Keritut</i> 17b</a>. The animal is the <i>koy</i>, for which it is impossible to ascertain whether it is domestic (whose suet is forbidden) or wild (whose suet is permitted).</i>.” What does Rav do with that? They<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The majority of Sages disagree with the Tanna R. Eleazar ben Shamua.</i> disagree with the words of Rebbi Eleazar. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 5:4" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.5.4">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 5:4</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Keritot 3:1" href="/Tosefta_Keritot.3.1">Tosephta <i>Keritut</i> 3:1</a>. Neither of these texts is identical with the <i>baraita</i> quoted here.</i>: “If there were both a piece of profane [meat] and a piece of sacrificial [meat], he ate one of them and it is not known which one, he brings a reparation offering for the doubt. If he [then] ate the second piece, he brings a reparation offering for a certain transgression<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that the person who ate is not a Cohen and commits a sin by eating sacrificial meat. The reparation offering is for unauthorized use of sacred property, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14-16" href="/Leviticus.5.14-16"><i>Lev</i>. 5:14–16</a>. Both texts quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.3">Note 55</a> require two sacrifices, one a reparation sacrifice for the use of sacred meat, the other a purification sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:27-35" href="/Leviticus.4.27-35"><i>Lev</i>. 4:27–35</a>) for the sin.</i>. If he ate the first piece and another person came and ate the second, each one brings a reparation offering for the doubt.” One understands that the first brings a reparation offering for the doubt. Why the second? Rebbi Yose said, explain it that the piece was large, he ate half of it and left the other half<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">It is impossible to explain that both people ate from one large piece since that is the case in which Rav denies that a reparation offering is due. If must be that one piece was eaten completely but of the other enough is left that it could be analyzed. (This is the explanation rejected by קרבן העדה).</i>. A Mishnah disagrees with Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">This quote is the reason the entire discussion is placed here.</i>: “If it is doubtful whether [the child is] a nine-month child of the first [brother] or a seven-month of the second, he has to divorce her, the child is legitimate, and they are obligated for a reparation offering for the doubt.” Here it is impossible to ascertain the true fact and they are obligated for a reparation offering for the doubt! Rebbi Yose said, Rebbi Ze‘ira explained it before Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba; Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: Rebbi Ze‘ira explained it before us. Since he could just have touched her<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic Hebrew, the expression הערה in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:17" href="/Leviticus.20.17"><i>Lev</i>. 20:17</a> is taken to mean “touched (the female genital by the male genital)”, not the etymologically more likely “bared”. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a> will explain that the biblically required act of validation of the marriage with the sister-in-law is the touching of the two genitals. They could have performed this act without ejaculation to be married (and make the brother financially responsible for the sister-in-law) and then waited the prescribed 90 days to ascertain the paternity of an eventual child.</i> and then separated, he could have known whether it is his or the other’s, it is as if he could have ascertained the true fact!
How do we hold<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the last sentence of the Mishnah, how xan a child be a nine-months child or a seven-months child with equal probabilities.</i>? If he came to her immediately after her husband’s death, and the fetus was recognized after two months, one should have stated: A nine-month child of either one of them or a seven-month of either one of them! But it may be that he came to her after two months and the fetus was recognized after three months<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Since a widow should not be married in levirate earlier than 3 months after the husband’s death (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.1">Mishnah 4:11</a>) in order to avoid situations like the one discussed in the Mishnah, it follows that there are pregnancies that are recognized only after three months.</i>, one should have stated: The sister-in-law should not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or be married in levirate until after five months! But it must be that he came to her after 40 days and the fetus was recognized after 50 days. That would be complete months for [a child of] the first [brother] and incomplete ones for the second<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">If the child was born exactly nine months after the death of the husband, then this would be 7 months and 10 days after the levir had intercourse with her.</i>. This implies that a woman may give birth after full months. This implies that there are two creations<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Certain regular pregnancies are terminated naturally during the seventh month; certain others only after 9 full months.</i>. This implies that a woman may give birth after incomplete months. This implies that a woman may become pregnant repeatedly<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 27" href="/Niddah.27">Babli, <i>Niddah 27</a></i> a, disagrees and holds that Jehudah and Ḥizqiah, children of Rebbi Ḥiyya, who were born 3 months apart, were twins; the one a seven-months child and the other a nine-months child.</i>. This implies that a woman cannot become pregnant simultaneously from two men<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah excludes the possibility that, even if there were twins, they could come from both brothers as fathers. In that case, according to Rav there would be no reparation offering for a doubt.</i>. And it disagrees with the sermonizing rabbis, since the sermonizing rabbis say “the middleman” “from the orders of the Philistines”, from 100 prepuces of Philistines, that 100 prepuces of Philistines touched her<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 2:21" href="/Ruth.2.21">Midrash <i>Ruth</i> 2(21</a>), Midrash <i>Samuel</i> ed. Buber 20(4), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 42b" href="/Sotah.42b">Babli <i>Soṭah</i> 42b</a> in the name of R. Joḥanan. These sermons identify (1) the Moabite Orpah, the daughter-in-law of Noemi who did not follow her to Bethlehem, with the Philistine Haraphah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:22" href="/II_Samuel.21.22"><i>2S</i>. 21:22</a>), and (2) Goliat mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21" href="/II_Samuel.21"><i>2S</i>. 21</a> with the warrior in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 17:23" href="/I_Samuel.17.23"><i>1S</i>. 17:23</a>. The latter is introduced in the written text as אִישׁ הַבֵּנַיִם מִמַּעַרְוֹת פְּלִשׁתִּים interpreted in a slightly pornographic way as “a man [created] in between the touchings (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.3">Note 59</a>) of the Philistines”, explaining that Orpah, once she had decided not to become Jewish, went to the enemies of the Jews, the Philistines of Gath, and slept with 100 of their warriors (מִמַּעַרְוֹת = מִמֵּאָה הֶעָרוֹת) in one night to create a super-warrior; in the words of R. Joḥanan, 100 fathers and one mother. One can construct such a sermon only if all gutturals had become silent and <i>pataḥ, qāmeṣ</i> assimilated to one another.</i>. Rebbi Mattaniah said, there is no disagreement. As long as the semen is not spoiled, a woman can become pregnant from several men simultaneously. After the semen is spoiled, a woman cannot become pregnant from several men simultaneously.
From where the two creations? Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Huna: “He created<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 2:7" href="/Genesis.2.7"><i>Gen</i>. 2:7</a>. In the creation of Man, it is written וייצר, in that of the animals, 2:19, only ויצר. The two letters י symbolize the two creations. A more detailed exposition of this sermon is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 14:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.14.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 14(2</a>).</i>”, a creation for seven and a creation for eight. If he was created for seven but born at eight, he lives; so much more if [born] by nine. If he was created for nine and born at eight, he does not live. If he was created for nine and born at seven? Come and see, if he does not live at eight, so much less at seven! They<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Some Greek speakers.</i> asked before Rebbi Abbahu. From where that a seven-month baby lives? he said to them, from yours I am giving to you: ζῇ τὰ ἑπτὰ, ζῇ τὰ ἑπτὰ<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">“It lives at seven, it lives at seven”. In all other sources, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 14:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.14.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i>14(2</a>), 20(13), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18" href="/Numbers.18"><i>Tanḥuma Bemidbar</i> 18</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 21" href="/Numbers.21"><i>Tanḥuma Buber Bemidbar</i> 21</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 4:3" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.4.3"><i>Bemidbar rabba</i> 4(3</a>), the reading seems to be זיטא אפטא איטא אוכטא for the interpretation of which S. Lieberman (יוונית ויוונות בארץ ישׂראל, Jerusalem 1962, p. 209) prefers the reading of A. Crusius: ζῇ τὰ ἑπτὰ &lt;μᾶλλον&gt; ἤ τὰ ὀκτώ “the life-expectancy of that of seven [is better than] that of eight,” a medical maxim. The formulation is a pun on the Hellenistic numeral values of letters, <i>zeta</i>ζʼ = 7, <i>eta</i> η’ = 8.</i>.
If the uncertain [son] comes to take his part in his father’s<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The putative father, his mother’s first husband.</i> [inheritance]. one says to him, the other one is your father. If the levir comes to take his part in his brother’s [inheritance], one says to him, that one is his son. How is that? They compromise between themselves and split the property of the deceased<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 37b" href="/Yevamot.37b">Babli, 37b</a>, notes that the inheritance of the deceased brother is “money which is in doubt and money in doubt one splits in the middle”. The Yerushalmi has no explicit rule on how the compromise is reached.</i>. One finds, compromise with his brother is loss to the brothers; competition between the brothers is catastrophy for the brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The compromise splits the inheritance between the uncertain son and his uncertain father; this excludes the other brothers from the inheritance of their childless brother The rules of inheritance in the cases of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate are spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnaiot 3–4</a>. If there is no compromise, nobody gets anything.</i>. If the old man dies, one finds that certain sons and an uncertain grandson come<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Inheritance of the grandfather goes to his children and grandchildren <i>per stirpes</i>. If the grandson cannot prove who his father was, he cannot inherit in the presence of sons orgrandsons of known fathers.</i>. If the uncertain [son] dies there exists a certain son of his father’s brother and an uncertain mother<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The mother is certain but she does not inherit. The sons of the levir inherit either as brothers or as cousins of the deceased. The other sons of the mother could inherit his part from his mother’s estate only if there were no relatives from the family of the possible fathers.</i>. If one of the brothers dies, there is a certain son and an uncertain son of a brother<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The uncertain son cannot claim a part in the inheritance of a childless uncle since he cannot prove whether he should get the full part of the first husband or a share with the other brothers of the levir.</i>. If the mother of the uncertain [son] dies, there is a certain son and an uncertain husband<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The levir cannot inherit since he cannot prove that the woman was his legal wife.</i>. If first the uncertain [son] dies and after that his mother, a son of the mother’s brother is certain but the husband uncertain<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The levir cannot inherit since he cannot prove that the woman was his legal wife.</i>. If the levir dies and the uncertain [son] comes to take his part in his father’s inheritance, if the first one was poor, they tell him, that one is your father. If he was rich, the tell him, we all are brothers, sons of his brother. Come and let us inherit our father’s part and the part of our father’s brother<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 37b" href="/Yevamot.37b">Babli, 37b</a>, there is a serious disagreement whether the inheritance of the first husband remains separate after the levir and the uncertain son did compromise (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.6">Note 72</a>). In practice, the Babli holds that the uncertain son cannot inherit more than what he got under the compromise since he cannot prove that he was the levir’s son.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:2" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.2">Tosephta 6:2</a>, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 37a" href="/Yevamot.37a">Babli 37a</a>.</i>: “The first son could be High Priest, any second son possibly is a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">If the first child is the son of the first husband, he certainly is in order. If he is the son of the levir, the first husband died childless and the levirate was legitimate. But any second child is the issue of a union which possibly is incestuous and punishable by divine extirpation.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said, there is no such thing as a possible bastard.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">He is considered a bastard, permitted to marry a bastard partner, since he cannot marry a legitimate Israel partner; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.2-5"><i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3</a>.</i>” Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob agrees in cases of doubt of Samaritans and desecrated persons<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">As noted before, Samaritans have different interpretations of incest and marriage laws; a child of a marriage with a Samaritan is not automatically excluded but subject to inquiry. The text speaks of Samaritans since in talmudic times they were the only remnants of Sadducee traditions. {Today, of the other tribes of Sadducee traditions, Ethiopians have accepted rabbinic rules and Karaites are legitimate marriage partners if they accept rabbinic rules.}<br>“Desecrated” children are children of the marriage of a Cohen with a divorcee or a prostitute; such a marriage is not incestuous and stringent exclusionary rules do not apply.</i>. This refers to what we have stated there: “Ten classes returned from Babylonia.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:1</a>: “Ten classes returned from Babylonia, Cohanim, Levites, Israel, desecrated, proselytes, freed slaves, bastards, Gibeonites, people of unknown paternity, and foundlings. Cohanim, Levites, Israel may marry one another. Levites, Israel, desecrated, proselytes, and freed slaves, may marry one another. Proselytes, freed slaves, bastards, Gibeonites, people of unknown paternity, and foundlings, may marry one another.”<br>For R. Eliezer ben Jacob, bastards, people of unknown paternity, and foundlings, all form one group.<br>In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.8.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 1:8</a>, Rabban Gamliel and R. Eliezer hold that the unmarried mother of a child of unknown paternity is believed if she asserts that the father was one of the first six categories (or a Gentile). For them, the special category of “child of unknown paternity” does not exist since the child inherits the status of his mother.</i>” In the opinion of Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob, eight. In the opinion of Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer, nine. In the opinion of the rabbis, ten.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If property came to a woman waiting for her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">She waits to be married in levirate or to be freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. In the meantime, the <i>ketubah</i>, the money due her at the dissolution of her marriage (her dowry and the capital due her from her husband) is not payable since concerning money matters levirate is considered as continuation of the first marriage. The capital due from the husband is at least 200 <i>zuz</i> for a virgin, defined in Mishnah <i>Peah</i> 8:8 as sufficient to disqualify her from public assistence.</i>, the House of Shammai agree with the House of Hillel that she may sell or give away and it is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">During the marriage, the husband has the administration and usufruct of her property. This power is not automatically transferred to the levir; it comes only with the actual levirate. Since the marriage with the first husband is now terminated, the administration of the properties is solely in her hands.</i>. If she dies, what does one do with her <i>ketubah</i> and property that enters and leaves with her<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Property she inherited or otherwise received during her marriage. In contrast to the dowry, for which the husband assumes responsibility in the <i>ketubah</i> contract and whose value only has to be returned at the dissolution of the marriage, these remain her property and, during marriage, may be sold or mortgaged only by the common action of the wife as owner and the husband as administrator. These properties are called נִכְסֵי מְלוֹג (Accadic <i>mulūgu</i> “wife’s property”), cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.1">Mishnah 8:1</a>.</i>? The House of Shammai say, the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs. But the House of Hillel say that all property remains where it is; the <i>ketubah</i> in the hands of the husband’s heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Her dowry remains in the husband’s family. {This is a matter of civil law, not a religious precept. In the Middle Ages, many communities promulgated rules that returned all or part of the dowry of a childless marriage of short duration to the wife’s family.}</i> and property that enters and leaves with her in the hands of her father’s heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">They never were the husband’s property.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If property came to a woman waiting for her levir,” etc. Here, you say “she may sell or give away and it is valid. If she dies, what does one do with her <i>ketubah</i>?” And you also say “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs!”<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">If she can dispose of the property without the consent of the husband’s family, the property belongs to her family. Why, according to the House of Shammai, should the late husband’s family get anything of the widow’s separate property?</i> Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 38b" href="/Yevamot.38b">Babli, 38b</a>, this is quoted as the opinion of Abbai (middle 4th Cent.), with a belated acknowledgment (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 39a" href="/Yevamot.39a">39a</a>) of the priority of R. Yose ben Ḥanina (middle 3rd Cent.). As Levy Ginzburg has pointed out, in the Babylonian Talmud the Babylonian authors are always mentioned before the Galileans; chronological order is followed within each group separately.<br>The wife of a childless man who has a brother becomes “a woman waiting for her levir” at the moment she is widowed.</i>, when do you say “she may sell or give away and it is valid”? If they came to her before she became a woman waiting for her levir. When do you say “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs”? If they came to her after she became a woman waiting for her levir. If they came to her before she became a woman waiting for her levir and produced revenue after she became a woman waiting for her levir, [that revenue is as if] they came to her after she became a woman waiting for her levir. Rebbi Ze‘ira<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion is not mentioned in the Babli. There, the opinion opposed to that of Abbai is that of Rava, who holds that the widow can only dispose of her property before “bespeaking”. For him, “bespeaking” for the House of Shammai makes the widow a wife in civil but not in criminal matters, while <i>qiddushin</i> makes the unencumbered woman a wife in criminal but not in civil matters.</i> said, the levir in this situation is a problem for the House of Shammai. If he is a husband, he inherits everything. If he is not a husband, he inherits nothing. Because of the doubt, “the husband’s heirs should split with her father’s heirs.” For the House of Hillel it is obvious that he is a husband and inherits everything. For even his brother had only the usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is the answer to an unasked question: If the husband inherits from his wife, why does the widow’s separate property return to her family? The answer is that this property, in contrast to the dowry, never was the husband’s. He only was the administrator and had the usufruct during her lifetime. The levir’s hand cannot be stronger than the husband’s. (The husband received the usufruct since he was under the obligation to provide for his wife a lifestyle appropriate to her social standing. This is one of the major topics of Tractate <i>Ketubot</i>.)</i>.
Rebbi Hoshaia stated: The heirs of her <i>ketubah</i> are obliged to bury her<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">This is also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 81a" href="/Ketubot.81a">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 81a</a>. The discussion there is irrelevant for the Yerushalmi.<br>The heirs of the <i>ketubah</i> are the heirs of the husband since her death terminates the obligation of <i>ketubah</i>. Since the husband is freed from the obligation of paying the <i>ketubah</i>, he has to pay all costs connected with her funeral.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, if Rebbi Hoshaia had not stated this, we would have had a problem. If she had no <i>ketubah</i>, do they not have to bury her? This is difficult. If a woman has no <i>ketubah</i>, does she not have to be buried<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">For example, if she sold her right to <i>ketubah</i> in case of dissolution of the marriage to her husband for current cash, nevertheless the husband is required to bear the expenses of her funeral. She must have had a <i>ketubah</i> to be married.</i>? A wife, even if she has a <i>ketubah</i>, must be buried. This one, if she has a <i>ketubah</i>, is entitled to burial costs. But here, if she does not have a <i>ketubah</i>, she is not entitled to burial costs<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, the expenses have to be covered from her estate, and if she leaves no estate, from her family.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he married her, she is his wife in every respect except that her <i>ketubah</i> is a lien on the property of her first husband<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">If the levir married his sister-in-law he does not write her a new <i>ketubah.</i> Therefore, he did not mortgage his own property to her.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he married her, she is his wife in every respect”, etc. What does he do? “He marries her, he may divorce her and take her back, and she writes him a receipt for her <i>ketubah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion is not mentioned in the Babli. There, the opinion opposed to that of Abbai is that of Rava, who holds that the widow can only dispose of her property before “bespeaking”. For him, “bespeaking” for the House of Shammai makes the widow a wife in civil but not in criminal matters, while <i>qiddushin</i> makes the unencumbered woman a wife in criminal but not in civil matters.</i> Rebbi Yose said, the <i>baraita</i> has two possibilities. “Or she writes him a receipt for her <i>ketubah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">If he takes her back before she received the payment of her <i>ketubah</i>, she obviously does not write a receipt. R. Yose wants to point out that the <i>baraita</i> quoted here is <i>not</i> the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 9:1</a>: “If somebody died and left his widow waiting for the levir, even if his estate is a hundred minas and her <i>ketubah</i> only one mina, the heirs cannot sell anything since her <i>ketubah</i> is a lien on the entire estate. What can he do? He marries her, divorces her, and she writes a receipt for her <i>ketubah</i>.”</i> Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Hamnuna: If he married her, divorced her, and took her back, if he wrote her a new <i>ketubah</i>, the lien is on his property; otherwise, it is on the property of her first husband. Rebbi Yose said in the name of Rav Ḥisda, a Mishnah said so: “For he who takes back his wife, takes her back under the terms of her first <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.8.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 9:9</a>.</i>.” At the end, if he married her, divorced her, and took her back? He tells you something new. Even if he married her, divorced her, and took her back, if he wrote her a new <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">If she refuses to come back under the old terms, her lien extends to the entire property of the levir.</i>, the lien is on his property; otherwise, it is on the property of her first husband.
Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Hamnuna said<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph belongs to the material of <i>Ketubot</i>; it has no bearing on the rules of levirate since it was noted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.4.2">Halakha 1:4</a> that women between <i>qiddushin</i> and marriage are not subject to levirate. The material is inserted here because this is the only other case where Rebbi Ze‘ira quotes Rav Hamnuna (of the students of Rav).</i>: A betrothed woman who died does not have a <i>ketubah</i> since she was not permitted to marry outside<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">This is a matter of great controversy in the Babli, which frequently (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 29b" href="/Yevamot.29b"><i>Yebamot</i> 29b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 43" href="/Yevamot.43">43</a>; <i>Ketubot</i>53, 89; <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 18a; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 28a</a>) quotes a <i>baraita</i> to the effect that if she dies, the husband does not inherit but if he dies, she collects her <i>ketubah</i>. Since a <i>ketubah</i> is not necessary for <i>qiddushin</i> but only for <i>nissuin</i>, the actual marriage, there is a problem only if the <i>ketubah</i> was already written at the time of <i>qiddushin</i>, which also implies that the dowry was determined or even delivered at that time. Then it is clear that at the groom’s death the betrothed woman can recover the dowry recorded in the <i>ketubah</i>. For the amount due from the husband, even though they disagree in the case of <i>ketubah</i> written at the betrothal, both Talmudim [<i>Ketubot</i>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.1.2-10">Yerushalmi 5:1</a> (fol. 29c), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56a" href="/Yevamot.56a">Babli 56a</a>] agree that any sum agreed to above the statutory minimum can be collected only after the consummation of the marriage.</i>. That you should not say [the case] should be considered as if he divorced her and she should have a <i>ketubah</i>; therefore it was necessary to say that she does not have a <i>ketubah</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The obligation of levirate is on the oldest [brother]<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Already stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.8.1">Mishnah 2:8</a>.</i>. If he refuses, one<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The local rabbinic court whose obligation it is to enforce the rules; cf. Maimonides, <i>Hilkhot Yibum</i> 2:7.</i> goes to all the other brothers. If they refuse, one returns to the oldest and tells him, the obligation is yours, either give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or marry in levirate.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">The brother available at the place of the widow.</i> made it dependent on a minor until he grows up, or on the oldest when he returns from overseas, or on a deaf-mute or on an insane [brother], one does not listen to him but tells him, the obligation is yours, either give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or marry in levirate.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law is like any of the other brothers for the inheritance and, if there is a father, the property goes to the father<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">The father is not mentioned in the biblical rules of inheritance (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num</i>. 27:6–11</a>) but since the paternal uncles are mentioned it is clear that one assumes that the father died before his son. Since the rules imply that thedescendants of the son rank before all other relatives, it is logical to assume that the father ranks before all his descendants and other relatives; <i>Baba batra</i> 8:2.</i>. He who marries his sister-in-law acquires his brother’s property. Rebbi Jehudah says, in any case if there is a father, the property goes to the father<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Subject to the lien of the widow’s <i>ketubah</i>. The problem does not appear in the case of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since the widow has to be paid in full before the inheritance is distributed. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.3">Tosephta, 6:3</a>, R. Jehudah also denies that the levir gets all the inheritance if there is no father.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law is like any of the other brothers for the inheritance,” etc. That one should not say, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing, intercourse is freeing<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:22" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.22">Chapter 1, Note 104</a>. The argument is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 40a" href="/Yevamot.40a">Babli, 40a</a>, and refuted. The accepted argument is that one might think that the levir who refuses to honor his duty of levirate should be punished by being excluded from inheriting his part, but this is not so.</i>; just as you say, “he who marries his sister-in-law acquires his brother’s property,” so he who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law acquires his brother’s property. Therefore, it is necessary to say “he is like any of the other brothers for the inheritance”.
Rav Jehudah said in the name of Samuel: He who “bespeaks” his sister-in-law does not acquire his brother’s property<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>qiddushin</i> do not give the husband any property rights, the weaker “bespeaking” cannot do it either.</i>. Even the House of Shammai agree to that<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">They hold that “bespeaking” is a biblical requirement for levirate. Still they cannot hold that “bespeaking” is stronger than <i>qiddushin</i>. The same argument is good for R. Simeon who only allows for the possibility that “bespeaking” might be like <i>qiddushin</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.4">Chapter 2, Note 16</a>).</i>; even Rebbi Simeon agrees to that, but not Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh. As Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh said, “bespeaking” acquires the sister-in-law totally. If there were two sisters-in-law, he “bespoke” one and came to the other. As you take it, either by “bespeaking” he acquires or by intercourse he acquires. Rebbi Yose said, since he cannot keep either one<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The second one is forbidden to him rabbinically for the House of Hillel, biblically for the House of Shammai. The first one is forbidden to him biblically for the House of Hillel.</i>, he did not acquire his brother’s property.
Rebbi Isaac ben Tevele in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: The reason of Rebbi Jehudah: “<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.6"><i>Deut</i>. 25:6</a>. The verse connects the birth of a first-born with the inheritance of the dead brother.</i> The first-born whom she will bear shall be”; He compared it to a first-born. Since the first-born does not inherit during his father’s lifetime, so this one does not inherit during his father’s lifetime. But since the first-born inherits after his father’s death, does this one inherit after his father’s death<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Since the first-born inherits an extra portion from the estate, does the levir inherit the separate inheritance of his wife’s first husband separately?</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, since the first-born does not inherit when it was time to inherit, so this one does not inherit when it was time to inherit<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The separatee inheritance of the first-born is restricted (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.17"><i>Deut</i>. 21:17</a>) to “all that is found of his property.” This is interpreted as excluding claims that are not yet collected; cf., e. g., <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 55a" href="/Bava_Batra.55a">Babli <i>Baba batra</i> 55a</a>. Since the inheritance of the dead brother is under his wife’s lien for her <i>ketubah</i>, it is not considered as “found of his property”.</i>. Afterwards he cannot inherit. Rebbi Abba bar Cahana, Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, practice follows Rebbi Judah. Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia, practice follows Rebbi Judah. Rebbi Joḥanan said, many times I sat before Rebbi Hoshaia and never heard that from him. He said to him, does nobody exist who heard something his partner did not hear<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 40a" href="/Yevamot.40a">Babli, 40a</a>, strongly disagrees since practice follows the anonymous majority. This is the position of R. Joḥanan’s teacher R. Yannai.</i>?

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law is forbidden her relatives and his relatives are forbidden to her<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">All relatives forbidden after a divorce (biblical or rabbinic) are rabbinically forbidden after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:13:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.13.1">Mishnah 4:13</a>.</i>. Forbidden to him are her mother and her mother’s mother, her father’s mother, her daughter, her daughter’s daughter and her son’s daughter, and her sister as long as she is alive. The brothers are permitted. Forbidden to her are his father, his father’s father, his son and his son’s son, his brother and his brother’s son. The relative of a co-wife of a person who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with him is permitted to him, but the co-wife of a relative of a person who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with him is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law,” etc. Because he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her. Therefore, if he did not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her but she died, her mother is permitted to him. <sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.6">Chapter 2, Notes 28–29</a>.</i> That is what Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If a woman waiting for her levir died, her mother is permitted to him. He had in her an interest of candidacy. When she died, the candidacy was eliminated. And here, when he died, the candidacy was eliminated. Rebbi Abun understood it from what follows: “And her sister as long as she is alive, but the brothers are permitted.” Is her sister’s position relative to the brothers not as if<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Relative to the brother chosen to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i> she herself had died?
“Forbidden to her are his father, his father’s father, his son and his son’s son, his brother and his brother’s son.” Does this imply that secondary prohibitions are imposed on the one performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? That says it, “his son and his son’s son, his brother and his brother’s son.” That implies that secondary prohibitions are imposed on the one performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the first quote is too long and should only refer to his father’s father. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 40b" href="/Yevamot.40b">Babli, 40b</a>, also raises the question why the paternal grandfather is forbidden and answers that the prohibition has nothing to do with <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since that grandfather was forbidden to her from the moment she married her husband. But the son’s and the brother’s sons are secondary prohibitions. This is also the conclusion of the Babli which, however, restricts secondary prohibitions arising from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> strictly to those enumerated in the Mishnah.</i>.
So is the Mishnah: “The relative of a co-wife of a person who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with him is permitted to him, but the co-wife of a relative of a person who had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with him is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text of the Mishnah. It seems that the intent of this note is not to correct the text but to reject the formulation “the sister of a co-wife …”, quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.3.3">Chapter 3 (Note 50</a>).</i>”. <sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The text is from Chapter 3; explained there in Notes 24, 25.</i> Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Avina: It is an inference <i>de minore ad majus</i>. If the Sages gave a co-wife to the sister of a woman for whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, which is rabbinic, here, where there is the prohibition of sisters, not so much more?

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with his sister-in-law while his brother had married her sister and then died, she must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">She is prohibited to the levir by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.8.1">Mishnah 8</a>. But these prohibitions are rabbinical. Since by biblical standards she could have been married in levirate, she needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. Similarly, if somebody divorces his wife while his brother had married her sister and then died, she is free<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The widow of the brother is forbidden to the levir by biblical standards, there can be no levirate and, therefore, no <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Similarly, if somebody divorces his wife,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 1, Notes 90, 91.</i> Simeon bar Abba asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: What is the difference between having <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and divorcing<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 38b" href="/Yevamot.38b">Babli, 38b</a>, this is quoted as the opinion of Abbai (middle 4th Cent.), with a belated acknowledgment (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 39a" href="/Yevamot.39a">39a</a>) of the priority of R. Yose ben Ḥanina (middle 3rd Cent.). As Levy Ginzburg has pointed out, in the Babylonian Talmud the Babylonian authors are always mentioned before the Galileans; chronological order is followed within each group separately.<br>The wife of a childless man who has a brother becomes “a woman waiting for her levir” at the moment she is widowed.</i>? He said to him: You think that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, but it is only freeing. The brothers are not guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion is not mentioned in the Babli. There, the opinion opposed to that of Abbai is that of Rava, who holds that the widow can only dispose of her property before “bespeaking”. For him, “bespeaking” for the House of Shammai makes the widow a wife in civil but not in criminal matters, while <i>qiddushin</i> makes the unencumbered woman a wife in criminal but not in civil matters.</i> for her under the category of “wife of the one acting in <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” but they are guilty under the category of “wife of the deceased”.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a brother gave <i>qiddushin</i> to the sister of a woman waiting for the levir, they said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra: One says to him wait until your older brother has acted. If [one of the] brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or married her, he may marry his wife. If the sister-in-law died, he may marry. If the levir died, he has to remove himself from his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s widow by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> It says only: If the sister-in-law died, his wife is permitted to him. But if his wife died, his sister-in-law is forbidden to him. Rebbi Joḥanan said, these are the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, if his sister-in-law died, his wife is permitted to him, if his wife died, his sister-in-law is permitted to him. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the Sages hold that for anything induced by a cause, if the cause is removed the prohibition is removed. But for Rebbi Eliezer, if the cause is removed the prohibition remains<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Text and explanation in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.3">Chapter 3, Notes 6–11</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> No sister-in-law should be a party to <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate until after three months. Similarly, no woman<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Who had been married. Included are preliminarily married women either as a matter of discipline or because of women betrothed in Judea (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.1">Note 129</a>).</i> should be married or receive <i>qiddushin</i> until after three months, whether virgin or not virgin, widow or divorcee, married or betrothed. Rebbi Jehudah says, those that had been married may receive <i>qiddushin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Since they cannot actually be married until 90 days after the death of the first husband, there is no danger that she will bear a child of undetermined paternity.</i> and those that had received <i>qiddushin</i> can be married except those that had received <i>qiddushin</i> in Judea because he is familiar with her<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">It is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 1:5</a> that in Judea one permitted the betrothed couple to be together unchaperoned. Therefore, one may assume that they slept together.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, any woman may receive <i>qiddushin</i> except a widow because of her mourning.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “No sister-in-law should be a party to <i>ḥalîṣah</i>,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The text of Symmachos is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 8b" href="/Niddah.8b">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 8b</a>, but the meaning is different there.<br>In the Babli, the discussion is not about recognizing a pregnancy for the question of remarriage; that question is settled by the proviso that a woman must wait 90 days after her husband’s death (as explained in the Mishnah here) and, if she turns out to be pregnant, she cannot remarry as long as the child is not weaned (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:6:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.6.2-6"><i>Ketubot</i> 5:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.3.2-5"><i>Sotah</i> 4:4</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 60" href="/Ketubot.60">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 60a/b</a>). The statement there is to the effect that if a woman has missed her period three times and is visibly pregnant, then, starting three months after her last period, any bleeding does not follow the general rules of menstrual flow but the special rules of pregnant women. There is no discussion of the rule and it is not claimed that the rule represents any medical validity.<br>But in the Yerushalmi it appears from the sequel that one sees in the rule a statement of biological fact. The Halakhah, up to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.5">Note 155</a>, is copied in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Niddah 1:3:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Niddah.1.3.2-8"><i>Niddah</i> 1:4</a>.</i> How long is it until a pregnancy is recognized? <sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.1.4">Tosephta <i>Niddah</i> 1:7</a>, including the statement attributed here to Rebbi Yudan.</i> Symmachos said in the name of Rebbi Meїr: After three months. Even though it is no proof, there is a hint: “It was after about three months.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 38:24" href="/Genesis.38.24"><i>Gen</i>. 38:24</a>.</i>” Rebbi Yudan said, even for a phantom pregnancy, “we were pregnant, we were sick, as if we gave birth to wind,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 26:18" href="/Isaiah.26.18"><i>Is</i>. 26:18</a>; as the Babli points out, this statement is addressed to males and therefore not a good support. In the interpretation of the Babli (Note 131), a fake delivery (“delivery of wind”) after recognition of the pregnancy does not change the status of the woman in matters of impurity.</i>” “get pregnant with dry grass, give birth to straw<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 33:11" href="/Isaiah.33.11"><i>Is</i>. 33:11</a>.</i>.” Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Abba bar Zuṭra said, Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of the Great Rebbi Ḥiyya: Even most of the first, most of the last, and the middle one complete<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">If the pregnancy is recognizable, the rules of pregnancy are applicable after 61 days.</i>. Rav Assi said, a full 90 days. Samuel said, they in their fulness<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel says the same of Rav Assi, three full (i. e., 30days long) months.</i>. A case came before the rabbis there; we do not know if thirteen of the first and seventeen of the last or seventeen of the first and thirteen of the last, and five complete ones in the middle; they wanted to touch the child because of a doubt of bastardy<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">A woman gave birth to a live baby exactly 180 days after her marriage. The rabbis wondered whether such a short pregnancy was possible for a live baby or whether the short time was proof that the woman had committed adultery in the time between <i>qiddushin</i> and her actual marriage, which would make the child a bastard.</i>. Rav Naḥman bar Jacob told them, such a case came before Abba bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The most famous of Jewish medical men of his age. Presumably Samuel, also a doctor by profession, learned most of his medical knowledge from his father.</i> and he declared it acceptable. Does Abba bar Abba disagree with his son Samuel? Rebbi Abba said, there is a difference between recognizing a pregnancy and giving birth. A pregnancy is recognized after full months, a birth can happen after fractional months. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 4:5.</i>: “How long can labor be<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">As a matter of principle, blood lost during labor is neither menstrual nor of the impure type known as <i>zivah</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:25" href="/Leviticus.15.25"><i>Lev.</i> 15:25</a>). The disagreement is on how long the exemption from impurity can be claimed.</i>? Rebbi Meїr said, even 40 to 50 days. Rebbi Jehudah said, her month is sufficient. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Simeon say, no labor is longer than two weeks”. “Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Abba: This implies that a woman gives birth after fractional months. Since otherwise one should have stated “thirty days”. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Abba: This implies that a woman gives birth after full months<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">See above, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.4">Note 63</a>, and in the next paragraph.</i>. Since we have stated: “Her month is sufficient.”
Rebbi Yudan asked: Does this hold until she gives birth? No, even if she had a miscarriage<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">If the woman has a miscarriage, is her blood retroactively classified as <i>zivah</i> blood which requires a purification offering? The Babli declares that miscarriages and stillborn babies make their mother impure retroactively (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 38b" href="/Niddah.38b"><i>Niddah</i> 38b</a>).</i>.
Rebbi Mana said, I heard in the name of Samuel that there is no difference between recognizing a pregnancy and giving birth, but I do not remember from whom I heard this. Rebbi Abba bar Cohen said before Rebbi Yose, Rebbi Jeremiah said this. Rebbi Ḥizqyah said to him, Rebbi Jeremiah did not say this; Rebbi Yose was offended by him. He said to him: Even Joshua who was bound to Moses would not have said so, but you said so<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">To claim that he knew absolutely everything his teacher ever said.</i>! He checked himself and said, it is true that he said that but as a person who quotes something and questions it; does Abba bar Abba disagree with his son Samuel? Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Samuel: A woman gives birth only either after 271, 272, 273, or 274, days<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">After her last period. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 38b" href="/Niddah.38b">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 38b</a>, Mar Zuṭra is quoted that a 9 months pregnancy is 271 days, the numerical value of הריון “pregnancy” in the Alexandrian system.</i>. Rebbi Mana said to him, from whom did the rabbi hear this? He said to him, from Rebbi Abba. The position of Rebbi Abba seems inverted. There, he says, there is a difference between recognizing a pregnancy and giving birth<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">That the length of a pregnancy is not counted in full months, and here he even counts them in full months of 30 days each.</i>, and here, he says so? Rebbi Abba bar Zuṭra in the name of Samuel: {If with ה Rabba, with א Rava.}<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The text in braces is the text from <i>Yebamot</i>; it is a gloss from a student of the Babli to distinguish between quotes of Rabba רבה (Rav Abba bar Naḥmani) and Rava רבא (Rav Abba bar Rav Joseph bar Ḥama), assuming the copyists made no mistakes.</i> Everything which is “many” is 208<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text from <i>Niddah</i> and it makes sense, that if in the Pentateuch there is a promise of הרבה ארבה (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 16:10" href="/Genesis.16.10"><i>Gen</i>. 16:10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 22:17" href="/Genesis.22.17">22:17</a>) it implies a seven month birth after א + ר + ב + ה = 1+200+2+5 days. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 38b" href="/Niddah.38b">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 38b</a>, Mar Zuṭra reads <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 1:20" href="/I_Samuel.1.20"><i>1S</i>. 1:20</a> that Hanna gave birth to Samuel after 2 seasons (of 91¼ days each) and two days, or 184.5 days, barely more than 6 full months.</i>.
Rab Ḥiyya bar Ashi was sitting before Rav who saw him disturbed. He said to him, what is the matter? He said to him, my female donkey is pregnant and will give birth; then I have to get her to copulate before she is out of heat. He said to him, when did the male mount her? He said, on day X. He calculated and said, she still has some time until then. It was stated so: A quick female donkey does not need less than the days of the moon<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">354 days in a lunar year.</i> and one who is late is not later than the days of the sun<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">365 days in a solar year. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 8a" href="/Bekhorot.8a">Babli, <i>Bekhorot</i> 8a</a>, simply states that impure domestic animals have a gestation period of 12 months.</i>. The words of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi disagree, since Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, the cattle herd of the government<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Niddah 1:3:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Niddah.1.3.2-8"><i>Niddah</i> 1:4</a>: “of Antoninus”; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.3.3"><i>Kilaim,</i> Chapter 9, Note 79</a>.</i> was there for copulating and those of the house of Rebbi took bulls from them to copulate. Some of them gave birth soon and some of them later<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">It seems, later than the 11 days‘ difference allowed by Rav.</i>. Here it is about a pure animal, there about an impure animal. But is it not written, “do you know the time the mountain goats will give birth, etc.” “Count months, make them complete, you will know the time of their giving birth.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 39:1-2" href="/Job.39.1-2"><i>Job</i> 39:1–2</a>.</i>” “Do you know the time of giving birth?” A pure wild animal is like a domestic impure animal<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">This supports the prior assertion of Rav and excludes only domestic pure animals from predicting the exact time of gestation. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 16" href="/Bava_Batra.16">Babli, <i>Baba batra</i> 16a/b</a>, uses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 39:1" href="/Job.39.1"><i>Job</i> 39:1</a> to prove that the time of birth of wild animals is unpredictable. Elsewhere, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 8a" href="/Bekhorot.8a"><i>Bekhorot</i> 8a</a>, the gestation period of great predators (lions, wolves, bears, panthers) as well as apes and marmosets is given as three years.</i>.
Rebbi Meїr<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">He is the author of the anonymous opinion in the Mishnah, as asserted by R. Simeon ben Laqish in the paragraph after the next. N. Rabbinovicz in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 47a" href="/Eruvin.47a"><i>Diqduqe Soferim Erubin</i> 47a (Note כ</a>) indicates that the Soncino edition, in the quote of the Mishnah here, has “the words of Rebbi Meїr”, a reading rejected by Rashi <i>ad</i> <i>loc</i>. It seems that the Soncino text is the correct quote of a parallel Mishnah.</i> is suspicious about bills of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">He is afraid that a man who had divorced his childless wife would notice too late that she was pregnant and say that, if he had known this, he never would have divorced her. This could invalidate the bill of divorce and make the divorcee and the second husband adulterers and the child a bastard. {Therefore, in modern divorce proceedings, one lets the husband state three times before witnesses that any later action to invalidate the bill will be null and void.}</i>. Rebbi Jehudah is suspicious about a child<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">He requires waiting only in cases where there could be a question of the paternity of a child. Since bills of divorce should be handled only by a competent authority, he is confident that the case behind R. Meїr‘s restrictions is not justified.</i>. Rebbi Yose is suspicious about bills of divorce and a child<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The “and” is taken in the strict sense: Only if there is a simultaneous question about a bill of divorce <i>and</i> paternity.</i>. Could you say that Rebbi Meїr is not suspicious about bills of divorce, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">תנן is an error of the corrector under the influence of the Babli instead of תנינן.</i>: “Those that had received <i>qiddushin</i> can be married.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is stated as R. Jehudah’s opinion, it follows that R. Meїr objects. To dissolve a preliminary marriage, a bill of divorce is needed even though there normally should not be any chance of pregnancy.</i>” Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Gedula<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, he is called Rav Gidul; a Babylonian of the second generation, student of Rav, who immigrated into Galilee.</i>: The one who repudiates does not have to wait three months; the one who leaves by a bill of divorce needs to wait three months<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Both statements are about underage girls, too young to have children. If the girl had been married off by her father, she cannot repudiate her husband but needs a bill of divorce. R. Meїr requires a waiting period for all divorcees even if there is no question of a possible pregnancy. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 34b" href="/Yevamot.34b">Babli, 34b</a>, this is a statement of Samuel.</i>. This supports Rebbi Me‘ir since Rebbi Meїr is suspicious about bills of divorce. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Jeremiah: A woman who has been raped does not have to wait three months<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 35a" href="/Yevamot.35a">Babli, 35a</a>, this is a tannaitic statement attributed to R. Yose, whose opinion is interpreted to assume that she will know how to rid herself of the unwanted semen. R. Jehudah is quoted as requiring her to wait three months; his opinion is interpreted as questioning the efficacy of means to rid herself of the unwanted semen.</i>. This supports Rebbi Yose, since Rebbi Yose is suspicious about bills of divorce and a child. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallels, only the first part, dealing with waiting before marriage, is quoted. A shortened version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:6" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.6">Tosephta 6:6</a>. The text quoted here is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 35a" href="/Yevamot.35a">Babli, 35a</a>, with the same lack of coordination between nouns and verbs.</i>: The proselyte, the captive, and the slave woman who were redeemed, or converted, or freed, have to wait three months, the words of Rebbi Judah. Rebbi Yose says, they do not have to wait. Their blood<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Their menstrual blood which is an original source of impurity. Gentiles cannot impart impurity by biblical standards; the impurity of menstruation certainly is not applicable to Gentiles. Therefore, a Gentile who converts to Judaism (or becomes fully Jewish in the case of the manumitted slave) really should not be a retroactive source of impurity. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 1:2" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.1.2">Tosephta, <i>Niddah</i> 1:3</a>, the attributions are switched, and this seems to be the background both for the remark of Rebbi (not in the Tosephta) and the later discussion since in a switched version, Rebbi seems to prefer the stringency of R. Judah in the matter of remarriage. But it is difficult to change the text against the testimony of both mss. (which, however, represent the same <i>Vorlage</i>.)<br>The Babli has no possible interest in this discussion since it holds (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 36b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.36b"><i>Avodah zarah</i> 36b</a>) that all Gentile women are rabbinically permanently menstruating {and biblically married, since in talmudic theory, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 58b" href="/Sanhedrin.58b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 58b</a>, a Gentile is married to the first partner he or she is copulating with, without possibility of divorce (a position which seems to be adopted by the Apostle Paul).}</i>, Rebbi Jehudah says, makes impure 24 hours retroactively; Rebbi Yose says, from its moment onwards. Rebbi said, the words of Rebbi Judah are reasonable for the blood, and the words of Rebbi Yose for the child. Rebbi Ḥanina ben Rebbi Abbahu said, my father had a case and he asked Rebbi Ḥiyya, Rebbi Yasa, and Rebbi Immi, and they instructed him following Rebbi Yose for the child. For if it were not so, what could we say? Between Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Yose, practice does not follow Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">In the practical rules of preference, Rebbi Yose ranks over all other students and colleagues of Rebbi Aqiba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 3:1:5-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.3.1.5-6">Yerushalmi <i>Terumot</i> 3:1, Notes 20–26</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 46b" href="/Eruvin.46b">Babli <i>Erubin</i> 46b</a>).</i>? But because Rebbi said, “they are reasonable”<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">This question makes sense only if Rebbi’s preference is formulated so it endorses R. Jehudah for the rules of remarriage.</i>. Did not Rebbi Abba say in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira, every time Rebbi taught “they are reasonable”, the disagreement is unresolved except in the case of the fig cake where each party to the controversy accepts the opposition’s argument<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">This seems to refer to the disagreement between rabbis Eliezer and Joshua over pressed figs among which some heave was lost; <i>Terumot</i> Halakhah 4:10, Tosephta 5:11. In neither source is there a reference to the position taken by Rebbi.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, I stated a difficulty before Rebbi Ḥanina ben Rebbi Abbahu: Even if it is certain that they had sex? He said to him, is a normal Gentile not like one who had sex? Simeon bar Abba said, there came a case before Rebbi Joḥanan and he instructed following Rebbi Yose. Rebbi Eleazar was sorry about this; he said, one disregards the anonymous [Mishnah] and follows an isolated opinion! He found that Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The Great R. Ḥiyya, not R. Ḥiyya bar Abba mentioned earlier in this paragraph.</i> stated it in the name of Rebbi Meїr. He understood that following Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">R. Simeon ben Laqish, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.6">Note 158</a>. The question mark put in the text by the editor of the ms. is unnecessary.</i>, he found that Rebbi Ḥiyya stated it in the name of Rebbi Meїr. He said, the old man<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan.</i> certainly understands the chapters about bills of divorce.
Rebbi Mana asked before Rebbi Yudan: There Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu, said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Every place where Rebbi taught a disagreement and afterwards taught it anonymously, practice follows the anonymous Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 42b" href="/Yevamot.42b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 42b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 102a" href="/Bava_Kamma.102a"><i>Baba</i> <i>qama</i> 102a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 7a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.7a"><i>Avodah zarah</i> 7a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 11b" href="/Niddah.11b"><i>Niddah</i> 11b</a>, quotes the corresponding statement (in the name of R. Joḥanan) in a very succinct way: Disagreement followed by anonymous statement implies practice follows the anonymous statement; anonymous statement followed by disagreement implies practice does not follow the anonymous statement. Therefore, the Babli has no problem to follow R. Yose in this Halakhah. The same conclusion is reached here in the last sentence of the paragraph.</i>. And here, you say so? He said to him, if not Rebbi, maybe somebody else said it? Since when Rebbi taught a disagreement and afterwards taught it anonymously, practice follows the anonymous [text]. It must be that Rebbi did not find a disagreement in the Mishnah; but if others taught it in disagreement and Rebbi taught it anonymously, certainly practice follows the anonymous [text]. There come Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Jacob bar Abba and Rebbi Simeon bar Abba, in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Even if others taught a disagreement but Rebbi taught it anonymously, practice follows the anonymous [text]. Why does he agree here with a dissenting opinion? Rebbi Samuel ben Inaya in the name of Rebbi Aḥa. That means, if no diagreement is stated together with the anonymous [text], but if a disagreement is stated together with the anonymous [text], practice does not follow the anonymous [opinion]. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Aḥa. That is, if individual disagrees with individual. But if an individual disagrees next to<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning “after”.</i> the [anonymous] Sages, practice does not follow the anonymous [text].
Rebbi Joḥanan said, everywhere one taught anonymous Mishnaiot, it follows the rabbis unless one’s teacher explains it [differently]. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish says, all anonymous Mishnaiot follow Rebbi Meїr unless one’s teacher explains it [differently]<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, both statements are attributed to R. Joḥanan: Practice follows the anonymous Mishnah as consensus of the majority (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 43a" href="/Chullin.43a"><i>Hulin</i> 43a</a>), the formulation usually is due to R. Meїr (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 86a" href="/Sanhedrin.86a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 86a</a>). The attributions of texts in other tannaitic works stated in the latter source have no parallels in Yerushalmi sources.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said before Rebbi Yasa, not that Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagrees, only he saw that most anonymous Mishnaiot follow Rebbi Meїr. Rebbi Ze‘ira asked before Rebbi Mana: What kind of teacher? The teacher of the <i>baraita</i> or the teacher of study<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">A tannaitic source or the Amora, his personal teacher?</i>? Does not the story of Rebbi Eleazar imply, the teacher of the <i>baraita</i>? “Following Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">R. Simeon ben Laqish, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.6">Note 158</a>. The question mark put in the text by the editor of the ms. is unnecessary.</i>, he found that Rebbi Ḥiyya stated it in the name of Rebbi Meїr. He said, the old man<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan.</i> certainly understands his chapters.” We have to say that he received instruction from the teacher of the <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">When R. Eleazar questioned the decision of his teacher R. Joḥanan, he certainly did not get his information from the latter. So the “teacher” must be the author of a <i>baraita</i> to be discovered by independent research.</i> when he understood that Rebbi Ḥiyya stated it in the name of Rebbi Meїr.
The woman who performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> counts from the moment of death<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Since she cannot be freed before three months, she may remarry immediately after <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 42a" href="/Yevamot.42a">Babli, 42a</a>, follows the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 6:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).6.7">Tosephta, 6:7</a>, that a sister-in-law who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> within the first three months must wait another three months.</i>. The one who leaves by a bill of divorce counts from the moment of delivery of her bill. Rebbi Ḥanina said, from the moment of delivery of her bill. Rebbi Joḥanan said, from the moment of writing. Rav and Samuel, Rav like Rebbi Ḥanina, Samuel like Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 42a" href="/Yevamot.42a">Babli 42a</a>.</i>. Samuel objected to Rav: According to you, since you say from the moment of delivery, about what are you suspicious? Because in the meantime she was alone with him! Then one should worry about an old bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">An bill of divorce is old at the moment of delivery if husband and wife were alone together at a place where they could have intercourse. For the House of Hillel, the bill is invalid and the woman is not divorced (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.8.4.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 8:4</a>). According to Samuel, Rav should not permit the delivery of a bill of divorce if husband and wife are at the same place and the bill was not delivered on the day it was written and signed.</i>! Rebbi Ḥanina objected to Rebbi Joḥanan: According to you, since you say from the moment of writing, if there were two bills of divorce, one written now and one later, and both delivered on the same day. This one you prohibit and that one you permit!<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 18a" href="/Gittin.18a">Babli <i>Giṭṭin</i> 18a</a>.</i> What Rav objected to Samuel, Rebbi Ḥanina objected to Rebbi Joḥanan. What Rebbi Joḥanan objected to Rebbi Ḥanina, Samuel objected to Rav. Practice: She counts from the time of writing if he never was alone with her<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 42a" href="/Yevamot.42a">Babli agrees, 42a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 18a" href="/Gittin.18a"><i>Giṭṭin</i>18a</a>.</i>.
“Except the widow because of her mourning.” How much does mourning last? Thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The same in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 43b" href="/Yevamot.43b">Babli, 43b</a>.</i>. That is, for women. But for men<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">All this, including the story (attributed to Joseph the Cohen), in Babli <i>Mo‘ed. Qaṭan</i> 23a. (Except when he has nobody to serve him; current practice follows the Yerushalmi.)</i>, three holidays. If he has children; but if he does not have children immediately. If he has somebody to serve him; but if he has nobody to serve him, immediately. If he does not have small children; but if he has small children, immediately, as in the following: It happened that Rebbi Ṭarphon’s wife died. While he still was in the cemetery, he said to her sister: Come into my house and raise your sister’s children. Even though he married her, he did not know her until 30 days had passed.

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If four brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The text in the Halakhah, “four of the brothers”, is a better formulation since one speaks of a large group of brothers.</i> were married to four women and died, if their oldest [brother] wants to marry all of them in levirate, he is permitted to do so. If somebody was married to two women and he died, intercourse or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with one of them frees the co-wife. If one was acceptable and the other blemished<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">One was eligible to marry a Cohen; the other (e. g., a divorcee) was blemished in this respect. Since a woman freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is considered a divorcee for a Cohen, the chances of remarriage of the acceptable one should not be diminished. For levirate, he may take either one.</i>, if he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, he performs it with the blemished; if he takes in levirate, he takes the acceptable one.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Four of the brothers,” etc. Explanation: There were thirteen brothers, of whom twelve died childless. They [the widows] came and wanted to be married in levirate before Rebbi. He said to him, go and take in levirate. He said to him, it overtaxes my means.
