But each one of them said, I will support during my month. He said, and who will support during that intercalary month? Rebbi said, I shall support during that intercalary month. He prayed for them and they went from him. After three years they came, carrying 36 toddlers. They came and stood in front of Rebbi’s dwelling. [People] went in and told [Rebbi], outside are rural toddlers who want to greet you. Rebbi looked down from the window and saw them. He asked them, for what are you here? They said to him, we beg that you give us [support for] that intercalary month; he gave them [support for] that intercalary month.
It is written: “<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">An inexact quote of <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 13:14" href="/I_Chronicles.13.14"><i>1Chr</i>. 13:14</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:10" href="/II_Samuel.6.10"><i>2S</i>. 6:10</a>.</i> The ark of the Eternal dwelt in the house of Obed Edom for three months, and the Eternal blessed,” etc. By what did he bless him? With sons. That is what is written: “<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 26:8" href="/I_Chronicles.26.8"><i>1Chr</i>. 26:8</a>.</i> All these were from the sons of Obed Edom, they, their sons and relatives, strong men for the service, sixty” etc., because each one of them gave birth to two every month. How was that? She was impure for seven days<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Since all children were males, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:2" href="/Leviticus.12.2"><i>Lev.</i> 12:2</a>.</i>, pure for seven days, and gave birth, was impure for seven days, pure for seven days, and gave birth. Sixteen every month<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">16 grandchildren since Obed Edom had 8 sons (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 26:4-5" href="/I_Chronicles.26.4-5"><i>1Chr.</i> 26:4–5</a>).</i>, in three months 48. And he, six<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">His own wife bore him six more sons. Together with the original 8, that makes 62 in all. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 63b-64a" href="/Berakhot.63b-64a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i>63b/64a</a>, the wife and all her daughters-in-law each had one birth of sextuplets.</i>. This makes 54 together. And those eight, sum total 62. That is what was written: “<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 26:8" href="/I_Chronicles.26.8"><i>1Chr</i>. 26:8</a>.</i>62 for Obed Edom”.
Rebbi Abba bar Zavda said, it is written: “His house should be called in Israel the house of the shoe-stripped.” A house which was permitted by one stripping. The same is true for intercourse. Stripping frees and intercourse frees. What you say about stripping you say about intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the sentence in the Mishnah that action by one of the widows frees the others without more ceremony. The argument is based on the singular describing the shoe which was stripped from the levir. A similar but more involved argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 44b" href="/Yevamot.44b">Babli 44b</a>, based on the same verse.</i>.
May one apply a trick<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what kind of trick is intended. From the context, it seems that the reference is to the last clause in the Mishnah, that in case of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> the one who cannot marry a Cohen should perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. If the older brother insists on having <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other widow, may one intervene to direct another brother to consent to the more desirable <i>ḥalîṣah</i>?</i>? Did Rebbi Ṭarphon, the father of all of Israel, not apply a trick? He gave <i>qiddushin</i> to 300 women in times of famine to let them eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">This must have been during the time of the Temple since later generations forbade any non-priestly woman marrying a Cohen to eat sacred food before the actual marriage (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.3.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 5:3</a>) and R. Ṭarphon formally acquired all 300 women but married none of them.</i>! There, every one of them was able to eat heave. But here, is each one able to perform levirate? Rebbi Yudan the son of Rebbi Ismael: One deals with him is such a way<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">This must have been during the time of the Temple since later generations forbade any non-priestly woman marrying a Cohen to eat sacred food before the actual marriage (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.3.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 5:3</a>) and R. Ṭarphon formally acquired all 300 women but married none of them.</i>.

Halakhah 13

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who takes back his divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">After she had married another man, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut</i>. 24:4</a>. This is a simple prohibition.</i>, or marries the woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Since she was a candidate for levirate, the incest prohibition of a sister-in-law does not apply. She is only forbidden because of the implication of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a> that he is a man “who will not build his brother’s house.” This excludes any belated levirate with a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> as a simple prohibition.</i>, or marries a relative of the woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">She is only forbidden by rabbinic decree according to most authorities.</i>, has to divorce her<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">This is accepted universally.</i> and any child is a bastard, the words of Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">R. Aqiba holds that any child of a prohibited union is a bastard, irrespective of the severity of the prohibition, and that the prohibition of the relatives of a woman with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is biblical.</i>. But the Sages say, it is not a bastard. But they agree that the child of one who marries a relative of his divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">All relatives of a wife that are forbidden are also forbidden of an ex-wife.</i> is a bastard.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He who takes back his divorcee,” etc. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: He who takes back his divorcee after she had remarried makes her blemished for the priesthood. Without that, is she not blemished for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Any divorcee is barred from marrying a Cohen.</i>? But, she is blemished in that she cannot eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">A childless daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel can return to her parent’s house and partake of their sacred food if she is not in any way desecrated.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The daughet of a man who takes back his divorcee after she had remarried is acceptable for the priesthood. What is the reason? “She is an abomination<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut</i>. 24:4</a>. The parallel to this paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 11b" href="/Yevamot.11b">Babli 11b</a>, where the first statement of R. Ḥiyya is quoted as tannaitic and a disagreement is noted whether <i>qiddushin</i> or marriage with another man triggers the prohibition.</i>”. She is an abomination, the child is not an abomination.

Halakhah 14

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> And what is a bastard? Any [child of a] blood-relation to whom he is forbidden to come, the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Simeon from Timna<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">One of the youngest members of the Academy at Jabne.</i> says, any [child of a relation] for which one is subject to extirpation by heaven’s action<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">As detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20" href="/Leviticus.20"><i>Lev</i>. 20</a>, also including capital crimes.</i>, and practice follows him. Rebbi Joshua said, any [child of a relation] which is a capital crime.

Halakhah 15

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Simeon ben Azai said, I found a genealogical list in Jerusalem and it was written in it: The man X is a bastard from a<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">From the adultery of a married woman.</i> married woman, to support the words of Rebbi Joshua.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “What is a bastard,” etc; “Rebbi Simeon ben Azai said,” etc. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, all of them learned from the father’s wife. “A man shall not take his father’s wife and not uncover his father’s garment’s wing.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1"><i>Deut</i>. 23:1</a>. This is only half the basis of the arguments. The other is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3">verse 3</a>: No bastard shall come into the community of the Eternal. Since v. 2 speaks of men who cannot have children, v. 3 is taken to refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1">v. 1</a>, that the child of a man and his stepmother is a bastard. This is spelled out in detail in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 49a" href="/Yevamot.49a">Babli, 49a</a>.</i>” Rebbi Aqiba explains: Just as his father’s wife is special in that she is a forbidden relation from which the child is a bastard, so in any case there is a forbidden relation, the child is a bastard. They objected, is there not a widow for the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>. Everybody agrees that the child is not a bastard from any of the priestly prohibitions since it is spelled out in v. 15 that the children would be desecrated, barred from the priesthood. This case is not discussed in the Babli.</i>? There is a difference, since desecration is spelled out. Simeon from Timna explained: Just as his father’s wife is special in that one is subject to extirpation for her<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">In case there are no eye witnesses for the forbidden sex act, when there can be no criminal prosecution.</i>, the child is a bastard, so in any case that one is subject to extirpation for her, the child is a bastard. They objected, is there not the menstruating woman<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:18" href="/Leviticus.20.18"><i>Lev</i>. 20:18</a>. In the Babli, this refers to an amoraic statement.</i>? There is a difference, since “blood-relation” is not written in reference to her. Rebbi Joshua explained: Just as his father’s wife is special in that one is subject to the death penalty for her, the child is a bastard, so in any case that one is subject to the death penalty for her, the child is a bastard.
Even though Rebbi Joshua said, the child of him who sleeps with his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">A paradigm for all relations punishable by divine extirpation but not capital crimes.</i> is acceptable, he agrees that if the child was female that she is blemished for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">By rabbinic standards.</i>. Even though Rebbi Simeon ben Jehudah [says] in the name of Rebbi Simeon: If a Gentile or a slave came to a daughter of Israel, the child is acceptable, they agree that if she was female, she is blemished for the priesthood. A man came to Rav and said, since the children of this man’s mother are from an Aramean? He said, acceptable. Rav Ḥama bar Guria said to him, let your feet carry you away before Samuel comes<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 45a" href="/Yevamot.45a">Babli, 45a</a>, Samuel agrees with Rav that the child is acceptable. The opinion expressed here, that the child is permitted only to marry outside the priesthood is attributed in the Babli to R. Joshua ben Levi. The Yerushalmi decides here against its own masters, R. Joḥanan and R. Eleazar, who hold in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.6.2">Halakhah 7:6</a> that the child is a bastard.</i> and declares you blemished. Even though Rav said, if a Gentile or a slave came to a daughter of Israel, the child is acceptable, he agrees that if she was female, she is blemished for the priesthood.
Why did they say, practice follows Rebbi Simeon from Timna? <sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">A very shortened version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Horayot 2:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Horayot.2.4.2"><i>Horaiot</i> 2:4</a>; much more truncated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Horayot 8a" href="/Horayot.8a">Babli <i>Horaiot</i> 8a</a>.</i> Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, from a place where all incest prohibitions were taken as one set [of sins] causing extirpation, the father’s wife came out to tell you about the bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">All incest prohibitions (including adultery) promulgated under one heading, as one set, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> Chapter 18</a> are punishable by divine extirpation as made clear in Chapter 20. The verses about the connection between the father’s wife and the bastard are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23" href="/Deuteronomy.23"><i>Deut.</i> 23</a>. The father’s wife represents a single element of the set of incest prohibitions. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23" href="/Deuteronomy.23"><i>Deut.</i> 23</a> has no penalties spelled out. It is presumed that the penalty common to all sins mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18</a> is also understood in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23" href="/Deuteronomy.23"><i>Deut.</i>23</a>. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.13">Chapter 11, Note 63</a>.</i>. The method of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina seems inverted. There, he infers from the set and here<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The topic of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Horayot 2:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Horayot.2.4.2"><i>Horaiot</i> 2:4</a>, for which transgressions a purification sacrifice is due, <i>viz</i>., those under penalty of divine extirpation. [Simple transgressions are expiated either by the punishment imposed by the court or by sincere repentance and the Day of Atonement (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 8:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.8.6.1">Mishnah <i>Yoma</i> 8:7</a>)].</i> he infers from one of its members. As we have stated: “The commandments of the Eternal,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:2" href="/Leviticus.4.2"><i>Lev.</i> 4:2</a>, the introduction to the laws of the purifying sacrifice: “If a person sins inadvertently <i>against any of the Eternal</i>’<i>s commandments</i> about what should not be done, but he did one of these.</i>” I could think that this includes also those who eat abominations and crawling things<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Forbidden in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11" href="/Leviticus.11"><i>Lev.</i> 11</a>; these are simple prohibitions, at most punishable by whipping.</i>. You argue, saying that here it says “from the eyes<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">“Here” is the purification offering of the congregation due (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:13" href="/Leviticus.4.13"><i>Lev.</i> 4:13</a>) “if the entire congregation of Israel errs and something is hidden <i>from the eyes</i> of the community and they do one of the actions which by the commandments of the Eternal should not be done, and they do damage.” This is part of a series of 5 different statements on purification offerings. “There” is the isolated statement about the particular purification offering due for the sin of apostasy (i. e., idolatry, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:22-28" href="/Numbers.15.22-28"><i>Num.</i> 15:22–28</a>). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:24" href="/Numbers.15.24"><i>Num.</i> 15:24</a> reads: “If <i>from the eyes</i> of the congregation it was done in error.” By the hermeneutic rule of גזירה שוה “equal cut”, parallel expressions imply parallel meanings.</i>” and there it says “from the eyes”. Just as “from the eyes” mentioned there means something for which one is obligated for a purification sacrifice in case of inadvertent sin and extirpation in case of intentional sin, also “from the eyes” mentioned here means something for which one is obligated for a purification sacrifice in case of inadvertent sin and extirpation in case of intentional sin. But since “from the eyes” mentioned there is a case<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Idolatry.</i> involving the death penalty, does “from the eyes” mentioned here involve the death penalty? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, from the place from which idolatry was singled out to teach about all who are subject to extirpation, there was no mention of anything but extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">The only penalty mentioned is extirpation in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:30" href="/Numbers.15.30"><i>Num.</i> 15:30</a> for the blasphemer and idolator, offenses which at other places are classified as capital crimes.</i>. But the death penalty is written elsewhere. The method of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina seems inverted. There, he infers from the set and here he infers from one of its members! There, all incest prohibitions were taken together as to the duty of sacrifice. Idolatry was singled out to teach who is obligated for a sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Since for idolatry the sacrifices are different from those for all other sins, it is necessary to treat this separately.</i>. What can you say? Here, all incest prohibitions were taken together concerning of bastards. The father’s wife was singled out to teach about the bastard.

Halakhah 16

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If his wife died, her sister is permitted to him. If he divorced her and she died, her sister is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev.</i> 18:18</a>. If she was his wife for one minute, her sister is forbidden to him during her lifetime, by biblical standards. The same holds for the sister-in-law from a childless brother by rabbinic standards.</i>. If she had married another man and died, her sister is permitted to him. If his sister-in-law died, her sister is permitted to him. If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her and she died, her sister is permitted to him.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If his wife died, her sister is permitted to him,” etc. That means, her mother is forbidden to him<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition of the sister is the only incest prohibition lifted after the death of the wife.</i>. Did not Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa say in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If a woman waiting for her levir died, her mother is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Since there was only candidacy and that becomes void with the death of the sister-in-law; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.2-6">Halakhot 2:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:8:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.8.2-4">4:8</a>, <i>Soṭa</i>2:5.</i>. But since we stated: “If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her and she died, her sister is permitted to him,” therefore he stated “her sister<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Since rabbinically, all close relatives of the sister-in-law except the sister remain forbidden.</i>.”

Chapter 5



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rabban Gamliel says, there is no bill of divorce after a bill of divorce, no “bespeaking” after “bespeaking”, no copulation after copulation, and no <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">If the childless brother left two widows and either brother gave a bill of divorce to both of them, or two brothers each gave a bill of divorce to one of them, the second bill of divorce has no legal value; the giver of the bill may marry any of the relatives of the sister-in-law who received the invalid document.<br>While a bill of divorce has no standing in levirate proceedings, it is an old rabbinic tradition that the delivery of a bill of divorce by one of the brothers prohibits all the widows from marrying any of the brothers as if it were a bill of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. For the freeing of the widows, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is still needed.<br>Similarly, if one of the brothers “bespoke” one of the widows, any later “bespeaking” of any other widow is null and void.<br>The parallel statement for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is obvious since by biblical standards the act prohibits all widows for all brothers for all times.</i>. But the Sages say, there is a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce and “bespeaking” after “bespeaking”, but nothing after copulation or after <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The Sages hold that no act which is only rabbinically valid has the power to eliminate biblical requirements; only levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> can be final.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Her levir shall come upon her”, that is cohabitation. “And take her as a wife for himself”, that is “bespeaking”. I might think that just as cohabitation is final so “bespeaking” is final; the verse says “her levir shall come upon her.” This directs the entire paragraph towards levirate. Cohabitation is final, “bespeaking” is not final. Then what is “bespeaking” good for? To forbid her to the brothers.
Rebbi Simeon says, “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire. What is the argument of Rebbi Simeon? “Her levir shall come upon her”, that is cohabitation. “And take her for himself”, that is “bespeaking”. Just as cohabitation is final so “bespeaking” is final. Or “her levir shall come upon her”, then she has been acquired by him and “bespeaking” was of no use to her.
Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh says, “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely. What is the argument of Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh? “And take her as wife for himself”, the same expression is used as for <i>qiddushin</i> of a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In both cases, the divorce document is meaningless and there is no relationship between the levir and the third widow. Cf. Tosephta 7:5 and Note 99.</i>. Just as <i>qiddushin</i> acquire completely, so “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely. What is the formula for “bespeaking” a sister-in-law? “You are betrothed to me by money or money’s worth.”
Since the rabbis say, “bespeaking” acquires but not completely, so they say, a bill of divorce frees but not completely. <sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The arguments of this paragraph (except the last one) are repeated in a few short lines in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 14a" href="/Kiddushin.14a">Babli <i>Qiddushin</i> 14a</a>.</i> Should not a bill of divorce completely free a sister-in-law by an argument <i>de minore ad majus?</i> Since <i>ḥalîṣah</i> does not free a wife<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">To marry another man.</i> but a bill of divorce does, is it not logical that a sister-in-law, who is freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, should be freed by a bill of divorce? The verse says, “she shall pull off.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Pulling off the levir’s shoe; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>. The Babli points to another part of the same verse, “<i>so</i> it should be done”, so and not otherwise.</i>” By pulling off she is freed; she is not freed by a bill of divorce. So it should free anything! It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5</a>.</i>: “She shall not belong … to a strange man.” Where do we hold? If he came upon her, she is his wife. If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her, she should go and marry an outsider. So we must hold that he gave her a bill of divorce. Also Ḥizqiah stated thus: From where that the sister-in-law is forbidden to himself and his brothers if he gave her a bill of divorce? For him, I read “whom he had sent away<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut.</i> 24:4</a>, speaking about the divorced wife.</i>”. For the brothers, I read “whom he had sent away”. Then should not <i>ḥalîṣah</i> free a wife by an argument <i>de minore ad majus?</i> Since a bill of divorce does not free a sister-in-law but <i>ḥalîṣah</i> does, is it not logical that a wife, who is freed by a bill of divorce, should be freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? The verse says, “<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1"><i>Deut.</i> 24:1</a>.</i> he shall write her a bill of divorce.” By a bill of divorce she is freed; she is not freed by <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> So [<i>ḥalîṣah</i>] should free partially! There, it is written, “she shall not belong … to a strange man.” Here, what do you have<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">There is no verse indicating any action of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> on the status of a married woman.</i>?
Since Rebbi Simeon says, “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire, does he say similarly that a bill of divorce frees or does not free? Let us hear from the following: Rebbi Simeon says, there is nothing after copulation if it is primary<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Mishnah and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.8.2">Halakhah 7</a>.</i>. Therefore, if it is secondary, there is something afterwards. That must deal with copulation after a bill of divorce. For if it were copulation after “bespeaking”, what could you say? If “bespeaking” acquired, there is nothing after that. If “bespeaking” did not acquire, intercourse will acquire and there is nothing after that. So we must speak about copulation after a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">If he gave a bill of divorce to one of the widows and afterwards had intercourse with the second, the second is his wife and the first, who is forbidden to him, needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in addition to her bill of divorce.</i>. This implies that a bill of divorce frees partially<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">He is certain that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is required after the bill of divorce; it is not a matter of doubt.</i>.
Does Rabban Gamliel follow Rebbi Simeon to say that “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire? And here, against Rebbi Simeon that a bill of divorce frees or does not free? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 7:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).7.3">Tosephta 7:3</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 51a" href="/Yevamot.51a">Babli 51a</a>.</i>: “Rabban Gamliel agrees with the Sages that there may be a bill of divorce after ‘bespeaking’<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">If there were two widows, and he “bespoke” the first and gave a bill of divorce to the second, the first and the relatives of both of them are now forbidden to him.</i> and ‘bespeaking’ after a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If he gave a bill of divorce to the first and “bespoke” the second, the second also needs a bill of divorce.</i>, a bill of divorce after intercourse and ‘bespeaking’, and ‘bespeaking’ after intercourse and a bill of divorce.” How can there be a bill of divorce after intercourse and “bespeaking”? There were three sisters-in-law. He “bespoke” one, had intercourse with another, and gave a bill of divorce to the third<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The bill of divorce is not meaningless; the relatives of the third widow are forbidden to him.</i>. This implies that “bespeaking” acquires partially. If you would say that “bespeaking” either acquires or does not acquire then, as you take it, if “bespeaking” acquired, there can be nothing after that. If “bespeaking” did not acquire, intercourse should acquire and there should be nothing after that<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In both cases, the divorce document is meaningless and there is no relationship between the levir and the third widow. Cf. Tosephta 7:5 and Note 99.</i>. This implies that “bespeaking” acquires partially<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This makes the intercourse with the second widow partially incestuous.</i>. How can there be “bespeaking” after intercourse and a bill of divorce? If there were three sisters-in-law. He gave a bill of divorce to one, had intercourse with another, and “bespoke” the third. This implies that a bill of divorce frees partially. If you would say that a bill of divorce either frees or does not free then, as you take it, if a bill of divorce frees, there can be nothing after that. If a bill of divorce does not free, intercourse should acquire and there should be nothing after that<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In both cases, the divorce document is meaningless and there is no relationship between the levir and the third widow. Cf. Tosephta 7:5 and Note 99.</i>. This implies that a bill of divorce frees partially<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This makes the intercourse with the second widow partially incestuous.</i>. Does Rabban Gamliel follow Rebbi Simeon? There is no “bespeaking” after “bespeaking” a sister-in-law following Rebbi Simeon. But the argument of one is different from the argument of the other. The argument of Rabban Gamliel: any part which a “bespeaking” of the the second could acquire in the future, the first already had acquired<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Since the form of the legal action of “bespeaking” is not dependent on the person who acts.</i>. Any part which a bill of divorce from the second [brother] could free in the future, the bill of divorce of the first already had freed. The reasoning of Rebbi Simeon: If the first [brother] acquired, so did the second<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The second brother cannot acquire anything since he was preempted by the first.</i>. If the first [brother] did not acquire, neither did the second. If the first [bill of divorce] did not free, neither did the second<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">If one levir gave bills of divorce to two sisters-in-law, neither of them goes free without <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for herself.</i>.
Is there a possibility of a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking” or of “bespeaking” after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking” for Rabban Gamliel? What is a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”? If there were two sisters-in-law, he “bespoke” one of them and gave her a bill of divorce; then he gave a bill of divorce to the second. If you say that a bill of divorce frees, anything “bespeaking” had acquired is subject to the bill of divorce; there is no bill of divorce after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The second divorce is invalid and the levir may marry any relative of the second widow.</i>. If you say that a bill of divorce does not free, for anything “bespeaking” had acquired there is no bill of divorce; there is a bill of divorce after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Both widows and their relatives are forbidden to the levir.</i>. What is “bespeaking” after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”? If there were two sisters-in-law, he “bespoke” one of them and gave her a bill of divorce; then he “bespoke” the second. If you say that a bill of divorce frees more than anything “bespeaking” had acquired, it is as if there were no “bespeaking” and there may be “bespeaking” after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">This is a theory not found elsewhere, that a divorce after (rabbinic) “bespeaking” should annul the consequences of “bespeaking” both for him, that all co-wives of the bespoken are no longer forbidden, and seemingly also for the other brothers,that the widows become permitted again for the “bespeaking” by another brother.<br>Since practice does not follow Rabban Gamliel, no answer is given. For the Sages, the answer is given in the next Halakhah.</i>. But if you say that a bill of divorce does not free more than he had acquired by “bespeaking”, there is “bespeaking” but no “bespeaking” after a bill of divorce for “bespeaking”.
In the opinion of Rabban Gamliel, can there be invalid intercourse after invalid intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">For example, the intercourse with the second of three widows discussed above. The question is whether a second intercourse would be unquestionably incestuous.</i>, or the intercourse of a nine-years-old after the intercourse of [another] nine-years-old<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.2">Chapter 3, Note 143</a>. Both children between 9 and 13 years old are supposed to be levirs of the widow.</i>, or invalid intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">By an adult.</i> after the intercourse of a nine-years-old, or intercourse of a nine-years-old after invalid intercourse? Do the Sages agree with Rabban Gamliel that there cannot be “bespeaking” after “bespeaking” for one sister-in-law? How is that? If he “bespoke” his sister-in-law, gave her a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">For the Sages, this makes the widow forever forbidden to all brothers.</i>, and “bespoke” her again. If you say, there can be “bespeaking” after “bespeaking”, she did not become free by that bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">She needs a divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. If you say, there cannot be “bespeaking” after “bespeaking”, she was freed by that bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">She still needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since she was not married in levirate.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">A similar paragraph in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.3">Chapter 3, Notes 102–105</a>.</i> Rebbi Yudan asked: If somebody gave <i>qiddushin</i> to a woman “from now and after thirty days” and her sister became a candidate for levirate with him during these thirty days, is there even in this case no “bespeaking” after “bespeaking<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Since biblical <i>qiddushin</i> are certainly stronger that rabbinic “bespeaking”, is his wife immune to the influence of her sister who became a candidate for levirate?</i>? He said, Rabban Gamliel said only “after a bill of divorce and ‘bespeaking’ ”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel did not mention <i>qiddushin</i> as excluding further action. Therefore, the claim of her sister forbids the woman to her prospective husband.<br>For the statement of R. Abbahu, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.4.3">Chapter 3, Notes 102–105</a>.</i>. But what Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, even a hundred <i>qiddushin</i> are valid for her, does not follow Rabban Gamliel.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">How are the rules of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> handled? This Mishnah is not a continuation of the previous one.</i>? If he “bespoke” his sister-in-law and gave her a bill of divorce, she needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> from him<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Since he started to divorce her, she is forbidden to him. He must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her and may not take her in levirate.</i>. If he “bespoke” and participated in <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> she needs a bill of divorce from him<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Since “bespeaking” is the formal equivalent of <i>qiddushin</i>, it can be dissolved only by (rabbinic) divorce.</i>. If he “bespoke” her and copulated, that is as it is commanded.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How? If he “bespoke” his sister-in-law,” etc. That means<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah which demands <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after “bespeaking” and divorce. Since it excludes levirate, it shows that the bill of divorce invalidated both “bespeaking” and candidacy.</i> that a bill of divorce frees more than anything “bespeaking” had acquired. If you would say that a bill of divorce does not free more than “bespeaking” had acquired, the levir could say: My bill of divorce shall not free more than my “bespeaking” had acquired<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">By excluding candidacy, he wants to reserve the right to levirate. This would prevent the widow from marrying outside the family. The entire proceeding is invalidated since a divorce is only valid if the divorcee has the unconditional right of remarriage.</i>. But then the bill of divorce did not even free what my “bespeaking” had acquired! “Cutting off<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1"><i>Deut.</i> 24:1</a>; the divorcing husband has to write “a document of cutting off” all his ties with her. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 52b" href="/Yevamot.52b">Babli, 52b</a>, notes that the rules of a purely rabbinic bill of divorce cannot well be grounded in biblical verses. The argument has to be classified as an intimation, rather than a proof.</i>.” That is no cutting off!
<i>Ḥalîṣah</i> against the rules frees<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a woman who was “bespoken” and did not yet receive her divorce document.</i>. In which respect? That if an outsider comes and gives <i>qiddushin</i> to her co-wife, they will lay hold of her<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">She certainly is freed by her co-wife’s <i>ḥalîṣah. Qiddushin</i> “lay hold of” a woman if the marriage is valid and the woman is forbidden to any other man by the laws of adultery. In this case, it is not only valid but also legal.</i>. If an outsider came and gave her<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The widow who was “bespoken” and performed <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i> <i>qiddushin,</i> since the candidacy from the deceased was removed from her<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">By biblical law, she is forbidden to all levirs.</i>, the <i>qiddushin</i> will lay hold of her, or maybe, since she still needs a bill of divorce for her “bespeaking”, the <i>qiddushin</i> will not lay hold of her?
Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, this means that there is an obligation first to give <i>qiddushin</i> and only after that to cohabit. Since here, where <i>qiddushin</i> are not written, you say “that is as it is commanded”, for a wife, where it is written, not so much more<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last statement of the Mishnah, that an orderly levirate is preceded by “bespeaking”. It is asserted that an orderly regular marriage is also preceded by <i>qiddushin</i> since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:13" href="/Deuteronomy.22.13"><i>Deut.</i> 22:13</a> prescribes that a man has to acquire a wife before cohabiting with her: “If a man acquires a wife and comes to her …” Even though in theory a marriage could be effected in criminal law and consummated in civil law by one act of cohabitation, this is frowned upon since the act is only valid if performed in the presence of two witnesses; the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 52a" href="/Yevamot.52a">Babli agrees emphatically (52a</a>).</i>!

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he delivered a bill of divorce and then “bespoke”, she needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> If he delivered a bill of divorce and then cohabited, she needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> If he delivered a bill of divorce and then performed <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nothing more is needed.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he delivered a bill of divorce and then “bespoke”, etc. A bill of divorce for his “bespeaking” and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for her candidacy<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The bill of divorce is only enough to forbid the widow to himself and all brothers but it does not fulfill the requirements of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–9</a>. Since “bespeaking” is rabbinic, the bill of divorce will be rabbinic (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 50b" href="/Yevamot.50b">Babli 50b</a>).</i>.
That means<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement that intercourse after divorce is invalid; it is incestuous. The sister-in-law may not become his wife. Therefore, a co-wife is not freed to marry outside the family.</i> that invalid intercourse does not free. Come and see, invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">An invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is one where levirate is impossible, as in the last case of the Mishnah. As the Mishnah notes, a <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is always final.</i> frees but invalid intercourse does not free! Since the purpose of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalidation, it frees. Intercourse, whose purpose is not invalidation, does not free. It should not free for leniency but might free for restriction. In which respect? If somebody came and gave <i>qiddushin</i> to the co-wife, these should lay hold on her. Rebbi Yudan said, I explained it. Any sister-in-law who is not totally outside remains inside until she leaves for the outside<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Since a widow under the obligation of levirate in unable to contract another marriage before the candidacy for levirate is lifted for her, no widow can remarry outside the family as long as not all required ceremonies have been performed.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, “bespoke” her, gave a bill of divorce, and cohabited<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">After <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, no transaction is legal between the levir and the widow.<br>“Bespeaking” and the bill of divorce become nonexistent, and the inter course incestuous.</i>, or cohabited, “bespoke”, gave a bill of divorce, and performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, nothing is valid after <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, “bespeaking” and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> are nonexistent. He married and then divorced the sister-in-law.</i>. There is no difference between one sister-in-law or two sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">This really is an introduction to the following Mishnaiot.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he performed <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> ‘bespoke’,” etc. Even though they said there is no <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> intercourse after <i>ḥalîṣah</i> disables her from priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">A second<i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid; it is as if it had never happened. But illicit sex always has consequences, whether in connection with levirate or not. The statement is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 7:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).7.5">Tosephta 7:5</a>.</i>. Is she not disabled from priesthood anyhow<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>ḥalîṣah</i> rabbinically is considered an equivalent of divorce, the widow of a childless man is always forbidden to marry a Cohen unless she is married in levirate.</i>? But she is disabled from eating heave<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">If she is the childless daughter of a Cohen; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:13:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.13.2">Chapter 4, Note 206</a>.</i>. If he had intercourse with the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> did he disable her from eating heave<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is predicated on the arguments in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.18">Chapter 1, Notes 80–88</a>, where it is held that probably for R. Joḥanan sexual contact of a levir with the widowed sister-in-law is never punishable. If it is not punishable, it cannot exclude the childless widow from returning to her priestly family.</i>? It must be that his brothers copulated with her. That agrees with the position that he is not guilty about the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> but his brothers are guilty about the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> But following the position that neither he nor his brothers are guilty about the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? It must be that he had intercourse with the co-wife. That agrees with the position that everybody agrees that he is guilty about the co-wife. But following the position that neither he nor his brothers are guilty about the co-wife? It must be that his brothers had intercourse with the co-wife. That agrees with the position that neither he nor his brothers are guilty about the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but are guilty about the co-wife. But following the position that neither he nor his brothers are guilty about either the woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or the co-wife? It must follow Rebbi Aqiba, since Rebbi Aqiba says that a bastard may come from a woman who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.18">Chapter 1, Note 80</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, explain it that the levir was a Cohen, had intercourse with her and desecrated her<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Once she is considered a divorcee in relation to a Cohen, <i>any</i> sexual relation with a Cohen desecrates her; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:6:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.6.7">Chapter 1, Note 239</a>.</i>.
“If he gave a bill of divorce, and <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> nothing is valid after <i>ḥalîṣah,</i>” etc. Did we not state already<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i> “there is nothing after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>”? Because we stated after that, “whether there is one sister-in-law or two sisters-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> it is not clear that after <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one widow all actions with regard to the other are also as if nonexistent.</i>”. If somebody gave <i>qiddushin</i> to the one with whom he performed <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> would they not lay hold on her<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Since it was established in Chapter 1 that the widow is at most forbidden by a simple prohibition, not threatened by divine extirpation, it is clear that <i>qiddushin</i> by one of the brothers will be illegal but valid.</i>? Explain it either following Rebbi if he did not intend it or according to everybody if he intended to acquire as “bespeaking” of a sister-in-law but she was not his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">While “bespeaking” has the external form of <i>qiddushin</i>, their rules are quite different. After <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, any “bespeaking” is impossible; an action of “bespeaking” is null and void but the same action with the intent of <i>qiddushin</i> in valid. The same position is taken in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 52b" href="/Yevamot.52b">Babli, 52b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abba said, this was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">A different but parallel formulation in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 19b" href="/Yevamot.19b">Babli, 19b</a>.</i>: “ ‘Bespeaking’ acquires whether intentional or not intentional, the words of Rebbi. But the Sages say, it acquires only with intention<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">For them, “bespeaking” follows the rules of <i>qiddushin</i> as closely as possible.</i>. Rebbi agrees that <i>qiddushin</i> acquire only with intention.” What is Rebbi’s reason? Intercourse acquires, “bespeaking” acquires. Just as intercourse acquires whether intentional or not intentional<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>.</i>, so “bespeaking” acquires whether intentional or not intentional. And just as Rebbi says, “bespeaking” acquires whether intentional or not intentional, so he says the bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The divorce document for “bespeaking”, which cannot exist without the groom’s initiative, can be delivered without getting the widow’s attention. Nothing is implied for divorce of an original marriage.</i> frees whether intentional or not intentional. And why does Rebbi say that “bespeaking” acquires whether intentional or not intentional? Since intercourse of an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">But not of a minor. Since a minor can act in practice but not in law, “bespeaking”, <i>qiddushin</i>, and divorce are not applicable to minors.</i> acquires whether intentional or not intentional. Even if the bill of divorce would free even if not intentional, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> can free only if it is intentional<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ḥalîṣah</i> is enacted by both parties; it cannot happen without conscious participation of both parties.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How? If he “bespoke” both of them, they need two bills of divorce and a <i>ḥalîṣah</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">By “bespeaking” one of them, he forbade the co-wife for himself (and the other brothers). By “bespeaking” both, he forbade both for himself and has to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with one of them.</i>. If he “bespoke” one and copulated with the other, they need two bills of divorce and a <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The intercourse was illegal, he may not keep his wife and has to divorce her. The first one needs a rabbinic divorce for her rabbinic “bespeaking”.</i>. If he “bespoke” one and gave a bill of divorce to the other, [the first one] needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Giving a bill of divorce to a sister-in-law forbids her and her co-wives to himself. Therefore, he is forbidden to marry the one he “bespoke” and has to free her by both a divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. If he “bespoke” one and performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other, the first one needs a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">She became forbidden to him by the other’s <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If there are bills of divorce for both of them, they need a <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">As if no divorce had happened. However, both are forbidden to him and to any Cohen.</i>. If there is a bill of divorce to one and he copulated with the other, [the latter] needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 72. The case is repeated to show that the order in which the acts follow one another is irrelevant.</i>. If he gave a bill of divorce to one and “bespoke” the other, [the second one] needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The intercourse was illegal, he may not keep his wife and has to divorce her. The first one needs a rabbinic divorce for her rabbinic “bespeaking”.</i>. If he gave a bill of divorce to one and performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other, nothing follows after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How? If he ‘bespoke’,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">This is a direct continuation of the previous paragraph.</i> In the opinion of Rebbi, what about his “bespeaking”, may a nine-year-old “bespeak”? The intercourse of an adult is final; his “bespeaking” partially acquires. The intercourse of a minor is final<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">It is not really final since a minor cannot acquire. However, since the sister-in-law becomes a wife of the levir by the fact of cohabitation irrespective of any thought process, the only way she might be freed from the underage levir is by divorce, which requires an adult partner. So, while she becomes the wife of the levir to the effect that adultery on her part will be a capital crime only through intercourse after he will have reached the age of 13 years and one day, in all other aspects she is his wife from the day of her first copulation.</i>; does his “bespeaking” partially acquire? What is the difference between his intercourse and his “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The answer is too simple to need spelling out: Intercourse is an act of reality which is in the power of the minor; “bespeaking” is a legal act outside the power of a minor.</i>? But some want to formulate: What is the difference between “bespeaking” of an adult and “bespeaking” of a minor? Samuel said, the words of Rebbi Meïr: They made the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 96a" href="/Yevamot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>, this is generally accepted. “Bespeaking” which does not lead to marriage has to be dissolved by divorce, which is outside the power of a minor.</i>. And as you said, they made the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult, they made the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult. But the rabbis said, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day is nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">The last two sentences have no parallel in the Babli.</i>. And why did they make the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult? Because the intercourse of an adult acquires whether intentional or not intentional<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The mind of neither party has to be engaged in this activity; therefore, it is applicable to a minor.</i>. The <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day was made like a bill of divorce by an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This is R. Meïr’s opinion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 96a" href="/Yevamot.96a">Babli, 96a</a>. The divorce of a “bespoken” woman is insufficient to free her for outside marriage; so is the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of the minor. She remains forbidden for everyone, levir or unrelated, until she is freed after the minor grows up.</i>. But <i>ḥalîṣah</i> by an adult can free only if it is intentional<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Probably addition by the scribe from the preceding paragraph.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah deals with the case of one levir and two sisters-in-law. It is understood that in any group, the first action refers to the first widow, the second to the second, but not both to one woman sequentially.</i>, performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> and “bespoke”<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The second <i>ḥaliṣah</i> is void; the second widow is not forbidden for a Cohen nor are her close relatives forbidden to the levir.</i>, gave a divorce document and copulated<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The intercourse was illegal, he may not keep his wife and has to divorce her. The first one needs a rabbinic divorce for her rabbinic “bespeaking”.</i>, or copulated with both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">He is married to the first; the relationship with the second was incestuous and no marital relationship was established with her.</i>, or copulated and “bespoke”<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The act of “bespeaking” is legally nonexistent.</i>, gave a divorce document and performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Case already treated in Mishnah 5:3.</i>, nothing comes after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, whether there are two sisters-in-law and one levir or two levirs with one sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The second case is treated at the beginning of the next Mishnah in a repetetive manner.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> and “bespoke”, gave a divorce document and copulated, or copulated and “bespoke”, gave a divorce document and performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i>, nothing comes after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, whether at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>ḥalîṣah</i> removes the widow from the family for good, no action of any levir after <i>ḥaliṣah</i> can establish a marriage relationship or dissolve one. “In the middle” is only possible if there are more than two widows or levirs.</i>. But in the case of copulation, nothing comes after it when it is at the start<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow is married to the levir.</i>’<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The anonymous majority holds that the intercourse required by the verse is one with an otherwise unencumbered widow. But if the widow has any claim or prohibition concerning another levir on her, they deny that any intercourse can have the status of fulfillment of the requirement of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>.</i>. Rebbi Neḥemiah says, nothing comes after copulation or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, whether at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">For him, the first intercourse always has biblical status except if it comes after <i>ḥaliṣah</i> when it is incestuous. <i>Ḥaliṣah</i> after intercourse is meaningless; the marriage can be dissolved only by a regular divorce.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with both of them, performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> and ‘bespoke’,” etc. “If he performed <i>ḥaliṣah</i> and ‘bespoke’,” etc. There<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. The statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 111a" href="/Yevamot.111a">Babli, 111a</a>. This is the simple understanding one has of the Mishnah since copulation is improper if it does not occur at the beginning.</i>, they say: The words of Rebbi Neḥemiah that an improper copulation frees. In the opinion of the rabbis there copulation frees, whether after “bespeaking” or after a bill of divorce. In the opinion of the rabbis here, intercourse after “bespeaking” frees; after a bill of divorce it does not free<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">No reason is given for the distinction. The Babli gives reasons why there should be a difference, <i>viz</i>., as a “fence around the law”. There is no indication that the Yerushalmi considers any statement about the consequences of “bespeaking” or divorce as being about “fences around the law”.</i>. They did not hear that Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Rebbi Neḥemiah, Rebbi Simeon, and Rebbi Ismael all said the same<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The name tradition is uncertain. Ms. A reads: ר׳ נחמיה ור׳ שנ׳ע ור׳ שמוא׳. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 51a" href="/Yevamot.51a">Babli (51a</a>) has:רבן גמליאל ובית שמי וּבן עזאי ורבי נחמיה. Rabban Gamliel’s opinion is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>. R. Simeon holds that maybe “bespeaking” acquires completely; this would imply that in the case of the Tosephta, the intercourse of the second does not free the first widow. Similarly, for the House of Shammai, “bespeaking” acquires by biblical standards. The relevant statement of R. Ismael is not recorded.</i>. As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 7:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).7.5">Tosephta 7:5</a>.</i>: “If there were three sisters-in-law for one levir, he ‘bespoke’ one, copulated with the second, and gave a bill of divorce to the third. Rebbi Neḥemiah says, the first one needs a bill of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, but after copulation there is nothing. An argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>. If nothing comes after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, which excludes her from the priesthood, whether she copulated or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, then it is only logical that nothing should come after intercourse which does not exclude her from the priesthood, whether she copulated or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. But for the rabbis he is forbidden the relatives of all three of them and they need three bills of divorce and <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Since the intercourse is invalid; the second widow is his wife but he must divorce her.</i>.”

Chapter 6



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody comes to his sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Widow of his childless brother.</i>, whether in error<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">He did not realize that she was his sister-in-law.</i>, or criminally<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Either he intended extramarital intercourse or he did not know that she was permitted to him.</i>, or under duress<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Someone forced him to have intercourse.</i>, or willingly<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">He intended to fulfill the biblical commandment. That case is not needed but it is mishnaic style always to mention באונס וברצון together.</i>, even if he is in error and she acts criminally, or he does it criminally but she is in error, or he is under duress but she is not, or she is under duress but he is not, whether he touched or completed<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The exact meaning of this term is discussed in the Halakhah. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.3">Chapter 4, Note 59</a>.</i>, he acquired her and there is no difference between intercourse and intercourse.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody comes to his sister-in-law,” etc. We have stated: “Even if he is in error and she acts criminally, or he does it criminally but she is in error.” Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 53b" href="/Yevamot.53b">Babli, 53b</a>.</i>: Even if both act in error, even if both act criminally. They wanted to say, a hearing person who is competent acquires both if he has the intention and if he does not have the intention but the deaf-mute, who is not competent, should acquire only if he has the intention. It was found that Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: Both the deaf-mute and the insane who copulated acquired [the widow] and freed the co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> requires only that “the levir should come upon her” for valid levirate. Marriage needs the intentional participation of both partners. Therefore the mentally incompetent cannot marry by biblical standards. But levirate of a mentally incompetent person is marriage by biblical standards.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The multiple explanation of the multiple expressions in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> is also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 54a" href="/Yevamot.54a">Babli, 54a</a>, in a different formulation.</i>“Her levir shall come upon her”, when he is aware of it. “And take her as a wife for himself”, when he is not aware of it. “And take her in levirate”, even against his will. “Her levir shall come upon her”, when she is aware of it. “And take her as a wife for himself”, when she is not aware of it. “And take her in levirate”, even against her will. “Her levir shall come upon her”, in the usual way. “And take her as a wife for himself”, not in the usual way. “And take her in levirate”, even from the side<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The expression “her levir shall come <i>upon</i> her” is not to be taken to mean that the act is only valid if the levir actually lies on top of the woman.</i>. “Her levir shall come upon her”, in a completed intercourse. “And take her as a wife for himself”, in incomplete intercourse. “And take her in levirate”, even if only touching.
What is touching<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 55b" href="/Yevamot.55b">Babli, 55b</a>, the statement of Samuel is formulated more graphically, that touching the female genital by the male must necessarily make a small indentation which is the act of acquisition. The opinion of R. Joḥanan is quoted in rather confusing three ways.</i>? Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel: That the finger should be seen between the lips. Rebbi Joḥanan said, until the gland enters. Rebbi Abba bar Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: When the gland has entered that is completion of intercourse. What are we dealing with<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The two statements of R. Joḥanan must refer to two different categories of laws.</i>? If about incest prohibitions, He made the one who touches equal to him who finishes<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">In the list of punishments for sexual offenses, “touching” is mentioned as the offense in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:18-19" href="/Leviticus.20.18-19"><i>Lev</i>. 20:18–19</a>.</i>. If for a bound slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:20-22" href="/Leviticus.19.20-22"><i>Lev</i>. 19:20–22</a>. The quasi adultery of a man with a slave girl which was somehow betrothed before she was manumitted is punishable only if there was ejaculation. {Tosaphot, Babli 55b, <i>s. v</i>. אינו, interprets the Babli as making the intercourse punishable in the moment an ejaculation leading to a pregnancy was possible even if none actually occured. It is impossible to read this into the text of the Yerushalmi.}</i>, until he ejaculates, since Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Abba bar Mamal, said in the name of Rav: “Flow of semen”, until he ejaculates. But we must deal with a widow for the High Priest. When he touched her, he became guilty for desecrating her. When the gland entered, he became guilty for having intercourse. When he ejaculated, he became guilty because “he shall not desecrate his semen in his people.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:15" href="/Leviticus.21.15"><i>Lev</i>. 21:15</a>. Since the three sins are committed at three different times, he can be indicted and punished for three different crimes without any question of competition of laws. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 78a" href="/Kiddushin.78a">Babli, <i>Qiddushin</i> 78a</a>, it is noted that the language of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a> implies that he can be punished for the second offense only if he actually had married the widow.</i>”
There<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:1. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 41b" href="/Niddah.41b">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 41b</a>, the names between R. Joḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish are switched.</i>, we have stated: “All women become impure in the outer cavity<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The impurity of menstrual blood is not dependent on the blood being visible outside her body; it is enough to be close to the vagina.</i>.” What is the outer cavity? Rebbi Joḥanan said, up to the place which is seen when girls sit down to urinate. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said to him, but in all impurities particular to her, she becomes impure only up to the place of teeth<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Impurities cannot be transmitted inside body cavities. For food, this means that impure food thrown into one’s mouth will not result in any impurity of the eater if it touches the walls of the mouth behind the tetth (except carcass meat). By analogy, anything happening in the womb of a woman inside of a place which can be considered corresponding to the teeth in the mouth cannot have any influence on her status of purity. The Yerushalmi to <i>Niddah</i> 5 is lost; in the Babli, Rav Jehudah defined the “teeth” as the place reached by the male organ during intercourse. That place is defined as being open to the outer world since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:18" href="/Leviticus.15.18"><i>Lev</i>. 15:18</a> decrees that semen causes impurity in the body of the woman.</i>. Rebbi Zakkai stated: Up to the place of teeth, and from between the teeth to the inside. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Samuel: The entire genitals are called “outer cavity”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">This statement has no parallel in the Babli.</i>.
“He acquired her and there is no difference between intercourse and intercourse.” What did he acquire<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In any of the kinds of intercourse, incomplete or involuntary, which would not be valid as betrothal of an unincumbered woman.</i>? Samuel said, he acquired only the things spelled out in the paragraph: To inherit the deceased’s property, (to be betrothed by a brother)<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This clause is questionable. It makes sense that any of the questionable kinds of intercourse is valid only as a betrothal (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>), not as marriage (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:21" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.21">Chapter 1, Note 95</a>). However, the clause is missing in ms. A (confirmed by <i>Tosaphot Sens</i>), and is quoted as לאוסרה לאחיו “to forbid her to his brothers” in <i>Arukh, s. v.</i> דבר א׳. One may assume that a compilor of a dictionary is more careful in his quotes than any other medieval author.</i>, and to permit her co-wife to the outside<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">But if she died before the actual marriage, he would not inherit from her.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56a" href="/Yevamot.56a">Babli, 56a</a>, this is the position of Rav. He and R. Joḥanan hold that intercourse, even of a questionable kind, with the sister-in-law effects marriage, not betrothal.</i> said, he acquired everything. Rebbi Isaac ben Eleazar said, when do they disagree? If he touched her. But if he completed the intercourse, everybody agrees that he acquired everything. Rebbi Mattaniah said, when do they disagree? If he had intercourse with her still in her father’s house. But if he had intercourse with her still in her husband’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Either the deceased first husband’s (which becomes the levir’s property by this intercourse) or the levir’s. It is agreed that in this situation, there is marriage not betrothal.</i>, everybody agrees that he acquired everything. Rebbi Yose said, the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.1">Mishnah 4:4</a>.</i> said: If he married her, she is his wife in every respect.
May she eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">After an unintentional intercourse. This is a direct continuation of the previous discussion since if the levir acquires every power the husband had, then his wife eats heave and other sanctified food by biblical decree (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>). In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56a" href="/Yevamot.56a">Babli, 56a</a>, the position of R. Joḥanan is again represented by Rav.</i>? Rebbi Abba in the name of Samuel: It is reasonable that she should eat if she was eating during her husband’s lifetime; otherwise she may not eat. Rebbi Joḥanan said, she eats even if she did not eat before. Rebbi Yose said, even if she was only able to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Since the main act of acquisition is <i>qiddushin</i>, the Israel bride should be able to eat the Cohen’s food after betrothal. In praxi she is not allowed to use that food until she enters the Cohen’s household where everything is organized to vouchsafe the holiness of the sanctified food.<br>R. Yose clarifies the position of R. Joḥanan; he is not a third party in the disagreement.</i>. There is a <i>baraita</i> in support of either one. There is a <i>baraita</i> supporting Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Partial quote of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.1">Tosephta 10:1</a>.</i>: A hearing<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">She is of sane mind and therefore legally responsible for her actions in contrast to the deaf-mute. The <i>qiddushin</i> of a deaf-mute person are invalid since he has no standing in law. His marriage by cohabitation is valid but it is not an acquisition in the legal sense. Therefore, his wife cannot eat sanctified food under the terms of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>.</i> daughter of an Israel who married a deaf-mute Cohen does not eat heave. If he died and she came before the levir, if he is hearing<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The part of the Tosephta not quoted here specifies that she may eat heave only after intercourse that was <i>intended</i> to fulfill the conditions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a>. This supports the position of Samuel that the consequences of unintended intercourse are very limited.</i>, she eats, deaf-mute does not eat. There is a <i>baraita</i> supporting Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.1">Tosephta 10:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56a" href="/Yevamot.56a">Babli 56a</a>.</i>: A hearing daughter of an Israel who became engaged to a hearing Cohen, who did not manage to bring her to the bridal chamber before he became deaf-mute or before she became deaf-mute<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">And who therefore was not acquired in the meaning of civil law.</i>, does not eat heave. If he died and she came before a levir she eats even if he is deaf-mute<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">No intercourse of the deaf-mute can have the legal status of being intentional. If <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5"><i>Deut</i>. 25:5</a> nevertheless decrees that the widow become the wife of the deaf-mute, it cannot make a distinction between intentional and unintentional intercourse. The Babli agrees that Samuel cannot explain this Tosephta (but its terminology implies that this is no reason for him to change his mind.)</i>. In this He increased the power of the levir over that of the husband since the deaf-mute levir enables her to eat, but the deaf-mute husband does not enable her to eat.

Halakhah 2
