<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Similarly, anybody who comes upon any of the incest-prohibited women specified in the Torah, or of the disqualified ones, [i. e.,] a widow for the High Priest or a divorcee or one who had participated in <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a private<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἰδιώτης.</i> Cohen, a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.5">Chapter 1, Note 29</a>.</i> or Gibeonite<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Chapter 2, Note 72</a>.</i> female for an Israel, or an Israel woman for a male bastard or Gibeonite, disqualified her<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">She is disqualified from marrying a Cohen, or, if she is the daughter of a Cohen, from eating sanctified food.</i> and there is no difference between intercourse and intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Any intercourse in the list of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> which would acquire the sister-in-law in levirate will disqualify any woman from marrying into the priesthood. {There are slight legal differences between the cases enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>. Any infraction of the “holiness prohibitions” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Mishnah 2:4</a>) desecrates the woman; the others formally make her a prostitute.}</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Similarly, anybody who comes upon any of the incest-prohibited women,” etc. “He should not take a widow<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">A fragment of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>.</i>.” Even if under duress? The verse says, “he shall not desecrate his seed in his people.” Even if he touched? The verse does not say לא יחול but לא יחלל, even under duress; לא יחול but לא יחלל, even by touching. So far following Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi Aqiba considers every <i>pillel</i> or <i>polel</i> verb an extension of an original <i>ayin waw</i> or <i>ayin yod</i> form. {The reading of ms. A is preferable since a חיל form of חלל is used in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:4" href="/Leviticus.21.4"><i>Lev</i>. 21:4</a>.} On the one hand, “to take” means “to marry”. On the other hand, the use of the <i>pillel</i> in v. 15 means an extension of the framework. This is taken as authorization of the judicial establishment to extend the range of the acts prohibited.</i>. Following Rebbi Ismael<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The basis of the argument is the 3rd exegetical rule of R. Ismael [Introduction to <i>Sifra</i> (2)]: The technical meaning of a word does not change from topic to topic.</i>? Rebbi Ismael stated: It says here<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The marriage restrictions imposed on the High Priest, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>, are formulated as prohibitions to “take” certain women.</i> “taking” and it says there “taking” referring to incest prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17-18" href="/Leviticus.18.17-18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17–18</a>.</i>. Since regarding “taking” referred to by incest prohibitions He treated the one who touched as equal to the one who completed<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The exact meaning of this term is discussed in the Halakhah. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.3">Chapter 4, Note 59</a>.</i>, so also regarding “taking” referred to here we should treat the one who touched as equal to the one who completed. Rebbi Ḥaggai asked, if regarding “taking” referred to by incest prohibitions He treated the one who touched as equal to the one who completed and the child is a bastard, so also regarding “taking” referred to here we should treat the one who touched as equal to the one who completed and treat the child as a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This would be the correct application of R. Ismael’s rule, leading to a result contradicting practice. A similar argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 54a" href="/Yevamot.54a">Babli, 54a</a>, is explicitly based on comparison with the menstruating woman whose children are not bastards, circumventing R. Ḥaggai’s objection.</i>. Rebbi Yosa said, for which purpose was “desecrated” written? Is not bastard worse than desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Since the child of a disapproved union of the High Priest is defined as “desecrated” it cannot be a bastard since everything forbidden to a desecrated person is forbidden to a bastard but not vice-versa. Therefore, the rule of R. Ismael cannot be applied in this form.</i>? Rebbi Abun bar Bisna came in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Mamal. It says here “taking” and it says there “taking” referring to the woman waiting for the levir. Since regarding “taking” referring to the one waiting for the levir He treated the one who touched as equal to the one who completed and the child is acceptable, so also regarding “taking” referred to here we should treat the one who touched as equal to the one who completed and treat the child as acceptable<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">At least for non-priestly unions.</i>, since Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said: When he touched, he became guilty because of the desecrated one. When the gland entered, he became guilty for having intercourse. When he ejaculated, he became guilty because of desecrating<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:15" href="/Leviticus.21.15"><i>Lev</i>. 21:15</a>. Since the three sins are committed at three different times, he can be indicted and punished for three different crimes without any question of competition of laws. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 78a" href="/Kiddushin.78a">Babli, <i>Qiddushin</i> 78a</a>, it is noted that the language of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a> implies that he can be punished for the second offense only if he actually had married the widow.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A widow<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The women here are daughters of priests who may eat heave in their fathers’ houses. The majority hold that once they are acquired by a man whose sex act will irrevocably disqualify them from the priesthood, they have lost all their privileges. The dissenting rabbis hold that they retain their status until they are actually desecrated.</i> betrothed to the High Priest, a divorcee or one who had participated in <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to a private Cohen are not permitted to eat heave; Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon declare them able. When they were widowed or divorced, after marriage they are disabled, after betrothal they are enabled<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Even the majority will follow here the reasoning of the dissenters.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A widow to the High Priest,” etc. What is the reason of the rabbis? “Being” is mentioned here<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>: “[The Cohen] <i>shall</i> <i>be</i> holy for you.”</i> and “being” is mentioned there, “if a girl <i>will be</i> betrothed to a man<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:23" href="/Deuteronomy.22.23"><i>Deut</i>. 22:23</a>, a shortened quote.</i>.” Just as “being” there means betrothal, so “being” here means betrothal<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The status of sanctity of a woman entering a Cohen’s house is determined by her betrothal. The argument follows R. Ismael’s rule, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.2.2">Note 45</a>.</i>. What is the reason of Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon? “Being” is mentioned here<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>: “[The Cohen] <i>shall</i> <i>be</i> holy for you.”</i> and “being” is mentioned there, “if the daughter of a Cohen <i>will be</i> an outside man’s<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev</i>. 22:12</a>.</i>”. Just as “being” there means marriage, so “being” here means marriage. Rebbi Yosa said, from where do Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon know that the daughter of a Cohen betrothed to an Israel may not eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.4.1">Mishnah 7:4</a> it is stated without opposition that betrothal of a Cohen’s daughter to an Israel disables her from eating have (but does not enable a daughter of an Israel engaged to a Cohen to eat heave).</i>? Not from that verse, “if the daughter of a Cohen <i>will be</i> an outside man’s”? Here they make it betrothal, there they make it marriage!<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The question remains unanswered, the arguments presented up to here are inconsistent.</i> What is the reason of the rabbis? “A man’s”, the man who enables to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 5 7" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_5.7"><i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i>5(7</a>): “ ‘If the daughter of a Cohen will be an outside man’s’, this includes not only a bastard, from where even to a Levi or an Israel? The verse says, ‘an outside man’s’. From where a widow to the High Priest, a divorcee or one who had participated in <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to a private Cohen? The verse says ‘a man’s’, a man’s who enables to eat.”<br>The rather cryptic argument here and in <i>Sifra</i> makes reference to the rule (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.3.1">Mishnah 7:3</a>) that only a man can enable a (non-priestly) woman to eat heave, not a fetus. An Israel woman married to a Cohen eats heave as long as her husband is alive or after his death if she has children, but not if she is the pregnant widow of an otherwise childless man. She will only regain her status as member of the priestly clan after she has given birth. This explains the emphasis of the verse which is formulated לאיש זר and not simply לזר.<br>For the rabbis, the entire verse refers to betrothal.</i>. Is it not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 5 8" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_5.8"><i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i> 5(8</a>). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56b" href="/Yevamot.56b">Babli, 56b</a>, tries an equally invalid argument.</i>? Since an Israel, whose intercourse does not disable her<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">A (widowed) daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel may return to her priestly status if she becomes a childless widow.</i> from the priesthood, by intercourse will disable her from eating heave<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Once she is married to an Israel by intercourse, she is barred from eating heave.</i>, the High Priest, whose intercourse does disable her from the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">He desecrates any widow by his intercourse.</i>, it should be logical that his intercourse will disable her from eating heave. No. If you argue about an Israel who cannot enable others to eat, what can you say about the High Priest who can enable others to eat? Since he can enable others to eat, his intercourse should not disable her from eating heave. The argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> is broken, and one has to return to the verse. Therefore, it must say “a man’s”; <i>viz</i>., the man who enables her to eat. <sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Text from ms. A.<br>Ms. L and <i>editio princeps</i>: מַה טַעֲמָא לֹא אָֽמְרוּ רִבִּי לָֽעְזָר וְרִבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן נִישּׂוּאִין פּוֹסְלִין אוֹתָהּ מִלּוֹכַל בִּתְרוּמָה. מַה עֲבַד לָהּ רִבִּי לָֽעְזָר וְרִבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן. מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהוּא רָאוּי לוֹכַל אוֹ מִשּׁוּם שֶׁאֵינוֹ רָאוּי לוֹכַל. נִשְׁמְעִינָהּ מִן הָדָא אִם לֹא יְדָעָהּ מִשּׁוּם מַה נַעֲשֶׂה פְצוּעַ דַּכָּא וּכְרוּת שָׁפְכָה הֲרֵי יֹאכֵלוּ. אָמַר רִבִּי לָֽעְזָר. דְּרִבִּי לָֽעְזָר וְרִבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. אִית לָךְ מֵימַר. הָדָא מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהוּא רָאוּי לֶאֱכוֹל וְהָכָא מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהוּא רָאוּי לְהַאֲכִיל. אָמַר רִבִּי יוֹסֵי בֵּירִבִּי בּוּן. לֹא סוֹף דָּבָר מִן הַנִּישּׂוּאִין. נִבְעֲלוּ בֵּין מִן הָאֵרוּסִין בֵּין מִן הַנִּישּׂוּאִין פְּסוּלוֹת. לֹא נִבְעֲלוּ בֵּין מִן הָאֵרוּסִין בֵּין .מִן הַנִּישּׂוּאִין כְּשֵׁירוֹת.<br>What is the reason that Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon did not say that marriage disables them from eating heave? What do Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon in this case? Because he may eat or because he is not fit to eat? Let us hear from the following: “If he did not know her why his testicles became injured or his penis cut off, these they enable to eat.” Rebbi Eleazar said, this follows Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon. You have to say, here it is because he enables to eat, there because he enables to eat. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, not only from marriage. If they had copulated whether betrothed or married, they are disabled; if they had not copulated whether betrothed or married, they are enabled.<br>The text is seen to be corrupt.</i> What is the reason of Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Interpreting the same verse as do the majority rabbis.</i>, because he may eat or because he may enable to eat? Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.1">Mishnah 8:1</a>. Since men with injured testicles or torn-off penis cannot marry (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:2" href="/Deuteronomy.23.2"><i>Deut</i>. 23:2</a>), if they are Cohanim their intercourse desecrates. They themselves are also barred from eating sanctified food. If they were healthy when they married, their wives retain their priestly status even if the priest who brought them into the priesthood loses his.</i>: “If he did not know her after his testicles became injured or his penis cut off, these they enable to eat.” Rebbi Eleazar said, this follows Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora R. Eleazar holds that the rabbis, who exclude the betrothed in a forbidden union from eating heave even though betrothal is an acquisition, must also exclude the wife of a man whose intercourse will disable her. The statement is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75a" href="/Yevamot.75a">Babli, 75a</a>, and contrasted (as in the Yerushalmi, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2-19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2-19">Halakhah 8:1</a>) with the opinion of R. Joḥanan that the rabbis can agree because she started to eat with permission; that permission cannot disappear without anything happening involving her person. According to R. Joḥanan, nothing is proven here.</i>. You have to say, here it is because he<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The Cohen before his accident.</i> enables to eat, there<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The High Priest who never could enable a widow.</i> because he cannot enable to eat. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, not really from betrothal or marriage. If they had copulated whether betrothed or married, they are disabled; if they had not copulated whether betrothed or married, they are enabled<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 57b" href="/Yevamot.57b">Babli, 57b</a>, this is the opinion of Samuel, interpreting the position of the rabbis (against the authoritative opinion of Rav).</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The High Priest shall not marry a widow, whether a widow from betrothal or a widow from marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition of the widow is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:14" href="/Deuteronomy.21.14"><i>Deut.</i> 21:14</a>. Since <i>qiddushin</i> are the marriage in criminal law, they can be dissolved only by a bill of divorce which makes the recipient a divorcee. Consequently, if the groom dies between betrothal and marriage, she becomes a widow.</i>. He shall not marry an adult; Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon enable the adult<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:13" href="/Leviticus.21.13"><i>Lev.</i> 21:13</a> is interpreted to mean “he shall take a woman with an intact hymen.” It is held that an adult, older than 12.5 years, has a softened hymen so that the act of deflowering might not be recognizable.</i>. He shall not marry one injured<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Her hymen injured.</i> by a piece of wood. If he gave <i>qiddushin</i> and afterwards was elected High Priest, he shall marry her<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>qiddushin</i> are the acquisition understood by the root לקח in the verses, she has already been acquired when he was appointed and verses 13–14 do not apply to him.</i>; it happened that Joshua ben Gamla had given <i>qiddushin</i> to Martha bat Boetos<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The richest woman of her time, from a priestly family. According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61a" href="/Yevamot.61a">Babli, 61a</a>, she bought her husband’s the appointment from king Agrippa I for 3 <i>qab</i>, about 6.5 liter, of gold denars. In <i>Midraš Ekha Rabbati</i> 1(50), her name is Miriam bat Boethos. Elsewhere in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 56a" href="/Gittin.56a">Babli (<i>Giṭṭin</i> 56a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 104a" href="/Ketubot.104a"><i>Ketubot</i> 104a</a>), her name is that of a legendary superrich woman.<br>A different story appears in Jesephus <i>Antiquities</i> xv, 320 ff., where king Herod dismisses the incumbent High Priest from office and replaces him with Simon ben Boethos, because he wants to marry Simon’s daughter (the granddaughter of a Boethos).<br>In addition to the similarities of names and subject, the sources also agree about the prevailing corruption. The note that the High Priest was appointed, not elected by his fellow priests, is an intended slur.</i> when the king appointed him as High Priest and he married her. If a woman was waiting for her Cohen levir when he was elected High Priest, even though he “bespoke” her, he may not marry her<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">“Bespeaking” is only rabbinical. Since he has the possibility to fulfill all biblical requirements by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, he may not marry the widow.</i>. If the brother of a High Priest died, he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The High Priest shall not marry a widow,” etc. “A widow he shall not take”, whether from betrothal or from marriage. “A divorcee he shall not take,” whether from betrothal or from marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The prescription of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:14</a> is absolute, referring to any woman who is called widow or divorcee. An extended argument parallel to this one is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59a" href="/Yevamot.59a">Babli, 59a</a>.</i>.
“He shall not marry an adult; Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon enable the adult.” They agree that he shall not marry one injured by a piece of wood. What is the difference between the adult and the one injured by a piece of wood? The hymen of an adult dissolved in her body. The hymen of one injured by a piece of wood came outside<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59b" href="/Yevamot.59b">Babli, 59b</a>, the disagreement between the majority and rabbis Eleazar and Simeon is described as one of the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:13" href="/Leviticus.21.13"><i>Lev</i>. 21:13</a>; parallel to the discussion here in the next paragraph. The switched version is not found elsewhere.</i>. Some switch: He shall not marry one injured by a piece of wood; Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Simeon enable one injured by a piece of wood.” They agree that he shall not marry an adult. What is the difference between the adult and the one injured by a piece of wood? An adult is no longer young. The one injured by a piece of wood is still young.
A sister injured by a piece of wood, Rebbi Meїr and Rebbi Simeon say, he shall not defile himself for her, but the Sages say, he must defile himself for her<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the rules <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-4" href="/Leviticus.21.1-4"><i>Lev.</i> 21:1–4</a>, that a Cohen may not defile himself by the impurity of the dead except for his close relative. His sister is included in the list as long as she belongs to his clan, i. e., as long as she is not married. The language of v. 3 is involved: “And for his virgin sister who is close to him, who never had been a man’s, for her he must defile himself”, inviting a close analysis of the meaning of the conditions attached.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 60a" href="/Yevamot.60a">Babli, 60a</a>, this is only R. Simeon’s opinion.</i>. Rebbi Meїr and Rebbi Simeon follow well what they have stated, but the argument of Sages seems inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what the reference is. It could be <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:23" href="/Deuteronomy.22.23"><i>Deut</i>. 22:23</a>, “If there was a virgin girl …” The statement of the rabbis referred to is not otherwise recorded.</i>, they say “a girl”, not an adult, “a virgin”, not one injured by a piece of wood; and here, they say so? Rebbi Hila said, every interpretation follows its context. There<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:3" href="/Leviticus.21.3"><i>Lev</i>. 21:3</a>. The argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 60a" href="/Yevamot.60a">Babli, 60a</a>.</i>, “and for his virgin sister”, that excludes the raped and the seduced one. Or maybe I should exclude the one injured by a piece of wood? The verse says, “who had not been a man’s.” Who became [deflowered] through the action of a man, not one who became it through something else. “The close one”, to include the betrothed one<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 60" href="/Yevamot.60">Babli, 60a/b</a>, the divorced sister is included.</i>. “To him”, to include the adult. The argument of Sages seems inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">In the interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:3" href="/Leviticus.21.3"><i>Lev</i>. 21:3</a> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor" href="/Sifra,_Emor"><i>Sifra Emor</i> 0(4</a>); the Cohen may not defile himself by the impurity of the dead, “except for his flesh close to him, for his mother and his father, his son and his daughter, and his brother.”</i>, they say “the close one”, to exclude the betrothed one<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">“His flesh close to him” is his wife after the marriage, not his betrothed.</i>, “to him”, to exclude the divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The Cohen is not permitted to defile himself for a wife forbidden to him.</i>. And here, they say so<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">His betrothed sister is included, his own betrothed is excluded. (Instead of ארוסתו, ms. A has the synonym כלתו.)</i>? Rebbi Hila said, every interpretation follows its context. “His sister” is always inside [the family] until she leaves; his betrothed is always outside until she enters.
His own rape victim or seduced woman he should not marry but if he married her one does not remove her from him. Somebody else’s rape victim or seduced woman he should not marry but if he married her one does remove her from him<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59b" href="/Yevamot.59b">Babli, 59b</a>, there is a related <i>baraita</i>: “His own rape victim or seduced woman he should not marry but if he married her he is married. Somebody else’s rape victim or seduced woman he should not marry but if he married her, R. Eliezer ben Jacob said, their child is desecrated, but the Sages say, their child is enabled.”</i>. He should not marry a minor<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61b" href="/Yevamot.61b">Babli 61b</a>. This restricts the unmarried High Priest to girls older than 12 years when they are no longer minors, but not older than 12 years 6 months, when they become adults.</i> but he may marry the one who repudiated<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">If she repudiated the prospective husband after betrothal and still is a virgin.</i>. Is the one who repudiated not a minor? One waits until she grows up.
“If he gave <i>qiddushin</i> and afterwards was elected High Priest, he shall marry her.” Similarly, If he gave <i>qiddushin</i> to a minor and afterwards was elected High Priest, shall he marry her? I am reading for her “a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:13" href="/Leviticus.21.13"><i>Lev</i>. 21:13</a>: “And he shall take a <i>woman</i> with an intact hymen.”</i>”, not a minor.
He tricked her<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua ben Gamla went into debt in order to marry a rich wife.. It is unclear what he borrowed.<br>The Mishnah quoted, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:8:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.8.2-3"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:9</a>, is explained in its Halakhah to mean that a big engagement feast is a kind of proof that a betrothal did in fact take place. If despite the rich gift no betrothal has taken place, a bill of divorce is nevertheless necessary to free the woman for marriage to another man.<br>If Martha bat Boethos had rejected the gift, as a “divorcee” this daughter of a High Priest would have been barred from marrying another priest.<br>The word in the recently discovered ms. A, בדיומה, is a <i>hapax</i> and probably corrupt. The text of A was chosen because at least the remainder of the sentence represents correct and coherent grammar.<br>The unintelligible word in ms. L פיריו מהו has been read as פיריומה which in different contexts has been explained as Greek φέρετρον (from the root φέρω “to bear, carry”) meaning a litter, or as περιωμίς meaning a garment covering the shoulders. Perhaps here it should be read as Greek φερνάριον, τό, diminutive of φερνή “gift to the wife, bridal gifts” (also from φέρω); also cf. the word παράφερνα “bride’s goods”, from which Latin “paraphernalia” derives (E. G.).</i>. He borrowed a בדיומה and seated his mother next to her. She heard and accepted. And we have stated: “If she has a reputation in town to be betrothed, then she is betrothed.”
Also the House of Shammai agree, also Rebbi Simeon agrees but not Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh, since Rebbi Eleazar ben Arakh says, “bespeaking” acquires a sister-in-law completely<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua ben Gamla went into debt in order to marry a rich wife.. It is unclear what he borrowed.<br>The Mishnah quoted, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:8:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.8.2-3"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:9</a>, is explained in its Halakhah to mean that a big engagement feast is a kind of proof that a betrothal did in fact take place. If despite the rich gift no betrothal has taken place, a bill of divorce is nevertheless necessary to free the woman for marriage to another man.<br>If Martha bat Boethos had rejected the gift, as a “divorcee” this daughter of a High Priest would have been barred from marrying another priest.<br>The word in the recently discovered ms. A, בדיומה, is a <i>hapax</i> and probably corrupt. The text of A was chosen because at least the remainder of the sentence represents correct and coherent grammar.<br>The unintelligible word in ms. L פיריו מהו has been read as פיריומה which in different contexts has been explained as Greek φέρετρον (from the root φέρω “to bear, carry”) meaning a litter, or as περιωμίς meaning a garment covering the shoulders. Perhaps here it should be read as Greek φερνάριον, τό, diminutive of φερνή “gift to the wife, bridal gifts” (also from φέρω); also cf. the word παράφερνα “bride’s goods”, from which Latin “paraphernalia” derives (E. G.).</i>.
“If a brother of the High Priest dies, he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.” This supports him who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is freeing. But according to him who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is acquisiton, does one say to him, transgress the words of the Torah?<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">This is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.2-10">Halakhah 3:1</a>, at <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.4.1">Note 75</a>.</i>

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A private priest should not marry a she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Who visibly is sterile.</i> unless he has a wife and children. Rebbi Jehudah says, even one who has a wife and children should not marry a she-ram since she is the harlot mentioned in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14">14</a>. For R. Jehudah, every sex act which is not one of possible procreation is harlotry.</i>. But the Sages say, a harlot is only a convert, a freedwoman, and one who copulated in harlotry<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">“Copulating in harlotry” is any sex act between people who either could not marry (close relatives, Gentiles, Slaves, or in adultery) or whose marriage would be sinful. The convert and the libertine will be excluded from marrying into the priesthood by their sexual contacts before becoming full Jews.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A private priest should not marry a she-ram,” etc. Does that mean that an Israel without wife and children may marry her? Still he is forbidden. But since we stated afterwards that “a harlot mentioned in the Torah is only a convert, a freedwoman, and one who copulated in harlotry,” all of which refer only to priests, for this reason it was not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61a" href="/Yevamot.61a">Babli 61a</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said, it is written: “Between their rows they make oil,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 24:11" href="/Job.24.11"><i>Job</i> 24:11</a>. In this pornographic sermon, the rows are the female’s legs, the oil is semen.</i>” “they to not turn to the way of vineyards<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 24:18" href="/Job.24.18"><i>Job</i> 24:18</a>. The evildoers are not interested in harvesting.</i>”, that their copulation was not for children. Rebbi Simon said, it is written: “They ate and were not satiated, they whored and did not spread,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 4:10" href="/Hosea.4.10"><i>Hos.</i> 4:10</a>. In the words of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61b" href="/Yevamot.61b">Babli, 61b</a>, “any intercourse not intended to spread (the human race)” is sinful.</i>” that their copulation was not for children. It is written: “Lemekh took for himself two wives<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 4:19" href="/Genesis.4.19"><i>Gen.</i> 4:19</a>. The intimation is that Adah “the jewel” was not supposed to have children to preserve her beauty. Ṣillah “the shadow” was shadowed by her children. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 23:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.23.3"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 23(3</a>), the roles of Adah and Ṣillah are reversed.</i>”, “Adah” who was beautifying her body. “Ṣillah”, who was sitting in the shadow of children.
They objected to Rebbi Jehudah: Think of it, if she was sterile and could not give birth. Think of it, if she was old<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">A very feminine-looking person can be sterile, as were Sarah, Rebecca, and Rachel. It is not sinful to marry a beautiful woman. An elderly widower is encouraged to marry an elderly woman, not a young girl whom he cannot satisfy.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, intercourse of an unmarried man with an unmarried woman not with the intent of marriage is intercourse of harlotry<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61b" href="/Yevamot.61b">Babli 61b</a>. A later Babylonian authority is emphatic that this is not practice.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, that implies that the High Priest who performed <i>qiddushin</i> by copulation is not having intercourse with a deflowered one<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible to save the money for <i>qiddushin</i> by having intercourse with intent of marriage (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 1:1</a>). If “intercourse” means completed intercourse then by “touching” the High Priest would have desecrated the woman and the later ejaculation would be sinful. Since R. Eleazar explicitly authorizes intercourse of unmarried persons for the purpose of marriage, it follows that the act of marriage is the beginning of intercourse and is available to the High Priest.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A man should not rest from being fruitful and multiply unless he has children. The House of Shammai say two males, but the House of Hillel say a male and a female, as it is said “male and female He created them<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:27" href="/Genesis.1.27"><i>Gen</i>. 1:27</a>.</i>.” If he married a wife and she stayed with him for ten years and had no child he is not permitted to rest. If he divorced her<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">He also might take a second wife.</i>, she is permitted to marry another and the second [husband] is permitted to stay with her for ten years, and if she had a miscarriage she counts from the moment of the miscarriage. The man is commanded to be fruitful and multiply but not the woman. Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa said, for both of them it says “God blessed them and God said to them, be fruitful and multiply,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:28" href="/Genesis.1.28"><i>Gen.</i> 1:28</a>.</i>” etc.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A man should not rest from being fruitful and multiply,” etc. The House of Shammai say two males, since “Gershom and Eliezer”<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 23:15" href="/I_Chronicles.23.15"><i>1Chr.</i> 23:15</a>. The argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61b" href="/Yevamot.61b">Babli 61b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 8:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).8.4">Tosephta 8:4</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 26" href="/Genesis.26">Tanḥuma Buber <i>Bereshit</i> 26</a>. Nobody has to be more strict than Moses.</i> are mentioned for Moses. The House of Hillel say a male and a female the way the world was created, as it is said “male and female He created them<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:27" href="/Genesis.1.27"><i>Gen</i>. 1:27</a>.</i>.” Rebbi Abun said, one has to understand “even a male and a female”. If it were not so, it should have been a Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">In Tractate <i>Idiut.</i> It must be that the House of Hillel accept either two males or male and female.</i> about the leniencies of the House of Shammai and the stringencies of the House of Hillel. Sons of sons are counted as sons<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 8:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).8.4">Tosephta 8:4</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 62b" href="/Yevamot.62b">Babli 62b</a>.</i>, sons of daughters are not counted as sons<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 62b" href="/Yevamot.62b">Babli, 62b</a>, this is the opinion of Abbai; it is rejected by the authoritative Rava (Rav Abba bar Rav Yosef bar Ḥama).</i>. The son’s son and the daughter’s daughter count; the son’s daughter and the daughter’s son do not count. A she-ram, a castrate, and those who cannot have children are not counted.
Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. The reason of that Tanna: “At the end of ten years since Abram lived in the Land of Canaan<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 16:3" href="/Genesis.16.3"><i>Gen</i>. 16:3</a>; Sarah gave her husband a second wife to have children.</i>.” Deduct the years outside the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 8:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).8.5">Tosephta 8:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 64a" href="/Yevamot.64a">Babli 64a</a> as tannaitic statement. In both sources, the verse is designated as hint, not as proof since Issac waited 20 years for his children. The rule does not apply outside the Land in any case.</i>. We also have stated: [The time during which] she was sick or he was sick, or he went overseas, does not count<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 8:6" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).8.6">Tosephta 8:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 64a" href="/Yevamot.64a">Babli 64a</a>.</i>. If she was married to the first [husband] and did not give birth, she receives <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.3.1">Chapter 4, Note 84</a>.</i>; from the second she receives <i>ketubah</i>, from the third she receives <i>ketubah</i>, from the fourth and fifth she has no <i>ketubah</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina bar ‘Agil in the name of Rebbi Ḥizqiah: From the third himself she has no <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 65a" href="/Yevamot.65a">Babli, 65a</a>: As a third husband, she should marry only a man with children. If she married a childless man, she has no <i>ketubah.</i></i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 65a" href="/Yevamot.65a">Babli, 65a</a>, this statement is characterized as tannaitic.</i> If she was married to a fourth or fifth and did not give birth, may the earlier ones have regress on her<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is now proven that she is sterile and most people would not marry a woman knowing that she was sterile. May they ask the <i>ketubah</i> money back?</i>? She can say, only now did this woman become sterile<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">The claimants would have to prove that she was sterile before.</i>. If she was married to the fifth and gave birth, has she regress on the fourth? He says to her, your silence is better than your talk<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth husband could say, had I known you were not sterile, I never would have given you a bill of divorce. This threatens retroactively to invalidate the divorce and to make her child a bastard (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 65a" href="/Yevamot.65a">Babli 65a</a>).</i>.
If she had intercourse and saw blood repeatedly. Some Tannaïm state, a second time she may have intercourse, a third time she may not. But some Tannaïm state, a third time she may have intercourse, a fourth time she may not<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 65b-66a" href="/Niddah.65b-66a">Babli, <i>Niddah</i> 65b/66a</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Niddah 8:1" href="/Tosefta_Niddah.8.1">Tosephta <i>Niddah</i> 8:1–2</a> know only of the more lenient opinion. This does not deal with a virgin but a woman who reacts to intercourse with interior bleeding that might be menstrual. After three consecutive episodes she may not have any more intercourse with this husband.</i>. They wanted to say<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">A conjecture, not a statement.</i> that he who says, a second time she may have intercourse, a third time she may not, holds with him who says that a third time she has no <i>ketubah</i>. But he who says, a third time she may have intercourse, a fourth time she may not, holds with him who says that the third time she has <i>ketubah</i>. If one gave birth to male childen and they died when being circumcised. Some Tannaïm state, a second time one should circumcise, a third time one should not circumcise. Some Tannaïm state, a third time one should circumcise, a fourth time one should not circumcise<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 64b" href="/Yevamot.64b">Babli, 64b</a> and other places, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:8" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.8">Tosephta <i>Shabbat</i> 15:8</a> the person who holds that in matters of physical danger two cases are proof is Rebbi, and the one who requires three is his father, Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel.</i>. They wanted to say that he who says, a second time one should circumcise, a third time one should not circumcise, holds with him who says that a third time she has no <i>ketubah</i> He who says, a third time one should circumcise, a fourth time one should not circumcise, holds with him who says that the third time she has <i>ketubah</i>. Even he, who says that the third time she has <i>ketubah</i> agrees here that one should not circumcise because of the danger<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 64b" href="/Yevamot.64b">Babli, 64b</a>, agrees that it is most careless not to follow Rebbi in matters of dangers to life. A warning example is Abbai, who died after he married a very beautiful twofold widow.</i>. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:8" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.8">Tosephta <i>Shabbat</i> 15:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 134a" href="/Shabbat.134a">Babli <i>Shabbat</i> 134a</a>. In both of these sources, the <i>third</i> child was brought before R. Nathan (the Babylonian), the baby was called Nathan the Babylonian, and it happened in Kappadokian Mazaca (pre-Roman name of Caesarea).</i>: Rebbi Nathan said, it happened that I went to Kappadokian Caesarea, and there was a woman who gave birth to male children and they died when being circumcised. She circumcised the first [child] and he died, the second and he died, the third and he died. She brought the fourth one before me, I looked at him and saw that he did not have enough blood for circumcision. I told them, wait for later. They waited, circumsised him, he turned out to be living, and they called him Nathan after me.
If she had children but they died, she counts from the time of death<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement in the Mishnah that after a miscarriage there starts a new period of 10 years.</i>. She can say, a spirit strangled the children of this woman and made me sterile<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Since she was not sterile at the moment of marriage, her <i>ketubah</i> is due her in any case.</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Zimra: The reason of that Tanna<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The last clause in the Mishnah, that only men are obligated to have children. The entire paragraph has its parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 65b" href="/Yevamot.65b">Babli, 65b</a>.</i>: “Be fruitful and multiply, fill the earth and conquer it.” It is written “he shall conquer it.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 1:28" href="/Genesis.1.28"><i>Gen.</i> 1:28</a>. The last word is written וכבשה which can be read as defective plural or regular singular.</i>” Who usually conquers? The man, not the woman. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Isaac bar Marion, in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Practice follows Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa and Rebbi Jacob bar Idi, Rebbi Isaac bar Ḥaqula in the name of Rebbi Jehudah Neśia: If she requests to be married, she has the law on her side<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">If a woman was childlessly married to a man for 10 years and requests a divorce in order to be able to have a child with a more potent man, the court is required to force the husband to divorce her with a full <i>ketubah.</i> The Babli is explicit in this matter, that she must claim to need children who will care for her in her old age. Such a statement is needed only if practice does <i>not</i> follow R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Practice follows Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda said to him, I was with you and it was only said that if she requests to be married, she has the law on her side. In a similar case<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Involving R. Eleazar and R. Abba bar Zavda and an erroneous statement. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 5" href="/Megillah.5">Babli, <i>Megillah</i> 5a/b</a>, the wrong statement is again given by R. Eleazar and the correction by R. Abba bar Zavda. From the insistence that the two cases are parallel, it seems that this should be the reading here also. But the text given here is confirmed by the parallel in <i>Megillah</i>1:1.</i>, referring to what we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Ta‘aniot</i> 4:9.</i>: “In the week in which the Ninth of Av<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The day of mourning for the destruction of the Temple.</i> falls, it is forbidden to get a haircut and to wash. But on Thursday one is permitted, in preparation for the Sabbath.” Rebbi Abba bar Zavda in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Rebbi wanted to do away with the Ninth of Av but they did not let him. Rebbi Eleazar said to him, I was with you and it was only said that Rebbi wanted to do away with the Ninth of Av which happened to be on the Sabbath but they did not let him. He said, since it is pushed away, let it be pushed away. They said to him, it should be pushed to the next day. He recited on these<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 4:9" href="/Ecclesiastes.4.9"><i>Eccl.</i> 4:9</a>. From the text in <i>Megillah</i>, it seems that “he” is a third person, possibly R. Ḥaninah,</i>: “Two are better than one.”

Chapter 7



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a widow [married] to a High Priest, or a divorcee or one freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> [married] to a simple priest, brought him slaves as paraphernalia or as mortmain<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Mortmain (“inalienable property”, ‘iron flock’, in German law <i>eisern Vieh</i>) whose value was determined in the marriage contract (<i>ketubah</i>) as <i>dos aestimata</i>, upon marriage became the husband’s property. At the termination of the marriage their value was due back to the wife.<br>Paraphernalia [from the Greek παράφερνα, Middle Latin <i>paraphernalia</i>(<i>bona</i>), as a legal term relevant here “bride’s goods beyond her dowry,” equivalent to Late Latin <i>parapherna</i> “bride’s property.” (For the etymology of מְלוֹג, Ashkenazic מְלוּג, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.7">Note 45</a>, also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.3.1">Chapter 4, Note 86</a>). These goods are <i>dos non aestimata,</i> property not entered in the marriage contract, of which the husband has administration for the duration of the marriage. He must maintain the value of this property and is compensated by receiving its usufruct but has no property rights.<br>Since in any irregular union (such as described in the Mishnah) the wife of a Cohen is barred from all sanctified food, her property is barred with her. But the property of a Cohen is entitled to share in his sanctified food (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i>22:11</a>).<br>The expression צאן ברזל “iron flock” for “inalienable, private property” may also be compared to Latin <i>peculium</i>“private property” which is derived from <i>pecus, -oris</i> “cattle” but used as a legal term for property in general.</i>: The slaves of separate property may not eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">And all other sanctified food that may be eaten outside the Temple precinct.</i>, the slaves of mortmain may eat heave. These are slaves of paraphernalia: If they died, they died as her property, if they increased, they increased as her property. Even though he is responsible for their upkeep, they may not eat heave. These are slaves of mortmain: If they died, they died as his property, if they increased, they increased as his property. Since he guarantees them, they may eat heave.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A widow [married] to a High Ptiest,” etc. From where that a priest who married a wife or bought slaves enables them to eat heave? The verse says “and if a priest buys a person as his money’s acquisition<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>: “And if a priest buys a person as his money’s acquisition, he shall eat of it; and the one born in his house, <i>they</i> shall eat of his food.” The wife is acquired by the <i>qiddushin</i> money.</i>,” etc. From where that if his wife bought slaves, and her slaves [bought] slaves, that they may eat heave? The verse says “and if a priest buys a person as his money’s acquisition,” etc. Also his acquisition which bought an acquisition enables him to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Note the incongruous plural in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>. Up to here the text is a <i>baraita</i>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 66a" href="/Yevamot.66a">Babli 66a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 5 1" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_5.1"><i>Sifra Emor Parasha</i>5(1</a>).</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar. “They shall eat<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>: “And if a priest buys a person as his money’s acquisition, he shall eat of it; and the one born in his house, <i>they</i> shall eat of his food.” The wife is acquired by the <i>qiddushin</i> money.</i>”, they shall enable to eat. The <i>baraita</i> speaks about a slave who acquired slaves within the power of his master. But if a slave acquired slaves on condition that his master have no power over them, they are his property<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Anything a slave buys is his owner’s property. Usually, what he otherwise acquires is also his owner’s property. But if he received something as a gift (e. g., money to buy his freedom) with the express stipulation that his master shall have no claim to it, then it is the slave’s direct property. If the slave received other slaves as such a gift, these are not the master’s acquisition and are barred from eating sanctified food.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar. If a slave acquired slaves on condition that his master have no power over them and he died, the first person who comes can grab them<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">They are ownerless. Since a slave can become free only by an act of manumission, these slaves are not freed by the death of their master and can be taken by anybody.</i>. In that case, [that slave] is not his property’s property<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The slave’s slave is not the slave’s master’s property.</i>.
Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: “They shall eat”, they shall enable to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.2">Note 4</a>. They read יאכלו as יַאֲכִלוּ. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 5 6" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_5.6"><i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i> 5(6</a>), this is a tannaitic argument of R. Simeon.</i>. The one who may eat enables to eat, the one who may not eat cannot enable to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since the divorcee becomes desecrated by her marriage to any priest, she never can herself eat heave nor cause her slaves to eat.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan says, because of a fine<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">By <i>qiddushin</i>, the divorcee was acquired by the priest. Her property was acquired with her. Therefore, by biblical standards her slaves could eat but it is a traditional fine imposed on irregular marriages that they should not confer the same advantages as a regular one.</i>. What is the difference between them? If an uncircumcised slave<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot eat sanctified food (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:48" href="/Exodus.12.48"><i>Ex.</i> 12:48</a>); the rules are spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2-19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2-19">Halakhah 8:1</a>.</i> buys slaves. If you say, it is a fine, here there is no fine<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">On condition that the slave remain uncircumcised in a way accepted in Jewish law.</i>. If you say the one who may eat enables to eat, this one, since he is not able to eat, cannot enable to eat.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, there is disagreement about mortmain slaves. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if he sold them, they are not sold<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Gittin 41a:11:2" href="/Tosafot_on_Gittin.41a.11.2">Tosaphot in <i>Giṭṭin</i> 41a, <i>s. v.</i> אשה</a>, are of the opinion that the Babli concurs.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said to him, they are eating heave by his power and you say so? He answered, do not paraphernalia slaves also eat by his power, and one says that if he sold them, they are not sold<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife is not from a priestly family, then her slaves can eat only because he made her his wife. He cannot sell them since nobody can sell what is not his; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta 9:1</a>.</i>. From your own they<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The developers of rabbinic doctrine.</i> gave to you. It would be logical that one<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">A paraphernalia slave who is not property of a Cohen.</i> should not eat heave. But they said that he eats<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">As if he were the property of a Cohen.</i>, and they said, if he sold them, they are not sold. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Josiah. A <i>baraita</i> supports one and another <i>baraita</i> supports the other. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Eleazar: Paraphernalia slaves are freed on account of “tooth and eye”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">If a slave loses a body part through his owner’s fault, he gains his freedom (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:26" href="/Exodus.21.26"><i>Ex.</i> 21:26</a>). Paraphernalia slaves are property of the wife but not the husband. This part of the <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the Babli. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 89a" href="/Bava_Kamma.89a"><i>Baba Qama</i> 89a</a>.</i> from the wife but not the husband. Mortmain slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> holds that they are the husband’s property; therefore, he must have the absolute power to sell them, against R. Joḥanan.</i> are freed by “tooth and eye” from the husband but not the wife. What does Rebbi Joḥanan do with this? They are quick to manumit<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli agrees without a dissenting opinion.</i>, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted as tannaitic text also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 4:4:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.4.4.2-7"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 4:4</a> (fol. 45b), as amoraic in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 11b" href="/Bava_Kamma.11b">Babli, <i>Baba Qama</i> 11b</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 33b" href="/Bava_Kamma.33b">33b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 44b" href="/Bava_Metzia.44b"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 44b</a>.</i>: If somebody mortgages<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὑποθήκη “mortgage”.</i> a slave and later sold him, he is not sold<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The creditor can foreclose on the slave in the hands of the buyer.</i>; if he freed him, he is freed<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The creditor has to sue the borrower for damages; he cannot put his hand on the ex-slave.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: Neither mortmain slaves nor paraphernalia slaves are under the rules of “one or two days”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:20" href="/Exodus.21.20"><i>Ex.</i> 21:20</a>. The exemption for the owner who hits his slave which provided that he is not prosecutable if the slave survives for two days is not available to either wife or husband. This <i>baraita</i> defines “owner” as a person who has both the right to and disposition of his property.<br>This text is also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 89b" href="/Bava_Kamma.89b">Babli <i>Baba Qama</i> 89b</a>.</i> and are freed by “tooth or eye” from neither the husband nor the wife. Where do they disagree? When he sold them forever or sold them for some time<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">“Selling temporarily” is not selling the property but leasing the use of the property for a limited period.</i>? If you say that he sold them permanently rather than temporarily, does everybody agree that they are sold? If you say that he sold them temporarily rather than permanently, does everybody agree that they are not sold? Let us hear from the following: <sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 10:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.10.1.6"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 10:1 (Notes 22–24</a>), in a slightly different version <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 41a" href="/Gittin.41a">Babli <i>Giṭṭin</i>41a</a>.</i> If somebody mortgages his field to his wife for her <i>ketubah</i> or to a creditor for his claim and then sells it, it is sold and the buyer should beware for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The buyer has to insure himself against the possibility that the creditor or the wife at the dissolution of her marriage will foreclose the property and he will have to sue the seller for restitution of the sale price.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, for the <i>ketubah</i> of the wife it is not sold since it is unthinkable that a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Without a male protector. Then the law has to protect her.</i> should run around at courts of law. They said, Rebbi Eleazar parallels the rabbis, Rebbi Joḥanan Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Since the wife has a lien on the mortmain slaves, the husband cannot alienate them without her consent, just as he cannot alienate real estate put up as collateral for her <i>ketubah.</i><br>Rosh (R. Asher ben Ieḥiel) in his commentary on this Yerushalmi (<i>Yebamot</i> 7 #1) holds that the husband is prevented even from leasing the property without his wife’s consent. Rif (R. Isaac Fasi), <i>Giṭṭin</i> #472 holds that the husband may not sell but may lease for a limited time.</i>. That means, we deal with a temporary sale. But if he sold permanently, everybody agrees that they are not sold.
<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 79b" href="/Ketubot.79b">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 79b</a>, this is a <i>baraita.</i> Since first generation Amoraim disagree over the rule, it seems that the Yerushalmi also presents this as a <i>baraita.</i></i> The offspring of a paraphernalia animal belongs to the husband, that of a paraphernalia slave girl belongs to the wife. Ḥanania the nephew of Rebbi Joshua said, the offspring of a paraphernalia animal is like that of a paraphernalia slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the formulation is: “the offspring of a paraphernalia slave girl is like that of a paraphernalia animal.” In the Babli, the child of the slave girl belongs to the husband; in the Yerushalmi, everything belongs to the wife.<br>In the Babli, the straight argument of Ḥanania is that the husband has the usufruct. In the Babli, the argument of the rabbis is that if the slave girl dies, the wife is left with nothing but if an animal dies, she is left with the value of the hide. There is no reason to transfer the argument of the Babli to the Yerushalmi. From the next paragraph it seems rather that the rabbis hold that the wife’s slaves belong to her father’s household and have to be treated as family heirlooms, and any increase in their number is increase of the value of the stock (which is the wife’s), not yield (which is the husband’s).</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said to the colleagues, you should know that Rebbi Joḥanan follows Ḥanania the nephew of Rebbi Joshua. Rav and Samuel, Rav follows the rabbis, but Samuel follows Ḥanania the nephew of Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli (Note 34) only Samuel’s opinion (opposite in meaning to his position here) is noted, without opposition.</i>. Samuel objected to Rav: According to you who says, they belong to the wife, should the first-born not take a double portion<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The first-born takes a double portion of the inheritance (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:17" href="/Deuteronomy.21.17"><i>Deut.</i> 21:17</a>, reading פי שנים as “double”, not “2/3”.) However, the first-born takes a double portion only from what is available at the father’s death. For example, property leased to others is available, debts collectable are not available (since the payor may default. Most modern authorities hold that sovereign debt is available.) In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 123b" href="/Bava_Batra.123b">Babli, <i>Baba Batra</i> 123b</a>, an anonymous <i>baraita</i> is quoted which in a different form is a Tosephta, <i>Bekhorot</i> 6:16, that the first-born gets a double interest in the calf of a cow who was pregnant at the father’s death. This must mean that the calf is increase of the value of the stock, of which the first-born gets adouble portion, not yield after the father’s death, of which he would get only a simple portion. It does not make any sense that Rav denies the young of the animal to the wife when he gives the first-born a double portion.</i>? Think of it, if she brought them when they were small and they grew up, are they not the wife’s, and you agree with me that the first-born takes a double portion<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Here everybody agrees that this represents increase in the stock, not yield.</i>!
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta 9:1</a>. The Tosephta deals with mortmain slaves and states that the wife has the right at the dissolution of the marriage to take the offspring of her slaves, even if their value today is greater than the value at which they were recorded in the marriage contract. She will have to indemnify her ex-husband for the difference in value but, since they are family heirlooms, he has no right to retain them against her will. This right extends to inanimate objects.</i>: If she brought them when they were small, she takes them when they are lads. If she brought him two vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">As mortmain property.</i>. If one of them was worth the value of her marriage contract, she takes it for her marriage contract<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketubah</i> in this connection denotes the entire value of the marriage contract, the statutory <i>ketubah</i> sum, the value of mortmain property, and the additional fee he agreed to pay in case of a dissolution of the marriage. For this reason the translation does not simply state <i>“ketubah”.</i> We are dealing with a state of rampant inflation, as it was recorded during the military anarchy of the Roman empire, where the sum stated in the contract would have lost most of its buying power over time.</i>. If one and a half was the value of her marriage contract, [disagreement of] Rav Huna and Rav Naḥman bar Jacob. One of them said, he pays for the second vessel and takes it; the other one says, she pays for the second vessel and takes it<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">They are not mentioned in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 66b-67a" href="/Yevamot.66b-67a">Babli, 66b/67a</a>. There, Rav Jehudah holds that the wife always has the right to take her dowry back and pay the difference but Rebbi Ammi (Immi) holds that it is the husband’s choice what to give her, in contrast to the position he is quoted for in the Yerushalmi. In the final decision after a lenghty discussion, the Babli sides with the Yerushalmi.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Cahana said before Rebbi Immi, Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The colleague of R. Immi in their separate place of study in Tiberias.</i>: Even if one was worth one and a half times the value of her marriage contract, she pays for the second vessel and takes it, because it is unthinkable that others should use her vessels. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira: A <i>baraita</i> says so: If she brought them for their monetary value, she takes them for their monetary value<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta 9:1</a>. Therefore, in times of inflation it is preferable to specify the property, not the monetary value, in marriage contracts.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada asked Rebbi Mana: What is the etymology of <i>“mĕlōg</i> slaves”? He said to him, as you say: strip off, strip off<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 45:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.45.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 45(2</a>) the etymology appears in the name of R. Simeon ben Laqish and it is explained that Hagar was a paraphernalia personal slave of Sarah whom Abraham had to feed but could not get services from. In the interpretation of <i>Arukh</i>, the simile here is the other way: since the husband has the usufruct of the property he is like somebody who strips the feathers off a chicken but cannot eat the meat.<br>The root מלג means “strip off (feathers, hair, etc.)” in Syriac. Ostensibly the word is Accadic <i>mulūgu</i>“paraphernalia”, which appears in the same meaning as an Eastern Semitic loanword <i>mlg</i> in Ugaritic (Canaanite); languages long dead by Talmudic times.<br>The relation between Arabic ملج מַלַגַ “to drink from the breast (baby)”, to Greek ἀμέλγω, Latin <i>mulgeo</i>, “to milk”, is not clear. But possibly the notion of “milking” associated with property of one kind contrasted with the notion of “flock” associated with another goes back to ancient images from times when property mainly consisted of livestock.</i>!
<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 2:4" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.2.4">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 2:4</a>. It is not totally clear what mortmain conditions for a shepherd are; cf. the extensive discussion in S. Lieberman, תוספתא כפשוטה בבא קמא-בבא מציעא New York 1988, pp 217–219.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 5:5:2-6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.5.5.2-6.2">Yerushalmi <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 5:7</a>, quoting <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bekhorot 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Bekhorot.5.1">Tosephta <i>Bekhorot</i> 5:1</a>,14, explains: “What is a mortmain flock? If [the owner] had 100 sheep and said [to the shepherd]: these are stipulated to be worth 100 gold denars, their lambs, their milk, and their shearings are yours, if they die, you are responsible, and for each one you give me a tetradrachma at the end, it is forbidden.” It is forbidden to the shepherd to receive a flock under these conditions from a Jew since most owners will structure the contract so they will make money, which turns the final payment (which accompanies the return of the flock to the owner) into a money-making proposition which looks like interest since the shepherd pays for the use of the flock which he received on credit. It is forbidden to pay interest to Jews. The same kind of contract is permitted with Gentiles.</i> There, we have stated: “If somebody receives [a flock] under mortmain conditions from a Gentile, the young are free, the young’s young are obligated.”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 5:5:2-6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.5.5.2-6.2"><i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 5:7</a> (fol. 10b).</i> Rebbi Jeremiah asked: There you say, the young are for the first, and here you say, the young are for the second<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah in <i>Bekhorot</i>, lambs are exempt because they belong to the Gentile even though the entire flock is the shepherd’s responsibility whereas the Mishnah here states that mortmain lambs belong to the husband who also carries the same responsibility as the shepherd.</i>! Rebbi Yosa said, there, because the property rights are with the first, the young belong to the first. But here, because the property rights are with the second, the young belong to the second<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The contract of the shepherd specifies that the flock must be returned intact at a specified time; the interest of the Gentile is there all the time. In the case of marriage, if the wife predeceases her husband, he inherits from her; his obligation to return the dowry is conditional.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a daughter of an Israel married a Cohen and brought him paraphernalia or mortmain slaves, they may eat heave. But if a daughter of a Cohen married an Israel and brought him paraphernalia or mortmain slaves, they may not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Heave may be eaten by “every pure person in [the Cohen’s] household” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:11" href="/Numbers.18.11"><i>Num.</i> 18:11</a>); this includes his wife and her circumcised slaves. But the daughter of a Cohen who marries outside the clan is barred from eating heave (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev.</i> 22:12</a>) and so are her slaves.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a daughter of an Israel married a Cohen who then died and left her pregnant, her slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Mortmain slaves who become the property of her child once he will be born.</i> may not eat heave because of the share of the fetus. A fetus disqualifies<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">A widowed, pregnant, otherwise childless daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel is precluded from returning to “her father’s house” because of the fetus who, once born, will not be a Cohen.</i> but cannot enable to eat, the words of Rebbi Yose. They said to him, after you testified before us about the daughter of an Israel [married] to a Cohen, even if a daughter of a Cohen [was married] to a Cohen who died and left her pregnant, her slaves may not eat heave because of the share of the fetus<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Even if she has other children, the fetus will be co-heir of the mortmain slaves and, since he is not a person, cannot have a “house” in which they eat heave.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Rebbi Eleazar said, so is the Mishnah: Her slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Paraphernalia slaves. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta, 9:1</a>, disagrees except if she has other children (since otherwise if for any reason the pregnancy did not result in a viable baby she had left the priestly clan at her husband’s death). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 67a" href="/Yevamot.67a">Babli, 67a</a>, formulates: “Paraphernalia slaves eat if and only if she eats.”</i> may eat, his slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Mortmain slaves.</i> may not eat. For if it were not so, she would eat<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah mentions only her slaves but not herself. The childless widow of a Cohen reverts to her status before marriage with regard to heave. On the other hand, the Mishnah does not state that the rule applies only to a widow without other children. If she has children from the Cohen then certainly she remains part of his house and eats heave. There is no reason why the paraphernalia slaves should not eat because of her status.</i> but her slaves would not eat! Rebbi Josia in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If it is from this, she also should not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">One could find an argument that if the fetus disables her slaves it must disable her also.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai said before Rebbi Yose: Not that Rebbi Joḥanan disagrees, he only said, for if it were not so, she would eat but her slaves would not eat. There came a case before Rebbi Joshua ben Levi. <sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">This text, position, and argument is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 7:5:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.7.5.11"><i>Peah</i> 7, Note 137</a>.</i> He said, go out and look how the public behaves. Rebbi Abin said in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, not only this practice, but in any practical question which is weak in court and you do not know how to decide, go out and see how the public acts, and act accordingly. And we see that they do not eat. Rebbi Yose said, this means that [the fetus] does not disable anybody able to eat and does not enable anybody unable to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">This disproves R. Joḥanan’s attempted argument. Since the Mishnah does not mention her but mentions her mortmain slaves, the fetus does not disable her but cannot enable her slaves whose enabler has died and was not yet replaced.</i>.
Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose stated in the name of his father: If there was a daughter, she enables to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.1">Tosephta 9:1</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 67a" href="/Yevamot.67a">Babli 67a</a>. In both sources it is emphasized that only a daughter lets mortmain slaves eat during the pregnancy of her mother but not sons. As R. Moses Margalit points out, the thrust of the argument of the Babli (not its details) must be understood also in the Yerushalmi that a daughter enables only in the presence of a son. By biblical rules (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num.</i> 27:6–11</a>), a daughter inherits only in the absence of sons, but the standard marriage contract assures the upkeep of unmarried daughters as a lien on the estate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:11</a>). This means that the claim of the daughter to be fed as a member of the priestly clan is prior to and independent of any claim of the male heirs; since she is fed, the slaves who secure her claim also may eat.
