But if there are no male heirs, the daughters are heirs according to biblical standards. If the fetus is male, he becomes the sole heir. If female, she becomes a co-heir and the slaves cannot eat because of her part. If there are male heirs, a female fetus has no influence since the marriage contract stipulates only support for living daughters.</i>. Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Because she is able to take her upkeep away from them. Is a wife not also able to take her upkeep away from them<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The widow has a choice of either claiming her <i>ketubah</i> or staying in her house and being supported by the estate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:12</a>).</i>? She might request her <i>ketubah</i> be paid or lose her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">By any of the transactions mentioned in Mishnah <i>Ketubot.</i></i>. This is difficult! The <i>ketubah</i> is a biblical institution<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">At least for a virgin bride, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:16" href="/Exodus.22.16"><i>Ex.</i>22:16</a>. The rabbinic document is reported to be an institution of Simeon ben Šetaḥ, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 8:11:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.8.11.2-5"><i>Ketubot</i>, Yerushalmi 8:11</a> (fol. 32c), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 82b" href="/Yevamot.82b">Babli 82b</a>. The opinion that the origin of the <i>ketubah</i> of a virgin (not the details of the text) is rabbinic is found only in the Babli, attributed to R. Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 56a" href="/Ketubot.56a"><i>Ketubot</i> 56a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 10a" href="/Ketubot.10a">10a</a>).</i>, the upkeep of the daughters is rabbinical; do their institutions uproot a word of the Torah? It follows him who said that they accepted tithes voluntarily<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The laws connected with the distribution of land alter the first conquest became moot with the Babylonian exile. They were voluntarily reintroduced in the times of Ezra; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.7.1.1"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 7:1, Note 11</a>.</i>.
We find that Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose disagrees with his father<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Conjectural reading required by the context.</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is from <i>Ševi‘it</i>, Halakhah 7:1, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:3:1-2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.3.1-2">Notes 52–57</a>.</i> since Rebbi Simon said in the name of Hilfai: Rebbi, Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose and Ben Qappara voted on the airspace of Ascalon and declared it pure from the testimony of Rebbi Phineas ben Yaïr who said, we were descending to the Saracen [market] at Ascalon where we bought wheat, returned to our town, immersed ourselves and ate our heave. The next day they wanted to vote to free it from tithes but Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose removed his hand.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">He declined to vote positively.</i> He was leaning on Ben Qappara. He said to him, my son, why did you not say to me: did you not remove your hand? I would have told you that yesterday I was he who declared it impure, I am he who declared it pure. But now I am saying, maybe it was conquered within the meaning of the Torah, how can I free it from the meaning of the Torah? <sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The following sentence was copied in error; it belongs to the next item in <i>Ševi‘it.</i></i> When is it impure because of territory of Gentiles? But we found that he stated in the name of his father that they accepted tithes voluntarily<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In the previous paragraph it was shown that R. Yose must hold that all rules of heave are rabbinical since biblical heave would require that every farmer till his ancestral soil given to the family by Joshua. In the present paragraph, R. Ismael holds that the rules are biblical.</i>! And he said, it is correct that if tithes are from their words and the food of the daughters is of their words that their words may uproot their words<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic institutions it is of the essence that the originators can settle the order of precedence.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic institutions it is of the essence that the originators can settle the order of precedence.</i>“If there are males they enable to eat, females do not enable to eat.” <sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The following text does not make much sense. The discussion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 67" href="/Yevamot.67">Babli, 67a/b</a>, is too hypothetical to be of much help here.</i> If there are males, they enable to eat since there is one doubt, whether he is male or female<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">As <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rashi on Ketubot 67a" href="/Rashi_on_Ketubot.67a">Rashi (<i>Ketubot</i> 67a</a>) points out, there are two doubts, whether the pregnancy leads to a live birth or not and if there is a live birth whether it will be a male or a female. If there is no live birth, the males are the heirs and the slaves may eat because of them. If the baby is female, again the existing males are the heirs. The Yerushalmi probably holds that the miscarriages and female births just about equal the male births so that there are equal probabilities that the existing males are all heirs and the slaves may or may not eat because of them.</i>. A doubt in biblical matters forces restriction<sup class="footnote-marker">73,</sup><i class="footnote">A generally accepted principle, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 3a" href="/Beitzah.3a">Babli <i>Beṣah</i> 3a</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">If heave were a biblical precept, the slaves could not eat if there was a male heir; if heave is rabbinic, they are enabled by him.</i>. Females<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The deceased had only daughters, no son.</i> do not enable to eat since there are two doubts<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">There is only one doubt but it has two sides, both of which support the position of R. Simeon.</i>, whether he is male or female, (after she was betrothed or maybe before she was betrothed.)<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The text in parentheses makes no sense here; it belongs to another category of doubts, discussed at length in Tractate <i>Ketubot</i>, cf., e.g., Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 1:6–7.</i> A doubt regarding their words forces leniency<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">A generally accepted principle, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 3a" href="/Beitzah.3a">Babli <i>Beṣah</i> 3a</a>.</i>. However you take it, if he is male, everything is his<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Then the slaves are disabled since before the birth they have no master who might enable them.</i>. Female, she takes her part with them<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">This parallels the case of boys. In this case there is a doubt concerning the applicability of biblical law which requires restrictive interpretation.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The fetus<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the previous Mishnah.</i>, the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The (not priestly) childless widow of a Cohen who waits for the levir is prevented from eating heave, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 5:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.5.3.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 5:3</a>.</i>, the betrothal<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of a Cohen betrothed to a non-Cohen is disabled.</i>, the deaf-and-dumb<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Since the deaf-and-dumb cannot legally acquire, his marriage is only of rabbinic validity.</i>, and the male nine years and one day old<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Who had intercourse with a woman, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.6.2">Chapter 5, Note 79</a>. If he is a Cohen and marries the woman rabbinically, he cannot enable her to eat heave until he grows two pubic hairs.</i> disable but do not enable to eat. If there was a doubt whether or not he had reached nine years and one dayt<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">If he did not reach the age of nine years and one day, his intercourse is inoperative and he did not disable a priest’s daughter. If he did reach that age, she is disabled.</i>; whether or not he had grown two pubic hairs<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">If he had not grown two pubic hairs his betrothal is not valid by biblical standards. If he is an Israel betrothed to the daughter of a Cohen she is not disabled. If he had grown two pubic hair his betrothal is valid by biblical standards and his betrothed is disabled. If the male is a Cohen and his wife an Israel, she can start eating heave only after he reaches adulthood (in the opinion of the Babli, once he had intercourse with her after growing two pubic hairs.)</i>; when the house fell on him and his brother’s daughter and it is not known who of them died first, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">If he died first, the niece who was his wife frees the co-wife from the obligation of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate. If she died first, the co-wife is permitted to the levirs.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The fetus, the levir, the betrothal,” etc. Rebbi Simeon said, here the logic is deficient, for if it is action to disable it also should be action to enable, and if it is not action to disable it also should not be action to enable<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The wording is correct in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.3">Tosephta 9:3</a>: “For if it is action to disable it also should be action to enable, and if it is not action to enable it also should not be action to disable.” S. Lieberman (<i>Tosephta ki-fshutah Yebamot</i>, pp. 83–85) shows that the question is restricted to the fetus.</i>. Rebbi Simeon is correct; what is the reason of the rabbis? “They shall eat”, they shall enable to eat. The one who may eat enables to eat, the one who may not eat cannot enable to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">See above, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.3">Notes 9–10</a>. Since in <i>Sifra</i> this is an argument of R. Simeon, S. Lieberman (<i>l</i>. <i>c.</i>) concludes that the objection of R. Simeon is a rhetorical device.</i>. They objected: there is the bastard who may not eat and he enables to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">This is a quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 5 4" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_5.4"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 5(4</a>), quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 69b" href="/Yevamot.69b">Babli 69b</a>; the scenario is elaborated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.7.1">Mishnah 7</a>. According to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.6.2">Halakhah 6</a>, Gentile or slave disable the woman partner from the priesthood; whether the child is a bastard is a matter of dispute (in Galilee, not in Babylonia). One has to assume that the desecrated mother of the disabled child has died. Since the verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>,12 speak only of “born in the house” and “descendants” without qualifications, the child from an improper union is as good as one from a proper union for the rules of eating heave. The biological fathers do not disable since they cannot be legal fathers; the child is the child of his mother and God alone, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:27" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.27"><i>Peah</i> 1:1, Note 116</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 31a" href="/Niddah.31a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 31a</a>.</i>! There is a difference, since it is written “born in the house<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev.</i> 22:11</a>. The simple meaning of the text is that slaves of a Cohen may eat heave, whether they are born in the house or bought by the master. The expression “born in the house” is extended here to disqualified children of the house.</i>”. Then the born should enable, the not born should not enable! There is a difference, <sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 6 1" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_6.1"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 6(1</a>) on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev.</i>22:12</a>, speaking about the issueless daughter of a Cohen returning to her father’s house to eat sanctified food. The text is also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 67b" href="/Yevamot.67b">Babli 67b</a>.</i> since it is written “and she returns to her father’s house”, to exclude the one waiting for the levir, “in her youth”, to exclude the pregnant one. Rebbi Yose said, that<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The language is not quite appropriate; it is influenced by the context of the quote at the end of the paragraph. R. Yose notes that the Tanna of <i>Sifra</i> interprets the biblical verse as implying the status of the fetus as described in the sentence; he should have said “the verse considers …”. The formulation as given is appropriate for the version of Ze‘ira/the rabbis who refer to rabbinic rules; “they” are the men of the Great Assembly who voluntarily reintroduced the rules of heave and tithes.</i> means that they considered pregnancy to be real to disable but did not consider it real to enable to eat. The words of the rabbis disagree since Ze‘ira<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 2:1:16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.2.1.16"><i>Berakhot</i> 2:1, Note 54</a>.</i> said, there<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. No parallel to this statement is found.</i> they state that the betrothed, the one waiting for the levir, and the pregnant, pay the capital but not the fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">If a person who is not enabled to eat heave transgresses and eats it, in general he is liable to pay for the amount he took plus a 25% fine to the priesthood; cf. <i>Terumot</i>, Chapters 6,7. Mishnah <i>Terumot</i> 7:2 states that the daughter of a Cohen never loses her priestly status, even if she is disabled from eating heave, to the effect that she never pays the fine.</i>. What are we speaking about? If about the daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel, even if she had children from him she is not an outsider for it. But we must deal with the daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen. If you say, they considered the fetus to be real to disable but did not consider it real to enable to eat, why does she pay the capital but not the fifth, should she not pay capital and fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Since even the marriage of the daughter of an Israel to a Cohen does not free her from the fine incurred before her marriage, Mishnah <i>Terumot</i> 6:2. This proves that the rule cannot be biblical; the reference to the verse is not a proof.</i>?
“The deaf-and-dumb disables.” Did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state: “The wife of the deaf-and-dumb or the insane immerses herself from her husband’s bosom and eats<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.4">Tosephta 9:4</a>: “The sane daughter of a Cohen married to an insane Israel …” Since marriages of the deaf-and-dumb or the insane are not valid, the woman does not lose her priestly status. She has to immerse herself after intercourse with her husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:18" href="/Leviticus.15.18"><i>Lev.</i> 15:18</a>) but is not disabled from eating heave. This contradicts the Mishnah.</i>”? Rebbi Abba Mari and Rebbi Mattaniah, one said, a disqualified deaf-and-dumb<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">A person whose intercourse would disable the woman even if he were hearing.</i>, the other said, a deaf-and-dumb levir<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">He disqualifies as levir, whose standing is not different from a hearing man; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.7">Chapter 6, Note 35</a>.</i>.
“Whether he had reached nine years and one day or not”, he is as if he were nine years and one day old to disable<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">If he did not reach the age of nine years and one day, his intercourse is inoperative and he did not disable a priest’s daughter. If he did reach that age, she is disabled.</i>; “whether he had grown two pubic hairs or not”, he is as if he had grown two pubic hairs to make her eat<sup class="footnote-marker">86,</sup><i class="footnote">If he had not grown two pubic hairs his betrothal is not valid by biblical standards. If he is an Israel betrothed to the daughter of a Cohen she is not disabled. If he had grown two pubic hair his betrothal is valid by biblical standards and his betrothed is disabled. If the male is a Cohen and his wife an Israel, she can start eating heave only after he reaches adulthood (in the opinion of the Babli, once he had intercourse with her after growing two pubic hairs.)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The Yerushalmi states here that a young man whose vows are valid can marry by biblical standards, an open question in the Babli. Cf. Mishnah Terumot 1:3, Note 105; Babli Niddah 46b.</i>.
“When the house fell on him and his brother’s daughter and it is not known who of them died first, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.” Why do we come here to state doubts? Since we had stated [the rules for] co-wives, we now state for doubts concerning co-wives.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The rapist, the seducer, and the insane<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Even if he is married to her since the insane cannot enter into any contract, not even a marriage.</i> do neither disable nor enable to eat, but if they are unable to marry in Israel they disable. How is that? If an Israel came upon the daughter of a Cohen, she may eat heave, if she became pregnant she may not eat. If the fetus was cut into pieces in her body<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">In that case, she did not give birth. If she has a child from a non-Cohen, the child prevents her from eating heave.</i> she may eat. If a Cohen came upon the daughter of an Israel, she may not eat heave, if she became pregnant she may not eat, if she gave birth she may eat<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The relationship of the child to his father does not depend on the marital status of the mother; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.5.1">Mishnah 2:5</a>.</i>. It turns out that the son’s power is greater than the father’s.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The rapist, the seducer,” etc. This means that rape does not disable an unmarried priestly woman<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The relationship of the child to his father does not depend on the marital status of the mother; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.5.1">Mishnah 2:5</a>.</i>.
This supports what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 9:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).9.4">Tosephta 9:4</a>: “The sane daughter of a Cohen married to an insane Israel …” Since marriages of the deaf-and-dumb or the insane are not valid, the woman does not lose her priestly status. She has to immerse herself after intercourse with her husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:18" href="/Leviticus.15.18"><i>Lev.</i> 15:18</a>) but is not disabled from eating heave. This contradicts the Mishnah.</i>: The wife of the deaf-and-dumb or the insane immerses herself from her husband’s bosom and eats, against Rebbi Eleazar, since Rebbi Eleazar said, also if an unmarried man had intercourse with an unmarried woman not for the purpose of marriage it is copulation of harlotry<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.4">Chapter 6, Note 108</a>. The woman would be disabled from marrying into the priesthood. Quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 61b" href="/Yevamot.61b">Babli 61b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 59b" href="/Yevamot.59b">59b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 51a" href="/Sanhedrin.51a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 51a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Temurah 30a" href="/Temurah.30a"><i>Temurah</i> 30a</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Jeremiah: A woman who has been raped does not have to wait three months<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.6">Chapter 4, Note 166</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jonah said this before Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">He wanted to prove the statement of R. Abba from the Mishnah since a Cohen’s daughter who was raped continuous to eat heave until it is ascertained that she is pregnant; the Mishnah does not say that for three months after the rape she could not eat heave.</i>. He said to him, do not accept that from here, they were lenient for eating heave. If a daughter of a Cohen was married to an Israel, her husband went overseas, and she received notice that he died, does she not immediately eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">If she has no child, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a>. But even though the husband left more than three months before his death, the widow must wait three months before remarrying. The argument is rejected in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 69b" href="/Yevamot.69b">Babli, 69b</a>.</i>? But because of a fetus she has to wait three months.
“If they are unable to marry in Israel they disable.” These are<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 68a" href="/Yevamot.68a">Babli 68a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 8:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).8.1">Tosephta <i>Yebamot</i>8:1</a>, <i>Niddah</i> 6:1.</i>: “A child of nine years and one day<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i>, an Ammonite, Moabite, or Egyptian<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Yadayim 4:4" href="/Mishnah_Yadayim.4.4">Mishnah <i>Yadaim</i> 4:4</a> notes that modern Ammonites, Moabites, and Egyptians are no longer the peoples living in these places at the time of the Exodus; therefore, the prohibitions of<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:4-9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.4-9"><i>Deut</i>. 23:4–9</a> are no longer operative. All arguments based on these rules are theoretical exercises of retrospection.</i> proselyte, or a bastard, desecrated, Gibeonite<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Chapter 2, Note 72</a>.</i>, Samaritan<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Their problems are discussed in the next Halakhah.</i>, and Gentile who had intercourse with the daughter of an Israel, a Cohen, or a Levite, disqualified her for the priesthood. Rebbi Yose said, everybody’s intercourse disqualifies whose descendant would be disqualified; his intercourse does not disqualify those whose descendant would not be disqualified. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, in all cases, if his daughter is permitted to you, so is his widow<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">For a Cohen, not necessarily for anybody else.</i>; if his daughter is not permitted to you, neither is his widow.” In what do they differ? Rebbi Joḥanan says, an Ammonite or Moabite proselyte<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">A female Moabite or Ammonite was never prohibited from marrying a Jew (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.1">Mishnah 8:3</a>; <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 249.). The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 69a" href="/Yevamot.69a">Babli 69a</a>.</i> is between them. For him who says, everybody’s intercourse disqualifies whose descendant would be disqualified, here since his descendant<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">If he is a male (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.1">Mishnah 8:3</a>).</i> would be disqualified, his intercourse disqualifies. For him who says, if you may marry his daughter you may marry his widow, here since you may marry his daughter you may marry his widow. The words of the Sages? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of [the rabbis], Rebbi Abba, both say: Regarding the daughter of an Ammonite or Moabite proselyte or the daughter of a second-generation Egyptian<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Any third generation Egyptian, male or female, is permitted; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.9"><i>Deut</i>. 23:9</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.1">Mishnah 8:3</a>.</i>, even though his daughter is permitted to you, his widow is forbidden to you. Rebbi Zakkai: Rebbi Alexander sent to ask [about] the daughter of an Ammonite proselyte and the daughter of a second-generation Egyptian. Rebbi Yose said to him, did you not hear that Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of the rabbis, Rebbi Abba, both say: Regarding the daughter of an Ammonite proselyte or the daughter of a second-generation Egyptian, even though his daughter is permitted to you, his widow is forbidden to you. And everybody’s intercourse disqualifies whose descendant would be disqualified. Do we not need it when her mother was from Israel? That you should not say that since her mother was desecrated so her daughter was desecrated. In addition, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagreed, the daughter of an Ammonite proselyte or the daughter of a second-generation Egyptian<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">From a Jewish mother.</i>, Rebbi Joḥanan said, they are acceptable, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they are disqualified. Rebbi Yose ben Abun said, they disagree about the old women<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">The mother, the wife of an Ammonite or second generation Egyptian.</i>: Rebbi Joḥanan said, they are acceptable<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">He follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. Rebbi Alexander’s question is not answered since it is moot anyhow.</i>, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they are disqualified.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A slave disables because of intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Since a free woman cannot marry a slave, her intercourse with him is a form of prostitution.</i> but not because of descendants. How is this? A daughter of an Israel [married] to a Cohen [or] the daughter of a Cohen [married] to an Israel had a son from him. The son went and was pressed on a slave girl who had a son from him; the latter is a slave<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">He has no legal relationship with his father.</i>. If his father’s mother was a daughter of an Israel [married] to a Cohen, she cannot eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">If her husband and all her descendants except that slave had died, she has no descendants in the priesthood and is barred from heave.</i>, the daughter of a Cohen [married] to an Israel may eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">If her husband and all her descendants except that slave had died, she has no descendants outside the priesthood and may eat heave.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A slave disables because of intercourse,” etc. From where that the intercourse with a slave disables? Rebbi Joḥanan said in the name of Rebbi Ismael: “If a Cohen’s daughter becomes a widow or a divorcee without issue,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev.</i> 22:13</a>. “If a Cohen’s daughter becomes a widow or a divorcee without issue, when she returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she shall eat from her father’s food.”</i>” from [a man] with whom she has widowhood or divorce she returns, from [a man] with whom she has no relation of widowhood or divorce she does not return. Rebbi Jeremiah objected: But if a widow whored she has no widowhood or divorce and she returns<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">If she is not married she cannot become a widow or be divorced. The objection is too stupid to deserve an answer since it is only required that she could have a marriage relationship, not that she actually must have had one.</i>! Rebbi Yose did not say so, but [he held] that the argument of Rebbi Joḥanan is reversed. In <i>Giṭṭin</i> he says, why are Samaritans disqualified? Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Ismael: Because if a Gentile or a slave has intercourse with a Jewish woman, the child is a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">In our text, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:4:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.4.2-5"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:5</a>, the statement is by R. Joḥanan in the name of R. Eleazar (the Tanna), in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:12:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.12.2-13"><i>Qiddushin</i> 3:14</a> it is an anonymous <i>baraita</i>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 45a" href="/Yevamot.45a">Babli, 45a</a>, the statement is by R. Joḥanan and R. Eleazar (the Amora); a parallel statement in the name of Rebbi.<br>There is no doubt in the Yerushalmi that the original Samaritans were Jews. They consider the children of a Jewish mother from a Gentile as Jewish, as is accepted as practice, under Babylonian influence, in the next Halakhah and as already was decided in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhah 4:15</a>.</i>. In <i>Qiddushin</i> one says, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, the child is a bastard. Here he says it in his own name but there he says it in the name of Rebbi Ismael! For also according to the words of the Sages the child is a bastard. Rebbi Ḥizqiah did not say so, but: the argument of Rebbi Joḥanan is reversed. In <i>Giṭṭin</i> he says, why are Samaritans disqualified? Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Ismael: Because if a Gentile or slave has intercourse with a Jewish woman, the child is a bastard. In <i>Qiddushin</i> one says, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, the child is a bastard. Here he says, from [a man] with whom she has widowhood or divorce she returns, from [a man] with whom she has no relation of widowhood or divorce she does not return<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">This implies that the child of a Gentile or a slave is not a bastard since the only person to be affected is the mother who cannot return to her priestly status if she was the daughter of a Cohen.</i>. Rebbi Mattaniah said, I went to Seḥora and heard: Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Ismael the sons of Jesua: “If a Cohen’s daughter becomes a widow or a divorcee without issue,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev.</i> 22:13</a>. “If a Cohen’s daughter becomes a widow or a divorcee without issue, when she returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she shall eat from her father’s food.”</i>” from [a man] with whom she has widowhood or divorce she returns, from [a man] with whom she has no relation of widowhood or divorce she does not return. And I said, that is correct, there is no bastard, following Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">It really is following R. Simeon from Timna (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.14.1">Mishnah 4:14</a>), but the more liberal R. Joshua will certainly agree that there is no hint of bastardy attached to the child. If the child is a girl, she will be disqualified from the priesthood, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhah 4:15</a>.</i>, for a bastard is only from a woman which is for him under an incest prohibition and for whom one is punished by divine extirpation.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A bastard disables and enables to eat. How is this? A daughter of an Israel [married] to a Cohen [or] the daughter of a Cohen [married] to an Israel had a daughter from him. If the daughter went and married a slave or a Gentile and had a son from him, that is a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">In practice, he is an unblemished Jew.</i>. If his mother’s mother was a daughter of an Israel [married] to a Cohen, she can eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">.If the grandmother’s husband and her daughter had died, the grandson is descended from a Cohen and keeps his grandmother in the priestly clan.</i>, the daughter of a Cohen [married] to an Israel cannot eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">If the grandmother’s husband and her daughter had died, the grandson is descended from an Israel and keeps his grandmother out of the priestly clan.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A bastard disables,” etc. Does that not disagree with Rav, since Rav said that if a Gentile or a slave has intercourse with a Jewish woman, the child is acceptable. Explain it that the Gentile disables and the slave disables<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">While the Mishnah speaks of a bastard, the interpretation following the current practice is that both the daughter and the grandchild become disabled for the priesthood; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhah 4:15</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 70a" href="/Yevamot.70a">Babli, 70a</a>, simply states that the Mishnah either follows R. Aqiba or that Rebbi holds that the grandchild is a bastard by rabbinic standards since there is a general biblical prohibition of sexual relations with a person whom one could not marry, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:18" href="/Deuteronomy.23.18"><i>Deut.</i> 23:18</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Sometimes the High Priest disables. How is this? A Cohen’s daughter was married to an Israel and had a daughter from him. The daughter went and was married to a Cohen and had a son from him. The latter possibly is a High Priest serving on top of the altar. He enables his mother to eat and disables his mother’s mother<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">If he is the only surviving descendent, he keeps his grandmother out and his mother in the clan of priests.</i>. The latter says, not like my son the High Priest who disables me from heave<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">This seems to have been a proverb describing a paradoxical situation.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The High Priest,” etc. Bar Kappara stated: A one-day-old disables and enables to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">For the situation described in the Mishnah, it is not necessary that the grandson be an adult admitted to the Temple service.</i>.
So is the Mishnah: “Not like my son the High Priest who disables me from heave.<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The text has some slight copying errors.</i>” A Cohen’s daughter was married to an Israel and had a daughter from him; an Israel’s daughter was married to a Cohen and had a son from him. The two married and had a son. The latter possibly is a High Priest serving on top of the altar. He enables his mother to eat and disables his mother’s mother<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">To get the maximum effect from the rearrangement of the Mishnah, it should read “He enables his paternal grandmother {who was born Israel} and disables his maternal grandmother {who was born priestly}.” It simply means that only the husband’s affiliation counts.</i>. The latter says, not like my son the High Priest who disables me from heave.

Chapter 8



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The uncircumcised and any impure persons may not eat heave; their wives and slaves may eat. Someone injured in his testicles or with cut-off penis and his slaves may eat, his wives may not eat; but if he did not know her carnally after he was injured in his testicles or his penis was cut off, they may eat<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">No uncircumcised person may eat any sanctified food (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:48" href="/Exodus.12.48"><i>Ex</i>. 12:48</a>) nor any impure (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:3" href="/Leviticus.22.3"><i>Lev.</i> 22:3</a>). If these persons belong to the priestly clan they are not excluded by their disability (assuming the the Cohen is legally uncircumcised, e. g., as a hemophiliac). But the rules of entitlement to heave follow only the rules of membership in the priestly clan. The person injured in his testicles is prevented from marrying inside the congregation; therefore, his intercourse disables his otherwise entitled sex partner from heave.<br>The numerical inconsistency in the last sentence is in the Mishnah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The uncircumcised and any impure persons,” etc. “Every man<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:4" href="/Leviticus.22.4"><i>Lev.</i> 22:4</a>. The verse excludes impure persons from sanctified food. The inclusive “<i>every</i> man” implies that every man of the descendents of Aaron is included among the prospective eaters of heave since every man is exluded when impure. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:7" href="/Leviticus.22.7">Verse 7</a> notes that after immersion in water he may eat the sanctified food after sundown; this refers to heave which does not require a prior purification sacrifice.</i>”, to include the uncircumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 70a" href="/Yevamot.70a">Babli (70a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a">71a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 74a" href="/Yevamot.74a">74a</a>) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 4 18" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_4.18"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 4(18</a>) in the name of R. Aqiba. He takes the emphatic expression “<i>every</i> man” to mean that in addition to the persons excluded in the text there must be some category of excluded persons not mentioned in the text.</i>. Or “every man” to include the mourner<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner during the period between the death of a relative and his burial, who is excluded from all religious duties except the care for the burial. As R. Hila points out at the end, the exclusion of the mourner is mentioned only in the declaration of tithes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut.</i> 26:14</a>), which implies that even the Israel farmer may not eat his sanctified food (the Second Tithe) while in mourning. From there, it is inferred that the Cohen certainly is disabled during his mourning.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, it is written, “no outsider shall eat sanctified [food]<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:10" href="/Leviticus.22.10"><i>Lev.</i> 22:10</a>: “No outsider (a non-priestly Jew; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:4" href="/Numbers.18.4"><i>Num.</i> 18:4</a>) shall eat sanctified [food], a Cohen’s sojourner (foreign worker) and hireling shall not eat sanctified [food].” The verse clearly disqualifies persons because of their intrinsic status, not because of a temporary disability. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 4 16" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_4.16"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i>4(16</a>) also classifies the bastard as an outsider.</i>”. I forbade to you because of outside status, I did not forbid because of prepuce<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a">Babli 71a</a>, “I did not forbid because of mourning” which is immediately corrected to “say: not lack of circumcision.” One may not correct the Yerushalmi text according to the first version of the Babli (done by most commentators and the editors of the Zhitomir/Wilna text), since not only the principle of <i>lectio difficilior</i> but also the next sentence in the text, and the parallel discussion in the Babli preclude such an approach. It is clear from the start that both the uncircumcised and the mourner are forbidden heave, and the entire discussion is one of hermeneutics. No temporary disabilities have any place in the interpretation of vv. 10–13. The question is only whether the rather arbitrary approach of R. Aqiba has any justification.</i>. The reddish Rebbi Tiufa<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">A Galilean Amora of the fourth generation; his name appears also as Ṭaifa. His sobriquet may mean that he was a redhead.</i> asked before Rebbi Yose: may we not say, I did not forbid because of prepuce and because of mourning? He said to him, since one verse includes and the other excludes<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">It is the general method of R. Aqiba to analyze verses for expressions of inclusion and exclusion. The expression in 22:4: אִישׁ אִישׁ “man, man” (translated as “every man”) implies that some man is included in the set of persons excluded from heave who is not mentioned in the verse. On the other hand, if the verse had simply read אִישׁ אִישׁ מִזֶּרַע אַהֲרֹן צָרוּעַ אוֹ זָב the same meaning as in the actual verse אִישׁ אִישׁ מִזֶּרַע אַהֲרֹן <b>והוּא</b> צָרוּעַ אוֹ זָב could have been expressed in correct grammar with one less word. This is taken as an exclusion, “<i>only if he be</i> a leper or sick with gonorrhea”, which decreases the size of the excluded set. The verse deals only with temporary disabilities. The verse 22:10 dealing with permanent disabilities has no exclusion. It is therefore acceptable to include a permanently disabled person in the excluded set and to exclude from that set an additional temporarily disabled person.</i>, I am including the uncircumcised who is missing some procedure performed on his body and excluding the mourner who is not missing some procedure performed on his body. So far following Rebbi Aqiba. Following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael stated<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 4 18" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_4.18"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 4(18</a>). In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 70a" href="/Yevamot.70a">Babli (70a</a>) and the <i>Mekhilta deR. Ismael, Bo</i> (ed. Horovitz-Rabin, p. 54), the argument is presented in the name of R. Eliezer, adding to the arguments of B. Z. Wacholder [<i>The date of the Mekhilta de-R. Ishmael</i>, HUCA 39(1968) 117–144] about the dependence of that Mekhilta on the Babli.</i>: It said “sojourner and hireling” with regard to Passover<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:45" href="/Exodus.12.45"><i>Ex.</i> 12:45</a>.</i> and “sojourner and hireling” with regard to heave<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:10" href="/Leviticus.22.10"><i>Lev.</i> 22:10</a>.</i>. Since “sojourner and hireling” with regard to Passover implies disabling the uncircumcised, so “sojourner and hireling” with regard to heave must imply disabling the uncircumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">An application of the principle of גזרה שוה, R. Ismael’s rule 2: One word found in two different laws which in neither of them are needed for the understanding of the law, are written to permit the transfer of rules from one to the other.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai questioned: If “sojourner and hireling” with regard to Passover is in a group of laws disabling the mourner, also “sojourner and hireling” with regard to heave should imply disabling the mourner<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">However, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 8:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.8.8.1">Mishnah <i>Pesaḥim</i>8:8</a>, explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 8:8:2-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.8.8.2-9"><i>Pesaḥim</i> [Yerushalmi 8:8</a> (fol. 36b), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a">Babli 92a</a>] states that the mourner is excluded by biblical decree only from services during daytime. This means that the mourner (as long as he is not impure) is admitted to the Passover meal. R. Haggai attempts to discredit R. Ismael’s approach.</i>. Rebbi Hila answered: They inferred from “under, under” only items mentioned in the paragraph<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">While the argument of R. Hila is almost understandable, this sentence is not. Neither in the laws of Passover nor in those of heave is the word תחת used. The Babli, in a somewhat similar discussion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a">71a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 74a" href="/Yevamot.74a">74a</a>) discusses the seemingly superfluous inclusion of three expressions “ממנו” in the laws of the Passover sacrifice offered in Egypt (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:9" href="/Exodus.12.9"><i>Ex.</i> 12:9</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:10" href="/Exodus.12.10">10</a>). The argument there is not applicable here. All R. Hila seems to say is that one does not derive laws not touched upon in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:43-50" href="/Exodus.22.43-50"><i>Ex.</i> 22:43–50</a> from there.</i>. The sexless and the hermaphrodite came under another category<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The sexless is excluded from sacrifices since he probably is a male with an ingrown penis and therefore uncircumcised. The hermaphrodite is circumcised and accepted. His inclusion here has to be rated an editorial or scribal error since “sexless and hermaphrodite” is a frequently occurring combination. (A priest hermaphrodite is excluded from the sacrifices reserved for men and admitted to those open to women; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:2" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.2">Tosephta 10:2</a>.)</i>. The mourner comes from second tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner during the period between the death of a relative and his burial, who is excluded from all religious duties except the care for the burial. As R. Hila points out at the end, the exclusion of the mourner is mentioned only in the declaration of tithes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut.</i> 26:14</a>), which implies that even the Israel farmer may not eat his sanctified food (the Second Tithe) while in mourning. From there, it is inferred that the Cohen certainly is disabled during his mourning.</i>.
Rebbi Abun asked: Should not heave be forbidden to the mourner by an inference <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Second tithe, which has to be eaten by the farmer’s family who are not priestly (cf. Tractate <i>Ma‘aser Šeni</i>).</i>, which is permitted to outsiders, is forbidden to the mourner<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner during the period between the death of a relative and his burial, who is excluded from all religious duties except the care for the burial. As R. Hila points out at the end, the exclusion of the mourner is mentioned only in the declaration of tithes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut.</i> 26:14</a>), which implies that even the Israel farmer may not eat his sanctified food (the Second Tithe) while in mourning. From there, it is inferred that the Cohen certainly is disabled during his mourning.</i>, should not heave, which is forbidden to outsiders, be forbidden to the mourner? No. If you said it about tithe which needs an enclosure<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Inside the walls of Jerusalem or, earlier, of Siloh.</i>, what can you say about heave which does not need an enclosure? Therefore, since each of them has an aspect missing in the other, they cannot teach an inference from one to the other.
Are sacrifices forbidden for the uncircumcised? One cannot deduce the answer from Passover since they are not subject to [the prohibition of] breaking a bone<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">No bone may be broken of the Passover sacrifice; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:46" href="/Exodus.12.46"><i>Ex.</i> 12:46</a>. The bone marrow of other sacrificial animals is not forbidden. Therefore, no argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> is possible from Passover to other sacrifices.</i>, neither from heave since that would be inference after inference<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In general, the rules of R. Ismael may be combined with one another; an exeption are the rules of sacrifices and sanctified matter. This is discussed in detail in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 47a:12-57b:12" href="/Zevachim.47a.12-57b.12">Babli, <i>Zebaḥim</i> Chapter 5</a>, which has no parallel in the Yerushalmi. Even though the authorities quoted there are all Babylonian, the reference here shows that the basis of the arguments is a Yerushalmi tradition. It is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 50a" href="/Zevachim.50a">Babli, <i>Zebaḥim</i> 50a</a>, that rules 2 and 3 in the scheme of R. Ismael cannot be used one after the other. Since the exclusion of the uncircumcised from heave was an application of rule 2 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2">Note 12</a>), the result cannot be used as premiss for an argument of type 3. An attempt to formulate the rules in an extension of symbolic logic is in H. Guggenheimer, <i>Über ein bemerkenswertes logisches System aus der Antike,</i> Methodos 1951, 150–164.</i>. At the end, you have to say “from it, from it<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">An application of rule 2 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2">Note 12</a>).</i>.” Since “from it”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:9" href="/Exodus.12.9"><i>Ex.</i> 12:9</a> (once), 10 (twice). The Babli must reject this argument since it deduces laws of Passover from all three instances of the word.</i> which was said in the laws of Passover implies that the uncircumcised is disqualified, so “from it”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:14" href="/Leviticus.7.14"><i>Lev.</i> 7:14</a>. The verse is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Menachot 8:2" href="/Mishnah_Menachot.8.2">Mishnah <i>Menaḥot</i> 8:2</a>.</i> which was said in the laws of sacrifices must imply that the uncircumcised is disqualified. Are sacrifices forbidden for the mourner?<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">There is no inference to be drawn from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:6" href="/Leviticus.10.6"><i>Lev.</i> 10:6</a> since, after the death of Nadab and Abihu, Aaron and his sons were commanded not to mourn.</i> “From it, from it.” Since “from it” which was said in the laws of tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The Second Tithe, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut.</i> 26:14</a>.</i> states that the mourner is disqualified, so “from it” which was said in the laws of Passover<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This word indicates an oversight by editor or copyist since (1) from the laws of Passover nothing can be inferred for other sacrifices and (2) the mourner (whose relative died outside of Jerusalem so that he could not defile himself) is admitted to the Passover sacrifice. It most probably should read “sacrifices” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.4">Note 22</a>).</i> must imply that the mourner is disqualified.
Is it free<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">This refers back to the argument (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2">Notes 9–12</a>) that the uncircumcised is barred from eating heave. It is claimed that the conditions for application of rule 2, גזרה שוה, are not fulfilled.</i>? Has it not been used for a derivation? As it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 70a" href="/Yevamot.70a">Babli 70a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 4a" href="/Kiddushin.4a"><i>Qiddushin</i> 4a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 62a" href="/Zevachim.62a"><i>Zebaḥim</i> 62a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 4 17" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_4.17"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 4(17</a>).</i>: “Sojourner”, that is the one who is permanently acquired, “hireling” the one temporarily acquired<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:10" href="/Leviticus.22.10"><i>Lev.</i> 22:10</a>: “A Cohen’s sojourner or hireling shall not eat from sanctified food.” Who are sojourner and hireling? They cannot be Gentiles; these were excluded in the first part of v. 10. They cannot be slaves; these are included (when circumcised) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11">v. 11</a>. They must be Hebrew “slaves”, i. e., indentured servants. The verse states that the money paid in acquiring a Hebrew slave is paid not to acquire his person but his working and earning power. Therefore, they are not able to partake of sanctified food. The Hebrew slave who is permanently acquired is the one who refuses to leave when his six years of indenture are passed; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:5-6" href="/Exodus.21.5-6"><i>Ex.</i> 21:5–6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 15:16-17" href="/Deuteronomy.15.16-17"><i>Deut.</i> 15:16–17</a>.<br>According to tradition, the institution of Hebrew slaves disappeared with the first commonwealth and could never be re-introduced. The argument here is purely one of biblical interpretation, not of actual law.</i>. It should only say “sojourner”; why does the verse mention “hireling”? Should the one who is permanently acquired be forbidden to eat and the one temporarily acquired be permitted? But I would have said that “sojourner” means the one temporarily acquired; the mention of the “hireling” teaches that “sojourner” means the one permanently acquired. Rebbi Mathias<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">He is mentioned only here.</i> said, since it is written “no uncircumcised person may eat from it,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:48" href="/Exodus.12.48"><i>Ex.</i> 12:48</a>.</i>” it is as if free from one side<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">While the verse in <i>Lev.</i> is used for clarification about the Hebrew slave, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:46" href="/Exodus.12.46"><i>Ex.</i> 12:46</a> cannot speak about him since no circumcised Jew is excluded from the Passover sacrifices. Therefore, the verse is not used for other deductions and the application of rule 2 might be justified.<br>The Yerushalmi does not clarify the difference between a straight גזרה שוה in which neither part is used for other implications (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2">Note 12</a>), and a conditional one in which only one of the conditions is fulfilled, which may be rejected on logical grounds. This is made explicit in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 70b" href="/Yevamot.70b">Babli, 70b</a>.</i>.
In the opinion of Rebbi Aqiba, for which reason were “sojourner or hireling” written for heave<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">He derives the exclusion of the uncircumcised from another verse, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.2">Note 8</a>. For him there is no necessity to explain “sojourner and hireling” as (no longer applicable) Jewish slaves; he takes “sojourner and hireling” both with respect to heave as with respect to Passover as Gentiles who have not completed the process of conversion.</i>? Like what Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Yasa, if somebody bought uncircumcised slaves from a Gentile with the understanding that he would circumcise them<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">That sentence seems to be incomplete. The following rules imply that nobody can be forced to be circumcised against his will. (This is the majority opinion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 48a" href="/Yevamot.48a">Babli, 48a</a>). A Jewish buyer will prefer to buy slaves only with their prior agreement to be circumcised.</i>. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If somebody bought uncircumcised slaves from a Gentile with the understanding that he would circumcise them, they [still] cannot eat heave even if circumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">If the buyer is a Cohen, the slave can become part of his household only if he became Jewish by circumcision followed by immersion in a <i>miqweh.</i> If the last step is missing, the conversion is void. A lawful conversion is necessary since upon manumission the slave becomes a full Jew.</i>. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If somebody bought slaves from a Gentile with the understanding that he would circumcise them but they changed their minds, he keeps them for twelve months. If they accept, it is fine; otherwise, he may sell them to a Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">But a converted slave cannot be sold to a Gentile under any circumstances. This rule and the following story also are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 48b" href="/Yevamot.48b">Babli, 48b</a>. The Babli also quotes R. Aqiba to the effect that one does not buy or keep a slave who did not give his prior agreement to be circumcised.</i>. Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: It happened that somebody bought a village full of uncircumcised slaves from a Gentile with the understanding that he would circumcise them but they changed their minds. He came and asked the rabbis. They said to him, keep them for twelve months. If they accept, it is fine; otherwise one follows the local customs.
Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman also said: Rebbi Joshua ben Levi was in Laodicea and met there Rebbi Jehudah the Patriarch<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The grandson of Rebbi.</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joshua ben Levi.</i> wanted to leave early, when he<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah Neśia.</i> said to him wait for us tomorrow to immerse this woman convert. Rebbi Zera<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">He might be R. Ze‘ira,name written in Babylonian style.</i> asked Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman: Was that to honor the old man<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joshua ben Levi.</i> or because one does not immerse a woman convert at night? He said to him, because one does not immerse a woman convert at night. A case came before Rebbi Yose whether one may immerse converts at night. They could not agree<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 46b" href="/Yevamot.46b">Babli, 46b</a>, the Galilean authorities are quoted without dissent that conversion needs a court of three judges and must be executed during daytime since “judgment” is written in this respect (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:16" href="/Numbers.15.16"><i>Num.</i> 15:16</a>).</i>.
A slave may be a permanent sojourner<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">A slave may refuse to be circumcised and stay in the Jewish household as a “sojourner”, a Gentile who has accepted the seven Noahide commandments (prohibition of idolatry, murder, adultery and incest with direct descendents; eating flesh torn from living beings, blasphemy; prohibition of robbery, duty to live under the rule of a civil law). As such he is under the protection of the often repeated commandment to treat the sojourner well and he can be tolerated in a Jewish household since his touch does not make wine prohibited (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 64b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.64b">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 64b</a>).<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 48b" href="/Yevamot.48b">Babli, 48b</a>, this is the position taken by R. Ismael; R. Aqiba (48b) and R. Eliezer (71a) prohibit keeping uncircumcised slaves.</i>. A sojourner is like a Gentile in every respect<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">This is not meant to be a generally valid statement; the idolator is not protected by the Covenant of the sojourner. What is meant is a rather technical detail. It is stated repeatedly in the Torah, e. g. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.18"><i>Deut.</i> 13:18</a>, that statues and other idolatrous objects are prohibited for any use by a Jew. Therefore, valuables of an idolatrous character may only be used by Jews (for example, melted down for their precious metal content) if they come into the hand of a Jew already profaned, i. e., if a non-Jew has treated them contemptuously, preferably damaging them. The Yerushalmi holds that the sojourner still has the power of a Gentile to render profane objects of idolatry even though he is a monotheist, and make them available for a Jew to use. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 64b-65a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.64b-65a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 64b/65a</a>, explains away all the reasons quoted in this paragraph and decides that only an idolator can effectively render idols profane.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Ḥiyya bar Jehudah in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: One keeps the sojourner for twelve months. If he changes his mind, that is fine; otherwise he is like a Gentile in all respects<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">This statement, that the status of sojourner is only temporary and should lead to full conversion is not found anywhere else.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Ḥiyya bar Jehudah, Rebbi Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi: The sojourner has to accept on condition that he may eat cadaver meat<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 64b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.64b">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 64b</a>, the opinion of “others” is that the sojourner has to accept all commandments in the Torah except those of kosher food.</i>. Rebbi Hila said, one would then say, the words are [interpreted] as they are written. What does it mean, the words are [interpreted] as they are written? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, “You shall not eat any cadaver; to the sojourner in your midst you shall give it that he eat it<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:21" href="/Deuteronomy.14.21"><i>Deut.</i> 14:21</a>: “You shall not eat any cadaver; to the sojourner in your midst you shall give it that he eat it, or sell it to a stranger.” This seems to imply that cadaver meat must be donated to the sojourner or sold to the Gentile. Whether it may be sold to the sojourner or donated to the Gentile is a matter of controversy in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 21b" href="/Pesachim.21b">Babli (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 21b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 20a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.20a"><i>Avodah zarah</i> 20a</a>) and <i>Sifry Deut</i> # 104. R. Hila wants to decide following the majority that a sale to the sojourner is permitted.</i>.” Some Tannaim state: One does not receive a sojourner unless he accepts all commandments written in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 64b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.64b">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 64b</a>, the opinion of “others” is that the sojourner has to accept all commandments in the Torah except those of kosher food.</i>. Some Tannaim state: One does not receive a sojourner unless he renounces his idolatry<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 64b" href="/Avodah_Zarah.64b">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 64b</a>, this is the opinion of R. Meïr. The operative majority opinion there, that he has to accept all seven Noahide commandments, is not mentioned in the Yerushalmi.</i>. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi: One does not receive a sojourner unless he renounces his idolatry as a Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This is the same statement as the preceding one, only it emphasizes that the sojourner has not lost his power to render idols profane which was his as an idolator.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, from their consensus: unless he renounces his idolatry as a Gentile. For if it were not so, what would we say? Since he is forbidden idolatry he cannot render profane. But are Gentiles not also forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The Noahide precepts are supposed to be valid for all mankind.</i> idolatry and they do render profane? Rebbi Yose said, that you should not say, since he is equal to an Israel in three respects, do not oppress<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:14" href="/Deuteronomy.24.14"><i>Deut.</i> 24:14</a>: “Do not oppress the poor hireling, or the deprived, from your brothers or the stranger in your land, in your gates.” The stranger who has the right of permanent residence in your gates is the approved sojourner.</i>, do not cheat<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:17" href="/Deuteronomy.23.17"><i>Deut.</i> 23:17</a>: “With you he shall dwell in your midst, at the place which he will chose, where he feels well within one of your gates; do not cheat him.”</i>, and he is exiled like an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The exile of the homicide to one of the cities of refuge, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:15" href="/Numbers.35.15"><i>Num.</i> 35:15</a>: “For the children of Israel and the sojourner in their midst should these six cities be a refuge.”</i>, that he has no power to render profane. Therefore, it was necessary to spell out that he renders idols profane like a Gentile. Who is the Tanna who includes “do not oppress”? He is Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">More explicit in Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 111b, Tosephta <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 10:4. In the latter source, it is explained that the prohibition of oppression includes the obligation to pay the day-laborer immediately.</i>: The sojourner is protected by the prohibition, the words of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah.
Rebbi Jehudah says, the sojourner on a Sabbath is like a Jew on a holiday. Just as a Jew bakes and cooks but is forbidden to work, so is the sojourner on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 9a" href="/Keritot.9a">Babli, <i>Keritut</i> 9a</a>, this is the opinion of R. Aqiba.</i>. Rebbi Yose says, the sojourner on a Sabbath is like a Jew on the intermediate days of a holiday<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is the opinion of the anonymous majority.</i>. Just as a Jew on the intermediate days of a holiday collects from the field but is forbidden agricultural work, so is the sojourner on the Sabbath. Rebbi Simeon says, the sojourner on a Sabbath is like a Jew on the remaining days of the year<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, he explicitly includes the sojourner-slave working for himself; work for the Jewish owner is forbidden.</i>. Just as a Jew on the remaining days of the year ploughs, sows, and harvests, so does the sojourner on the Sabbath. Rav Ada, Rav Hamnuna, Rav Ada bar Aḥawa in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, quoted by <i>Šiṭṭa Mequbeṣet</i> from manuscript: Rav Idi bar Naḥman in the name of Rav Ada bar Ahava (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:2:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.2.7"><i>Berakhot</i>, Chapter 1, Note 161</a>.)</i>.
It is written: “Any slave who is a man bought by money<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:44" href="/Exodus.12.44"><i>Ex</i>. 12:44</a>: “Any slave who is a man bought for money, when you have circumcised him, then he may eat from [the Passover sacrifice].” In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 48a" href="/Yevamot.48a">Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 48a</a>) the anonymous opinion here is the minority opinion of R. Simeon ben Eleazar. The <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> follows the Yerushalmi; the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a"><i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> follows the Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 71a</a>) in referring the sentence “then he may eat from [the Passover sacrifice]” to the owner who in that interpretation is barred from the sacrifice as long as not all his slaves are circumcised. (Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.8">Note 41</a>, the position of R. Aqiba).</i>.” You circumcise by force a slave who is a man<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The verse notes only the activity of the owner.</i>, you do not circumcise by force a son who is a man<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">A proselyte may only circumcise his minor sons with him.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan asked, does this imply that you may circumcise a minor by force? Even like one of undescended testicles<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The word אורכניס. has a number of explanations in the dictionaries which do not fit since they denote persons of high social standing. It is difficult to see how a foundling can be a son of a “ruler” (Mussaphia) or a “chief leader” (Kohut), etc. According to the context, one may translate בן not as “son” but “endowed with a certain quality” and take אורכניס as a composite of Greek ὀρχίς “testicles”, such as ὀρχιπέδη “restraint of testicles, impotence” (E. G.).</i>? Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Abba: It is so. “If he found there a foundling. If he immersed him as a slave, he circumcises him as a slave; [if he immersed him] as a free person, he circumcises him as a free person.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Makhshirin 2:7" href="/Mishnah_Makhshirin.2.7">Mishnah <i>Makhshirin</i> 2:7</a> explains that in a city where Jews and Gentiles dwell together, a foundling has the status of the majority (according to R. Jehudah the majority of those who abandon their children; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Makhshirin 1:6-7" href="/Tosefta_Makhshirin.1.6-7">Tosephta <i>Makhshirin</i> 1:8</a> he declares the foundling to be a Gentile or a slave if only one Gentile or female slave of childbearing age lives there.)</i>” Rebbi Joḥanan asked, as a slave, he circumcises him as a slave; even like one of undescended testicles? Rebbi Abbahu and Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia did not say so, but “any slave who is a man bought by money.” If your slave is a man, you circumcise him by force. If your son is a man, you do not circumcise him by force. This refers to what Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Yasa: If somebody buys uncircumcised slaves from Gentiles on condition that he will circumcise them, in any case if they are slaves who are men, you circumcise them by force. On condition<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">A condition negotiated with the slave trader.</i> that he will not circumcise them, he is like a son who is a man, you do not circumcise him by force.
The one drawn [circumcised]<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">A circumcised person who extended the skin of his penis that it should look like a prepuce and he should not be recognized as a Jew.</i>, the one born circumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">His circumcision had no connection with Judaism. He cannot be circumcised for fear that his penis would be injured. If one drop of blood can be drawn from him, then he is considered fully circumcised; see below.</i>, and the circumcised before he converted<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">His circumcision had no connection with Judaism. He cannot be circumcised for fear that his penis would be injured. If one drop of blood can be drawn from him, then he is considered fully circumcised; see below.</i> may not eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In the first two cases, if the man is a Cohen.</i>. Rebbi Zeriqan, Rebbi Yannay ben Rebbi Ismael, in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: As a fine. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac in the name of Rav: They instituted a fence<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 72a" href="/Yevamot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>, Rav Huna states that the drawn [circumcised] is forbidden heave only by rabbinic standards; everybody in the Yarushalmi will agree.</i>. What is the difference between them? If another person drew it<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Against the will of the person on whom the procedure is executed.</i>, or that it regrew by itself. If you want to say, it is a fine, there is no place for a fine. If you say they instituted a fence, nevertheless they instituted a fence.
“Circumcising he shall circumcise<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Gen. 17:13.</i>.” A decision for two circumcisions, one for the circumcision, the other for the uncovering<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The follow-up to the act of circumcision in which the skin is cut and plied back to uncover the corona.</i>. One for the uncovering, the other for the fibers<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Eventual fibers of the prepuce which have to be cleaned from the wound. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 72a" href="/Yevamot.72a">Babli, 72a</a>.</i>. So far following Rebbi Aqiba who said, these are expressions of additions<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation of double expressions is also attributed to R. Aqiba in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 27b" href="/Shevuot.27b">Babli, <i>Shevuot</i> 27b</a>.</i>. From where for Rebbi Ismael who said, these are double expressions in the style of the Torah, “going you went, desiring you desired, by stealing I was stolen<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 31:30" href="/Genesis.31.30"><i>Gen</i>. 31:30</a>, a speech of Laban; 40:15, Josef’s address to the cup-bearer. Both verses are without legal implications; this proves that the repetitions are a literary device to express emphasis. The same argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 27a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.27a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 27a</a>.</i>”? Rebbi Judah bar Pazi said, “then she said, a blood bridegroom for circumcisions<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 4:26" href="/Exodus.4.26"><i>Ex</i>. 4:26</a>, the inference is from the plural form מולות. {Modern interpreters take the words of the Ismaelite Ṣippora to be Arabic, “poor circumcised one, may it be for opulence”.}</i>,” from here that there are two circumcisions, one for the circumcision, the other for the uncovering; one for the uncovering, the other for the fibers. Rav said, “circumcising he shall circumcise,” from here that one has to draw a drop of covenant blood from one born circumcised. “Circumcising he shall circumcise,” from here that an uncircumcised Jew cannot circumcise until he circumcises himself; not to speak of an uncircumcised Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 46:8" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.46.8"><i>Gen</i>. <i>rabba</i> 46(8</a>), this is the argument of R. Joḥanan.</i>.
