Rebbi Levi said, it is written: “But you have to keep my covenant.” You and yours<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 46:8" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.46.8"><i>Gen</i>. <i>rabba</i> 46(8</a>), this is the argument of Rav Huna. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 27a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.27a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i> 27a</a>, it is attributed to Rebbi.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 27a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.27a">Babli <i>Avodah zarah</i> 27a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Avodah Zarah 3:5" href="/Tosefta_Avodah_Zarah.3.5">Tosephta <i>Avodah zarah</i> 3:13</a>.</i>: “A Jew may circumcise a Samaritan but a Samaritan may not circumcise a Jew since he is circumcised in the name of Mount Gerizim, the words of Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Yose said to him, where do we find in the Torah that circumcision needs intent? Let him continue to circumcise in the name of Mount Gerizim until he dies!” “The drawn should not circumcise [again] lest he get into danger, the words of Rebbi Jehudah. Rebbi Yose said to him, many drawn<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">They might have been forcibly circumcised in the general conscription ordered by Bar Kokhba.</i> ones were in the days of Ben Koziba, they all circumcised, lived, and begat sons and daughters. One has to draw a drop of covenant blood from the drawn [circumcised]<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">A circumcised person who extended the skin of his penis that it should look like a prepuce and he should not be recognized as a Jew.</i>, the one born circumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">His circumcision had no connection with Judaism. He cannot be circumcised for fear that his penis would be injured. If one drop of blood can be drawn from him, then he is considered fully circumcised; see below.</i>, and the circumcised before he converted.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">His circumcision had no connection with Judaism. He cannot be circumcised for fear that his penis would be injured. If one drop of blood can be drawn from him, then he is considered fully circumcised; see below.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar stated: The House of Shammai and the House of Hillel did not disagree that one has to draw a drop of covenant blood from the one born circumcised since that is a compressed prepuce; what did they disagree about? About the convert who converted when already circumcised, for the House of Shammai said one has to draw a drop of covenant blood from him, but the House of Hillel say, one does not have to draw a drop of covenant blood from him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifra Tazria‘ Pereq</i> 1(7); also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:9" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.9">Tosephta <i>Shabbat</i> 15:9</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 135a" href="/Shabbat.135a">Babli <i>Shabbat</i> 135a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 46:9" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.46.9"><i>Gen</i>. <i>rabba</i> 46(9</a>).</i> Rebbi Issac bar Naḥman said in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: Practice follows the words of the student<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">R. Simeon ben Eleazar, a student of R. Jehudah who is quoted in a <i>baraita</i> in the Babli as stating that the Houses of Shammai and Hillel disagree about the child born without prepuce.</i>. There came a case before Rav, who said: Who is he who said that it is a compressed prepuce<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 135a" href="/Shabbat.135a">Babli, <i>Shabbat</i> 135a</a>, he is quoted as deciding practice following R. Jehudah.</i>? That means<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The statement of R. Simeon ben Eleazar, who asserts flatly that the baby apparently without prepuce has a compressed prepuce, not that possibly he has one.</i>, he certainly is uncircumcised and one pushes the Sabbath away for him<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the next paragraph, a child born on the Sabbath is circumcised on the following Sabbath (if he is healthy enough to be circumcised on the eighth day.)</i>. Rebbi Abbahu said, one does not push the Sabbath away for him but one has to draw a drop of covenant blood from him<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">This is the uncontested anonymous decision of the Babli.</i>. A male child was born to Rav Ada bar Aḥawa in that condition<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 135a" href="/Shabbat.135a">Babli <i>Shabbat</i> 135a</a>. There, R. Ada bar Ahava accused himself of being punished for not following the ruling of his teacher Rav.</i>. He squeezed it, he died. Rebbi Abin said, his penis was damaged and he fasted for him that he should die. The rabbis of Caesarea said, his testicles became injured and he fasted for him that he should die.
A certain prepuce pushes away the Sabbath, but a doubtful one does not push away the Sabbath. “His prepuce<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 12:3" href="/Leviticus.12.3"><i>Lev</i>. 12:3</a>: “On the eighth day, one circumcises the prepuce of his flesh.” “The flesh” is the penis as boneless member; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 23:20" href="/Ezekiel.23.20"><i>Ez</i>. 23:20</a>. Since the commandment is unconditional, a baby boy born on the Sabbath has to be circumcised on the following Sabbath even though without the commandment it would be a desecration of the Sabbath and a capital crime.<br>From here to the end of the Halakhah, most of the text is also found in <i>Shabbat</i>, Chapter 18.<br>The text is from <i>Sifra Tazria‘ Pereq</i> 1(5), also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 134b" href="/Shabbat.134b">Babli <i>Shabbat</i> 134b</a>. The details are only applications of the general principle stated at the start.</i>”, his certain prepuce pushes away the Sabbath, but the hermaphrodite does not push away the Sabbath even though Rebbi Jehudah said one pushes away the Sabbath for the hermaphrodite and is punished for him by divine extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">He considers the hermaphrodite as a certain male. Therefore, cohabitation of a male with the female aspect of an hermaphrodite nevertheless is homosexual behavior; cf. Notes 243 ff.</i>. “His prepuce”, his certain prepuce pushes away the Sabbath, but the one born at dusk does not push away the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">When it is not clear whether the child was born on the Sabbath which starts at nightfall, which time is not well defined; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.5"><i>Berakhot</i> Chapter 1, Notes 20</a> ff.</i>. “His prepuce”, his certain prepuce pushes away the Sabbath, but the one born circumcised does not push away the Sabbath even though the House of Shammai say one has to draw a drop of covenant blood from him<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">This disproves the earlier statement that the child apparently born without prepuce has a compressed one.</i>.
There<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Chagigah 1:1:1-20" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Chagigah.1.1.1-20">Mishnah <i>Ḥagigah</i> 1:1</a>. This refers to the duty of pilgrimage. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:17" href="/Exodus.23.17"><i>Ex.</i>23:17</a>: “Three times a year all your male population <i>should be seen</i> before the Lord, the Eternal.”</i>, we have stated: “Everybody is required to be seen except the deaf-and-dumb, the insane, the minor, the sexless, and the hermaphrodite<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The first three are not subject to commandments, the last two may not be males.</i>.” What says Rebbi Jehudah in this respect? Let us hear from the following: Rebbi Joḥanan ben Dahavai said in the name of Rebbi Jehudah, “also the blind one.”<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Chagigah (Lieberman) 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Chagigah_(Lieberman).1.1">Tosephta <i>Ḥagigah</i> 1:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 2a" href="/Chagigah.2a">Babli <i>Ḥagigah</i> 2a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 4b" href="/Chagigah.4b">4b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 4b" href="/Sanhedrin.4b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 4b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 2b" href="/Arakhin.2b"><i>Arakhin</i>2b</a>.</i> Nobody says “also” unless he agrees with the preceding statement. The argument of Rebbi Jehudah seems to be inverted. There he says to exclude, but here he says to include<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">For the pilgrimage he agrees that the person whose masculinity is questionable is excluded but for circumcision he includes him as male.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah and the rabbis explain the same verse<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 17:14" href="/Genesis.17.14"><i>Gen</i>. 17:14</a>: “An uncircumcised male who refuses to circumcise the prepuce of his flesh …”</i>. The rabbis explain “uncircumcised”, why does the verse add “male”? Only if he is totally male<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">They disregard the existence of societies practicing female circumcision.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah explains “male”, why does the verse add “uncircumcised”? Even if he is partially male<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 136b-137a" href="/Shabbat.136b-137a">Babli, <i>Shabbat</i> 136b/137a</a>.</i>. But here, “all your maleness”, that excludes the hermaphrodite.
There<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shabbat 19:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shabbat.19.5.1">Mishnah <i>Shabbat</i> 19:5</a>.</i>, we have stated: “One does not circumcise a sick baby until he gets well.” Samuel said, even if he runs a fever for one hour one waits with him up to one month<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a">Babli, 71a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 137a" href="/Shabbat.137a"><i>Shabbat</i> 137a</a>, he gives a minimum of 7 times 24 hours.</i>. May one feed him with milk-substitute<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Some baby food made from heave grain.</i> from heave? May one rub him with heave oil? Let us hear from the following: “The uncircumcised and any impure persons may not eat heave; their wives and slaves may eat.” Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum: The prepuce is counted only from the eighth day onward<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 71a" href="/Yevamot.71a">Babli, 71a</a>, asserts the opposite, that uncircumcised babies of Cohanim may not be fed heave products.</i>. It was stated so: For the entire thirty days it is forbidden to feed him with milk-substitute from heave and forbidden to rub him with heave oil. How do you treat the night of the eighth day? Since it was stated: In the night of the eighth day it enters the corral to be tithed<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">A newborn animal is acceptable as sacrifice only after eight days. If a calf can be counted for tithing already in the night of the eighth day, that proves that one does not have to wait until it is daytime; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 12a" href="/Zevachim.12a">Babli <i>Zebaḥim</i> 12a</a>. Therefore, the baby may not be fed heave products between nightfall of the eighth day and the time of circumcision on the next morning.</i>, that means that the night of the eighth is treated like the eighth day. It was stated so: All seven days long one is permitted to feed him with milk-substitute from heave and permitted to rub him with heave oil.
There<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shabbat 19:1:2-6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shabbat.19.1.2-6.3">Mishnah <i>Shabbat</i> 19:6</a>: These are the fibers which invalidate the circumcision: flesh that covers most of the corona. If he was fat, one has to fix it because of the bad appearance. If he circumcised and did not fold back, it is as if he did not circumcise.</i>, we have stated: “These are the fibers which invalidate the circumcision.” Rebbi Avina in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: If it covers most of the height of the corona<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Making clear that “most” in the Mishnah refers to the vertical, not the horizontal. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 137b" href="/Shabbat.137b">Babli, <i>Shabbat</i> 137b</a>, this is a statement of Rebbi Avina in the name of (the Babylonian) RavJeremiah bar Abba. This is the correct version since R. Avina lived two generations before Rebbi Jeremiah (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 6:4:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.6.4.4"><i>Berakhot</i> Chapter 6, Note 148</a>).</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since he was a Galilean Amora of the last generation, his statement makes sense only if the preceding statement was Babylonian, i. e., that the Yerushalmi version also read “Rav Jeremiah bar Abba.”</i> said, if it covers most of the top of the corona. Rebbi Tebi in the name of Samuel: One checks at the time of an erection<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the fat baby mentioned in the Mishnah; if only the uncovered part of his corona is visible, nothing has to be done. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 137b" href="/Shabbat.137b">Babli, <i>Shabbat</i> 137b</a>, this is a statement of Samuel, modifying a tannaitic statement of Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:9" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.9">Tosephta <i>Shabbat</i> 15:9</a>).</i>. “If he circumcised and did not fold back, it is as if he did not circumcise.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shabbat 19:1:2-6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shabbat.19.1.2-6.3">Mishnah <i>Shabbat</i> 19:6</a>: These are the fibers which invalidate the circumcision: flesh that covers most of the corona. If he was fat, one has to fix it because of the bad appearance. If he circumcised and did not fold back, it is as if he did not circumcise.</i>” It was stated: He is subject to divine extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">The person who performs an invalid circumcision on the Sabbath.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: That is to say if there is no time left in the day to correct it. But if there is time left in the day to correct, he corrects without hesitation.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>baraita</i> also quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 133b" href="/Shabbat.133b">Babli <i>Shabbat</i> 133b</a> and determined there to disagree with R. Yose (the Tanna).</i>: As long as he is occupied with the circumcision, he may return both to fibers which invalidate the circumcision as also to fibers that do not invalidate the circumcision. Once he has stopped, he may return only to fibers which invalidate the circumcision. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the words of Rebbi Yose imply that even after he has stopped he may return even to fibers that do not invalidate the circumcision. Which [statement of] Rebbi Yose? That which we had stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 3:10:3-12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.3.10.3-12.1">Mishnah <i>Sukkah</i> 3:14</a>. R. Yose holds that since the Torah requires one to take a palm branch on the first day of Tabernacles (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:40" href="/Leviticus.23.40"><i>Lev</i>. 23:40</a>), even taking it out on the Sabbath cannot be punishable. The same then holds for the knife for a circumcision which must be performed on the Sabbath and the unleavened bread which <i>must</i> be eaten during the first night of Passover even if that happens to be on a Sabbath. (The remainder of Passover, leavened matter is forbidden but consumption of unleavened bread is not commanded.)</i>: “Rebbi Yose said, if the first day of Tabernacles falls on a Sabbath and somebody forgot [that it was the Sabbath] and took the palm branch into the public domain he is free [from punishment] since he took it out with permission.” Is it the same for the knife of circumcision, for a <i>maṣṣah</i>? Since Rebbi Joḥanan said, the words of Rebbi Yose imply that even after he has stopped he may return even to fibers that do not invalidate the circumcision, that means the same holds for the knife of circumcision, for a <i>maṣṣah</i>.
“If he did not know her carnally after he was injured in his testicles or his penis was cut off, they may eat.” Rebbi Eleazar said, this is Rebbi Eleazar’s and Rebbi Simeon’s<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">They say in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.3.1">Mishnah 6:3</a> that a priestly woman who is disqualified for marriage to a priest but nevertheless betrothed to a priest may continue to eat heave up to the time of the actual marriage. A similar discussion is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75a" href="/Yevamot.75a">Babli, 75a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, it is everybody’s opinion; there is a difference since he did not add an acquisition to disable<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The case is not comparable to that of a widow betrothed to a High Priest. In the latter case, the act of betrothal is an illegitimate act of acquisition which disqualifies the woman. But in the case here there was no transaction between the man and the woman which could change the latter’s status.</i>. It turns out that this disagreement parallels the other disagreement, since they disagreed: A priestly woman waiting for her levir who became eligible to two priestly levirs. If one of them “bespoke” her but did not have occasion to bring her to the marriage chamber before he became injured in his testicles or his penis was damaged<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Her situation is bad. If she goes ahead with the now forbidden marriage, she is disqualified from priestly prebends. If she does not go ahead, she needs a (rabbinic) divorce and becomes disqualified.</i>, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, since she is a candidate for disabling intercourse, she is disabled. Rebbi Joḥanan said, when he will copulate<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">If she stays engaged permanently, neither married nor divorced, she can continue to eat heave indefinitely.</i>. If one of them was qualified but the other disqualified, even Rebbi Joḥanan agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Her first husband’s death confers on her the equal candidacy of both levirs. This is a disabling change of status.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada asked before Rebbi Mana, if the qualified one “bespoke” her? He said to him, the disagreement of Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">But everybody will agree that marriage to the qualified levir will remove her temporary disability.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Who is injured in his lower parts<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah will investigate why דכא means the testicles. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>, and most moderns hold that the word means “crushed”, the object crushed being understood without being mentioned. In the opinion of the Yerushalmi, the root of the word is דך “downtrodden”, the lowest organ of the body.</i>? Everyone whose testicles are injured, even one of them. The one whose urethra<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Really “discharge pipe”; this meaning is used in the Halakhah.</i> is cut off, anyone whose penis is cut, but he is qualified if there is a thread’s<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: A hair’s breadth.</i> [breath] left of the corona. The ones injured in their testicles or with cut-off urethra are permitted [to marry] a convert or a manumitted woman; they are only forbidden to marry into the congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The definition of “congregation” is discussed in the Halakhah.</i>, as it was said<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:2" href="/Deuteronomy.23.2"><i>Deut.</i> 23:2</a>.</i>: “No one with a damaged testicle or with cut-off penis may marry into the Eternal’s congregation.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Who is injured in his lower parts,” etc. “Injured,” I would have said in his eye. The verse says “discharge pipe<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The original meaning of שפכה, translated in the Mishnah as “urethra”.</i>”, he is injured in the neighborhood of the discharge pipe. If he is injured in the neighborhood of the discharge pipe it might be his eye in the neighborhood of his nose<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Which also is a conduit for body discharges.</i>! The verse says, “the lowly”. What comes between his heels. Rebbi Ḥaggai said before Rebbi Mana, a man’s lowest part when he sits down are his testicles. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, that is correct. You should know that this is so since in all other cases “generations” are written except in this case since he is infertile<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In all other marriage prohibitions in that group, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3-9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3-9"><i>Deut.</i> 23:3–9</a>, the prohibition includes descendants. Only in v. 2 there is no mention of descendants. This is the only argument accepted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>.</i>. And not only if [a testicle] is injured but also if it is gangrenous, or dried up, or missing<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different text, including punctured and excluding dried-up testicles, is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.3">Tosephta 10:3</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75a" href="/Yevamot.75a">Babli 75a</a>.</i>. It was stated: Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa says: I heard in the vineyard at Jabne that nobody [born] with only one testicle can be fertile and he is a “sun eunuch”<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">A person infertile by natural causes is not forbidden to marry into the congregation. Rashba, in his commentary to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75a" href="/Yevamot.75a">Babli 75a</a>, has the version: “Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa says: I heard in the vineyard at Jabne that a person [born] with only one testicle <i>and</i> infertile is a ‘sun eunuch’”. The language in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75a" href="/Yevamot.75a">Babli, 75a</a>, seems to indicate that even a person who had one testicle removed with the second intact is not prohibited from marrying into the congregation.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, I heard that practice follows Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa but I do not remember from whom I heard it. Rebbi Immi said, certainly Rebbi Yose did not hear it from a minor personality. Samuel said, if a person with only one testicle will come before me, I shall declare him qualified. Rebbi Ḥuna said, because he thinks like Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Joḥanan. Rebbi Yudan ben Ḥanin said, but only the one of the right hand side<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Tosaphot <i>Yebamot</i> 75a/b, <i>s</i>. <i>v</i>. שאין read וּבִלְבַד שְּׁלֵימִין “only if intact”. This is by far the better reading but it is not accepted in the halakhic tradition.</i>. There came a case before Rebbi Immi. He said, yes, my daughter, you are permitted to him. But you should know that he is infertile. Rebbi Ze‘ira praised him for making the case clear.
Some Tannaïm state: Through human action he is disqualified, through Heaven’s action he is qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">This is the only opinion reporte in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>.</i>. Some Tannaïm state: He is disqualified both through human or Heaven’s action<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.3">Tosephta. 10:3</a>, this is the opinion of R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa.</i>. He who said, through human action he is disqualified, through Heaven’s action he is qualified, infers it from a bastard. “A bastard may not marry,” “no one with a damaged testicle may marry.” Just as a bastard is created by human action<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">There is no bastard without human incest or adultery. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>.</i>, so the one injured in a testicle is created by human action. He who said, he is disqualified both through human or Heaven’s action, from where does he infer it? Rebbi Mana said, from here: “No one with a damaged testicle may marry,” ever. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, he still infers it from a bastard. “A bastard may not marry,” “no one with a damaged testicle may marry.” Just as a bastard is created by Heaven’s action, so the one injured in a testicle is created by Heaven’s action. Is the bastard created by Heaven’s action? His formation is by Heaven’s action. They wanted to say that he who said, through human action he is disqualified, through Heaven’s action he is qualified, follows Rebbi Ismael the son of Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa; he who said, he is disqualified both through human or Heaven’s action, [follows] the rabbis. Rebbi Aḥai bar Pappaios<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Elsewhere, he is called R. Aḥa bar Pappus.</i> said before Rebbi Ze‘ira, all follows the rabbis. For instance, if scab developed and he rubbed or squeezed it off, that is human action induced by Heaven’s action.
“The one whose urethra is cut off, anyone whose penis is cut, but he is qualified if there is a thread’s [breath] left of the corona,” etc. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Of the upper side of the corona. Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: Of the lower side of the corona. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, of the lower side of the corona<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>, it is only required that a hair’s breadth of the corona be left along the greater part of the circumference of the penis.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 75b" href="/Yevamot.75b">Babli, 75b</a>, there are different opinions in the matter. Maimonides interprets the Babli as being parallel to the Yerushalmi; R. Jacob ben Asher (<i>Ṭur</i>) holds that the Babli opposes the Yerushalmi. A drainpipe is cut at a right angle to the pipe.</i>, they said, if it has the shape of a drainpipe, he is qualified. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, if it has the shape of a writing reed, he is qualified, of an inverted writing reed, he is disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">A writing reed (and a quill) is cut to be short at the top and long at the bottom; that is acceptable. But if the penis is cut short at the bottom and long at the top, it might not be possible to deliver the semen into the vagina and the man is disqualified for marriage.</i>. If it is punctured, from the inside he is disqualified, from the outside he is qualified. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Jehudah, “inside” [means] from the corona towards the body; “outside” [means] from the corona away from the body. If it is punctured, he is disqualified; if it became blocked, he is qualified. If [the urethra] is punctured, he is disqualified, because it pours out; if it became blocked, he is qualified because he can be fertile<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76a" href="/Yevamot.76a">Babli 76a</a>.</i>. That is a disqualification which can revert to a qualification. The only difference between one injured in his lower parts and one whose testicles are injured are medical rules since an injured testicle may heal, an injured urethra does not heal. What can he do? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rav Jehudah: He brings ants, lets them bite, and cuts them off<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76a" href="/Yevamot.76a">Babli 76a</a>. One clips off the bodies of the ants while they still hold the flesh together in their fangs.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥilqiah, Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: One did state this<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The statement in the Mishnah that people injured in their testicles may marry people forbidden to marry into the congregation. The injured Cohen remains a Cohen and may not marry at all; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76a" href="/Yevamot.76a">Babli 76a</a>.</i> only for an Israel with an injured testicle, but not a Cohen with an injured testicle. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3</a>.</i>: “All those forbidden to marry into the congregation may marry one another; Rebbi Jehudah forbids.” <sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs form <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.2-5">Halakhah <i>Qiddushin</i>4:3</a>.</i> Rebbi Jeremiah said, as a matter of principle, an Israel with an injured testicle may marry a female bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Since both are excluded from marrying into the congregation.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, it<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3</a>.</i> applies only to family blemishes, not to bodily defects. The strength of Rebbi Yose comes from the statement of Rebbi Ḥilqiah, Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: One did state this only for an Israel with an injured testicle, but not a Cohen, since, as you say there, if he is certainly a Cohen it is disabling if he married a convert<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">According to R. Joshua ben Levi, if he marries a convert (who is assumed to have had illicit sex before she converted) he becomes disabled for heave. For the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76a" href="/Yevamot.76a">Babli, 76a</a>, a Cohen injured in his testicles is disabled for heave and may marry a convert, siding with R. Jeremiah.</i>; here also, he is certainly an Israel and forbidden to marry a female bastard.
In the opinion of Rebbi Jehudah, may a male bastard not marry a female bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Kiddushin 4:3" href="/Mishnah_Kiddushin.4.3">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3 (Note 135</a>), R. Jehudah makes a sweeping statement that no two people disqualified from marrying into the congregation may marry one another. The rabbis also will agree that a Moabite or Ammonite cannot marry a Moabite or Ammonite woman, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>. R. Jehudah may hold that converts form a congregation of their own and therefore bastards are prohibited from marrying them but are permitted to marry bastards, or he may hold, as is asserted later in the Halakhah, that bastards should not marry any Jew and are prohibited from marrying other bastards.</i>? Let us hear from the following, as Rebbi Immi said, Rebbi Jacob from Gebal stated before Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Isaac bar Tevele in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Rebbi Jehudah stated that a male bastard should not marry a female bastard so that bastards should disappear from the world<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.11.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 3:13</a>, R. Tarphon counsels the male bastard to live with a slave girl whose children will be slaves not legally connected with him. If he converts (and therefore frees) his biological children at birth they will be converts, free from the taint of bastardy. The female bastard may marry a convert; since this marriage is legal and untainted, the child will be a convert, not a bastard (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.10.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 3:12</a>).</i>. Similarly, is an Ammonite man forbidden to marry an Ammonite woman? Was that needed for the rabbis? For if Rebbi Jehudah would think that disqualified converts form one of the Eternal’s congregations, then [the Ammonite] could not marry an Ammonite woman since for her he would be of the Eternal’s congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The text given is the corrector’s. The uncorrected text is inconsistent: שהוא קהל יי֨ אצלו which probably should be שהיא קהל יי֨ אצלו “for she belongs to the Eternal’s congregation [forbidden] to him,” cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>.</i>. He could not marry an Egyptian woman since for her he would be of the Eternal’s congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Jehudah only.</i>. Rebbi Mattania said, one frees a slave girl for him. Similarly, could an Egyptian man not marry an Egyptian woman? Let us hear from the following, as Rebbi Abbahu stated before Rebbi Joḥanan: “Rebbi Jehudah said, Benjamin, an Egyptian convert, was a student of Rebbi Aqiba. He said, I am an Egyptian convert married to an Egyptian convert. My son is an Egyptian convert; I shall marry him to an Egyptian convert so that my grandson will be qualified to marry into the congregation<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78a" href="/Yevamot.78a">Babli, 78a</a>, Rabba bar bar Ḥana justifies Benjamin against R. Aqiba since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.10.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 3:12</a> states that in all marriages that are perfectly lawful the status of the child is determined by that of the father alone.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba said to him, my son, it is not so. But you marry him to the daughter of an Egyptian woman convert so that there should be three generations on every side.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The text (without R. Aqiba’s remark) is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76b" href="/Yevamot.76b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 76b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78a" href="/Yevamot.78a">78a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 9a" href="/Sotah.9a"><i>Soṭah</i> 9a</a>. A full text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kiddushin (Lieberman) 5:4" href="/Tosefta_Kiddushin_(Lieberman).5.4">Tosephta <i>Qiddushin</i> 5:4</a>. There, the text is up-to-date, following <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Yadayim 4:5" href="/Mishnah_Yadayim.4.5">Mishnah <i>Yadaim</i> 4:5</a>: “Rebbi Aqiba told him: Benjamin, you erred in the practice. Since Sanherib came and mixed all peoples {by mass deportations}, neither Ammonites and Moabites {permanently barred} nor Egyptians and Edomites {barred for two generations} are in their places … but everybody may marry one of any family on earth.” But in Tosephta <i>Yadaim</i> 4:18 it is stated that from all peoples only the restrictions on Egyptians are valid since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 29:13" href="/Ezekiel.29.13">Ezechiel (29:13</a>) certified that the Egyptians returned to their land. In any case, it is clear that R. Aqiba asserts that an Egyptian woman may marry an Egyptian man.</i>”
Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3</a> he states that people who certainly are barred from marrying into the congregation may marry one another but that those of unclear status, foundlings and Samaritans, cannot marry. This and the next paragraphs are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.3.2-5"><i>Qiddushin</i> 4:3</a>.</i>. The words of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Who permit people who are certainly excluded to marry those who are excluded only because of doubt.</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac, it is written: “No bastard shall marry into the Eternal’s congregation”. He cannot marry into a congregation which is certain. He may marry if the membership in the congregation is questionable<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 73a" href="/Kiddushin.73a">Babli <i>Qiddushin</i> 73a</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.1">Mishnah 4:2</a>.</i> There, we have stated: “If it is doubtful whether [the child is] a nine-month’s child of the first [brother] or a seven-month’s of the second, he has to divorce her, the child is legitimate, and they are obligated for a reparation offering for a possible sin.” <sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.4">Halakhah 4:2, Notes 79–83</a>.</i> It was stated: “The first son could be High Priest, any second son possibly is a bastard. Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said, there is no such thing as a possible bastard.” Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob agrees in cases of doubt of Samaritans and desecrated persons. This refers to what we have stated there: “Ten classes returned from Babylonia.” In the opinion of Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob, eight. In the opinion of Rabban Gamliel and Rebbi Eliezer, nine. In the opinion of the rabbis, ten.
Rebbi Ḥinena said, the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.2-16"><i>Qiddushin</i> 4:1</a>. The paragraph is from there, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:1:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.1.2-6">Halakhah 4:1</a>.</i> does not follow Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah states that converts may marry anybody, including bastards.</i>, since Rebbi Jehudah said that four congregations are called “congregation”, the congregation of Cohanim, the congregation of Levites, the congregation of Israelites, the cogregation of converts. They objected to Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">In verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:2-9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.2-9"><i>Deut.</i> 23:2–9</a>, the expression “the Eternal’s congregation” appears 6 times. Should there not be 6 congregations?</i>, but is it not written, “one injured in his testicles should not come”? That refers to bodily blemishes<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:2" href="/Deuteronomy.23.2"><i>Deut.</i> 23:2</a>. This is a personal exclusion, not a generic one. This verse is not counted. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.2.5">Note 135</a>.</i>. But is it not written, “children that will be born to them, the third generation shall come from them”? That is a positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.9"><i>Deut</i>. 23:9</a>. The prohibition of Egyptians and Edomites is only by inference. Since it is a positive commandment to let Egyptian converts of the third generation marry into the congregation, it follows that the first two may not. But as a positive commandment, an infraction of the rule is not prosecutable. R. Jehudah counts only mentionings of “the Eternal’s congregation” connected to explicit prohibitions of groups.</i>. But the rabbis said, there are three congregations, the congregation of Cohanim, the congregation of Levites, the congregation of Israelites; “they shall not come, they shall not come, they shall not come<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbis agree that four times one finds the expression בקהל יי֨ לא יבא, but only three are left for symbolical inferences since at least one is needed for the fact of the prohibition.</i>.”
Example. The elder Rebbi Hoshaia and Rebbi Judah Neśia were sitting together. Rebbi Joḥanan ran und whispered into Rebbi Hoshaia the elder’s ear: May a Cohen who is injured in his testicles marry the daughter of converts? He<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah Neśia.</i> asked him, what did he tell you? He answered, a question which a carpenter, son of carpenters<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">A Sage, son of Sages.</i>, cannot resolve. He did not ask me about a convert, since she is like a whore for him<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.1">Mishnah 6:5</a>.</i>. He did not ask about an Israelite daughter, for she will be desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Since he remains a Cohen, he desecrates any woman forbidden to him.</i>. He asked only about the daughter of converts! Is the daughter of converts not an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.6.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:6</a>. If she was conceived after conversion, she is an Israel for everybody except R. Jehudah who excludes descendants of converts from the priesthood on basis of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 44:22" href="/Ezekiel.44.22"><i>Ez.</i> 44:22</a>. Cf. <i>Bikkurim,</i> Chapter 1, Notes 96, 104.</i>? You have to explain it following Rebbi Jehudah, since Rebbi Jehudah says, the daughter of a male convert has the status of a desecrated male<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Jehudah is not followed in practice, R. Joḥanan’s question is answered in the negative even by a minor capacity such as R. Jehudah Neśia.</i>.
If a Cohen had intercourse with a divorcee and had a daughter, and the daughter a daughter, what is her status? Rebbi Ḥanania and Rebbi Mana, one said she is qualified, the other said she is disqualified. The one who said she is qualified objected to the one who said she is disqualified: The daughter of a desecrated male is desecrated for the priesthood. Is this one<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">The Cohen’s granddaughter from an Israel son-in-law is explicitly qualified for the priesthood by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.6.1">Mishnah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:6</a>. An extended discussion of this case is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:6:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.6.2-7">Halakhah <i>Qiddushin</i> 4:6</a>.</i> not from an Israel? Why do you declare her disqualified?
<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:5-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.5-7"><i>Bikkurim</i> 1:6</a>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:1:17-18" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.1.17-18">Notes 101–106</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:7:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.7.2-3"><i>Qiddushin</i>4:7</a>.</i> Rebbi Jacob bar Idi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: It happened that a family in Rhodes was in bad reputation. Rebbi sent Rebbi Romanus to investigate them. He investigated and found that a grandmother had been converted at less than three years and a day of age, and he declared them fit for the priesthood. Rav Hoshaia said, he declared them fit following Rebbi Simeon. Rebbi Zeїra said, here it is everybody’s opinion since Rebbi Zeїra said in the name of Rav Ada bar Ahava, Rebbi Judan brings it in the name of Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The child of an adult is fit since it is a prohibition deduced from a positive commandment. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:13" href="/Leviticus.21.13"><i>Lev.</i> 21:13</a>) “But he shall take a wife in her virginity,” which is a prohibition deduced from a positive commandment. Similarly, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:14</a>) “only a virgin from among his people he shall take as wife,” not a proselyte. Any prohibition deduced from a positive commandment is a positive commandment. Rebbi Hoshaia objected: But the second generation of an Egyptian is under a prohibition deduced from a positive commandment! Rebbi Hoshaia turned around and said, a positive commandment for an Israel cannot be compared to a positive commandment for Cohanim. A positive commandment for an Israel implies a prohibition for everybody. A positive commandment for Cohanim implies a prohibition for Cohanim but a permission for Levites and Israel.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Ammonites and Moabites are eternally forbidden but their females are immediately permitted. Egyptians and Edomites are forbidden only for three generations, both males and females. Rebbi Simeon said, is it not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? If He permitted the females immediately in a case where the males are eternally forbidden, should we not permit the females in a case where He forbade the males only for three generations? They said to him: If it is practice<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">What in the Babli usually is called “practice going back to Moses on Mount Sinai”, meaning accepted practice whose origin lies so far back that its originator can no longer be ascertained. The Mishnah speaks only of Jews.</i>, we shall accept this; if it is a logical argument, there is a counter-argument. He said to them, in fact, I am declaring practice. Bastards and Gibeonites are eternally forbidden, both males and females.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Ammonites and Moabites are forbidden,” etc. “Ammonite<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:4" href="/Deuteronomy.23.4"><i>Deut.</i>23:4</a>.</i>,” but not female Ammonite. “Moabite<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:4" href="/Deuteronomy.23.4"><i>Deut.</i>23:4</a>.</i>,” but not female Moabite. Similarly, “Edomite<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:8" href="/Deuteronomy.23.8"><i>Deut.</i> 23:8</a>.</i>” but not female Edomite, “Egyptian<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:8" href="/Deuteronomy.23.8"><i>Deut.</i> 23:8</a>.</i>” but not female Egyptian? It is written: “Because they did not receive you with bread and water<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:5" href="/Deuteronomy.23.5"><i>Deut.</i> 23:5</a>, the reason for the exclusion of Ammonites and Moabites, even if converted.</i>,” should the women have received? “Who hired against you<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 6:5" href="/Micah.6.5"><i>Micah</i> 6:5</a>, speaking of Bileam being hired to curse the Israelites. The argument is slightly extended in <i>Sifry Deut.</i> #249, 250.</i>,” “who took counsel,” who usually hires? Males but not females. Who usually sits in counsel? Males but not females.
It is written: “Shaḥaraim fathered children in the fields of Moab, after he had sent them, Ḥushim and Ba‘arah his wives<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 8:8" href="/I_Chronicles.8.8"><i>1Chr.</i> 8:8</a>, speaking of the tribe of Benjamin. The verse probably means that he fathered children from a new Moabitic wife after he had divorced his two Benjaminite wives. The same text also in <i>Ruth rabba</i> 4:1.</i>.” “Shaḥaraim,” that is Boaz who was freed from sins. “He fathered children in the fields of Moab” because he married Ruth the Moabite. “After he had sent them,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The masoretic text reads מִן שִּׁלְחוֹ אוֹתָם “after he had divorced them”.</i>” he was from the tribe of Judah, of whom it is written, “he sent Jehudah before him<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 46:28" href="/Genesis.46.28"><i>Gen.</i> 46:28</a>.</i>”. “Ḥushim and Ba‘arah his wives,” can anybody father his wives? But it means that he was quick as a panther and explained the practice. “He fathered from New Moon his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 8:9" href="/I_Chronicles.8.9"><i>1Chr.</i> 8:9</a>. It might also mean: He fathered from his new wife.</i>,” should it not have been: he fathered from Baarah, one of his wives<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">The children of Ḥushim are mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 8:11" href="/I_Chronicles.8.11"><i>1Chr.</i> 8:11</a>; no children of Ba‘arah are mentioned.</i>? But through her, practice was newly defined: “Ammonite,” and but female Ammonite. “Moabite,” but not female Moabite.
One verse<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 17:25" href="/II_Samuel.17.25"><i>2S.</i> 17:25</a>.</i> says, “his name was Yitra the Israelite;” another verse says, “Yeter the Ismaelite<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 2:17" href="/I_Chronicles.2.17"><i>1Chr.</i> 2:17</a>. Both names refer to the same person, father of Amasa, nephew of David.</i>.” Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, he was an Ismaelite. And you say, he was an Israelite? But he entered the court of Isaiah<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the author of this piece identifies Isay with his descendant Isaiah 500 years later.</i> and found him sitting and explaining: “turn to me and be saved, all ends of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 45:22" href="/Isaiah.45.22"><i>Is.</i> 45:22</a>.</i>,” and converted. Then he gave him his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">It is very doubtful whether David’s sisters ever agreed to live under the authority of a husband.</i>. But the rabbis say, he was an Israelite, and you say, an Ismaelite? But he girded his loins like an Ismaelite and stuck his sword in the earth in court, to kill or be killed, to support the word of my teacher: I shall kill with this sword anybody who transgresses this practice: “Ammonite,” and not female Ammonite; “Moabite,” and not female Moabite. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, I have only what I did learn<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible that instead of משנה one should read משׂדה, “I have only ‘from the field’”, referring to the preceding paragraph that שדה מוֹאב is a catchword for Ruth the Moabite.</i>: “Naomi returned with Ruth the Moabite, her daughter-in-law, who returned from the fields of Moab<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 1:22" href="/Ruth.1.22"><i>Ruth</i> 1:22</a>.</i>.” She is the one who first returned from the fields of Moab. Afterwards, he<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 2:11" href="/Ruth.2.11"><i>Ruth</i> 2:11</a>, a speech of Boaz. The implication is that Boaz was instrumental in declaring Moabite women eligible for marriage before he became involved with Ruth since otherwise he would have had to recuse himself from decision making. In the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77a" href="/Yevamot.77a">Babli, 77a</a>, the decision is directly attributed to the prophet Samuel.</i> told her: “You abandoned your father and your mother.” He said to her: If you had come to us yesterday or the day before, we would not have accepted you.
Rebbi Zakkai stated before Rebbi Joḥanan: The daughter of an Ammonite convert is enabled, the daughter of an Ammonite woman convert is disabled. Rebbi Joḥanan told him: Babylonian, you crossed three rivers on your way and got lost! But both the daughter of an Ammonite convert and the daughter of an Ammonite woman convert are enabled<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that R. Zakkai only had heard the statement that the daughter of a male Ammonite convert was enabled to be married into the priesthood and concluded that the insistence on a male would imply the quite unreasonable implication that the daughter of a female Ammonite would be disabled. R. Joḥanan points out that the statement on the daughter of a male Ammonite convert is needed for itself if the mother is an Israelite woman. Since the marriage of the parents is forbidden, the mother becomes desecrated for the priesthood. It is noteworthy that the disability does not extend to the daughter.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77b" href="/Yevamot.77b">Babli, 77b</a>, one version of the statement of R. Zakkai is explicit: The daughter of an Ammonite and an Israelite woman is disabled. This is rejected by R. Joḥanan.</i>. Rebbi Yosa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The statement is needed only if her mother was from Israel. That you should not say, since her mother was desecrated, so the daughter is desecrated. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, she is enabled even for the High Priest. What is the reason? “In his peoples<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:14</a>, speaking of the High Priest, “only a virgin from among his people he may take as a wife.” In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77b" href="/Yevamot.77b">Babli, 77b</a>, R. Zakkai is the source of this argument but he wrongly requires the (converted) parents to be from the same people.</i>”. A people divided into two peoples, the males are forbidden but their females permitted. Rebbi Ḥaggai in the name of Rebbi Pedat: Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish did not say so, but the daughter of an Ammonite convert is disabled since she comes from a disabled drop<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77a" href="/Yevamot.77a">Babli 77a</a>, a different reason ascribed to him.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, we have stated thus: Of Gentiles married unconverted, the males are permanently forbidden but their females are immediately permitted. If they converted, the males are permanently forbidden but their females are permitted after three generations<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">If an Ammonite and an Egyptian woman married as Gentiles, the children are Ammonites since in permitted marriages the child’s status is that of the father. But if they married when converted, the child inherits the disabilities of both parents. Therefore, the daughter, who does not inherit any disability from her father, has the status of a second generation Egyptian from her mother (in the opinion of the rabbis who reject R. Simeon’s argument.)<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78a" href="/Yevamot.78a">Babli, 78a</a>, formulates this explicitly: Among Gentiles, the status of the father is determining. If they converted, the more disabled is determining.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of [Rebbi] Aḥa: A <i>baraita</i> states this: From where can you say that if one of any of the families of the earth cohabited with a Canaanite woman and she gave birth to a son, that you may buy him as a slave? The verse says, “whom they will father in your land,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:45" href="/Leviticus.25.45"><i>Lev.</i> 25:45</a>. In v. 44 it is stated that slaves may be bought (only) from the surrounding peoples, since Canaanites are not to be tolerated in the Land. It is then stated that a child fathered in the Land can be tolerated if his father was not a Canaanite; the argument is parallel to that of the <i>baraita</i> quoted earlier. The same statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78a" href="/Yevamot.78a">Babli, 78a</a>.</i>” not from those who dwell in your land.
Samuel bar Abba asked: Are generations counted for slaves? How is that? A converted<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">A slave circumcised as property of a Jew who will become a full Jew upon manumission.</i> Ammonite slave who married a converted Egyptian slave. After three generations they converted<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">As it stands, this makes no sense. One may either emend the text to read “were manumitted” instead of “converted” or one may read the fact of manumission into the expression “converted into full Jews”.</i>. If you say that generations are counted for slaves, the males are permanently forbidden but the females are permitted after three generations<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., the females are permitted immediately upon manumission of the third generation.</i>.
“They said to him: If it is practice, we shall accept this; if it is a logical argument, there is a counter-argument.” What could they have argued? Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina: Are not his grandchildren forbidden for three generations, both male and female<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>, incest with direct descendents is forbidden for three generations, equally for males and females. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77b" href="/Yevamot.77b">Babli, 77b</a>, has the same argument. There, the two questions of R. Abbahu are answered in the negative; incest prohibitions which concern capital crimes cannot be used as counter arguments in an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> involving simple prohibitions (regarding Ammonites and Moabites) or prohibitions derived from a positive commandment (regarding Edomites and Egyptians) but they may be used in applications of rules 3 and 4 of R. Ismael (under conditions not recognized by the Yerushalmi.)</i>? Rebbi Abbahu said that Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish questioned, does one argue a matter concerning bastardy in a matter not concerning bastardy? Rebbi Ḥaggai said that Rebbi Abbahu questioned, does one argue a matter concerning extirpation in a matter not concerning extirpation? He said to them, in fact, I am declaring practice and a verse supports me. “Sons,” not daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:9" href="/Deuteronomy.23.9"><i>Deut</i>. 23:9</a>: “Sons that will be born to them in the third generation shall come (masc.) for them into the Eternal’s congregation.” The entire sentence is in the masculine.</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Josia: The eleventh generation of bastards is qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">As marriage partners for all Jews.</i> following Rebbi Simeon; he does not use the principle of <i>gezerah šawah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The principle that identical expressions must have identical legal implications (R. Ismael’s rule #2). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:3" href="/Deuteronomy.23.3"><i>Deut</i>. 23:3</a> forbids the bastard <i>even up to the tenth generation</i>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:4" href="/Deuteronomy.23.4">Verse 4</a> forbids Ammonites and Moabites <i>even up to the tenth generation, forever</i>. The rule of <i>gezerah šawah</i> is invoked in <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. #248, 249 to imply that the prohibition of the bastard also is <i>forever</i>.</i>. It was stated: Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon says, in the eleventh generation of bastards, the males are forbidden and the females permitted. Here also the males are forbidden and the females permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar ben R. Simeon disagrees with his father and accepts the <i>gezerah šawah</i>, with the automatic consequence that it can be applied only to males since in the case of Ammonites it applies only to males. Female bastards are forbidden only to the tenth generation as stated explicitly in the verse.</i>. Rebbi Samuel ben Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, it turns out that Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon follows the argument of Rebbi Meїr. As Rebbi Meїr said, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is as if written in a verse, so Rebbi [Eleazar] ben Rebbi Simeon says, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is as if written in a verse. Here also, the males are forbidden and the females permitted. In that case, even immediately? Only from the tenth and further.
They asked Rebbi Eliezer, what is the status of the eleventh generation of a bastard? He said to them, bring to me a third generation and I shall declare him pure<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78b" href="/Yevamot.78b">Babli, 78b</a>.</i>. What is Rebbi Eliezer’s reason since he does not seem to follow Rebbi Ḥanina? As Rebbi Ḥanina said, once every sixty to seventy years the Holy One, praise to Him, brings a plague into the world to finish off the bastards and he takes the qualified ones with them in order not to publicize the sinners<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">This describes the situation in the later Roman Empire where the plague had become endemic during the reign of the emperor Hadrian.</i>. This parallels what Rebbi Levi said in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “In the place where the ascent offering has its throat cut before the Eternal, the purification sacrifice has its throat cut,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:18" href="/Leviticus.6.18"><i>Lev</i>. 6:18</a>; the purification sacrifice atones for inadvertent sins. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 32b" href="/Sotah.32b">Babli, <i>Soṭah</i> 32b</a>, the statement is by R. Joḥanan in the name of R. Simeon bar Ioḥai.</i>” in order not to publicize the sinners. What is the reason? “<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 31:2" href="/Isaiah.31.2"><i>Is</i>. 31:2</a>.</i> Also He is wise and brings evil;” should it not rather be “brings good”? But to teach you that even the evil that the Holy One, praise to Him, brings to the world, He brings in wisdom. “His word He did not remove,” why all this? “He overcomes the house of evildoers and accomplices of workers of iniquity.” That parallels what Rebbi Levi said in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “In the place where the ascent offering has its throat cut before the Eternal, the purification sacrifice has its throat cut,” in order not to publicize the sinners. Rav Huna said, no bastard lives more than thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">A convenient legal fiction which allows every male to marry every female without investigating his or her background. The same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78b" href="/Yevamot.78b">Babli, 78b</a>.</i>. When Rebbi Ze‘ira immigrated here, he heard voices call “he-bastard, she-bastard”. He said, what is this? There goes that of Rav Huna, since Rav Huna said, no bastard lives more than thirty days. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said to him, I was with you when Rebbi Abba, Rav Huna said in the name of Rav: No bastard lives more than thirty days, when? If it is unknown. Therefore, if it is known, he lives<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:11:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.11.2"><i>Qiddushin</i> 3:13</a>, the argument is by Rebbi Uqba bar Aḥa. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78b" href="/Yevamot.78b">Babli, 78b</a>, the entire argument is R. Ze‘ira’s, based on a statement of his teacher Rav Jehudah.</i>.
Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: In the future, the Holy One, praise to Him, will only deal with the tribe of Levi<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">He denies that all bastards automatically disappear (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:11:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.11.2"><i>Qiddushin</i>3:13</a>) and holds that in the days of the Messiah only from the tribe of Levy will they be eliminated by divine action.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 70b" href="/Kiddushin.70b">Babli, <i>Qiddushin</i> 70b</a>, the same verse is used to declare that the tribe of Levi is cleansed of bastards first of all the tribes.</i>. What is the reason? “<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 3:3" href="/Malachi.3.3">Mal. 3:3</a>.</i> The refiner will sit, the purifier of silver, and will refine them,” etc. Rebbi Ze‘ira said, like a man who only drinks from a clean cup. Rav Hoshaia said, because we are Levites, should we lose? Rebbi Ḥanina the son of Rebbi Abbahu said, also in the future, the Holy One, praise to Him, will deal with them charitably. What is the reason? “<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 3:3" href="/Malachi.3.3">Mal. 3:3</a>.</i> They will be for the Eternal presenters of an offering in charity.”
Rebbi Joḥanan said, one does not investigate a family in which a family disqualification<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Either a disqualification of bastardy or a disqualification for the priesthood.</i> has disappeared. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, a Mishnah says so: “There was a family in Bet Ṣerifa in Transjordan who was forcibly distanced by Ben Ṣion. Another [family] was there who was forcibly integrated by Ben Ṣion.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 8:7" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.8.7">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 8:7</a>. It is not known who this Ben Ṣion was. The text states that one family was deemed unworthy of marrying into priesthood against the will of the rabbis and one was declared worthy also against the will of the rabbis. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 70a" href="/Kiddushin.70a">Babli <i>Qiddushin</i> 70a</a>.</i>” Nevertheless, the Sages did not want to make their names public<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">This proves R. Joḥanan’s point that one may not investigate accepted families for disqualifications.</i>. But the Sages transmit them to their sons and students two times in a Week<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">A sabbatical period of 7 years.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, by the Temple service, I know them<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Reading אני for the ms. איני; following the <i>editio princeps</i>. Another formulation of the same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 70a" href="/Kiddushin.70a">Babli, <i>Qiddushin</i> 70a</a>.</i> and the leading personalities of the generation have disappeared in them. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Pashḥur ben Immer the priest had 5000 slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">4000 in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 70a" href="/Kiddushin.70a">Babli, <i>Qiddushin</i> 70a</a>. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 20:1" href="/Jeremiah.20.1"><i>Jer</i>. 20:1</a>.</i>, and their traces have disappeared in the high priesthood. These are the insolent in the priesthood. Rebbi Eleazar said, their main training<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">In modern Hebrew טִירוֹנוּת, from Latin <i>tiro</i> “recruit”, cf. <i>Ma‘aser Šeni</i> p. 214. The verse, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 4:4" href="/Hosea.4.4"><i>Hos</i>. 4:4</a>, proves that priest were quarrelsome long before Jeremiah’s time and strong-armed behavior is ingrained in Cohanim even without any admixture of slaves. The same argument by R. Eleazar in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 69b" href="/Kiddushin.69b">Bablim <i>Qiddushin</i> 69b</a>.</i>: “Your people is like quarrelsome priests.” Rebbi Abbahu said, Samaritans<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Who might be bastards in the rabbinic view; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.7">Chapter 4, Note 82</a>.</i> disappeared in thirteen villages in the times of persecution. They said, the village of Moshhan<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The village and the time of persecution are not identified.</i> is one of them.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Joshua said, I heard<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">An ancient tradition.</i> that the castrate performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife, and that the castrate does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife, and I cannot explain. Rebbi Aqiba said, I shall explain it. A castrate by human action performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">He certainly cannot perform levirate since he is not qualified to marry in the congregation. But his widow might be married in levirate.</i> and one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife since he had been qualified; a congenital castrate<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Literal translation: “A sun Castrate”.</i> does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife since he never had been qualified. Rebbi Eliezer said, it is not so, but a congenital castrate performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife since he might be healed, a castrate by human action does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife since he cannot be healed. Rebbi Joshua ben Bathyra testified about Ben Megisa in Jerusalem that he was a castrate by human action and they instructed that levirate be performed for his wife, to endorse the words of Rebbi Aqiba.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The castrate does not perform either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate; similarly, the she-ram does not perform either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah overrules the previous one even though usually the statement that a certain action had been executed determines practice.</i>. The castrate who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his sister-in-law did not disable her<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">All he did was an empty gesture.</i>; if he copulated with her he disabled her because it is incestuous<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Since levirate is permitted only if the couple can have children (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.6"><i>Deut</i>. 25:6</a>). Therefore, if one of the partners is certified sterile, the sister-in-law is under the incest prohibition of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>.</i>. Similarly, if the brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a she-ram, they did not disable her; if they copulated with her they disabled her because it is incestuous.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Joshua said, I heard,” etc. “That the castrate does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>” etc. “Similarly, if the brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a she-ram,” etc. What is a sun-castrate? Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, anybody whom the sun did not see qualified even for one hour<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 79b-80a" href="/Yevamot.79b-80a">Babli, 79b/80a</a>.</i>. If somebody stretched out his hand and castrated [the not yet born baby] in the womb, everybody agrees that [when born] he is prohibited from marrying into the congregation and he cannot perform either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate. One imposes upon him the restrictions of both castrate by human action and sun-castrate<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is both.</i> in this disagreement.
The argument of Rebbi Eliezer is inverted. There, he says “it is not so, but a congenital castrate performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife,” and you say so? Rebbi Iniah said, Rebbi Eliezer referred only to criminal responsibility<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is copied from the lost fifth chapter of Tractate <i>Niddah</i>. In the Mishnah there, the House of Hillel say that 20 year olds of both sexes who have not developed pubic hair should prove their age and then are declared as congenital castrate or she-ram and unable to perform either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate. The House of Shammai puts the age limit at 18 and R. Eliezer at 18 for the female and 20 for the male. From his silence about levirate one concludes that he agrees that the congenital castrate cannot perform either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate, in contradiction to his statement here in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.<br>The answer, given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80a" href="/Yevamot.80a">Babli 80a</a> by the Amora R. Eleazar, is that R. Eliezer only refers to the declaration of adulthood for the sun-castrate and the she-ram; for all other persons adulthood starts with the development of pubic hair.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: These are the words of Rebbi Eliezer, Rebbi Aqiba, and Rebbi Joshua. But the words of the Sages are that neither the castrate by human action nor the congenital castrate is able to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nor does one perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80b" href="/Yevamot.80b">Babli, 80b</a>, disagrees and holds that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.5.1">Mishnah 5</a> explains <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.4.1">Mishnah 4</a> and refers only to the congenital castrate who parallels the she-ram, following R. Aqiba.</i>. He cannot perform levirate, nor does one marry his wife in levirate. That is the Mishnah: “The castrate who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his sister-in-law did not disable her; if he copulated with her, he disabled her because it is incestuous.” The hermaphrodite who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for his sister-in-law did not disable her; if he copulated with her, he disabled her because it is incestuous<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 2:6" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).2.6">Tosephta, 2:6</a> and 11:2, equates all rules of the hermaphrodite with those of the congenital castrate. It seems that this tradition (ascribed to Rebbis Yose and Simeon in the next Mishnah) considers the hermaphrodite as a congenitally infertile male.</i>. “Similarly, if the brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a she-ram, they did not disable her; if they copulated with her, they disabled her because it is incestuous.”

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A congenital castrate priest who married an Israel daughter enables her to eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">He has a penis but no visible testicles. He is not injured in his testicles and, therefore, able to marry in the congregation.</i>. Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Simeon say, an hermaphrodite<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Since he has a penis and testicles, he is a male and may marry. That he also has female breasts and a vagina is irrelevant.</i> priest who married an Israel daughter enables her to eat heave. Rebbi Jehudah says, a seemingly sexless<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">He was born without apparent penis or vagina. If it turns out that he has a penis, covered by skin, that can be laid bare, he still is congenitally infertile.</i> who was cut open and found to be a male does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> since he is like a castrate. The hermaphrodite marries but is not married<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">A male marries, a female is married.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar says [a male] is guilty to be stoned for [homosexual intercourse] with an hermaphrodite as with a male.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A congenital castrate priest,” etc. It was stated: He enables her to eat breast and thigh<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">The part of breast and right front thigh from a well-being offering which has to be given to the Cohen and is eaten by him and his family; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:34" href="/Leviticus.7.34"><i>Lev.</i> 7:34</a>.
