In the interpretation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 81a" href="/Yevamot.81a">Babli, 81a</a>, “breast and thigh” stands for all gifts to the Cohen which are biblical; “heave” is today’s heave which is only a rabbinical obligation. The following discussion in the Yerushalmi shows that this cannot be the Yerushalmi’s interpretation.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he enables her for heave but not for breast and thigh<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 81a" href="/Yevamot.81a">Babli, 81a</a>, this position is ascribed to R. Simeon ben Laqish, the opposite statement to R. Joḥanan. Since practice in general follows R. Joḥanan, the two Talmudim take opposite positions in practice. According to the Babli, the entire discussion is about the hermaphrodite Cohen, not the one born without testicles. It seems from the second paragraph following that the Yerushalmi also has to be read in this sense.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, there are several arguments <i>de minore ad majus</i> in this matter. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina asked, what means “there are several arguments <i>de minore ad majus</i> in this matter”? He said to him, open your mouth and receive. Rebbi Mana said, he made fun of him. Rebbi Abun said, he gave him an example. <sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Tzav, Chapter 17 5" href="/Sifra,_Tzav,_Chapter_17.5"><i>Sifra Ṣaw Pereq</i> 17(5</a>). R. Simeon ben Laqish intimates that there may be more (amoraic) arguments in the vein of the tannaitic statement to be quoted.</i>“Since she eats heave that never was within the reach of an Israel, is it not logical that she should eat breast and thigh that were within the reach of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what the argument is. R. Abraham ben David in his commentary to <i>Sifra</i> gives two possible explanations. (1) Before the sin of the Golden Calf, first-borns exercised the priestly functions. (2) In the obligatory sacrifices of Passover and animal tithes, the Cohen gets nothing. (In profane slaughter he should get some other parts, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:3" href="/Deuteronomy.18.3"><i>Deut.</i> 18:3</a>. During the stay in the desert, profane slaughter was forbidden, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 17:3-4" href="/Leviticus.17.3-4"><i>Lev.</i> 17:3–4</a>). Since this shows that there is nothing intrinsic in the nature of a sacrifice which requires a part to be given to the Cohen, the Cohen’s parts are in some sense robbed from the Israel and given to the Cohen.</i>? Breast and thigh were within the reach of Israel but when they became guilty these were taken from them and given to the priests. I could think, since these were taken from them when they incurred guilt, so they would be given back to them when they acquire merit. The verse<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:34" href="/Leviticus.7.34"><i>Lev.</i>7:34</a>.</i> says, ‘I gave them to Aaron and his sons for an eternal law;’ since a gift is not returned, so these are not returned.”
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said the argument is about the daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">The problem is not that of a handicapped Cohen but arises anytime a perfectly normal Cohen marries outsides his clan. There is no mention of such a problem anywhere else in the Talmudim.</i>: Rebbi Joḥanan said, he enables her for heave but not for breast and thigh. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, there are several arguments <i>de minore ad majus</i> in this matter. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Ḥanina asked, what means “there are several arguments <i>de minore ad majus</i> in this matter”? He said to him, open your mouth and receive. Rebbi Mana said, he made fun of him. Rebbi Abun said, he gave him an example. “Since she eats heave that never was within the reach of an Israel, is it not logical that she should eat breast and thigh that were within the reach of Israel? Breast and thigh were within the reach of Israel but when they became guilty these were taken from them and given to the priests. I could think, since these were taken from them when they incurred guilt, so they would be given back to them when they acquire merit. The verse says, ‘I gave them to Aaron the priest<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">This is the correct quote.</i> and his sons for an eternal law;’ since a gift is not returned, so these are not returned.”
Is there nobody who disagrees with Rebbi Jehudah? Since Rebbi Yose said in the name of Rebbi Hila, one marries his<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">The hermaphrodite’s.</i> wife in levirate, that means that nobody disagrees with Rebbi Jehudah. If he betrothed, his betrothal is not problematic. If he was betrothed, his betrothal is problematic<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is forbidden to her male partner, she needs a divorce.</i>. If he was copulated with, he becomes disabled from heave like a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Like any woman having intercourse with a man she could not marry.</i>. That is difficult. Rebbi Niḥa bar Rebbi Sava<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">A student of Rebbis Jonah and Yose of the fourth generation.</i>, Rebbi Jonah in the name of Rav Hamnuna: Even with his own kind in any case<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Intercourse of two hermaphrodites disables both of them, whether homosexual or heterosexual.</i>. That is difficult, if he is a male, no male disables a male<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">It is inferred from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev.</i> 21:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14">14</a> that the intercourse of a Cohen with a woman forbidden to him in marriage desecrates the woman and her children but not the man [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor" href="/Sifra,_Emor"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> (7</a>)].</i>. If she is a female, no female disables a female<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">In the tradition of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 8:8:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.8.8.2-3">Yerushalmi (<i>Giṭṭin</i> 8:10</a>, fol. 49c) a lesbian relationship disables from heave for the House of Shammai but not for the House of Hillel. In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 76a" href="/Yevamot.76a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 76a</a>, lesbianism is undesirable but not sanctionable. [Rabbinic practice follows an obscure <i>baraita</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 9 8" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_9.8"><i>Sifra Emor Parasha</i> 9(8</a>)), the House of Shammai in the Yerushalmi, and Paul in Romans 1:26.]</i>. The male aspect of one disables the female aspect of the other<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Like any woman having intercourse with a man she could not marry.</i>. He enables his wives to eat but does not enable his slaves. He enables his wives to eat by his male aspect. But he does not enable his slaves because of his double aspect; his female aspect was desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">His female aspect is desecrated and his slaves barred from heave only if he ever had a sexual relationship with either a male or another hermaphrodite.</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi in the name of Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, only from the place of masculinity<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the last sentence in this Mishnah, the assertion of R. Eleazar ben Shamua (in the Babli, R. Eliezer) that for the definition of homosexuality an hermaphrodite is a full male. The position of R. Joḥanan here is an explicit statement of R. Eleazar (ben Shamua) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 10:2" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).10.2">Tosephta 10:2</a>.</i>. Rebbi Simon in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: even from the female place<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">For him, heterosexual intercourse of a male with an hermaphrodite is still homosexuality. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 83b" href="/Yevamot.83b">Babli, 83b</a>, that is the opinion of Rav.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Rebbi Joshua ben Levi retracted this, from the following verse<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:22" href="/Leviticus.18.22"><i>Lev.</i> 18:22</a>. As the Babli explains, on the face of it, the verse seems to support the first opinion of R. Joshua ben Levi, but a second look shows that the prohibition is to lie with a male, i. e., the male aspect of the hermaphrodite.</i>: “And with a male you should not lie in the way of a woman’s beddings”, one who may lie in two ways, including the female. Who is that? That is the hermaphrodite. Rebbi said, I looked for but did not find words of Ben Shamua about the hermaphrodite, for the entire group ganged up on me<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84a" href="/Yevamot.84a">Babli 84a</a>; there, “the students of R. Eleazar ben Shamua ganged up on him like chickens in a chicken coop.”</i>. Why? Not to make it public or because he was not worth it? What difference does it make? He usually made public. If you say, it was not to make it public<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">The uncommon form לגלע instead of the common לגלות seems so be an Arabism, from جلع “to uncover indecently”. It seems that the teachings of R. Eleazar ben Shamua’s students were esoteric.</i>, the publicity is already in his hand. The reason must be that he was not worth it. What could he made public? He inherits<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">If there are 2 children, a hermaphrodite and a daughter, at the death of the father the daughter has a claim on the estate for a dowry but the only heir is the hermaphrodite.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 83b" href="/Yevamot.83b">Babli, 83b</a>, which attributes the Mishnah to R. Eliezer, proves from parallel statements that the hermaphrodite is considered a full male only in respect to homosexuality. In all other respects, it is considered a case of doubt whether he is male or female.</i>, he testifies<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">He can testify formally in cases where a male witness is required (such as the validity of certain legal acts.)</i>, his grain offering is burnt completely<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">The grain offering of a Cohen is burned completely (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:16" href="/Leviticus.6.16"><i>Lev.</i> 6:16</a>); the grain offering of the daughter of a Cohen is treated like the offering of an Israel and most of it is eaten by the Cohanim in the Temple precinct.</i>, one says grace with him as with a male.

Chapter 9



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> There exist women<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Women who are forbidden but not by an incest prohibition whose marriages are nevertheless valid, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.3.2-3">Halakhah 2:3</a>.</i> permitted to their husbands but forbidden to their levirs, permitted to their levirs but forbidden to their husbands, permitted to both of them, or forbidden to both.<br>The following are permitted to their husbands but forbidden to their levirs: If a simple priest was betrothed<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: is married to.</i> to a widow and has a brother who is High Priest, or a qualified man married a qualified woman and has a disqualified brother<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: If a <i>desecrated</i>[priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a <i>qualified</i> brother.</i>, or an Israel married an Israelite woman and has a bastard brother, or a bastard married a bastard woman and has an Israel brother, [the women] are permitted to their husbands and forbidden for their levirs.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “There exist women permitted to their husbands,” etc. Rebbi Niḥa bar Sava asked before Rebbi Jonah: Why “married”? Even “betrothed”! Why a widow? even a virgin<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The questions show that the Mishnah before the Amoraim was the Babylonian version and that the Mishnah in the Yerushalmi ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> is a version modified according to the discussion here.<br>The questions refer to the Cohen who has a brother who is High Priest. A widow is forbidden to the High Priest even if she is not a sister-in-law. The same questions are asked in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84a" href="/Yevamot.84a">Babli, 84a</a>.</i>! Are these all? She and her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that with a woman also the co-wife is forbidden; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.3.1">Mishnah 2:3</a> and the commentary of Meïri, <i>Bet Habeḥira, Yebamot,</i> ed. Ḥ. Albeck, p. 89, Note עה.</i>. I also have others: The co-wife of one suspected of adultery is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A woman formally charged by her husband as a possible adulteress is forbidden to her husband until she undergoes the ordeal described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:11-31" href="/Numbers.5.11-31"><i>Num.</i>5:11–31</a> (<i>Sifry Num.</i> 8). If the husband dies before he can bring his suspected wife to the Temple, she cannot be married in levirate and neither can her co-wife but the suspicion of adultery of one wife has no bearing on the status of the co-wife in the marriage.</i>. If his brother had slept with the sister of one who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with him, she is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Brother A had married the sister of a woman who had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with brother B. If A dies childless, his widow is forbidden to B. However, this prohibition is purely rabbinical and its place should be in the discussion of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.4.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i>. If a qualified [priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a desecrated brother, she is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">While a qualified woman is not forbidden to marry a desecrated or otherwise disqualified man (see the next paragraph) and could have married the disqualified brother in a first marriage, she cannot be married in levirate since her child would be barred from the priesthood and could not come “in place of the deceased” who was a priest. The widow therefore is forbidden to the disqualified brother by the incest prohibition of the sister-in-law.<br>The mention of this sentence here is not a scribal error as assumed by the commentaries.</i>. This supports Rebbi Jonah, since Rebbi Jonah said, the groupings of Rebbi are not exhaustive<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Accepted by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84b" href="/Yevamot.84b">Babli, 84b</a>.</i>.
“If a qualified [priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a desecrated brother, she is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her levir.” Did not Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun say in the name of Rav that a proselyte, a freedman, and a disqualified priest are permitted priestly [wives]? So is the Mishnah: If a qualified [priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a desecrated brother. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said in the name of Rav: A proselyte, a freedman, and a disqualified priest are permitted priestly [wives]. What is the reason? Qualified men are warned against disqualified women and disqualified men against qualified women but not disqualified women against qualified men nor qualified women against disqualified men. Did we not state: “they should not take, should not take”, which teaches that the woman is warned through the man? They wanted to say, qualified women against disqualified women but it is only disqualified women against qualified women<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is in very bad shape. It seems that it should be corrected as follows:</i>.<br>“If a qualified [priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a desecrated brother, she is permitted to her husband and forbidden to her levir.” Did not Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun say that a proselyte, a freedman, and a disqualified priest are permitted priestly [wives]<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Priestly women are not enjoined to stay in their priestly status. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84b" href="/Yevamot.84b">Babli concurs, 84b</a>, also in the name of Rav.</i>? So is the Mishnah: If a <i>desecrated</i> [priest], married to a woman qualified for the priesthood, has a <i>qualified</i> brother<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Since the wife is disabled for the priesthood by her marriage to the desecrated man, she is forbidden to the brother.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said in the name of Rav: A proselyte, a freedman, and a disqualified priest are permitted priestly [wives]. What is the reason? Qualified men are warned against disqualified women but not disqualified women against qualified men nor qualified women against disqualified men. Did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84b" href="/Yevamot.84b">Babli 84b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 1 12" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_1.12"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 1(12</a>). The verse <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>, “A promiscuous and a desecrated woman <i>they should not take</i> and a woman divorced from her husband <i>they</i> <i>should not take</i>…” The two prohibitions are interpreted as one for the man, not to take a disabled wife, and one for the woman, not to seduce a man into a forbidden marriage.</i>: “they should not take, should not take”, which teaches that the woman is warned through the man? They wanted to say, qualified women against disqualified <i>men</i> but it is only disqualified women against qualified <i>men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The clause “nor qualified women against disqualified men” is shown to be false.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> These are permitted to their levirs and forbidden to their husbands: If a High Priest was betrothed to a widow and has a brother who is a simple priest, or qualified [priest] married a disqualified woman and has a disqualified brother, or an Israel married a bastard woman and has a bastard brother, or a bastard who married an Israel woman and has an Israel brother; [the women] are permitted to their levirs and forbidden to their husbands.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following are permitted to their husbands,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">A quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.1.1">Mishnah 2</a>, irrelevant for the sequel.</i>” etc. He only said “betrothed<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.2.1">Mishnah 3</a>, the mention of betrothal is essential; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.3.1">Mishnah 4</a> the mention of marriage. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.1.1">Mishnah 2</a>, either betrothal or marriage may be mentioned for the High Priest’s brother.</i>”, but if he copulated with her, the copulation disqualifies her. That is what we stated: “Forbidden to both of them.”
Are these all? There are others: If somebody takes back a woman he divorced after she had been married [to another man], she is forbidden to the husband<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut.</i> 24:4</a>.</i> but permitted to the levir. If he slept with the sister of a woman with whom he had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, she is forbidden to the husband<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A purely rabbinical prohibition as sister of a quasi-wife; cf. Halakhah4:7.</i> but permitted to the levir. If a man with injured testicles married a qualified woman, she is forbidden to the husband but permitted to the levir. This supports Rebbi Jonah, since Rebbi Jonah said, the groupings of Rebbi are not exhaustive<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Accepted by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84b" href="/Yevamot.84b">Babli, 84b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Forbidden to both of them: If a High Priest married a widow and has a brother who is a High Priest or a simple priest, or a qualified [priest] married a disqualified woman and has a qualified brother, or an Israel married a bastard woman and has an Israel brother, or a bastard married an Israel woman and has a bastard brother; these [women] are forbidden to both of them and all other women are permitted to their husbands and their levirs.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Are these all<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.9.3.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i>? There are others: A woman suspected of adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A woman formally charged by her husband as a possible adulteress is forbidden to her husband until she undergoes the ordeal described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:11-31" href="/Numbers.5.11-31"><i>Num.</i>5:11–31</a> (<i>Sifry Num.</i> 8). If the husband dies before he can bring his suspected wife to the Temple, she cannot be married in levirate and neither can her co-wife but the suspicion of adultery of one wife has no bearing on the status of the co-wife in the marriage.</i> is forbidden to both of them. The widow after <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">If a woman was freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> she is forbidden to all levirs. If nevertheless one of the levirs marries her, she remains forbidden to all of them.</i> is forbidden to both of them. If a man with injured testicles married a qualified woman and has a brother with injured testicles, she is forbidden to both of them. This supports Rebbi Jonah, since Rebbi Jonah said, the groupings of Rebbi are not exhaustive<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Accepted by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 84b" href="/Yevamot.84b">Babli, 84b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Secondary prohibitions instituted by the Sopherim<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.1">Mishnah 2:4</a>.</i>. If she is secondarily prohibited to the husband but not to the levir, she is forbidden to the husband but permitted to the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Since the first marriage was legitimate by biblical standards the levirate also will be legitimate by biblical standards.</i>. Secondarily prohibited to the levir but not to the husband, she is forbidden to the levir but permitted to the husband. Secondarily prohibited to both of them, she is forbidden to both of them. She may claim neither <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.3.1">Chapter 4, Note 84</a>.</i> nor usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">She cannot reclaim the usufruct the husband had from her dowry during the marriage.</i> nor upkeep nor wear<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">If part of the dowry was in the form of vessels or clothing, she cannot claim the diminution in value caused by wear during the marriage.</i> but the child is qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage is completely legitimate by biblical standards, the child is qualified even for the office of High Priest.</i> and one forces him to divorce her<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbinic court if it has the power to do so. All these rules are made to dissuade women to consent to such a marriage which otherwise they would have no incentive to refuse since the children are qualified.</i>. A widow married to the High Priest, a divorcee of one that performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> married to a simple priest, a female bastard or a Gibeoness married to an Israel, and Israel woman married to a Gibeonite or a bastard have a claim of <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Since in this case the children are disqualified, the woman has every incentive not to agree to such a marriage.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Secondary prohibitions instituted by the Sopherim,” etc. “If she is secondarily, rabbinically, prohibited to the husband but not to the levir, she is forbidden to the husband but permitted to the levir.” Does she have <i>Ketubah</i> from the levir? Since she is permitted to him, she has <i>Ketubah</i>, or because the <i>Ketubah</i> is a lien on the estate of her first husband and she was forbidden to him, does she have no <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The question is not answered; in the absence of a rule, no claim of the woman married in levirate can be enforced in court. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 85a" href="/Yevamot.85a">Babli, 85a</a>, decides that she has no <i>Ketubah</i>; in this case, the court will actively prohibit a claim of <i>Ketubah</i>.</i>?
“If she is secondarily prohibited to the levir but not to the husband, she is forbidden to the levir but permitted to the husband.” Does she have <i>Ketubah</i> from the levir? Since she is forbidden to him, she does not have <i>Ketubah</i>, or because the <i>Ketubah</i> is a lien on the estate of her first husband and she was permitted to him, does she have <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The question is not treated in the Babli. Her claim of <i>Ketubah</i> is not enforceable in court.</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, this is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:7:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.7.2-8">Halakhah <i>Ketubot</i> 11:7</a>.</i>“No usufruct.” Rebbi Jeremiah said, that he has from her only the usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This is the only right he has as a husband; he has no right to what she finds or earns, nor may he dissolve any of her vows.</i>. Rebbi Yose the Sidonian<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">An Amora of the fourth generation; he appears in the Babli as Rav Yosef Ṣidonî.</i> stated before Rebbi Jeremiah, in disgreement with Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 2:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).2.4">Tosephta, 2:4</a>, states the opposite: “He has no right to what she finds and earns, and no right to dissolve her vows.”</i>: “He has the right to what she finds and earns, and to dissolve her vows.” What means “no usufruct”? That she cannot reclaim from him the usufruct he had [from her property].
Rebbi Yose said: All the time Rebbi Hila told me, state in your <i>baraita</i> that he inherits from her and defiles himself for her<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 2:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).2.4">Tosephta 2:4</a>.</i>. We have also stated so: A man defiles himself for his qualified wife but does not become defiled for his disqualified wife<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">A Cohen is required to become impure for the burial of his close relatives (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-3" href="/Leviticus.21.1-3"><i>Lev</i>. 21:1–3</a>). The secondarily prohibited is a qualified wife by biblical standards; he must bury her. A divorcee for a Cohen is disqualified; he may not become impure for her.</i>.
Rebbi Abun asked before Rebbi Mana: May the slaves of a secondarily forbidden [wife]<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The mortmain slaves of the wife of a Cohen.</i> eat heave? He said to him, be quiet, it is better for you. She eats<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Her marriage is legitimate by biblical standards.</i> but her slaves do not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Since the husband has no obligation to feed her and her slaves, the acquisition is not complete and the slaves cannot eat from what the Cohen does not have to give them (Maimonides, <i>Hilkhot Terumah</i> 6:20, commentary of Radbaz.)</i>.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.7.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 9:8</a>.</i>: “A forced bill of divorce is valid in Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">If a rabbinic court forces the husband to divorce his wife, the divorce is valid.</i>; it is invalid from Gentiles.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife appeals to the Gentile court or ruler to force a divorce from her husband, the divorce document is invalid (except, as stated in the Mishnah, if the Gentile court or ruler forces the husband to obey the directives of the rabbinic court.)</i>” Samuel said, it is invalid and disqualifies for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The woman who uses the instruments of the Gentile government to force a divorce is not divorced but disqualified for the priesthood.</i>. And Samuel said, publicize in your towns: It is invalid and disqualifies for the priesthood. Samuel said, one does not force, only disqualify<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of parallel sources, it is difficult to ascertain the exact text and its meaning.</i>. Samuel said, one does not force except for example a widow married to a High Priest, a divorcee or one freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a simple priest. But did we not state: “Secondarily forbidden”? Did he not say “for example”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">He approves of judicial intervention in the case of any sinful marriage, whether by biblical or rabbinic standards.</i>? But did we not state: “A person who by a vow forbids his wife to have any usufruct from him, up to 30 days he shall appoint a caretaker; after 30 days he shall divorce her and pay <i>Ketubah</i>”! We heard that he shall divorce; did we hear that one forces him<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In this case, only moral pressure is acceptable; one may not jail the recalcitrant husband until he agrees to a divorce.</i>?
What is the difference between these and those<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Between the disqualified women married to priests who receive <i>Ketubah</i> at the time of divorce and the secondarily prohibited who do not.</i>? Since these are words of the Torah and the words of the Torah do not need support, therefore they have <i>Ketubah</i>. Those, because they are words of the Sopherim and the words of the Sopherim need support, therefore they do not have <i>Ketubah</i>. Some want to say since these are punished together with the child, they did not fine them, therefore they have <i>Ketubah</i>. Those, since they are not punished together with the child, they fined them, therefore they do not have <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">A more detailed discussion is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 2:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).2.4">Tosephta 2:4</a>/<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 85b" href="/Yevamot.85b">Babli 85b</a>. Both these sources stress that a disqualified woman has no reason to seek out a Cohen since her child will be desecrated whereas a secondarily forbidden (who might be permitted to him by another sect) might want to be married by a relative.</i> What is the difference between them? He who remarried his divorced wife after she had remarried<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This case is not discussed in the parallel sources.</i>. For him who says since these are words of the Torah, and this case is a word of the Torah, therefore she has <i>Ketubah</i>. For those who want to say since these are punished together with the child, this one, since neither she nor the child is punished, therefore, she has no <i>Ketubah</i>.
Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said that Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Hila say that they differ about upkeep<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of an irregular marriage of a Cohen.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, she may demand upkeep<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">From her husband.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said to him, one says to [him]<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Reading לה in the ms. and the <i>ediio princeps</i> as לו.</i>, divorce her! And you say so? They wanted to say so, they differ about the conditions attached to a <i>Ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The general framework of the obligations of a husband towards his wife and her heirs which can be enforced even if not written in the document (Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> Chapter 4).</i>. Everybody agrees that she cannot claim support since they even punished her heirs, so much more herself. But for him who says that they differ about upkeep it follows that they do not differ about the conditions attached to a <i>Ketubah</i>. They fined her but not her heirs.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> An Israel woman betrothed to a Cohen, or pregnant from a Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">A pregnant widow, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.3.1">Mishnah 7:3</a>. All cases will be explained in the Halakhah.</i>, or waiting for her Cohen levir, and also a Cohen woman betrothed to an Israel may not eat heave. An Israel woman betrothed to a Levite, or pregnant from a Levite, or waiting for her Levite levir, and also a Levite woman betrothed to an Israel may not eat tithe. A Levite woman betrothed to a Cohen, or pregnant from a Cohen, or waiting for her Cohen levir, and also a Levite woman betrothed to a Cohen may not eat either heave or tithe.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “An Israel woman betrothed to a Cohen.” “Any pure person in your house may eat it,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:11" href="/Numbers.18.11"><i>Num</i>. 18:11</a>, speaking of heave. While she was acquired by her husband (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>), she is not in his house before the actual marriage. She has a claim if the husband drags his feet for the marriage, cf. Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 5:2–3.</i>” but she is not in his house. “From a Cohen”, for the one born in his house; this one is not born in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the pregnant widow. The reason given is a misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>: “Any born in his house, they should eat from his food.” The unborn does not eat.</i>. “The one waiting for her Cohen levir,” “any pure person in your house may eat it,” but she is not in his house. “And also a Cohen woman betrothed to an Israel,” “a daughter of a Cohen when she will belong to an outside man<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev</i>. 22:12</a>: “she may not eat from the holy heaves.”</i>.” One<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Speaking of the parallel cases not mentioned in the Mishnah of a Cohen’s daughter betrothed to, pregnant from, or waiting for a levir of, an Israel.</i> pregnant from an Israel or waiting for an Israel levir: “When she returns to her father’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev</i>. 22:12</a>: “she may eat from her father’s food.” The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 87a" href="/Yevamot.87a">Babli, 87a</a>. A longer discussion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 6 1" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_6.1"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 6(1</a>)</i>,” that excludes the one waiting for her levir, “as in her youth<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Speaking of the parallel cases not mentioned in the Mishnah of a Cohen’s daughter betrothed to, pregnant from, or waiting for a levir of, an Israel.</i>,” that excludes the pregnant one.
“An Israel woman betrothed to a Levite,” “you and your house<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:31" href="/Numbers.18.31"><i>Num</i>. 18:31</a>.</i>” but she is not in his house. “Pregnant from a Levite,” “born in the house,” this one is not born in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the pregnant widow. The reason given is a misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>: “Any born in his house, they should eat from his food.” The unborn does not eat.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, is not “born in the house” written only for a Cohen? As you say there, whoever is born lets eat, whoever is not born does not let eat; here also whoever is born lets eat, whoever is not born does not let eat<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">All rules for the Levites are (rabbinically) derived from those of the Cohen; they are not biblical.</i>. “Waiting for her Levite levir,” “you and your house,” but he is not in her house. “And also a Levite woman”: “And a daughter of a Cohen when she will belong to an outside man<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev</i>. 22:12</a>: “she may not eat from the holy heaves.”</i>.” Is there not written “daughter of a Cohen”? Rebbi Yose said “daughter”, whether she is a Cohen’s or a Levi’s<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">This argument is a little less cryptic in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 68b" href="/Yevamot.68b">Babli, 68b</a>, in the name of R. Abba: Since it is written “<i>and</i> a daughter” and not simply “a daughter”, following R. Aqiba one has to add another category of daughters who do not eat their part of agricultural produce.</i>. The daughter of a Cohen who was married to an Israel may return and eat, the daughter of an Israel who was married to a Cohen may return and not eat. One<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Again the case of the Levite is assimilated into that of the Cohen.</i> pregnant from an Israel or waiting for an Israel levir: “When she returns to her father’s house,” that excludes the one waiting for her levir, “as in her youth,” that excludes the pregnant one.
“A Levitic woman betrothed to a Cohen.” “Any pure person in your house may eat it,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:11" href="/Numbers.18.11"><i>Num</i>. 18:11</a>, speaking of heave. While she was acquired by her husband (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>), she is not in his house before the actual marriage. She has a claim if the husband drags his feet for the marriage, cf. Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 5:2–3.</i>” but he is not in her house. “From a Cohen”, for the one born in his house; this one is not born in his house<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the pregnant widow. The reason given is a misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:11" href="/Leviticus.22.11"><i>Lev</i>. 22:11</a>: “Any born in his house, they should eat from his food.” The unborn does not eat.</i>. “The one waiting for her Cohen levir,” “any pure person in your house may eat it,” but she is not in his house. <sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This text is copied from <i>Ma‘aser Sheni</i> 5:9, Notes 176–177.</i>“Similarly, the daughter of a Cohen [betrothed] to a Levite should eat neither heave nor tithe.” We understand that she should not eat heave. But tithe any way you take it, if she is a Cohen’s daughter she should eat, if she is a Levite’s wife she should eat. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: [It follows] him who says one does not give tithe to Cohanim. That means, he himself says one gives heave to Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This last sentence is inappropriate here; it refers to the position of R. Joḥanan that the daughter of a Cohen betrothed to a Levite may eat tithe. The discussion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 86" href="/Yevamot.86">Babli, 86a/b</a>, remains inconclusive.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> An Israel woman married to a Cohen shall eat heave. If he died but she had a son from him, she shall eat heave. If [then] she married a Levite, she shall eat tithe. If he died but she had a son from him, she shall eat tithe. If [then] she marries an Israel, she may eat neither heave nor tithe.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he died but she had a son from him, she may eat neither heave nor tithe. If her son from the Israel died, she may eat tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Not only her child, but all of her child’s children. As long as any descendant of the husband is alive, she belongs to the husband’s family. This holds for all these cases. This Mishnah presumes that a Cohen, being also a Levite, is free to eat tithe, as are all members of his household.</i>. From the Levite, she may eat heave. If her son from the Cohen died, she may eat neither heave nor tithe.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A Cohen’s daughter married to an Israel may not eat heave. If he died but she had a son from him, she may not eat heave. If [then] she married a Levite, she may eat tithe. If he died but she had a son from him, she may eat tithe. If [then] she married a Cohen, she may eat heave. If he died but she had a son from him, she may eat heave. If her son from the Cohen died, she may eat tithe; from the Levite, she may not eat tithe. If her son from the Israel died, she returns to her father’s house and for this case it was said: “She returns to her father’s house as in her youth<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a>. “If the daughter of a Cohen becomes a widow or divorcee without issue, she returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she shall eat of her father’s food, but no outsider may eat of it.”</i>.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A Cohen’s daughter married to an Israel,” etc. Rebbi Leontes asked before Rebbi Yose: One understands that a Cohen’s daughter who was married to an Israel returns to eat. But why does the daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen not eat when she should be enabled to eat<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">As long as the Cohen’s son is alive she should be able to eat heave since for him she remains in the Cohen’s family after her husband’s death.</i>? He said to him, so said Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Anan in the name of Rav: What means “a Cohen’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a>.</i>”, one who is trained by a Cohen. As you say, “Babylon’s ransacked daughter,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 137:8" href="/Psalms.137.8"><i>Ps</i>. 137:8</a>, speaking of Edom.</i>” was she the daughter of Babylon? But she behaved in Babylon’s way. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rav: Two daughters are mentioned in the paragraph<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:12" href="/Leviticus.22.12"><i>Lev</i>. 22:12</a>, a daughter who does not eat, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a> one who does eat.</i>. One returns and eats, the other returns but does not eat. A Cohen’s daughter who was married to an Israel returns to eat. A daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen returns but does not eat. Say also, if she was married to a qualified person, she returns and eats, to a disqualified person she returns but does not eat<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">A Cohen’s daughter married to a person disqualified for priesthood remains permanently disabled.</i>. Rav said, practice is that she returns to eat heave but not to eat breast and foreleg<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.6.2">Chapter 8, Note 228</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, she eats breast and foreleg. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated a support for Rav: “<i>of</i> food,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:13" href="/Leviticus.22.13"><i>Lev</i>. 22:13</a>. “If the daughter of a Cohen becomes a widow or divorcee without issue, she returns to her father’s house as in her youth; she shall eat <i>of</i> her father’s food.” As usual, the prefix מ is used as partitive. The same argument (anonymous) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 6 1" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_6.1"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 6(1</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 87a" href="/Yevamot.87a">Babli 87a</a>.</i>” not all the food. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated a support for Rebbi Joḥanan: “of her father’s food she shall eat,” to include the loaves of the thanksgiving sacrifice and the cakes of the <i>nazir</i>.

Chapter 10



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A woman’s husband went overseas and some persons<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The language of the Mishnah implies that the wife was told (maybe by hearsay), not that she received testimony that would stand up in court. This is clear from the following Mishnaiot and the discussion at the end of Halakhah 2.</i> came and told her, your husband died. If she remarried<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Without having her husband declared dead by a competent court. That a woman may remarry even if her husband’s death is not confirmed by two independent witnesses of sterling character (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>) is a rabbinic institution.</i> and then the husband returned, she has to leave both husbands<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that she has to leave the second husband since her marriage to him was invalid by biblical standards. As pointed out by both Talmudim, this shows that the rules of the Mishnah are rabbinical.</i>, she needs a bill of divorce from both of them, she has neither <i>ketubah</i> nor usufruct nor used clothing from either of them, and if she took anything she must return it. Any child from either of the men is a bastard; neither of them may defile himself for her. Neither man has any claim on what she finds or earns, or on invalidation of her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 30:14" href="/Numbers.30.14"><i>Num</i>. 30:14</a>.</i>. If she was the daughter of an Israel, she is disabled from priesthood, the daughter of a Levite from tithe, the daughter of a Cohen from heave. The heirs of neither man inherit her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">If the deceased husband had sons from different wives, before the inheritance is distributed the <i>ketubah</i> of each wife should be given to her sons; only the remainder is distributed among all sons.</i>. If they died<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Before the divorce documents were executed and there are no children.</i>, the brothers of both of them perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A woman’s husband went overseas,” etc. As you say there<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:12:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.12.1">Mishnah 3:12</a>, speaking of a bride who was switched in the night of the marriage.</i>, “these women one separates for three months to see whether they are pregnant. If they were minors not yet able to have a child one returns them at once.” Should one not say the same here<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">What is the difference between the bride who was led into the wrong chamber and the wife given wrong information?</i>? There is a difference, since there others deceived them. Did here not also others deceive them? They instituted a fine so that she should investigate carefully<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In biblical standards, there is no difference; she should be able to return to the first husband since the second marriage is nonexistent. By rabbinic decree they made the consequences of error so enormous that the presumed widow should investigate the report of her husband’s death very thoroughly.</i>. Then they should fine her with respect to the second [husband] but not with respect to the first! Rebbi Joḥanan said, they touched this case because it looks like adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The wife inadvertently committed adultery with the second husband. If it had been intentional she would be forbidden to both men (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>); inadvertent adultery is not a cause of forced divorce unless the husband is a Cohen. They treated the inadvertent adultery in this case under the rules of the intentional. This argument is not found in the Babli.</i>. Then she should not need a bill of divorce from him<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">If the second marriage is treated as adulterous, it is invalid and does not require a divorce.</i>! There is a difference since she was married to him in a lawful manner<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Since imperfect witnesses, even slaves, are accepted in court in cases involving a disappeared husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:4:1-5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.4.1-5.4">Mishnah 15:4</a>), the second marriage, based on imperfect witnesses, cannot be declared invalid.</i>. Samuel said, I say, maybe he sent her a bill of divorce from overseas<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is given by Rav Huna, Rav’s student, in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 88b" href="/Yevamot.88b">Babli (88b</a>). People would think that the woman entered on her second marriage after receiving a bill of divorce from overseas. If she could return from the second husband to the first without formality, people would think that a marriage may be dissolved without formality.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai objected before Rebbi Ze‘ira: Did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.1">Mishnah 10:7</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 88b-89a" href="/Yevamot.88b-89a">Babli, 88b/89a</a>, the argument is anonymous.</i>: “If they said to her, your husband has died, she was betrothed and then her husband came, she is permitted to return to him.” If you say, maybe he sent her a bill of divorce from overseas; should she not be forbidden to return to him<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">A divorcee may remarry her ex-husband only if she was not married to another man in the meantime, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1-4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1-4"><i>Deut</i>. 24:1–4</a>. The language of the verses makes it clear that this law applies only if the first marriage was consummated. Since, in general, “to take a wife” means to perform a formal betrothal (cf. Chapter 1, Notes 63, 95; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 6:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.6.2.6"><i>Peah</i> 6, Note 46</a>), the prohibition is triggered by formal betrothal to the second husband.</i>? But it must follow Rebbi Yose ben Kipper, as Rebbi Yose ben Kipper said, from betrothal it is permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">To remarry one’s divorcee who was divorced from a second husband whose marriage was never consummated. This minority opinion is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 88b" href="/Yevamot.88b">Babli, 88b</a>, as background of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.1">Mishnah 10:7</a>.</i>. Did Rebbi Yose ben Kipper not agree that if the second husband gave her a bill of divorce that she was not disabled from priesthood? As we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.1">Mishnah 10:7</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 88b-89a" href="/Yevamot.88b-89a">Babli, 88b/89a</a>, the argument is anonymous.</i>, “even if the second husband gave her a bill of divorce, she was not disabled from priesthood.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The reason is spelled out in the Mishnah, that the betrothal was invalid and the dissolution of a non-marriage does not turn the woman into a divorcee forbidden to priests.</i>” The rabbis of Caesarea in the name of Rebbi Hila: In order to make clear the prohibition of the first<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This is a new explanation of the Mishnah. Even though the second marriage is in fact invalid, the court will require a divorce from the second husband to make clear that the woman is forbidden to return to her first husband.</i>.
So far<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The penalties spelled out in the Mishnah apply to a married woman who knowingly enters a relationship that might be adulterous.</i> if she knows that she is a married woman. What if she did not know that she was a married woman? Let us hear from the following: An underage girl who was married off by her father. She was divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This clause is a scribal error, induced by the frequent references to a minor who was married off by her father and then divorced. As the text stands, there is no problem at all since by marriage the underage girl is emancipated. If she is divorced as a minor, she becomes “an orphan while her father is living” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:6:1-7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.6.1-7.4">Mishnah 13:6</a>) and her subsequent marriage is rabbinically valid.<br>If the clause is deleted, then we assume that the girl was not informed that her father had betrothed her. While the acts of a minor have no standing in law, the fact that she contracted an invalid marriage necessitates a divorce by the reasoning of R. Hila.</i> and went and married on her own. About this Rebbi Hila said, one states there<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. The Babylonian text is quite different (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 94b" href="/Yevamot.94b">Babli 94b</a>): “For incestuous relationships no divorce is needed except for a married woman {whose husband had disappeared and} <i>who remarried with the consent of the court</i>; Rebbi Aqiba says also from his wife’s sister and his brother’s wife.” In all these cases, the marriages would have been valid if the information about the death of husband or wife or absence of a child had been true (explanation of RITBA).</i>, for incestuous relationships no divorce is needed except for a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Since adultery is included in the chapter (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a>) on incest prohibitions, it is technically considered incestuous.</i>; Rebbi Aqiba says also from his wife’s sister<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since a man may marry his deceased wife’s sister (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>).</i> and his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Who might be married in levirate.</i>. Is there a difference? There, whether she knows or does not know, here also whether she knows or does not know<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This proves only that a formal divorce is needed in all cases. It implies nothing about the material consequences spelled out in the Mishnah. It is to be assumed that the question referred only to the necessity of a divorce which is the subject of the previous discussion.</i>.
“Nor usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The husband upon marriage becomes the administrator of the wife’s property; he is indemnified for his care and, e. g., for the obligation to redeem his wife should she be kidnapped, by receiving the usufruct of her properties; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.1.1">Chapter 7, Note 1</a>.</i>.” Rebbi Avina said, that she cannot recover from him<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The second husband.</i> the usufruct he took. That means<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">In the (French) text before <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Yevamot 85a:15:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Yevamot.85a.15.1">Tosafot (85a, <i>s</i>. <i>v</i>. אלמנה</a>) “Rebbi Ḥanina said, that means …” The ms. text corresponds to the Sephardic text before R. Isaac Fasi (§116, 28b in the Wilna edition).</i>, before the first [husband] returned. But if he took after the return of the first, she can recover<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Since from the moment of the return of the first husband, the second knew that he had no right to the property.</i>.
“And if she took anything one takes it away from her.” That means, if she took something after the first [husband] returned. But if she took before the first returned, just as she cannot take from him so he cannot take from her<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">In his absence, she naturally administers the estate and takes the usufruct; cf. <i>Nimmuqe Yosef</i> on <i>RIF</i>, Wilna edition 26b.</i>.
“Any child from either of the men is a bastard.” One understands that the child is a bastard from the second [husband]<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">This child is the result of adultery.</i>. Is it a bastard from the first<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The marriage to the first is valid.</i>? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira, this follows Rebbi Aqiba, since Rebbi Aqiba says if a man copulates with his wife whom he accuses of infidelity<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:11-31" href="/Numbers.5.11-31"><i>Num</i>. 5:11–31</a>. If the husband formally accuses his wife of infidelity, she is forbidden to him until she is cleared (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.3.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 1:3</a>). R. Aqiba holds that any child conceived in a union which is not unconditionally permitted is a bastard.</i> the child is a bastard, if a man takes back his divorcee after she had remarried the child is a bastard. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila, according to everybody the child is acceptable<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Even according to R. Aqiba, thechild of the first husband is not blemished since the wife did not act with criminal intent. The child of the second husband is a bastard by biblical standards; he or she is forbidden to marry an unblemished partner but permitted a bastard. The child of the first husband is a rabbinic bastard; he or she is forbidden to marry an unblemished partner by rabbinic decree and a bastard by biblical standards. This interpretation is explicitly stated in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 89b" href="/Yevamot.89b">Babli, 89b</a>.</i>; the status of her bill of divorce is the status of her bastardy. What is the difference between them? If the second one gave her a bill of divorce and then the first one copulated with her. In the opinion of Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Ze‘ira, the child is a bastard following Rebbi Aqiba; in the opinion of Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila, according to everybody the child is acceptable.
“Neither of them may defile himself for her.” That is what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: “A man defiles himself for his acceptable wife but he does not defile himself for his disqualified wife.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">If either one of the two husbands is a Cohen, he may not defile himself to bury her. The statement ascribed to R. Ḥiyya is anonymous in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 94b" href="/Yevamot.94b">Babli (94b</a>), where the rule is derived from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:4" href="/Leviticus.21.4"><i>Lev</i>. 21:4</a>: “A husband may not defile himself if this desecrates him.”</i>”
Some Tannaim state, she leaves under thirteen disabilities, but some Tannaim state, she leaves under fourteen disabilities. He who says that she leaves under thirteen disabilities takes what she finds and what she earns as one case, but he who says under fourteen disabilities takes each one by itself<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, if one takes all disabilities stated in the Mishnah and the next under 13 or 14 categories, one has to take quite a few statements as one category. The Babli does not try to give a number.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah said, the promiscuous levitic woman still eats tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Tithe in the hands of a Levite is totally profane; its consumption does not require any status of holiness.</i>. One has stated thus: If a levitic woman was kidnapped<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">And presumed raped.</i> or if any one barred for her<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Whom she could not legally marry.</i> copulated with her, he<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The male illegally having sex with her. In all these cases, the daughter of a Cohen would be disabled for heave.</i> is not empowered to disable her. One does not suspect even a hint of disability for Levites who were compromised from their mother’s side<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Whose father was a Levite or Cohen of questionable standing.</i>. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i>: “the daughter of a Levite from tithe”? Rebbi Yose said, explain it that an Israel came upon her and she bore him a son<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The status of the mother always follows that of her child; the mother of an Israel is an Israel woman. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.2-4">Halakhot 7:3–4</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Bisna in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: A promiscuous priestly woman may eat tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Since any Cohen is also a Levite (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:1" href="/Deuteronomy.18.1"><i>Deut</i>. 18:1</a>), he holds that even if a priestly woman loses her priestly status she is still levitic.</i>. Is that not the Mishnah: “the daughter of a Cohen from heave,” this implies that she eats tithe. It may follow him who says that tithe is not given to Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">In that case, no statement about tithe is implied; cf. <i>Ma‘aśer Šeni</i> 5:9.</i>. Rebbi Nasa said, the words of the rabbis disagree, since Rebbi Hila, Simeon ben Yosina, in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia said: If a Cohen came upon a divorcee, had a son from her, and died. [If the father died] within thirty days [of the son’s birth], the son must redeem himself. After thirty days, the presumption is that his father redeemed him<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The children of priests and Levites, as well as priestly or levitic women of good standing, are not redeemed (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 3:11-13" href="/Numbers.3.11-13"><i>Num</i>. 3:11–13</a>). If the disabled son of a Cohen has to be redeemed, it follows that with the priestly he also lost the levitic status. This disproves R. Bisna’s statement.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 47b" href="/Bekhorot.47b">Babli, <i>Bekhorot</i> 47b</a>, there is a dissenting opinion that even if the father died before 30 days, the son does not have to give his redemption money to a Cohen since his father, being a Cohen, could not be sued for the money by other Cohanim. This does not change the validity of the argument given here.</i>. If he redeems for others, certainly for his son.
Had it not already been stated: “she has no <i>ketubah</i>”?<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement in the Mishnah that no children of hers, by any of her husbands, do inherit her claim to <i>ketubah</i> if she predeceases the husbands. Since it was stated earlier that she has no claim to any <i>ketubah</i> sum, the statement about her children seems superfluous.</i> Rebbi Yose ben Jacob said, that you should not say, they fined her but not her heirs. Therefore it was necessary to say, she has no <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">That means, the first mention of the <i>ketubah</i> also refers to the claim of the children (explanation of Rav Papa in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 91a" href="/Yevamot.91a">Babli 91a</a>).</i>.
Just as the woman accused of infidelity is forbidden to her husband, so she is forbidden to her paramour<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>; <i>Sifry Num</i>. 19. Unless she is cleared from the accusation, she may not marry her presumed paramour after being divorced or after her husband’s death</i>. Just as she is forbidden to her husband’s brother<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">If her husband dies childless and her status was not clarified; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.2.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 1:2</a>.</i>, so she is forbidden to her paramour’s brother. I might think that just as the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity is forbidden to her husband’s brother<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">As explained at the end of this paragraph.</i>, so she should be forbidden to her paramour’s brother. Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.3">Tosephta 14:3</a>.</i>: “A woman’s husband went overseas; they came and told her that her husband had died, and she had a levir here; he married her in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The husband was childless.</i> and died. Then her husband returned. She is forbidden to him but her co-widow is permitted to him; she is forbidden to him but his brother’s wife is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The two parts of this sentence say the same: the co-widow is the brother’s wife.</i>.” Is his brother’s wife not like the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity? That means that the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity is permitted to her paramour’s brother. Rebbi Judan said, this follows the rabbis there<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The Tosephta must be Babylonian. Since for the anonymous majority a woman married in incestuous levirate does not need a bill of divorce; she never was a co-wife in the legal sense and her disabilities cannot be transferred to her co-wives.</i>, as Rebbi Hila said, one states there<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. The Babylonian text is quite different (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 94b" href="/Yevamot.94b">Babli 94b</a>): “For incestuous relationships no divorce is needed except for a married woman {whose husband had disappeared and} <i>who remarried with the consent of the court</i>; Rebbi Aqiba says also from his wife’s sister and his brother’s wife.” In all these cases, the marriages would have been valid if the information about the death of husband or wife or absence of a child had been true (explanation of RITBA).</i>, for incestuous relationships no divorce is needed except for a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Since adultery is included in the chapter (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a>) on incest prohibitions, it is technically considered incestuous.</i>; Rebbi Aqiba says also from his wife’s sister<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since a man may marry his deceased wife’s sister (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>).</i> and his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Who might be married in levirate.</i> (not like the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity? That implies that the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity is permitted to her paramour’s brother.)<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The text in parentheses is dittography and is missing in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:2:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.2.2-10"><i>Soṭah</i> 1:2</a>.</i> But following the rabbis here? Rebbi Ḥiyya said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, everybody agrees that his brother’s wife needs a bill of divorce from him<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">This negates R. Judan’s premiss.</i> because of the rule of a married wife. He married a person forbidden by the incest rules, and an incest-prohibited woman frees her co-wife. Rebbi Ḥananiah said, it is accepted even according to the rabbis here. They fined her but not her heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is figurative speech. It means that in most cases of fines, the heirs are not responsible, so also in this case her disability is not transferred to her co-wives.</i>. Rebbi Ḥananiah, the son of Rebbi Hillel, said, according to the rabbis there, she should be permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Since according to the Babylonian rabbis an erroneous levirate does not necessitate a divorce, the wife committed unintentional adultery which does not cause a forced divorce except for Cohanim.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity is forbidden, the co-wife of a divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">A divorcee remarried by her ex-husband after a second marriage. The remarriage is forbidden but not incestuous. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 11b" href="/Yevamot.11b">Babli agrees, 11b</a>.</i> is permitted. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: All co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Of a woman in a forbidden but non-incestuous marriage.</i> are permitted except the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity. Samuel said, the divorcee herself is permitted in her house<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband died childless, she may be married in levirate.</i>. Does he disagree? Since they were discussing co-wives they did not mention divorcees. Why is the co-wife of a woman accused of infidelity forbidden? Rebbi Joḥanan said, they touched this case because it looks like adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The wife inadvertently committed adultery with the second husband. If it had been intentional she would be forbidden to both men (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.5.1.1">Mishnah <i>Soṭah</i> 5:1</a>); inadvertent adultery is not a cause of forced divorce unless the husband is a Cohen. They treated the inadvertent adultery in this case under the rules of the intentional. This argument is not found in the Babli.</i>. Rav said, because impurity is written there parallel to incest prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Incestuous relations are declared impure in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:24" href="/Leviticus.18.24"><i>Lev</i>. 18:24</a>. Adultery is declared impure repeatedly in the law of the suspected wife, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:11-31" href="/Numbers.5.11-31"><i>Num</i>. 5:11–31</a>. This argument is the only one given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 11a" href="/Yevamot.11a">Babli, 11a</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Yose says, her <i>ketubah</i> is from the property of her first husband<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The Tannaïm mentioned in this Mishnah all disagree with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> in some respects. R. Yose must hold that the first husband also must provide for her until she is divorced.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar says, the first [husband] is entitled to what she finds and earns and may annul her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">He agrees with R. Yose that she is entitled to <i>ketubah</i> from the first husband; therefore, the husband is entitled to receive her earnings.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, copulation<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">If the first husband dies childless in the case she was permitted to return to him, the levir may take her in regular levirate.</i> with her or <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with her by a brother of the first [husband] frees her co-wives and a child from him<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">The first husband. The child from him after his return even if he is not allowed to take her back is never a bastard.</i> is not a bastard; if she was married without permission<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">She remarried on the basis of the information by two witnesses that her husband had died without asking the court for a declaration that the husband was dead. Then her second marriage was in error and is non-existent; her adultery was unintentional and does not bar her from returning to an Israel husband. But if the second marriage was contracted under the supervision of the court, it cannot be considered non-existent and she cannot return to her first husband parallel to the remarried divorcee. In any case, any sexual relation she may have with the first husband after the dissolution of the second marriage cannot be incestuous (cf. Notes 64,128).</i> she is permitted to return to him.<br>If she married by a decision of the court, she must leave but is free from the sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">A purification sacrifice is available only to persons acting carelessly (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:2" href="/Leviticus.4.2"><i>Lev</i>. 4:2</a>). Her transgression is neither intentional (for which no sacrifice would atone, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:30-31" href="/Numbers.15.30-31"><i>Num</i>. 15:30–31</a>) nor careless; no guilt is attached to her in the eyes of the earthly or the Heavenly court.</i>; without a decision of the court, she must leave but must bring the sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Not asking the court to investigate the disappearance of her husband is carelessness.</i>. The power of the court frees her from the sacrifice. If the court instructed her to marry but she misbehaved<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">By having unmarried sex; in the opinion of the Babli also by entering a forbidden marriage, e. g., a divorcee marrying a Cohen. The Yerushalmi accepts and the Babli rejects the entire Mishnah.</i>, she must bring a sacrifice since they permitted her only to marry.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she married by a decision of the court,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The origin of this paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.2-7">Halakhah 8</a>, about other Mishnaiot.</i> Rebbi Abba: Rav Hamnuna and Rebbi Ze‘ira both say that this refers to the beginning of the chapter<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.2.1">Mishnah 3</a> is a continuation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>, not <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.2.1">Mishnah 2</a>.</i>.
