What does Rebbi Yose say about the other matters? Let us hear from the following: “Rebbi Yose said, anything which disables for others disables for himself; anything which does not disable for others does not disable for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.2.2">Mishnah 10</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 11:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).11.7">Tosephta 11:7</a>. Since the second husband by his intercourse disables the wife for her first husband, he disables her for himself and she must be divorced by both of them as is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>. But if a woman went overseas and her husband married her single sister on the erroneous news of his wife’s death, since he does not disable the sister for anybody by his invalid marriage he does not disable himself to return to his wife.</i>.” And Rebbi Abba said, Rav Hamnuna and Rebbi Ze‘ira both say that this refers to the beginning of the chapter. This means that Rebbi Yose does not disagree about the other matters<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The only disagreement of R. Yose with the Tanna of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> is that he holds that the wife can collect her <i>ketubah</i> from her first husband.</i>.
What does Rebbi Eleazar say about <i>ketubah</i>? If you say that he is entitled to things that come to him in prohibition, then <i>ketubah</i> that came to him in permission certainly<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">If the first husband has the right to his wife’s earnings as long as he did not divorce her, then certainly he is obligated to pay the <i>ketubah</i> whose obligation he accepted voluntarily when she was permitted to him.</i>!
It is reasonable to say that Rebbi Eleazar agrees with Rebbi Yose but Rebbi Yose does not agree with Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 91a" href="/Yevamot.91a">Babli, 91a</a>, this is the opinion of Rav Huna and is disputed by R. Joḥanan. In Rav Huna’s interpretation, for R. Eleazar the first husband can get his wife’s earnings only on the basis of the marital contract which is the <i>ketubah</i>; R. Yose will hold that the husband gets nothing to induce him to grant a speedy divorce.</i>; Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Eleazar agree with Rebbi Simeon but Rebbi Simeon does not agree with Rebbi Yose and Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 91a" href="/Yevamot.91a">Babli, 91a</a>, this is the opinion of R. Joḥanan and is disputed by Rav Huna. It seems that here only the first statement of R. Simeon is considered (as shown by the next sentence), that if the first husband dies childless before he could divorce his wife, the action of a brother in levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her is invalid as marriage act but effective to free the co-wives. The reason given in the Babli is that R. Simeon holds that no rabbinic decree exists in this case after the death of the first husband.<br>The Babli holds that the composition principle in this Mishnah is that direction of agreement is always the same, either the later agree with the former (Rav Huna) or the former agree with the later (R. Joḥanan). This explains the slight deviation in the Mishnah from the chronological principle (R. Simeon is slightly older than R. Eleazar ben Shamua). The Yerushalmi rejects such schematism.</i>. This means that in the opinion of Rebbi Simeon, invalid intercourse frees<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Chapter 5, Notes 96, 98.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.2.1">Mishnah 3</a>.</i> Would it not be reasonable that she should be permitted if she remarried with permission, forbidden if she remarried without permission? Rebbi Joḥanan said, the words of Rebbi Simeon [imply] that the court made their decision like intentional [relations between] man and woman<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Intentional adultery.</i>, if she remarried without permission<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The only case in which she could remarry without permission of the court is that two witnesses testified to the first husband’s death. Since two concurrent witnesses must be believed by biblical standards, her remarriage was an excusable error which can be atoned for by a purification sacrifice.</i> like erroneous [relations between] man and woman. Rebbi Joḥanan said, there is no “free” here but “obligated”<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that the woman acted in good faith in both cases and that, therefore, her adultery was unintentional in both cases and can be expiated by a purification sacrifice. This is the position of Ze‘iri in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a">Babli, 92a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai objected before Rebbi Yose: should it not be an act of instruction? When they instructed that it is permitted to sleep with an [otherwise] married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody knows that adultery is biblically prohibited and that it is not in the power of the court to permit it.</i>. Is that not uprooting a principle<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">It is agreed that if the supreme court instructs that a biblical commandment is invalidated, no individual has the right to follow that instruction; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Horayot 1:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Horayot.1.3.2-3"><i>Horaiot</i> 1:3</a> (fol. 46a), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 4a" href="/Yevamot.4a">Babli 4a</a>.</i>? When they instructed that she is forbidden for five years, from then on permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">To declare the husband as dead after five years is within the competence of the court. If the wife remarried after five years, she was behaving correctly.</i>. Then it should be so if she misbehaved! Misbehaving is like eating fat or blood. When they instructed that fat is permitted and [she ate] blood<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">“Any fat or blood” is forbidden to eat (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 3:17" href="/Leviticus.3.17"><i>Lev</i>. 3:17</a>). However, it is clear from the context that only fat is forbidden which may be burned on the altar (cf., e. g., <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:8" href="/Leviticus.4.8"><i>Lev</i>. 4:8</a>). Therefore, a technical ruling is needed to define which fat of cattle, sheep, or goats qualifies as חלב. If the court rules that certain fat that was considered forbidden is now permitted, a lay person who follows their ruling is excused; the sin is the court’s. But if the layman uses the permission of fat to eat of the permitted fat when it still contains blood, he is guilty since the ruling never included permission to eat “unkoshered” fat. Similarly, a permission to remarry does not include permission of promiscuity whose prohibition has biblical roots that have nothing to do with adultery.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a">Babli concurs, 92a</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A woman’s husband and son<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The husband’s only child.</i> went overseas and people came and told her, your husband died and after that your son died<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">From the last sentence in the Mishnah it follows that there were two separate informations, one about the husband’s death and later one about the son’s.</i>, and she remarried. After that, they said to her, the sequence was inverted<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband had a brother she would need levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to marry outside the family.</i>. Then she must leave and the first<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody agrees that a child conceived while the first husband was still alive is a bastard.</i> and the last<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Only R. Aqiba holds that a child from a widow remarried without levirate or <i>ḥalīṣah</i> is a bastard.</i> children are bastards.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman’s husband and son went overseas,” etc. How do you consider this situation, comparing<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The two pairs of witnesses mentioned in the Mishnah.</i> to witnesses of death or witnesses of divorce? If you compare it to witnesses of death, it disagrees with the (rabbis there)<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The argument in the Halakhah shows that the positions of “rabbis there” and “rabbis here and those there” must be switched.</i>. If you compare it to witnesses of divorce, it disagrees (both with the rabbis here and those there). <sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:2:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.2.2-4"><i>Ketubot</i> 2:2</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, it was stated thus: Two [witnesses] say he died, [later] two witnesses said, he did not die. She shall not remarry, but if she has remarried she should not leave. Two [witnesses] say she was divorced, [later] two witnesses said, she was not divorced. She shall not remarry; if she has remarried she must leave<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22b" href="/Ketubot.22b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 22b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>. In the Babli, the position of “the rabbis here” is that of R. Joḥanan only, based on a minor Tanna R. Menaḥem bar Yose.</i>. There, they say, it makes no difference; whether about death or divorce she should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22b" href="/Ketubot.22b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 22b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>. In the Babli, the position of “the rabbis here” is that of R. Joḥanan only, based on a minor Tanna R. Menaḥem bar Yose.</i>. In the opinion of the rabbis there it is understandable, there is no difference between death and divorce. In the opinion of the rabbis here, what is the difference between death and divorce? Rebbi Ze‘ira said it without attribution, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It is reasonable to decide in the case of witnesses of death that if he comes he contradicts them<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli is a little more explicit. Since a return of the husband is absolute proof that he is alive, the wife will not remarry unless she is absolutely convinced that the witnesses are truthful. But in the case of divorce, if the husband claims that he never divorced her, she can contradict him based on her witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah said, the rabbis there stick to their opinion since the rabbis there say, when the [first] testimony was accepted, it was accepted as certain<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.2.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i>2:2</a>: “Rebbi Joshua agrees if somebody says to another person: This field did belong to your father but I bought it from him, one believes him [in the absence of documents] since the mouth which forbade is the mouth which permitted {the person stating that the field was another person’s being the same who states that now it belongs to him}. But if there are witnesses that it belongs to [the second person’s] father and [the first] says I bought it from him, he cannot be believed [without documents].<br>The situation described in the Yerushalmi is that each party in a court case brings two witnesses; Simeon proves that when his father died the field was still in his possession and Reuben (who is in actual possession) brings two witnesses that the field was not in Simeon’s father’s possession when he died. In that case, we do not say that the case is undecidable on basis of the evidence before the court and, therefore, the field should be split between the parties (position of Symmachos, in Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 2b) but that the burden of proof is on the claimant and, therefore, the field remains in the possession of Reuben.<br>The situation discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22b" href="/Ketubot.22b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 22b</a> is different: Reuben is in actual possession of the field the number of years which creates a presumption of ownership, but he has no documentation of his acquisition. Simeon brings two witnesses that his father had died in possession of the field. Since squatting is no proof of ownership, the court puts Simeon in possession. Later, Reuben comes again to court with two witnesses who testify that Simeon’s father was not in possession at the time of his death. By the same principle as above, the field remains in the possession of Simeon.<br>The commentators, following the Babli, require to substitute “Simeon” for “Reuben” at all occurrences here and in <i>Ketubot</i>. Such a correction is unwarranted.</i>. So the rabbis here say, at the moment of her remarriage, she remarried based on certain testimony. Rebbi Yose said, it is reasonable that the rabbis there did not change their argument. Do the rabbis there not agree if two [witnesses] say, his father died while in possession, and two say his father died while not in possession, that the field is in Reuben’s possession<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.2.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i>2:2</a>: “Rebbi Joshua agrees if somebody says to another person: This field did belong to your father but I bought it from him, one believes him [in the absence of documents] since the mouth which forbade is the mouth which permitted {the person stating that the field was another person’s being the same who states that now it belongs to him}. But if there are witnesses that it belongs to [the second person’s] father and [the first] says I bought it from him, he cannot be believed [without documents].<br>The situation described in the Yerushalmi is that each party in a court case brings two witnesses; Simeon proves that when his father died the field was still in his possession and Reuben (who is in actual possession) brings two witnesses that the field was not in Simeon’s father’s possession when he died. In that case, we do not say that the case is undecidable on basis of the evidence before the court and, therefore, the field should be split between the parties (position of Symmachos, in Babli <i>Baba meṣi‘a</i> 2b) but that the burden of proof is on the claimant and, therefore, the field remains in the possession of Reuben.<br>The situation discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22b" href="/Ketubot.22b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 22b</a> is different: Reuben is in actual possession of the field the number of years which creates a presumption of ownership, but he has no documentation of his acquisition. Simeon brings two witnesses that his father had died in possession of the field. Since squatting is no proof of ownership, the court puts Simeon in possession. Later, Reuben comes again to court with two witnesses who testify that Simeon’s father was not in possession at the time of his death. By the same principle as above, the field remains in the possession of Simeon.<br>The commentators, following the Babli, require to substitute “Simeon” for “Reuben” at all occurrences here and in <i>Ketubot</i>. Such a correction is unwarranted.</i>? Therefore, if two say, she was married, divorced, and remarried, and two say<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Later.</i> she was not divorced, rightly she should not leave.
A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">His statement that the woman who married on testimony that she was divorced by an absent husband must be divorced by the second husband on contradicting testimony.</i>: “If two are saying, she was betrothed<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">As a minor by an absent father. The situation should be the same as in the case of witnesses to the divorce.</i>, and two are saying, she was not betrothed, she should not be married, but if she married she should not leave.” Rebbi Hoshaia said, Rebbi Joḥanan may explain it as follows: “If two are saying, she was betrothed and divorced, and two are saying, she was not divorced, she should not be married, but if she married she should not leave.” What is the difference between this and the first case<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">His statement that the woman who married on testimony that she was divorced by an absent husband must be divorced by the second husband on contradicting testimony.</i>? There, she was considered a married woman in everybody’s opinion. Here, she is considered a married woman only for two people. If two others would come and identify the man who was betrothed to her<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Then the case can be independently investigated and we are no longer dependent on contradictory testimonies.</i>.
A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">His statement that the woman who married on testimony that she was divorced by an absent husband must be divorced by the second husband on contradicting testimony.</i>: “If two are saying, she was kidnapped but is pure, and two are saying, she was kidnapped and is impure<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The kidnappers slept with her. She cannot marry a Cohen.</i>, she should not be married, but if she married she should not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 2:2" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).2.2">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 2:2</a>.</i>.” Rebbi Yose said, since these say, she is pure, and those say, she is impure, it is as if two said, she was kidnapped, and two said, she was not kidnapped, and we depend on what she says<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The trustworthiness of a person concerning himself is the topic of Mishnaiot <i>Ketubot</i> 1:6–9.</i>.
If two are saying, she had been betrothed and two are saying she had not been betrothed. Rebbi Jonah compares that to fat<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.2.5">Note 91</a>.</i>. If two would say, X ate fat, and two would say, X did not eat fat, did he not have to bring a “hung” reparation sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The sacrifice of expiation for a sin which is only suspected; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 2:6:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.2.6.4"><i>Bikkurim</i> 2, Note 162</a>.</i> because of the doubt? Here, he<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The second husband who had married the adult girl under the impression that as a minor she had not been betrothed by her father to a man unknown to her.</i> should give a bill of divorce because of the doubt. Rebbi Yose said to him, do not compare this to fat, because even if he says my conscience bothers me, he brings a “hung” reparation sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Even in the absence of witnesses.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with Rebbi Yose: If two are saying she had been betrothed and two are saying she had not been betrothed, she should not be married. The end disagrees with Rebbi Jonah: If she married she must leave. Rebbi Mana said, Rebbi Yose did not say that she may marry, nor did Rebbi Jonah say if she married she must leave, he said only, do not compare this to fat, because even if he says my conscience bothers me, he brings a “hung” reparation sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Their disagreement is one of classification, not of differences in practice.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> They came and told her, your son died and after that your husband died, and she was married in levirate. After that, they said to her, the sequence was inverted<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The husband had a child at the moment of his death and therefore the levir is forbidden to the widow by an incest prohibition (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>) punishable by divine extirpation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:21" href="/Leviticus.21.21"><i>Lev</i>. 21:21</a>), which makes all children of this union bastards, whether conceived before or after the husband’s death.</i>. Then she must leave and the first<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody agrees that a child conceived while the first husband was still alive is a bastard.</i> and the last<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Only R. Aqiba holds that a child from a widow remarried without levirate or <i>ḥalīṣah</i> is a bastard.</i> children are bastards.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “They came and told her, your son died,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The same text <i>Giṭṭin</i>, Halakhah 8:6. In both places, the problem discussed is not the one stated in the Mishnah. The parallel discussion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92" href="/Yevamot.92">Babli is 92a/b</a> where there is no mention of the position of R. Jeremiah.</i> If she should not have married but entered levirate, this is the case of a sister-in-law who married without <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said, this man performs <i>ḥalīṣah</i>, the other one keeps her. Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: She must leave<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rabbinic decree since the outside marriage of a woman under obligation of levirate is invalid (Chapter 1, Notes 93, 94); therefore, the widow was not legally married during the levir’s lifetime and how can you leave a nonexisting marriage?</i>. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila: She must leave. Rebbi Yose asked Rebbi Phineas, how does the rabbi hold? He said, with Rebbi Jeremiah. He said to him, change your mind, for otherwise I shall publicly call you a rebellious Elder<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.12"><i>Deut</i>. 17:12</a>.</i>. Rebbi Zevidah said, a <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 11:8" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).11.8">Tosephta 11:8</a>, <i>Giṭṭin</i> 8:6.</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: “She must leave both of them and the thirteen items<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>.</i> apply to her, following Rebbi Meïr who said it in the name of his teacher Rebbi Aqibah. But the Sages say, there is no bastard from a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.2-4">Halakhah 4:15</a>.</i>.” They only said, “there is no bastard from a sister-in-law,” therefore she must leave. And we have stated, “she must leave”. And Rebbi Joḥanan said, she must leave.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If they told her, your husband died, and she remarried, and then they told her, he was alive but died, she must leave and the first child<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Any child conceived during the first husband’s lifetime.</i> is a bastard, but the last is not a bastard.<br>If they told her, your husband died; she was betrothed<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">But she never slept with the prospective second husband.</i> and after that her husband returned, she is permitted to return to him. Even though the second [husband] gave her a bill of divorce he did not disable her from priesthood. This Rebbi Eleazar ben Matthew explained, “a woman divorced from her husband,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>, from the list of women prohibited to a priest.</i>” and not a woman divorced from a non-husband<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Since betrothal of a married woman has no legal standing.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If they told her, your husband died,” etc. “If they told her, your husband died; she was betrothed,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Her only problem would be aspersion on the priesthood, but the court will not tolerate aspersion<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The priests, who were very particular about purity of their lineage, might not want to accept the return of a woman for whom one might construe a violation of priestly rules. Even though the courts go along with some of the self-imposed restrictions of Cohanim, such as the prohibition of a toddler convert, this would be one they will reject.</i>.
How do you explain these<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">All Mishnaiot of this chapter which deal with a wife remarried on testimony that her husband had died.</i>? With one witness or with two witnesses? If you explain with one witness, then one witness would permit her to the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in Chapter 15, a single witness is accepted to free a widow to remarry. But in that case, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.4.1">Mishnah 5</a> implies that a single witness can lift the incest prohibition of the sister-in-law by permitting her to the levir. This is against our general rules that biblical prohibitions can be lifted only by two credible independent witnesses.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 93b" href="/Yevamot.93b">Babli, 93b</a>, Rav Ḥisda accepts the argument that a single witness may lift the prohibition of the sister-in-law. It is accepted in the Babli that the restrictions enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> are intended to make sure the presumed widow checks carefully the truthfulness of a single witness.</i>. If you explain with two witnesses, then it disagrees with Rav since Rav Naḥman bar<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Reading בר instead of בשם רבי, from the text in Halakhah 15:4. The last word תני is read with Halakhah 15:4 אתנו = אַתְּ (הִ)נּוֹ “you are him”.</i> Jacob said in the name of Rav, if she was married by the testimony of two witnesses, even if he returns, she says to him, you are not him.
From where that no betrothal is valid for a married woman? Rebbi Immi in the name of Rebbi Yannai: “She left his house, went, and became another man’s.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:2" href="/Deuteronomy.24.2"><i>Deut</i>. 24:2</a>.</i>” When she leaves his house she may be with another. And from where that no betrothal is valid for incestual relations? Rebbi Tanḥuma in the name of Rav Huna: “She left his house, went, and became another man’s.” Why does the verse say “another”? To exclude the list of incest relations<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>Qiddušin</i> 88b, this is quoted in the name of R. Yannai; there the argument is rejected as insufficient. Perhaps for “another” one should translate “an outsider”. The Babli always subsumes adultery under incest prohibitions and does not need a separate argument.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A man’s wife went overseas, they came and told him: your wife died, and he married her sister. If after that his wife returned, she is permitted to return to him. He is permitted [to marry] the relatives of the second, the second is permitted his relatives<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage to the sister is incestuous (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>) it is non-existent and the restrictions detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.8.1">Mishnah 4:8</a> do not apply.</i>. If the first [sister] died, the second one is permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Following the principles of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>, she should be prohibited to her brother-in-law.</i>.<br>They said to him, your wife died, and he married her sister; if afterwards they said to him that she was still alive but died later, the first child is a bastard, the last is not a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Any child conceived by the sister during the first wife’s lifetime is a bastard as result of an incestuous union.</i>.<br>If they said to him “your wife died,” and he married her paternal sister<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">She is a paternal half-sister.</i>, “she died<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">This also is known only by the testimony of a single witness.</i>” and he married her maternal sister<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">She is a maternal half-sister of the second wife and unrelated to the first. In this way, the fifth wife is unrelated to the first and third wives.</i>, “she died” and he married her paternal sister, “she died” and he married her maternal sister, but it turned out that all were alive, the first, third, and fifth are permitted to him and they would release their co-wives<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Since they are all legal cowives, if the husband died childless, the levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one of them releases all others.</i>; the second and fourth are prohibited to him<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">The marriage of the second is invalid since it is an incestuous relationship with the sister of the first wife; similarly, the fourth is forbidden because of the third. Since the second and fourth wives are not married to the husband, they do not become widows and their actions with respect to the levirs can have no influence on the status of the legally married ones.</i> and intercourse of any one of these does not release the co-wife.<br>If he has intercourse with the second one after the death of the first, the second and fourth are permitted to him and they would release their co-wives; the third and fifth are prohibited to him and intercourse of any one of these does not release the co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Since both he and his second wife thought that she was actually married to him, if he sleeps with her after the first wife’s death it is with the idea that they are married; therefore, they are married and the situation becomes identical to that of the preceding Mishnah only with even and odd numbers changing places.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a man’s wife went overseas,”, etc. It is written: “If a man slept with <i>her</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:13" href="/Numbers.5.13"><i>Num</i>. 5:13</a>; written in the paragraph about the wife suspected of unfaithfulness, from where one infers that an adulterous wife is forbidden to her husband. It is implied here that an action of the husband has no influence on her status (but in the paragraph after the next it is pointed out that the husband’s action may forbid him to her). <i>Sifry Num</i>. 7 (an involved argument in the style of the paragraph after the next), a short parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli, 95a</a>.</i>” her sleeping prohibits her, the sleeping of another woman does not prohibit her. There, it also says “replacing your husband,” that excludes rape cases<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">She is forbidden only if her paramour replaces the husband, i. e., if she sleeps with him voluntarily.</i>.
Rebbi Mattaniah said, they made a fence about situations that occur frequently but not about rare situations<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">He explains why the husband is not forbidden to the two sisters following the principles of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>. It was shown in the preceding Halakhah that most of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> is purely rabbinical and has the status of “a fence around the law”. The problem with this argument is that the rule which is relevant here, that the woman is forbidden to both men, is biblical (<i>Sifry Num</i>. 19).</i>. A man frequently travels overseas; it is infrequent that a woman travels overseas.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">A short version of the discussion started here is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli 95a</a>; the very succinct source is in <i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 9(15)-(18).</i>: Rebbi Jehudah said, the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel agree that one who copulates with his mother-in-law disables his wife. Where did they disagree? If he copulates with his wife’s sister; where the House of Shammai say, he disabled her<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Treating the man’s transgression as equal in consequence to the woman’s. In their opinion, the husband is forced to divorce his wife and pay her all that is due in a divorce which is his fault.</i>, but the House of Hillel say, he did not disable her. The colleagues in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The reason of Rebbi Jehudah: “In fire they should burn him and them<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>.</i>.” Where do we hold? If it is about burning, only one of them is burned<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <i>Sifra</i>, the prohibition (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>) is that of incestuous intercourse; the prescription of the punishment (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>) deals only with the case that a man marries a woman and her mother. The problem is that if one of them is married to him, he cannot possibly marry the other since any act of incestuous betrothal or final marriage is invalid and legally nonexistent. Therefore, while intercourse with mother and daughter is incestuous and forbidden, it is a capital crime only if the man is married to one of them at the time he sleeps with the other. The innocent wife did not commit any crime and, therefore, cannot be punished. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.10">Chapter 11, Note 46</a>.</i>. So if it cannot be relevant for burning, let it be relevant for prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sifra</i>, as in the Yerushalmi, this is R. Aqiba’s position. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli, 95a</a>, this is an amoraic interpretation of R. Simeon ben Laqish reported by R. Ammi.</i>. So far following Rebbi Aqiba; following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael stated: “In fire they should burn him and them,” him and the second one<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sifra</i>, “one of them.” He reads the unusual word אתהן (substituting for אותן) as abbreviation of <b>את</b> אחת <b>מהן</b>.</i>. And the House of Shammai was arguing: Since in a case where a slightly prohibited person copulated with a slightly prohibited person the cause of the prohibition became forbidden, if a strongly prohibited person copulated with a strongly prohibited person, it is only logical that the cause of the prohibition is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">This difficult argument is quoted anonymously in <i>Sifry Num</i>. 7 as argument that her husband’s adulterous relationship with her mother does not prohibit the wife, and explained in detail in <i>Num. Rabba Naśo</i> 9(35) (most probably a Provençal text): “Since in a case where a slightly prohibited person copulated with a slightly prohibited person, <i>this refers to adultery since her prohibition is not permanent</i> (her husband could divorce her), the cause of the prohibition (<i>the husband</i>) became forbidden (<i>he has to divorce his wife</i>), if a strongly prohibited person copulated with a strongly prohibited person, <i>this refers to a man sleeping with his mother-in-law whose prohibition is permanent</i>, it is only logical that the cause of the prohibition (<i>the wife</i>) should forbidden”, the verse says “with <i>her</i>” (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.2">Note 134</a>).<br>A simple and short version is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 12" href="/Numbers.12"><i>Sifre Zuṭa, Midrash Haggadol Num</i>. 12, ed. Rabbinowitz p. 51</a>.</i>. Which rule is slight? Rebbi Joḥanan said, the beginning of the chapter<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a>, the case of careless adultery.</i>. But this is very strong<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">There is no stronger sexual prohibition than that of adultery, the only one mentioned in the Ten Commandments.</i>! There is a difference since she was permitted to be married to him<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">If the woman remarried on the testimony of one witness, while she took all the risk, the marriage was permitted under our rules. But the sister of the living wife and the mother-in-law are permanently forbidden.</i>.
The elder Rebbi Hoshaia<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli, 95a</a>, this is attributed to the Babylonian Rav Ḥisda.</i> said, the <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The “slight prohibition” referred to in the argument of the House of Shammai in the preceding paragraph.</i> is about someone who takes back his divorcee after she had been married to another. Why after she had been married, not also after she had been betrothed<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The divorcee is forbidden if (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:2" href="/Deuteronomy.24.2"><i>Deut</i>. 24:2</a>) “she went and was another’s”. “To be a man’s” is everywhere explained as to be formally betrothed to him (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>).</i>? Because of Rebbi Yose ben Kipper, since Rebbi Yose ben Kipper said, she is permitted after betrothal<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 11b" href="/Yevamot.11b">Babli, 11b</a>, by R. Yose ben Kipper in the name of R. Eleazar (ben Shamua), in <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 270 in the name of R. Eleazar ben Azariah. The reason given is the expression (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut</i>. 24:4</a>) “after she had been defiled” which for the anonymous majority means that a wife divorced for adultery is permanently forbidden to her ex-husband.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">One has to read לעזר, the word in the text, ליעזר, refers only to the Tanna R. Eliezer (ben Hyrkanos) who cannot be meant here, being a generation older than R. Simeon. His case is not mentioned in the Babli.</i> said, the <i>baraita</i> is about a sister-in-law who became eligible before two levirs, when one of them “bespoke” her and then the other copulated with her<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The intercourse is partially incestuous for R. Simeon and clearly incestuous for the House of Shammai and R. Eleazar ben Arakh as explained at the beginning of Chapters 2 and 5.</i>. Why when one of them “bespoke” her, even if he had not “bespoken” her<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">If the first levir had slept with the widow without bespeaking, she would thereby have become his wife and intercourse with the other levir would be adultery.</i>! Why if he copulated with her, even if he did not copulate with her<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rabban Gamliel, R. Simeon and the House of Shammai, “bespeaking” acquires absolutely; if the second levir had not slept with the sister-in-law but had “bespoken” her, nothing would have happened, for then it would have been as if somebody became betrothed to an otherwise married woman.</i>! Because of the House of Shammai, because of Rebbi Simeon. As it was stated, Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli, 95a</a>, “R. Yose”. The difference in names is important; between R. Yose and R. Jehudah, practice always follows R. Yose (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.6">Chapter 4, Note 169</a>) whereas between R. Simeon and R. Jehudah, practice usually follows R. Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 3:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.3.1.6"><i>Terumot</i> Chapter 3, Note 25</a>.) The following argument is closely reproduced in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95a" href="/Yevamot.95a">Babli, 95a</a>.</i> said, the House of Shammai and the House of Hillel did not disagree that one who copulates with his wife’s sister disables his wife. Where did they disagree? If he copulates with his mother-in-law; where the House of Shammai say, he disabled her, but the House of Hillel say, he did not disable her. The House of Hillel were arguing: A man is permitted all women, a woman is permitted all men<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Except close relatives, if they are unmarried.</i>. When he becomes betrothed to her, he forbids her and she forbids him. The prohibition through which he forbids her is greater than the prohibition through which she forbids him, since he forbids her to go to marry any other man but she forbids him only her relatives. And is that not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? If she, whose prohibition is greater, transgressed the prohibition in error, is not forbidden even to the one permitted to her<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">If a married woman sleeps with a man she is tricked into thinking is her husband and she is in error, she is not punishable and not forbidden to her husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.4.2-3"><i>Soṭah</i> 4:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 56b" href="/Yevamot.56b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i>56b</a>). The case of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 1</a> is classified as negligence, not error.</i>, he, whose prohibition is less, if he transgressed the prohibition in error, is it not logical that he should not be forbidden even to the one permitted to him<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">He is permitted to his wife.</i>? That works for an error. From where if intentional: <sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.6.2">Note 134</a>.</i> The verse says “with <i>her</i>;” her sleeping prohibits her, the sleeping of another woman does not prohibit her.
Immi the father of Samuel bar Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli the son has the title “Rebbi”. A third generation Amora of R. Ze‘ira’s academy.</i> in the name of Rav Jehudah: Practice follows Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel. It is difficult to understand why practice has to be declared in the Babli since between R. Yose and R. Jehudah it should be clear that practice follows R. Yose. Probably the statement in the Babli is induced by that in the Yerushalmi.</i>. There came a case before Rebbi Mana and he removed her from him<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">The man was convicted of incest with his mother-in-law and R. Mana forced him to divorce his wife.</i>. Does he hold with Rebbi Jehudah? No, she regularly came to him<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The mother-in-law regularly visited her daughter; R. Mana felt it was necessary to remove the daughter to keep her mother away from the son-in-law. This is a matter of judgment, not of the strict law. In the Babli, Rav Jehudah had the offender whipped and told him that he would have forced him to divorce if he were not bound by his teacher Samuel’s statement.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">This text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.3">Halakhah 3, Notes 76–78</a>.</i> Rebbi Abba: Rav Hamnuna and Rebbi Ze‘ira both say that this refers to the beginning of the chapter. What does Rebbi Yose say about the other matters? Let us hear from the following: “Rebbi Yose said, anything which disables for others disables for himself; anything which does not disable for others does not disable for himself.” And Rebbi Abba said, Rav Hamnuna and Rebbi Ze‘ira both say that this refers to the beginning of the chapter.
“Rebbi Yose says, anything which disables,” etc. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: If his wife’s sister was married, since he disables her for others, he disables her for himself. But his wife’s unmarried sister which he does not disable for others, he does not disable for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose in the Mishnah refers to the preceding Mishnah. If the wife and the sister’s husband went overseas and her husband and sister received erroneous notice that the wife and her brother-in-law both had died, the widowed husband and wife’s sister married, and then the two who were believed to have died returned, since the husband by his relations with the wife’s sister forbade her to her husband, he also forbade his own wife to himself. But if the wife’s sister was unmarried, his wife returns to him.</i>. As Rebbi Hila said in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, she needs a bill of divorce from him<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">They explain the mechanism by which the wife becomes forbidden to him even though R. Yose agrees to the deduction in the preceding Halakhah that intercourse with the wife’s sister does not disable the wife. In the first case, the wife’s sister must receive a divorce document from him; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.2">Note 18</a>. But then the wife becomes the sister of his divorcee and is automatically forbidden to him.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 95b" href="/Yevamot.95b">Babli, 95b</a>, this is only a conjectural explanation of R. Yose’s intention.</i>.
“If they said to him “your wife died,” etc. How can that be<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">How may a man marry five partially related women from one family? Man A has a daughter a1 and a stepdaughter a2 from an earlier marriage. Woman B has a daughter b1 and a stepdaughter b2 from an earlier marriage. They marry and have a daughter c. If an outsider C marries first b2, on her death he may marry her paternal halfsister b1. Then he may marry c, b1’s maternal halfsister, afterwards c’s paternal halfsister a1 and then a1’s maternal halfsister a2.<br>As known, the Yerushalmi is very weak in the grammar of gender; it uses the masculine as nonspecific universal.</i>? A man has a daughter and a stepdaughter, a woman has a daughter and a stepdaughter. They married and had a daughter. It starts with the woman’s stepdaughter.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> [A male] nine years and one day old<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.2">Chapter 3, Note 143</a>, for the status of a male older than 9 years.</i> disables for the brothers and the brothers disable for him; only that he disables at the beginning and the brothers disable at beginning and end<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">His action counts only if he acted before any of the adult brothers.</i>.<br>How is that? [A male] nine years and one day old who copulated with his sister-in-law disabled her for the brothers. If [any one of] the brothers copulated with her, “bespoke” her, divorced her, or performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her, they disabled her for him.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “[A male] nine years and one day old disables,” etc. At the end he does not disable after his “bespeaking”<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah which declares that the minor’s act counts only if he precedes his adult brothers refers to the legal ceremony of “bespeaking”; but intercourse is a real act which cannot be disregarded under any circumstances and prohibits the widow in all cases.</i>, but after his intercourse he disables. However he can disable only by one act but they may disable by four acts.
<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">This Halakhah is copied from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddushin</i> 1:2,</a> fol. 59b/c which has a better and more complete text.</i>“How is that? [A male] nine years and one day old.” “If he allots her to his son.<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:9" href="/Exodus.21.9"><i>Ex</i>. 21:9</a>, speaking about a minor girl sold by her father as a slave with the understanding that her price would count as betrothal gift in case the owner would desire to marry her or would give her to his son. In that case, the betrothal is called “allotment”. If she is not married, she regains her freedom by reaching adulthood at 12 years of age.</i>” He allots her to his son but may not allot her to the brothers<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is reproduced in <i>Mekhilta deR. Ismael, Masekhta dinziqin</i> 3, <i>Mekhilta deR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> Chap. 21 (p. 167); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 17b" href="/Kiddushin.17b">Babli <i>Qiddushin</i> 17b</a>.</i>. He should be able to allot her to the brothers by an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>! If he may allot her to his son who may not take his place for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate, should it not be logical that he may allot her to his brother who may take his place for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli rejects this argument by noting that levirate presumes the absence of a son.</i>? The verse says, “if he allots her to his son.” He allots her [to his son] but may not allot her to the brothers. No. If you would accept the son since he will take [the father’s] place in a field of inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The family estate going back to the distribution of land under Joshua, for which the succession is determined by the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:6-11" href="/Numbers.27.6-11"><i>Num</i>. 27:6–11</a>.</i>, what can you say about his brother who will not take his place in a field of inheritance? Would it be reasonable that he may allot her to him? The verse says, “if he allots her to his son.” He allots her to his son but may not allot her to the brothers.
“If he allots her to his son;” he allots her to his son but he may not allot her to his grandson. Samuel bar Abba asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: In matters of inheritance you take the grandson like the son but here you do not take the grandson like the son<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">If the son died before the father, the grandson inherits the son’s part.</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira said, if anybody explains this matter, I shall pour him spiced wine<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>conditum</i> (sc., <i>vinum</i>),“spiced wine”.</i>. Rebbi Tanḥum<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Qiddushin</i>: R. Naḥum, a third generation Amora, student of Samuel bar Abba. His name fits into the scheme of things but not the fifth generation R. Tanḥum.</i> answered: In matters of inheritance where the brother can take the place of the son and all others can take the place of the son, the grandson takes the place of the son.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Here, a sentence is missing which appears in the text of <i>Qiddushin:</i> וְכָאן שֶׁלֹּא עָשִׂיתָ אָח כְּבֵן וּשְׁאָר כָּל־הַקְּרוֹבִים כְּבֵן אֵין אַתְּ עוֹשֶׂה בֶן בֵּן כְּבֵן: “but here, where neither the brother nor the other relatives take the role of the son, the grandson does not take the role of the son.”</i> The rabbis of Caesarea answered: In matters of impurity you consider the brother like the son and all [near] relatives like the son but not the grandson like the son<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">In the list of close relatives who have to defile themselves for the burial of the deceased (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:2-3" href="/Leviticus.21.2-3"><i>Lev</i>. 21:2–3</a>), the grandson or grandfather is absent. Among Cohanim, the grandson may not defile himself for his grandfather.</i>. He said, there went the spiced wine.
“If he allots her to his son;” with [the girl’s] agreement<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">This is the explicit interpretation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 19a" href="/Kiddushin.19a">Babli (<i>Qiddushin</i> 19a</a>) which seems to be valid here also and explains the apparent duplication of the argument in this paragraph.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, there is no agreement here. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said so, the statement follows Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">He holds in a <i>baraita</i>(<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddushin</i>1:2</a>, fol. 59c; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 19a" href="/Yevamot.19a">Babli 19a</a>) that the money given to the father does not count as bride money but that the allotment is a legal betrothal since from the moment of betrothal she is no longer a servant. The money with which she is bought is money with which her services are bought for the duration of her servitude. By allotment, the value of the remainder of the money (computed by the remaining days of her servitude) is given as wedding gift. This implies that on the last day of her servitude she can be allotted to master or son only if at least a <i>peruṭah’s</i> worth of servitude is left (if the day’s worth is prorated by hours).</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Eudaimon said, even if you say the statement follows Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah, is he not a minor<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Who is not called “a man” and cannot legally acquire. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 19a" href="/Yevamot.19a">Babli (19a</a>) refers to the case of a levir aged 9 years and 1 day (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.4.1">Mishnah <i>Yebamot</i> 7:4</a>) who by intercourse does acquire preliminarily his sister-in-law by biblical standards, except that his wife cannot be prosecuted for adultery since it is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:10" href="/Leviticus.20.10"><i>Lev</i>. 20:10</a>): “A <i>man</i> who commits adultery with a <i>man’s</i> wife”. This implies that there are cases where a woman can be legally married to a male without being a <i>man’s</i> wife.</i>? “If he allots her to his son;” with [the latter’s] agreement. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he allots her to his minor or adult son, with and without the latter’s agreement. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, he allots her only to his adult son with the latter’s agreement<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">In the Yerushalmi, practice should follow R. Joḥanan. In the Babli, R. Joḥanan’s opinion is not mentioned; what is asserted here in the name of R. Simeon ben Laqish is there attributed to the unquestioned authority of R. Yannai, the teacher of both R. Joḥanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>.
“A male nine years and one day old makes<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">If he marries, the marriage is valid to turn his widow into a woman forbidden to the High Priest and if he divorces her, she becomes forbidden to a common priest.</i> a widow for the High Priest or a divorcee or one who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a common priest.” In the opinion of R. Joḥanan who will explain this for allotments<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">He restricts the validity of the statement to a girl married by allotment since only in that case is his marriage valid by biblical standards.</i> it is understandable; since he acquires by allotment he makes a widow for the High Priest or a divorcee or one who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a common priest. In the opinion of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">For him, a minor cannot be allotted a wife; therefore, the marriage must be contracted under rabbinic rules and the author of that <i>baraita</i> cannot accept the statement in the next Mishnah that the widow of a childless minor is not subject to the laws of levirate.</i> who must explain this for a marriage, she should also be free from levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah 17.</i>: “If he married a woman, that one is free from levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.” Rebbi Abin said, following Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish it<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>baraita</i> which opened this paragraph must follow R. Yose ben R. Jehudah while the Mishnah follows the anonymous majority.</i> comes following Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah, as it was stated so: If a male nine years and one day old up to twelve years and one day old grew two pubic hairs, they are warts<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Not signs of adulthood defined as onset of puberty. Quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 46a" href="/Niddah.46a">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 46a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah said, they are indicators<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Greek σημεῖον “sign, marker”.</i> [of puberty]. Rebbi Jacob ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: Only if they were still there at the time of indicators<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">During his thirteenth year, when the growth of pubic hair is expected. In the Babli, the statement is attributed to a R. Kruspedai ben Sabbatai.</i>.
Rebbi Yose asked: When they<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">The pubic hairs.</i> remained until the time of indicators, does he retroactively become a man or from that time onward? For Rebbi Abun it is obvious that he becomes a man retroactively, so certainly also for the future, for he explains the position of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish by Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah. Why does Rebbi Yose not explain the position of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish by Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah since he asked, when they remained until the time of indicators, does he retroactively become a man or from that time onward? Rebbi Mana said, because he had difficulty. Rebbi Yose asked: When they remained until the time of indicators, does he retroactively become a man or from that time onward<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">His difficulty is following R. Yose ben R. Jehudah, not R. Simeon ben Laqish who denies the validity of actions of a minor. His problem is with R. Joḥanan.</i>? One understands the case of a widow<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">If his marriage by allotment is sanctioned by biblical decree, if he dies the widow is a widow by biblical standards and unquestionably forbidden to the High Priest.</i>. But a divorcee<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Even if his marriage, effected by his adult father, is valid, a divorce which needs his conscious action is certainly invalid as long as he is a minor.</i>? Explain it if he copulated with her after he became an adult and divorced her. <i>Ḥalîṣah</i>? Explain it if he copulated with her, died, and the [adult] brothers performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; she had <i>ḥalîṣah</i> because of him. In that case, even if he was younger than nine [years]! Rebbi Samuel ben Eudaimon said, that is correct. But because in all cases one stated “nine”, one stated this with them.
Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: Rebbi Yose ben Jehudah learned from Aḥaz, as it was stated: Aḥaz produced a child at age nine<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">He became king at age 20 and ruled for 16 years (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 16:2" href="/II_Kings.16.2"><i>2K</i>. 16:2</a>). His son Ḥizqiah became king at age 25 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 18:2" href="/II_Kings.18.2"><i>2K</i>. 18:2</a>). That seems to mean that Ḥizqiah was born when his father was 11 years old. However, since the first year of the reign is only counted from the day of accession to the next New Year’s Day, it is possible that he was born when his father was 10 and was conceived when he was 9. This computation has no parallel in the sources.</i>, Haran at age six<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The computation is detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69b" href="/Sanhedrin.69b">Babli Sanhedrin 69b</a> and is based on two hypotheses, (1) that Sarah, 10 years younger than Abraham, was Abraham’s niece, Haran’s daughter, against the explicit testimony of the biblical text that she was his paternal halfsister, and that (2) Haran was the youngest of Teraḥ’s sons (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 11:27" href="/Genesis.11.27"><i>Gen</i>. 11:27</a>) and at least two years younger than Abraham.</i>, and Caleb at age ten following him who identifies Caleb ben Ḥeṣron with Caleb ben Yephuneh<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">This also is detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69b" href="/Sanhedrin.69b">Babli Sanhedrin 69b</a> and is based on the identification of Caleb ben Yephuneh the spy, whose children are enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 4:15" href="/I_Chronicles.4.15"><i>1Chr</i>. 4:15</a>, with Caleb ben Ḥeṣron whose descendants are mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 2:18-21" href="/I_Chronicles.2.18-21"><i>1Chr</i>. 2:18–21</a>. Caleb ben Ḥeṣron is described as the great-grandfather of Beṣalel who built the Tabernacle. {The Babli never mentions the problem of the quite impossible identification of the two Calebs.} Since Caleb ben Yephuneh was 40 years of age in the year after the Exodus (<i>Jos</i>. 14:7) and Beṣalel is called “man” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 36:4" href="/Exodus.36.4"><i>Ex</i>. 36:4</a>, he was at least 13 years of age, only 27 years younger than his great-grandfather. That means that Caleb, Uri, and Ḥur all were fathers at age 9. If Caleb was father at age 10, then one of his descendants was father at age 8.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If [a male] nine years and one day old<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in Mishnah 18, if he is older than nine full years as long as he did not grow two pubic hairs.</i> copulated with his sister-in-law and after that his brother, who [also] was nine years and one day old, copulated with her, [the brother] disabled her for [the first levir]. Rebbi Simeon says, he did not disable<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">As will be repeated in the Halakhah, the majority holds that intercourse of an almost grown up male is like “bespeaking” of an adult and therefore follows the rules of “bespeaking” which disables but does not fully acquire. For R. Simeon, intercourse of a minor either acquires by biblical standards or it does not acquire at all, but we do not know which assertion holds (Halakhah 3:5). If it acquires, then the sister-in-law is the first levir’s wife and the action of a minor has no legal consequence; if it does not acquire for the first it did not acquire for the second, both are legally minors and their actions as minors cannot influence the status of the widow when the levirs become grownups.<br>The same argument holds for R. Simeon in the cases following.</i>.<br>If [a male] nine years and one day old copulated with his sister-in-law, and after that he copulated with her co-wife, he disabled her for himself. Rebbi Simeon says, he did not disable.<br>If [a male] nine years and one day old copulated with his sister-in-law and died, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow’s legal status is one of “bespoken” but not fully married, if the levir dies she becomes the widow of two brothers and may not marry in levirate (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.1.2-10">Halakhah 3:1</a>).</i>. If he married a woman and died, she is free<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Outside of levirate, the marriage of a minor is invalid; the woman is not a widow.</i>.<br>If [a male] nine years and one day old copulated with his sister-in-law and after he became an adult married another woman and died, if he never had intercourse with the first after he became an adult, the second [wife] either performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate, the first performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babylonian Mishnah, the order of the actions is inverted. The order of the Yerushalmi is more reasonable. The second is a real wife, who can be married in levirate if the husband dies childless. For the majority, the first one is only “bespoken”; she becomes the widow of two brothers and is disqualified from levirate.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, he takes in levirate the one he likes and performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Simeon, the first one either was the wife of the deceased or she was not. If she was not, she is the widow of her first husband and can be married in levirate; if she was, she is the widow of her second husband and can be married in levirate. The second certainly can be married in levirate. But only one of the co-widows can be married. In this case, the other is not free since maybe the first one was not a wife.</i>. It makes no difference whether he is nine years and one day or twenty years old, as long as he did not grow two pubic hairs.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5">Halakhah 5:5, Notes 79–83</a>.</i> Samuel said, the words of Rebbi Meïr: They made the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult. And as you said, they made the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult, they made the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day like a bill of divorce of an adult. But the rabbis said, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day is nothing. And why did they make the intercourse of a child of nine years and one day like “bespeaking” of an adult? Because the intercourse of an adult acquires whether intentional or not intentional. The <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of a child of nine years and one day was made like a bill of divorce by an adult. But <i>ḥalîṣah</i> by an adult can free only if it is intentional.
<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">The text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.3">Halakhah 3:10, Notes 140–148</a>.</i> Can a woman waiting for a levir who became available to several brothers-in-law not be married in levirate? Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: The wife of one dead [husband] is married in levirate, not the wife of two dead. Rebbi Eleazar said, this follows Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr said, “any one who cannot marry me in levirate, cannot marry my co-wife in levirate.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, Rebbi Eleazar formulated what he had heard from me. Rebbi Yose said, a Mishnah said so: “If [a male] nine years and one day old copulated with his sister-in-law and after he became an adult married another woman and died, if he never had intercourse with the first after he became an adult, the second [wife] either performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate, the first performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate. The first one must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and cannot be married in levirate.” Here you say, she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; there you say, she is married in levirate! Where you say she performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Simeon; where you say, she is married in levirate, Rebbi Simeon and the rabbis.
The following is obvious: If a person younger than twenty years of age developed two pubic hairs, he becomes a man retroactively. Older than twenty years of age, he becomes a man from that point into the future<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80b" href="/Yevamot.80b">Babli, 80b</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 47b" href="/Niddah.47b"><i>Niddah</i> 47b</a>, disagrees and treats the man who at age 20 has no pubic hair and shows the body characteristics of a castrate as castrated by nature who never will be accepted as a man; otherwise he will be a minor until age 35, half the normal life span. (There is an Amora who disagrees and holds that many cases of impotent men without pubic hair can be treated medically.)</i>. Where do they disagree? If he is twenty. Samuel said, he becomes a man retroactively. Rav said, he becomes a man from that point into the future<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80a" href="/Yevamot.80a">Babli, 80a</a>, Rav holds that if he or she are late to grow pubic hair but do so before they reach 20, they retroactively become adult and can be prosecuted for any crimes committed earlier; Samuel holds that they remain underage until they grow pubic hair or reach age 18 when they immediately become adults.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> disagrees with both of them: The castrate cannot become a rebellious son<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18-21" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18-21"><i>Deut</i>. 21:18–21</a>. Since he is called “son” rather than “child”, it is concluded that he must be an adult. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80a" href="/Yevamot.80a">Babli concurs, 80a</a>.</i> since he has no pubic hair. Should one not warn him, maybe he will develop two pubic hairs within the next three months? Following him who says, one does not accept conditional warnings<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The opinion of R. Simeon ben Laqish in the next Chapter; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 16a" href="/Makkot.16a">Babli <i>Makkot</i> 16a</a>. In the Babli, that opinion is unopposed.</i>. Our Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">That the legal status of one 20 years old is not different from one 9 years old if he did not grow two pubic hairs.</i> disagrees with Samuel: Does it make no difference whether he is nine years and one day or twelve years and one day old, if by then he did not grow two pubic hairs, he becomes a man retroactively? Could you say: If he did grow two pubic hairs between the ages of nine years and one day until twelve years and one day<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the text is formulated in the masculine, it must refer to girls since for a boy standard adulthood is at age 13.</i>, he becomes a man retroactively? Similarly, if he is older than twenty years of age and did not grow two pubic hairs, he becomes a man from that point into the future. How does Samuel handle this? He explains it: soon after he turns twenty<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">But if he grows pubic hair by his 20th birthday, he retroactively becomes an adult from age 13.</i>.

Chapter 11



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One may marry [relatives of] a rape victim or a seduced woman<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Incest prohibitions which are not effective at birth can be created only by marriage, not by promiscuity.</i>. He who rapes or seduces [a relative of] a married woman is guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">He is liable not only for rape and seduction but also for incest.</i>. A person may marry his father’s rape victim or seduced woman, his son’s rape victim or seduced woman. Rebbi Jehudah prohibits his father’s rape victim or seduced woman<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The majority considers both parts of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1"><i>Deut</i>. 23:1</a>: “Nobody may marry his father’s wife, and he should not uncover his father’s garment’s corner” as one prohibition; R. Jehudah reads the second clause as referring to women with whom his father has extramarital relations.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One may marry [relatives of] a rape victim or a seduced woman,” etc. So is the Mishnah: One may marry after a rape victim or seduced woman<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The language “… נוֹשְׂאִין עַל” may be interpreted to mean “one marries additionally to …” This naturally is not meant here.</i>. If he raped a woman, her mother is permitted; if he seduced a woman, her daughter is permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted as <i>baraita</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 97a" href="/Yevamot.97a">Babli 97a</a>.</i>.
“He who rapes or seduces [a relative of] a married woman is guilty.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, one stated this for marriage. If he married a woman and then raped her mother, he is guilty. If he married a woman and then seduced her daughter, he is guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">This is obvious, cf. Chapter 10, Notes 139, 140.</i>.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Chullin 5:3" href="/Mishnah_Chullin.5.3">Mishnah <i>Ḥulin</i> 5:3</a>.</i>: “If he slaughtered her, her daughter’s daughter, and afterwards her daughter, he absorbs forty [lashes].<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Really, 39 lashes, the maximum permitted (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:3" href="/Deuteronomy.25.3"><i>Deut</i>. 25:3</a>). Similarly, Symmachos’s 80 are really 78.</i> Symmachos said in Rebbi Meïr’s name, he absorbs eighty.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:28" href="/Leviticus.22.28"><i>Lev</i>. 22:28</a>: “A cow or a sheep, it and its young you shall not slaughter on the same day.” Slaughtering a cow and a second generation calf on the same day is not forbidden. If after that the calf is slaughtered on the same day, with one act he slaughters {the cow and her calf} and {the calf’s calf and her mother}. For the rabbis, violating one law by one act can be punished only once. For Symmachos, the order of execution is important; the prohibition of slaughtering the calf after its mother is separate from that of slaughtering the mother after its calf.</i>” Rebbi Eleazar said, [Symmachos]<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in the text, required by the context.</i> and Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said the same thing, since we stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 3:6" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.3.6">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 3:6</a>. R. Eleazar’s opinion is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 14b" href="/Keritot.14b">Babli, <i>Keritut</i> 14b</a>.</i>: “Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said, he who copulates with his mother-in-law may be guilty because of his mother-in-law, his mother-in-law’s mother and his father-in-law’s mother. They said to him, all three fall under the same law<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The relevant verse is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>: “The genitals of a woman and her daughter you shall not uncover; her son’s daughter and her daughter’s daughter you shall not take to uncover her nakedness; they are family, it is taboo.” The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Keritot 1:13" href="/Tosefta_Keritot.1.13">Tosephta (<i>Keritut</i> 1:21</a>) explains that R.
