Joḥanan ben Nuri speaks about a man who married three wives, a woman and her nieces from a sister and a brother; i. e. a daughter and two granddaughters of the same woman. If the man sleeps with his mother-in-law, by one act he sleeps with a woman and her daughter, a woman and her daughter’s daughter, and a woman and her son’s daughter. If it is three times the same transgression, he is punished only once; if the one act implies three different paragraphs have been violated, he receives multiple punishment.</i>.” Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Symmachos agrees to the earlier [part of the Mishnah]<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ḥulin</i> 5:3, where it is stated that everybody agrees that if he slaughtered first the mother and after that two of her calves he is whipped “80” times but if he first slaughtered the two calves and then the mother, he is whipped only “40” times.</i>. If was found stated, it still is in dispute<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Chullin 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Chullin.5.1">Tosephta <i>Ḥulin</i> 5:7</a>: “If he slaughtered its five calves and then the cow, Symmachos said in the name of Rebbi Meïr he is guilty of five transgressions but he only is guilty for transgression of one prohibition.” This shows that Symmachos counts instances of the same prohibition separately; he cannot have the same position as R. Joḥanan ben Nuri. This is the position of Rava in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 15a" href="/Keritot.15a">Babli, <i>Keritut</i> 15a</a>; cf. צבי דור, תורת ארץ ישׂראל בבבל, דביר, תל אביב 1971, p. 42.</i>. What is Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri’s reason? Since a woman and her daughter and a woman and her daughter’s daughter fall under two separate prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">For him, the two parts of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a> are two separate paragraphs; for the rabbis the verse counts as only one.</i>, also a woman and her son’s daughter and her daughter’s daughter fall under two separate prohibitions. What is the reason of the rabbis? Since a woman and her daughter and a woman and her daughter’s daughter fall under one and the same prohibition, also a woman and her son’s daughter and her daughter’s daughter fall under one and the same prohibition.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a></i>: “If a man takes a woman and her mother, it is taboo.” Everywhere is written “lying with”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In the punishment list of Chap. 20. In the prohibition of Chap. 18, the expression used is mostly “uncovering genitals”.</i> but here is written “taking”, to teach you that he cannot be guilty for the second [woman] unless the first one is prepared<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Available to him at least by betrothal or obligation of levirate. The criminal sanction cannot be applied if one of the parties was married to him but died.</i> for him. Or maybe only by marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">That he had to marry both women. This is impossible since an incestuous marriage has no existence in law.</i>? We already said that there is no incestuous marriage. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1"><i>Deut</i>. 23:1</a>; neither the term “lying with” nor the term “uncovering genitals” is used. Does this mean that only the marriage with a stepmother is forbidden?<br>This and the following questions challenge the assertion that the incest prohibition of a man with mother and daughter is the only one where “taking” is mentioned.</i>: “Nobody may marry his father’s wife, and he should not uncover his father’s garment’s corner”? This comes to tell you that she was permitted to him before his father married her<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The statement that he may not marry her makes sense only if without the father’s marriage the son could have married her. This supports the Mishnah.</i>. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:21" href="/Leviticus.20.21"><i>Lev</i>. 20:21</a>. This is a relevant question since the verse is also from Chapter 20.</i>: “If a man take his brother’s wife, it is despicable”? This comes to tell you that she was permitted to him before his brother married her. This is confirmed by levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">She again becomes permitted to the levir.</i>. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:18" href="/Leviticus.18.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18:18</a>. The argument following is parallel to that of the verse quoted before this one.</i>: “You should not take a woman in addition to her sister to make her a co-wife”? This comes to tell you that she was permitted to him before he married her sister. This is confirmed after her sister’s death. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:17" href="/Leviticus.20.17"><i>Lev</i>. 20:17</a>. The argument identifies חסד I “to be well behaved” and חסד II “to act shamefully”. A similar argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 58b" href="/Sanhedrin.58b">Babli <i>Sanhedrin 58b</a></i>.</i>: “A man who would take his sister, his father’s daughter or his mother’s daughter; he sees her genitals and she sees his genitals, it is <i>ḥesed</i>.” Rebbi Avin said, that you should not say that Kain married his sister, Abel married his sister, “it is charitable”, I was charitable with the first generations so the world could be inhabited; “I said, the world was built on <i>ḥesed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 89:3" href="/Psalms.89.3"><i>Ps</i>. 89:3</a>.</i>.” But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:7" href="/Leviticus.21.7"><i>Lev</i>. 21:7</a>.</i>: “Widow, divorcee, and desecrated, these he shall not take”? This comes to tell you that if he became betrothed to her that the betrothal is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The marriages forbidden only to priests, “prohibitions of holiness”, are not incestuous; they are sinful but valid, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.3.2-3">Halakhah 2:3</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">This is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.7">Chapter 2, Notes 104–109</a>.</i> Rebbi Ḥuna understood all of them from this verse: “The genitals of a woman and her daughter you should not uncover, etc.” Taboo - taboo, for an equal cut. Since there are three generations downwards, so there are three generations upwards. Since there is a prohibition downwards, so there is a prohibition upwards. Since upwards one requires marriage, so downwards one requires marriage. Since upwards they are burned, so downwards they are burned. Since downwards, He gave the male’s daughter the same status as the female’s daughter, so upwards we give the male’s mother the same status as the female’s mother.
And following Rebbi Meïr? Since Rebbi Meïr said, a <i>gezerah šawah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 8:3:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.8.3.8">Chapter 8, Note 195</a>. R. Meïr holds that a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is valid only for the rules covered by the respective verses.</i> is at the place it comes from, from where is the third generation (below) forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Instead of “below” one has to read מלמעל “above”. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>, the daughter and granddaughter of a woman are forbidden as taboo to a man sleeping with the woman. Therefore, the question can only be whether the grandmother also is forbidden since the pivot of the prohibition is the woman he slept with first and, as a matter of principle, infractions of prohibitions are punishable only if the punishment is stated in the code. The mother is certainly under an incest prohibition whose infraction would be a capital crime; this is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>.</i>? And following the rabbis, who say, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is said about them<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">It refers to all aspects of the laws involved.</i>, from where that the third generation above is punished by burning<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Since she is not mentioned in the verse.</i>? Both for Rebbi Meïr and the rabbis, from where that the third generation above is forbidden? Since it is written “taboo, taboo” for a <i>gezerah šawah</i>, it is as if all were included; all are included<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">In both Chapters 18 and 20, the prohibition of a woman and either her descendants or ancestors appear in one verse. Therefore, in this case there is no difference in the positions of R. Meïr and the rabbis. The <i>gezerah šawah</i> is sufficient to transfer the prohibition of the descendants (18:17) to the ancestors (20:14) and the punishment from the ancestors to the descendants. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.2-10">Halakhah 2:4</a>. The same argument is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 75b" href="/Sanhedrin.75b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 75b</a>.</i>.
So far his daughter’s daughter from marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">As noted before, both <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14">20:14</a> contain expressions of marriage.</i>. His daughter’s daughter from a rape? “The genitals of your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a> prohibits incest with granddaughters. If only legitimate children were intended, the verse would be superfluous. Therefore, it must refer also to all illegitimate children; “rape” is only an example.</i>.” Where do we hold? If from marriage, it already had been said. So it it cannot refer to marriage but must refer to rape. So far for the warning, from where the punishment<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a> contains no indication of any punishment.</i>? Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, “they, they; taboo, taboo”.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev.</i> 18:10</a> ends עֶרְוָֽתְךָ <b>הֵנָּה</b> “they are your genitals;” <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev.</i> 18:17</a> ends שַׁאֲרָה הֵנָּה <b>זִאָה הִיא</b> “<i>they</i> are relatives, it is <i>taboo</i>;” <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a> reads וְלֹא תִהְיֶה <b>זִאָה</b>בְּתוֹכְכֶם “there should be no <i>taboo</i> among you.” He accepts a <i>gezerah šawah</i> between 18:10 and 17 based on the common word הנה and one between 18:17 and 20:14 based on the common word זמה. This concatenation of two transfers is not without problems (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 50a" href="/Zevachim.50a">Babli <i>Zebaḥim</i> 50a</a>); the Yerushalmi here indicates that it is only acceptable for R. Aqiba, not for R. Ismael. The argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 3a" href="/Yevamot.3a">Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 3a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 75b" href="/Sanhedrin.75b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 75b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">76a</a>) in the name of Rav Isaac bar Eudaimon.</i> That follows Rebbi Aqiba; following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael stated: “they”, from “them”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">He makes a direct connection between <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14">20:14</a>, taking the unusual word אתהן (for אותן), the combination of the <i>nota accusativi</i> and הן, הנה “they”, to indicate the connection. This argument is not quoted in the Babli.</i>. So far about his daughter’s daughter, from where his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a> makes no mention of the daughter as incest prohibition.</i>? Rav said, if he is forewarned about his daughter’s daughter, so much more for his daughter! If for his daughter’s daughter he is subject to extirpation, so much more for his daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 76a</a>, notes the obvious contradiction to the principle that no punishment can be imposed that is not clearly stated in the text (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.7">Note 31</a>) and holds that the argument is so simple that the prohibition must be considered as if it were written in the verse.</i>!
They asked before Rebbi Abbahu: His daughter’s daughter from a marriage; his daughter’s daughter from a rape? He said to them, every “daughter’s daughter” falls under the same category<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">R. Abbahu rejects the argument (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.8">Note 36</a>) that the illegitimate offspring needs an extra verse. The simple meaning of the verse includes all daughter’s daughters.</i>. They asked before Rebbi Abbahu: If [a man] came to a woman, she had a daughter, and after that he came and copulated with her<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Something must be missing here. The most simple scenario would be that a man sleeps with his illegitimate daughter when he married two granddaughters of the mother, one from a son and one from another daughter. If the copulation was in ignorance of the family relationship, how many purification sacrifices does he have to bring?</i>. Is he guilty about her because of a woman and her daughter, her daughter’s daughter and her son’s daughter? He said to them, “they are relatives, it is taboo;” all because of taboo<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Multiple transgression of the same statute can be punished only once.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥaggai asked before Rebbi Yose: Why do we not say, “your daughter you should not uncover, your daughter’s daughter you should not uncover”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">He questions the position of R. Abbahu; why should one not consider <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a> as containing two separate prohibitions?</i>? He said to him, if it were written “the genitals of a woman and her daughter’s daughter you shall not uncover”, we would have said, “your daughter you should not uncover, your daughter’s daughter you should not uncover”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">If the verse had not contained the mention of “taking” (i. e. “marrying”) to make the offense a capital crime, one could have considered the caesura in the verse as defining two separate clauses. But now, since the condition of marriage to at least one of them is essential for the definition of criminality of the act, that cannot be the interpretation.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 22b" href="/Yevamot.22b">Babli, 22b</a>, has a totally different take on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:10" href="/Leviticus.18.10"><i>Lev</i>. 18:10</a>: That verse speaks only of <i>his</i> granddaughters, but 18:17 deals with the granddaughters of his wife. It is concluded that the granddaughters of a woman with whom he has a child but who is not his wife cannot be under an incest prohibition which is a capital crime. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:7:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.7.6">Chapter 10, Note 195</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Hoshaiah. If there are two prohibitions and one liability to extirpation, the prohibitions split the extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">It is a general principle of hermeneutics in both Talmudim that for every prohibition one verse has to explain what is forbidden and another verse, often at a different place, has to spell out the punishment. If the latter verse refers to several prohibitions at once, the number of sins committed in one act (the number of required cleansing sacrifices if the sin was inadvertent) is counted by the number of prohibitions, not by the number of punishments enumerated separately. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 14b" href="/Makkot.14b">Babli (<i>Makkot</i> 14b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 3a" href="/Keritot.3a"><i>Keritut</i> 3a</a>), this is a matter of dispute.</i>. What is the reason? “On human flesh it may not be rubbed and in its proportions you should not make [a compound] like it.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:32" href="/Exodus.30.32"><i>Ex</i>. 30:32</a>, speaking of the oil used to anoint priests and holy vessels.</i>” And it is written: “A man who would compound like it<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:33" href="/Exodus.30.33"><i>Ex</i>. 30:33</a>: “A man who would compound its likeness or who would apply it on an outside person {who is not a priest} will be extirpated from his people.” There are only two prohibitions since the “human” of v. 32 is defined as “not a priest” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:33" href="/Exodus.30.33">v. 33</a>.</i>”. Here are two prohibitions and one liability to extirpation. The prohibitions divide the extirpation. This follows Rebbi Ismael, since Rebbi Ismael said one infers from an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> but one does not punish from an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">A principle spelled out many times in the Babli, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 5b" href="/Makkot.5b"><i>Makkot</i> 5b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 14a" href="/Makkot.14a">14a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 17a" href="/Makkot.17a">17a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 54a</a>.</i>. Where does he have that from? It comes following what Ḥizqiah stated: “If the daughter of a Cohen is desecrated by whoring.” Why does the verse say, “a man<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a>. “A Cohen man’s daughter if she is desecrated by whoring with her father, shall be burned in fire;” cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76" href="/Sanhedrin.76">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 76</a>.</i>”? To include him who cohabits with his daughter’s daughter from a rape that she should be [under sentence of] burning<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">It was determined earlier that the prohibition of 20:14 of descendents or progenitors in the direct line applies only if one of the women is married to the man. For priests, this is extended also to extramarital children.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, one may even understand this from the warning: “Do not desecrate your daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:29" href="/Leviticus.19.29"><i>Lev</i>. 19:29</a>: “Do not desecrate your daughter to cause her to whore.” This interpretation is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 76a</a>, in the name of R. Abun’s father and there is only one of several alternative interpretations.</i>.”
What is the reason of Rebbi Jehudah? “<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1"><i>Deut</i>. 23:1</a>. The hermeneutic principles require that two parallel clauses be interpreted as referring to two different situations. If such an interpretation is impossible, then the two clauses count as two separate prohibitions.</i> A man may not take his father’s wife,” that refers to his father’s wife; “and he should not uncover his father’s wing,” that is his rape victim. How do the rabbis explain “his father’s wing”? There<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 97a" href="/Yevamot.97a">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 97a</a>, stated in the name of Samuel.</i>, they say and they do not know the origin of the tradition, that refers to a wing which leans on his father<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The widow of a childless uncle who waits to be married in levirate by his father and in the meantime is forebidden to all other men.</i>. Would he not anyhow be guilty for her because of his father’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">For the rabbis who hold that candidacy counts as betrothal; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.1.6">Chapter 2, Note 27</a>.</i>? Rebbi Hila said, because of forewarning<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic interpretation, no punishment is possible in criminal cases unless criminal intent was established by two witnesses who testify that the perpetrator was duly warned that his intended act was criminal.</i>, that if he was warned because of his father’s wife, he will be whipped, and because of his father’s wing, he will be whipped<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 97a" href="/Yevamot.97a">Babli, 97a</a>, an anonymous statement that if we warned for both his father’s wife and his father’s wing, he transgresses two prohibitions in one act.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about whipping. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Since no penalty is stated in the Torah for the man who marries a woman who had unmarried sex with his father, he cannot be punished and, therefore, is unable to bring a sacrifice even if his act is considered sinful.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about all other doubtful cases that he is free<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">If the woman had sex with any man other than his father, a marriage to whom would make her current marriage incestuous, no punishment can be meted out even according to R. Jehudah since there is no biblical basis for it. Consequently, the marriage is valid.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah agrees that if he gave her <i>qiddušin</i> that these <i>qiddušin</i> are legally valid.
Rebbi Ḥaggai asked before Rebbi Yose: Is the child a bastard following Rebbi Jehudah? He said to him, “No one with a damaged testicle or with cut-off penis may marry<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:2" href="/Deuteronomy.23.2">Deut. 23:2</a></i>. The prohibition of the father’s wife is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:1" href="/Deuteronomy.23.1">verse 1</a>, the rule of bastardy is verse 3; cf. Chaper 4, Note 211.</i>” interrupts the argument. It interrupted the argument in the matter of the father’s wife. He retorted, the father’s wife was part of the set of all incest prohibitions; it was selected from this set to teach about bastardy for all incest prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">This is an application of Rule 9 of R. Ismael (Introduction to <i>Sifra</i>): “Anything in a set which was selected from that set to teach, was not selected to teach only for itself but for the entire set.”<br>The prohibition of the stepmother is contained in the set of all incest prohibitions (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>., Chapters 18</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20" href="/Leviticus.20">20</a>). Therefore, if the result of incest with a stepmother is a bastard, the result of any other incestuous relation must be a bastard (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.14.1">Mishnaiot 4:14</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:15:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.15.1">15</a>).</i>. (Let the father’s wife be selected to teach about bastardy for all incests prohibitions.) Similarly, let the rape victim be selected to teach a prohibition concerning all rape victims<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥaggai wants to argue that since according to R. Jehudah, the prohibition of a person who had unmarried sex with his father is written in one verse with the prohibition of the father’s wife, all relationships that would be incestuous in the case of marriage should be prohibited.</i>. He said to him, the father’s wife was part of the set of all incest prohibitions; it was selected from this set to teach about bastardy for all incest prohibitions. Can you say that the rape victim was in a set of all rape victims, that it could teach a prohibition concerning all rape victims<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">There does not exist a set of women prohibited as incestuous by extramarital sex; the set to which Rule 9 might be applied contains only the woman who had slept with his father. The parallel reasoning implied by R. Ḥaggai does not work.</i>? Why cannot the father’s wife be selected to teach about the rape victims in her case? He said to him, is she is the father’s wife, she is not his rape victim; is she is the father’s rape victim, she is not his wife.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The sons of a female convert who converted with her do neither perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> nor levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Even if they biologically are children of the same father, they legally are not since the rules of family relationships are restricted to Jews.</i> even if a first [son] was not conceived in holiness<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Before conversion.</i> but born in holiness and a second [son] was conceived and born in holiness. The same applies to a slave girl<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Who before manumission already was Jewish as a slave.</i> who was freed together with her sons.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A female convert who converted,” etc. Is not<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The interrogative here does not make much sense; the <i>baraita</i> text is a copy from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim"><i>Sifra Qedošim Parašah</i> 9(9</a>), where the rhetorical question is appropriate.</i> the convert guilty for his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">If he injures or curses his mother (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:15" href="/Exodus.21.15"><i>Ex</i>. 21:15</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:17" href="/Exodus.21.17">17</a>). R. Yose the Galilean holds that a Gentile cannot claim relationship with his children, whether the mother is Gentile or Jewish.</i> but not for his father following Rebbi Yose the Galilean? Rebbi Aqiba says, “his father and mother he cursed.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:9" href="/Leviticus.20.9"><i>Lev</i>. 20:9</a>: “Any man who would curse his father and (or) his mother shall certainly die; his father and (or) mother he cursed, his blood is on him.” R. Aqiba infers from “curse his father”, “his mother he cursed”, that the rules for father and mother must be identical.</i>” Anybody potentially guilty for his mother is potentially guilty for his father but nobody who cannot be guilty for his mother can be guilty for his father<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">In fact, the argument goes the other way, anybody who cannot be guilty for his father cannot be guilty for his mother. Therefore, the child who converted with his mother cannot be prosecuted for injuring or cursing his mother.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba agrees that the “silenced<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">A person of unknown paternity, who is <i>silenced</i> by his mother should he adress any man as his father. If his father were known, he would be a normal Jew.</i>” one is potentially guilty for his mother but not for his father. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Where do they<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose the Galilean and R. Aqiba.</i> disagree? About a convert not conceived in holiness but born in holiness. But about a convert conceived and born in holiness even Rebbi Yose the Galilean agrees<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">There is not much to disagree since the child is born as full Jew (even though he is called a proselyte after his father, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.3.10.1">Mishna <i>Qiddušin</i> 3:12</a>)..</i>.
Rebbi Yasa went to Ḥomṣ<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The city in Syria.</i>. People came and asked him about the family of Ashtin<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Demai</i> Chapter 6 they are called Astor.</i> who were converts, might they marry in levirate? He said to them, so says Rebbi Joḥanan: It is prohibited. They wanted to say, if a woman has children<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The widow had children but all of them were born while she was a Gentile.</i>. But if the woman has no children, what can you say? He married his brother’s wife in levirate. If she is not his brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">If converts born as Gentile brothers are not legally brothers after conversion, the wife of one cannot be forbidden to the other.</i>, should he not be considered as marrying a wife from outside? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa came in the name of Rebbi Isaac bar Naḥman: Even so it is forbidden, that people should not say, we saw the commandment of levirate among converts. When has this been said? When he lived with her after he converted<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">By the first intercourse after conversion, which certainly was executed as an act between husband and wife, the Gentile marriage became valid in Jewish law.</i>. But if he did not live with her after he converted, everybody agrees that it is as if he<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The surviving brother may marry the woman who never was Jewishly married to his brother even if the relationship of brotherhood remained in effect after conversion.</i> married a woman from outside.
A convert who converted while married to a woman and her daughter, or a woman and her sister, marries one and separates from the other<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">He marries one in Jewish law and separates from the other or divorces her in Gentile law.</i>. When has this been said? If he did not live with either of them. But if he lived with one of them after he converted, the one he lived with is his wife. If he lived with both of them, since he lived with them, he lived with them<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Since family relationships are dissolved by conversion, the two co-wives are not related in biblical law and, therefore, not prohibited in biblical law. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 98b" href="/Yevamot.98b">Babli, 98b</a>, disagrees and holds that if he comes to ask, one tells him to separate from both of them. If he married one of them, he may keep her. It seems from this that the Babli would not tolerate a man to live with two wives who before conversion were mother and daughter or sisters.</i>.
A convert has to separate from his sister, whether paternal or maternal, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Jehudah says, he must separate from his maternal halfsister; a paternal halfsister he may keep. He must separate from his mother’s sister but may keep his father’s sister, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Jehudah says, he must separate from his mother’s maternal halfsister but may keep his mother’s paternal halfsister<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">If he was married to any one of them at the moment of his conversion. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 98b" href="/Yevamot.98b">Babli, 98b</a>, R. Meïr is quoted as he is here, but instead of R. Jehudah, the anonymous Sages are quoted as permitting all sisters and aunts. In <i>Gen. Rabba</i> 18(7), the <i>baraita</i> is quoted as it is here, only that instead of R. Jehudah one has the anonymous Sages.</i>. If he married any other incest prohibited woman, he may keep her. It was only said, “if he married”. Therefore, not from the start<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">If he comes to ask, one does not permit the marriage. In the Babli, all women who are not blood relatives are unconditionally permitted.</i>.
A Gentile has to separate from his sister, whether paternal or maternal, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Jehudah says, he must separate from his maternal halfsister; a paternal halfsister he may keep. He must separate from his mother’s sister but may keep his father’s sister, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Jehudah says, he must separate from his mother’s maternal halfsister but may keep his mother’s paternal halfsister<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The rules for Gentiles living under Jewish law are identical to those valid for converts; in the Babli they are given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 58a" href="/Sanhedrin.58a"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 58a</a>, identical to the rules given for converts in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 98b" href="/Yevamot.98b"><i>Yebamot</i>98b</a>.</i>. Rav Ḥanin said, he<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">This must be Rav, Rav Ḥanin’s teacher and father-in-law.</i> explained us the words of Rebbi Meïr simply: “Therefore, a man has to abandon his father and his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 2:24" href="/Genesis.2.24"><i>Gen</i>. 2:24</a>. The common interpretation of the verse as basis of a “natural law” of incest prohibitions is in the sources [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 58a" href="/Sanhedrin.58a">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 58a</a>, <i>Gen. rabba</i> 18(8)]: “Therefore, a man leaves his father (the father’s wife who might not be his mother) and his mother and clings to his wife (marriage is effected by intercourse, but after the first intercourse of a woman all sex acts with other people are adulterous since there is no divorce; male homosexual activity is also forbidden) and they will be one flesh (only vaginal intercourse is counted as such).” All other incest prohibitions of <i>Lev</i>. are for Jews only. (A minority opinion, that of R. Eliezer in the Babli, identifies the “father” as the father’s sisters.)</i>.” What is close to him from his father’s side, what is close to him from his mother’s side. Rebbi Vivian asked: Then his father’s sister should be forbidden because she is close to his father! His mother’s sister should be forbidden because she is close to his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that the opinion of R. Eliezer, quoted in the Babli (see the preceding note) was unknown to the editors of the Yerushalmi.</i>! Rebbi Simeon, the son of Rebbi Ayvo objected: “Amram took his aunt Yokhebed as wife<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 6:20" href="/Exodus.6.20"><i>Ex</i>. 6:20</a>. According to the rules promulgated by him, Moses was a bastard. This proves (a) that the incest prohibitions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a> are introduced because of the holiness of the Land or as prohibition of idolatrous practices and (b) the paternal aunt is permitted to a Gentile.</i>.” Does that mean that the Israelites did not even behave as descendants of Noah? Rebbi Hila said, what is close to him from his father’s side, what is close to him from his mother’s side<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Only the father’s wives and the mother.</i>. They objected to Rebbi Meïr: “And truly she is my sister, my father’s daughter, but not my mother’s.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 20:12" href="/Genesis.20.12"><i>Gen</i>. 20:12</a>. According to Philo (<i>Special Laws III</i>, 22–25), the practice of marrying halfsisters was recognized in Greece and that of marrying full sisters in Egypt.</i>” He said to them: Is a proof from there? Not “she became my wife”<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">I am at a loss to understand the argument. The expedient chosen by the talmudic sources, that Sarah was not Abraham’s sister but his niece, should be excluded out of respect for the biblical text (Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:7:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.7.8">Chapter 10, Note 210</a>). This cannot be a general Jewish tradition since Sadducee (Karaite) traditions prohibit the niece to the uncle because the text prohibits the nephew to the aunt.</i>?
What about it<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">What is the practice about prohibited Gentile marriages.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, about any incest prohibition which for a Jewish court is a capital crime, a descendant of Noah<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Any Gentile.</i> is forewarned; and about any incest prohibition which for a court is not a capital crime, a descendant of Noah is not forewarned<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This is characterized as R. Meïr’s minority opinion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 57b" href="/Sanhedrin.57b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 57b</a>.</i>. They objected: Is not a case involving the sister a capital crime for a Jewish court and the descendants of Noah are not forewarned<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The example is exceedingly bad since incest with one’s sister is punished by Heaven with extirpation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:17" href="/Leviticus.20.17"><i>Lev</i>. 20:17</a>) but is not a capital crime on Earth. Maybe the reference should be to a man married to a woman and her daughter; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.2.4">Note 82</a>.</i>? Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “Because of these abominations, the Eternal, your God, uproots them before you.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:12" href="/Deuteronomy.18.12"><i>Deut</i>. 18:12</a>, speaking of idolatry.</i>” This teaches that the Holy One, praise to Him, does not punish if He did not warn<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition of idolatry is universal, valid for all descendants of Noah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 57b" href="/Sanhedrin.57b">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 57b</a>). Therefore, Gentiles can be punished for idolatrous practices since they have been warned about them. R. Hila seems to agree that the incest prohibitions which exceed the bare minimum are directed against idolatrous practices.</i>.
Rebbi Idi said before Rebbi Yose, a slave is permitted his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">As the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 58b" href="/Sanhedrin.58b">Babli explains (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 58b</a>), he is no longer a Gentile but not yet a responsible Jew. He cannot be punished in either law and he cannot legally marry.</i>. He said to him, did you hear this even if she is from the same mother? He said, yes. He said to him, but did we not state: “The same applies to a slave girl who was freed together with her sons.” For <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">But not for criminal matters. The convert changed from one set of laws to another; the libertine enters a set of laws that previously were not applicable to her.</i>. Rebbi Phineas said before Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Yasa: A slave who slept with his mother is obligated for a purification sacrifice. “You shall command them<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 1:2" href="/Leviticus.1.2"><i>Lev</i>. 1:2</a>. After the introduction: “Speak to the Children of Israel”, the addition “you shall command them” seems superfluous unless it includes people whose inclusion among the Children of Israel is doubtful.</i>,” including slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since in theory anything a slaves owns belongs to his master, any obligation of sacrifice would have to be deferred until after the slave’s manumission.</i>. Or should we say, this was said about fat<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">While a slave is obligated to obey all prohibitions in the Torah, it may be that in matters of sexual relations his status is different. (Since slaves cannot marry, as a matter of principle promiscuity is permitted to them; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 8:4:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.8.4.10"><i>Terumot</i> Chapter 8, Note 247</a>.)</i>? Do we find in his relation to his mother that her converted aspect accompanies the unconverted aspect just as with a slave girl her converted aspect accompanies the unconverted aspect<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">A betrothed girl is a wife for criminal law; adultery with her is a capital crime (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:23-24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.23-24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:23–24</a>). By contrast, adultery with a half-freed slave girl engaged to be married to a free man (in expectation of her full emancipation; she did belong to two masters one of whom manumitted his share) can be expiated by a reparation offering (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:20-22" href="/Leviticus.19.20-22"><i>Lev</i>. 19:20–22</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 5" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_5"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 5</a>). This shows that her semi-free status interferes with the operation of criminal law for free persons. In analogy, we could conjecture that the status of a slave as incompletely converted (since he is not obligated to observe most positive commandments) interferes with the operation of the laws of obligatory sacrifices.<br>The problem is not resolved, probably because it is not realistic.</i>?

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the children of five women were mixed up, and the mixed-up became adults, married wives, and died, then four perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one marries in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that each woman had another child whose family membership is clear. If one of the mixed-up children dies childless, then it is not known whose brother he was. Therefore, one brother known to be from each of the families involved performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the widow who may be his sister-in-law or four perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one marries. The one who marries either performs levirate or he marries an unrelated woman; in both cases the marriage is unquestionably valid.</i>. This one and three others perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for another one and another one marries in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The one who married the first widow might also marry the second one. The number five here is irrelevant; the same rules apply to any number <i>n</i> of mixed-up children. The death of a childless man of the mixed-up group causes <i>n</i>-1 <i>ḥalîṣot</i> and 1 levirate or <i>n ḥalîṣot</i>.</i>. It turns out that there are four <i>ḥaliṣot</i> and one levirate marriage for every one.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the children of five women were mixed up,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The one who married the first widow might also marry the second one. The number five here is irrelevant; the same rules apply to any number <i>n</i> of mixed-up children. The death of a childless man of the mixed-up group causes <i>n</i>-1 <i>ḥalîṣot</i> and 1 levirate or <i>n ḥalîṣot</i>.</i> Everywhere you say, there is no <i>ḥalîṣah</i> after <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, and here, you say so? There, it is was sure, here it is in doubt. Everywhere you say, if one does not say to him, take in levirate, one does not say, perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, and here, you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah is to be interpreted strictly, that the widow is permitted to one of then possible brothers only after all other have performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her; otherwise he might marry another man’s brother’s widow. That means that the four first men must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and are forbidden for levirate.</i>? There, it is was sure, here it is doubtful.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman’s child was mixed up with her daughter-in-law’s child, the mixed-up children became adults, married wives, and died<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">One of the mixed-up sons died childless while being married.</i>. The other sons of the daughter-in-law must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate since for them it is doubtful whether [the widow was] a brother’s wife or an uncle’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">If the deceased was the son of the daughter-in-law, his widow could be married in levirate but if he was the son of the mother-in-law, she is forbidden to her husband’s nephew. Therefore, one of the other sons of the daughter-in-law must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her.</i>. But the sons of the old woman may either perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate since for them she was either a brother’s wife or a nephew’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">If a son of the daughter-in-law had performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, then the widow is either the sister-in-law of her husband’s brother and can be married in levirate or she is the widow of a nephew who can be married. “Levirate” in this case has to be taken with a grain of salt since unintentional intercourse (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.1.1">Mishnah 6:1</a>) will only possibly make the widow a wife.</i>. If one of the identified ones died, the mixed-up ones must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate for a son of the old woman since there is a doubt whether [the widow was] a brother’s wife or an uncle’s wife. But for the sons of the daughter-in-law, one performs <i>ḥalîṣah;</i> the other may marry in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">If the widow already had one <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, she is either the sister-in-law or the free widow of a nephew and permitted.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a woman’s child was mixed up,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said: So is the Mishnah: The sister-in-law’s sons’ wives, the old woman’s sons’ wives<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">An obvious correction of the language of the Mishnah; one does not speak of the sons of mother-in-law or daughter-in-law but of their childless widows.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, this implies that a man may marry a nephew’s ex-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">There is no doubt that such a union is permitted by biblical standards; for some reason it was felt necessary to state thaï there is no rabbinic restriction in the case.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the child of a priestly woman was mixed up with the child of her slave girl then both may eat heave; they together take one part from the threshing floor, they may not defile themselves by becoming impure for the dead, and they may not marry women enabled or disabled [for the priesthood]<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Each of them is a possible Cohen. The details are explained in the Halakhah; the removal of the disabilities is the subject of the next Mishnah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the child of a priestly woman was mixed up,” etc. “Both may eat heave”, since slaves of Cohanim eat heave.
“They together take one part from the threshing floor,” that is what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: One does not distribute to women and slaves on the threshing floor<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">As the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 99b" href="/Yevamot.99b">Babli (99b</a>) explains, one does not admit women to the public distribution of heave and tithes since a woman may lose her priestly status from one distribution to the next and still receive heave and/or tithes since the farmer may recognize her from former distributions. Slaves are excluded since the entitlement to heave was counted as a proof of priestly status (cf. <i>Ketubot</i> 2:7,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:7:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.7.2-4">8</a>).</i> but one gives them the gifts of priesthood and/or those due to Levites from the barn<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Privately, where no presumption of priestly status is created.</i>.
“They may not marry women, whether enabled or disabled [for the priesthood].” Not enabled ones because of the disabled one. Not disabled ones because of the enabled one<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The slave cannot marry any woman; the priest is forbidden to marry a woman disabled for the priesthood.</i>.
May they bring one cereal offering together that would be totally burned<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The cereal offering of a Cohen in the Temple must be burned completely (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:16" href="/Leviticus.6.16"><i>Lev</i>. 6:16</a>). They may bring a cereal offering to the Temple and declare that it should be counted as the offering of the one of them who is a Cohen.</i>? It was stated: They may bring one cereal offering conditionally that would be totally burned. May they bring two cereal offerings one of which should be burned totally and the other have a handful taken and the rest eaten<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">They may bring two cereal offerings to the Temple and declare that one should be counted as the offering of the one of them who is a Cohen and the other one as the offering of the slave. A handful of the second offering together with all its incense is burned on the altar and the rest eaten by the Cohanim under the rules of most holy offerings (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:7-11" href="/Leviticus.6.7-11"><i>Lev</i>. 6:7–11</a>).</i>? It was stated: They may bring two cereal offerings of one which is burned totally and of the other a handful is taken and the rest eaten. May they testify together that it should be counted as testimony of one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Slaves are not admitted as formal witnesses. (They are admitted to ascertain facts, such as the death of a man to permit the widow to remarry.) If their testimonies are identical, may the court accept the testimony of the one who really is a Cohen?</i>? That would follow the rule of Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav Isaac in the name of Rav Assi: Since if they were to be found perjured they could not be executed, the murderer could not be executed<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">A false witness must receive the punishment that would have been meted out to the accused had his testimony been accepted by the court. Since a slave cannot be a witness in a criminal proceeding, he cannot be punished as a perjured witness. Since it is not known who of the two is a slave, neither of them can be punished. In the formulation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 41a" href="/Sanhedrin.41a">Babli (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 41a</a>): Testimony which is not subject to the penalties of perjuty is no testimony. The remark: “This applies here also” shows that the statement of Rav Assi refers to criminal proceedings in general. The murderer cannot be executed if one of the testimonies to his guilt is not subject to the penalties of perjury.</i>. This applies here also.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> When the mixed-up children became adults and manumitted one another<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Then the slave is manumitted and becomes a full Israel. The manumission of the Cohen is invalid and does not damage him.</i> they may marry women appropriate for the priesthood, may not defile themselves for the dead, but if they became defiled they do not suffer forty lashes<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In order to punish one of them for wilfully desecrating himself, the court would have to prove that the culprit is a Cohen. Since this is impossible, neither of them can ever be punished for any infraction of priestly rules.</i>. They may not eat heave, but if they ate they do not have to pay its value and and additional fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Since the monetary penalty for unauthorized use of heave has to be given to a Cohen (Mishnaiot <i>Terumot</i> 6:1, 7:1), and no Cohen can successfully sue any of them for payment by proving that he is not a Cohen, they do not have to pay.</i>. They cannot attend distributions on the threshing floor; they have to sell their heave, but the money is theirs<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">They may not eat heave since the eater may be the former slave. They keep the money since they cannot be sued for it, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.7.1">Note 126</a>.</i>. They have no part in the Temple sacrifices, one does not give them sacrifices, but one cannot take theirs from them<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Since a Cohen has the right to sacrifice in the Temple even if he is not on duty there, they have the right to hand over their sacrifices to any certified Cohen and are not obligated to give it to the group of Cohanim currently serving there.</i>. They are exempt from the foreleg, the chin, and the first stomach<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The gift to the Cohanim from profane slaughter, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:3" href="/Deuteronomy.18.3"><i>Deut</i>. 18:3</a>.</i>. Their firstborn animal should graze until it develops a blemish<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">An unblemished firstborn animal must be given to a Cohen to be sacrificed in the Temple and eaten by the Cohen. Once it is blemished it can be slaughtered locally and eaten by anybody, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 15:19-23" href="/Deuteronomy.15.19-23"><i>Deut</i>. 15:19–23</a>.</i>. One charges them with the disabilities of an Israel and those of Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">This gives the rationale for the entire Mishnah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the mixed-up children became adults,” after it happened<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">One would have expected the Mishnah to read: Once adults, they manumit one another. Does the formulation of the Mishnah imply that the manumission is not recommended?</i>. Does that mean, not from the start? So is the Mishnah: It is permitted from the start to manumit<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 100a" href="/Yevamot.100a">Babli, 100a</a>, insists that the court forces them to manumit one another.</i>. Even Rebbi Yose the Galilean, who said that one is forbidden to manumit<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Based on the verse <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:46" href="/Leviticus.25.46"><i>Lev</i>. 25:46</a>: “You shall have them work for you forever”. In the Babli, this interpretation is quoted in the name of the Amora Rav Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 47b" href="/Berakhot.47b"><i>Berakhot</i> 47b</a>), R. Aqiba (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 3b" href="/Sotah.3b"><i>Soṭah</i> 3b</a>, against R. Ismael who reads “You may have them work for you forever”), Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 38b" href="/Gittin.38b"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 38b</a>).</i>, will agree here that it is permitted for the benefit of children. What means “appropriate”? Not disabled.
From where that a Cohen presents his sacrifices during [the period of duty of] any watch<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The land of Israel was divided into 24 districts and the priests from each district came to the Temple for one week (serving as <i>watch</i> from the presentation of the shew-bread on one Sabbath to its removal the next Sabbath). The priests were indemnified for their work by receiving the skins of most holy sacrifices and all gifts to priests during their week of work. A hint of this is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:9" href="/Deuteronomy.18.9"><i>Deut</i>. 18:9</a>.<br>Even after the destruction of the Temple, the calendar of service of the districts was retained for special occasions, cf. Mishnah <i>Ta‘aniot</i> 2:7.</i> he chooses? The verse says, “he may come as his heart desires … and serve”<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:6-7" href="/Deuteronomy.18.6-7"><i>Deut</i>. 18:6–7</a>. Priests acting for themselves are exempt from the obligation to use the watch in charge of the week. The same argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 109b" href="/Bava_Kamma.109b">Babli <i>Baba Qama</i> 109b</a>, where verses are quoted in support of the assertion here that the hide and meat do not belong to the acting watch. In contrast, <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 168 restricts the right of the Cohen to participation in the priestly blessing any time he so desires.</i>. If he was old or sick, he may give it to any watch he likes but the hide and meat are his. If he was impure or had a bodily defect, he must give it to the acting watch<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The old or sick in principle are able to sacrifice by themselves; the impure and disfigured are barred from entering the Temple. The latter cannot sacrifice and in this respect are not different in status from a non-Cohen.</i>, and the hide and meat are theirs. These mixed-up ones, how do you treat them? Comparing them to the old or sick, or to the impure or to those with a bodily defect. It seems reasonable to compare them to the impure or those having a bodily defect<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">They could not possibly be accepted as acting priests in the Temple.</i>; but the Mishnah compares them to the old or sick, since we have stated: “One cannot take his from him<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">This is the language of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.7.1">Mishnah 8</a>.</i>.”

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> [A woman] did not wait three months after [the death of] her husband, married, and gave birth, and it is not known whether it is a nine months’ child of the first or a seven months’ child of the second. If she had sons from the first and the second, they perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">If the questionable child married and died childless, the widow needs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> from both sides. She cannot marry any one of them since her husband might have been the son of the other man and the marriage would then be incestuous.</i>. Similarly, he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">If he had only one brother on one side and that one died childless, he must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for the widow but is forbidden levirate.</i>. If he had brothers from the first or from the second not from the same mother, he may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that he is not a candidate for either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate if there is another brother who could marry or release a widow without complication. If there was only one brother on one side who died childless, his widow either is a sister-in-law who can be married by the levir or she is an unrelated woman free to marry any man.</i> and they may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and a number of independent Mishnah mss.: “One performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one may marry in levirate.” In that version, if the questionable son dies childless, a brother from one side must perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>; then one of the other side either may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or marry in levirate since either the widow is his sister-in-law or she is unrelated and free to marry any man. One must assume that the version of the Yerushalmi (and a group of independent Mishnah mss.) is shorthand for the version of the Babli.</i>.<br>If one was an Israel and the other a priest<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The two husbands.</i>, he may marry a woman appropriate for the priesthood, may not defile himself for the dead, but if he became defiled he does not suffer forty lashes<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In order to punish one of them for wilfully desecrating himself, the court would have to prove that the culprit is a Cohen. Since this is impossible, neither of them can ever be punished for any infraction of priestly rules.</i>. He may not eat heave but if he ate, he does not have to pay its value and additional fifth<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Since the monetary penalty for unauthorized use of heave has to be given to a Cohen (Mishnaiot <i>Terumot</i> 6:1, 7:1), and no Cohen can successfully sue any of them for payment by proving that he is not a Cohen, they do not have to pay.</i>. He cannot attend distributions on the threshing floor. He has to sell his heave but the money is his<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">They may not eat heave since the eater may be the former slave. They keep the money since they cannot be sued for it, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.7.1">Note 126</a>.</i>. He has no part in the Temple sacrifices, one does not give him sacrifices but one cannot take his from him<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Since a Cohen has the right to sacrifice in the Temple even if he is not on duty there, they have the right to hand over their sacrifices to any certified Cohen and are not obligated to give it to the group of Cohanim currently serving there.</i>. He is exempt from the foreleg, the chin, and the first stomach<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The gift to the Cohanim from profane slaughter, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:3" href="/Deuteronomy.18.3"><i>Deut</i>. 18:3</a>.</i>. His firstborn animal should graze until it develops a blemish<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">An unblemished firstborn animal must be given to a Cohen to be sacrificed in the Temple and eaten by the Cohen. Once it is blemished it can be slaughtered locally and eaten by anybody, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 15:19-23" href="/Deuteronomy.15.19-23"><i>Deut</i>. 15:19–23</a>.</i>. One charges him with the disabilities of an Israel and those of Cohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">This gives the rationale for the entire Mishnah.</i>.<br>If both<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">The two husbands.</i> were Cohanim, he has to mourn intensely for them and they for him<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">On the day of death of one of his possible fathers, he is forbidden to serve in priestly functions. If he dies, both possible fathers are barred. The disability of a priest on the day of death of a close relative is inferred from the command given to Aaron and his sons on the day Nadab and Abihu died (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:6" href="/Leviticus.10.6"><i>Lev</i>. 10:6</a>) to continue their Temple service. If it were not forbidden in general, no special permission would have been needed.</i>. He may not defile himself for them, they may not defile themselves for him. He does not inherit from them<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot prove to the other heirs that he is the son of the deceased.</i> but they inherit from him<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">If he dies without issue, his father should inherit his property. Since neither of them can prove that he is the father, they split his estate between them.</i>. He is not prosecutable if he injures or curses either one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The prosecutor cannot prove that he cursed or injured his father.</i>. He may serve on the watch of either one but does not participate in distributions<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">He is a Cohen for the divine service but has no property rights since he cannot prove his claim if the fathers belong to different watches.</i>. If both were of the same watch, he takes one part.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “[A woman] did not wait three months,” etc. “If both were Cohanim, he has to mourn intensely for them,” etc. Where do we hold<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Under which circumstances did she separate from the first husband?</i>? It is impossible after death [of the first] since we have stated: “He has to mourn intensely for them and they<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Including the first husband, who then must be alive.</i> for him.” One understands that he does not defile himself for the second [husband], I say that he is the son of the first. But why does he not defile himself for the first one? It must be that he divorced. Then, as you take it, if he is his son, he should defile himself for him. If he is not his son, he is desecrated, and what happens if he defiles himself<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">If the second husband married a divorcee, his child is not a Cohen and not under the disabilities of Cohanim.</i>? It must be that he<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The second man is not a husband; then he did not marry a divorcee and his son is a Cohen. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 100b" href="/Yevamot.100b">Babli, 100b</a>, expands on the same arguments and concludes that the first might have been a husband who married after an invalid betrothal, whose wife may walk out on him without a divorce.</i> raped. Did not Rebbi Abba say in the name of Abba bar Jeremiah that a rape victim does not have to wait three months<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:11:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.11.6">Chapter 4, Note 166</a>.</i>? Should we say, following the rabbis, but we follow Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah follows the opinion that a rape victim does have to wait three months before marrying but practice does not follow this opinion.</i>!
Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: One mourns deeply and defiles himself in a case of doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">From the following it seems that this covers two different kinds of doubt: A doubt of paternity and a doubt whether a child is a stillbirth or not. The second problem arises when a child is born after eight months of pregnancy and does not live for 30 days (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.2.5">Chapter 4, Note 70</a>).</i>. Rebbi Yose said, the Mishnah says so: “He has to mourn intensely for them and they for him.” Rebbi Ashian bar Yaqim had a case<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Of an 8-months’ child who did not live.</i>. He asked Rebbi Yose, who told him, you do not have to. He said to him, but did not Rebbi Ḥiyya say, one mourns deeply and defiles himself in a case of doubt? His signs were clear<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya requires full mourning if the child had hair and fingernails (following Rebbi in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:7" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.7">Tosephta <i>Sabbath</i> 15:7</a>). In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80b" href="/Yevamot.80b">Babli, 80b</a>, complete hair and fingernails prove that the child is a living seven-months’ baby who just lingered in the womb.</i>. But did not the colleagues say in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: One does not act on the signs of an eight months’ child<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The signs does not prove that the child is able to live.</i>? He had a sign that he had intercourse and then separated<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">The husband went on a trip after having the last intercourse and did not return before the pregnancy was visible, which gives a lower bound for the duration of pregnancy which came to 8 months and 1 day, i. e., 9 months.</i>.
An eight months’ child is like a stone<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:5" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.5">Tosephta <i>Sabbath</i> 15:5</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 135a" href="/Shabbat.135a">Babli <i>Sabbath</i> 135a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 80a" href="/Yevamot.80a"><i>Yebamot</i> 80a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 20a" href="/Bava_Batra.20a"><i>Baba Batra</i> 20a</a>. He is considered to be dead.</i> and one does not move him on the Sabbath, but his mother lies down beside him and nurses him. Rebbi Yose asked: May one push aside the Sabbath for babies that are in doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">May a child which possibly may be an eight-months’ child be circumcised on the Sabbath if he was born on the Sabbath? It is clear that the Toseptha <i>Sabbath</i> 15:5 was not known to the Yerushalmi since it clearly states: In case of doubt whether it is a seven or an eight months’ child, one does not push aside the Sabbath.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, it is fine. How you take it, if he is a nine months’ child, he must be circumcised. If he is an eight months’ child, it is as if he cut flesh without need. The rabbis of Caesarea said, Rebbi Jacob ben Dositheos<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that he was an Amora of the fourth generation. In other sources, he is called בן דוסאי, בן דוֹסתאי.</i> asked, who permitted to cut flesh without need<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">They answer the question in the negative; one has to wait until after the Sabbath. It is clear from the next paragraph that one has to wait 30 days to circumcise an eight months’ baby. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 136a" href="/Shabbat.136a">Babli, <i>Sabbath</i> 136a</a>, in the name of R. Ada bar Ahava, follows R. Yose bar Abun here and explains the Tosephta (Note 162) that one may not push aside the Sabbath if one forgot to bring the necessary implements and would have to carry them in the public domain on the Sabbath.</i>?
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Shabbat (Lieberman) 15:7" href="/Tosefta_Shabbat_(Lieberman).15.7">Tosephta <i>Sabbath</i> 15:7</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 135a" href="/Shabbat.135a">Babli <i>Sabbath</i> 135a</a>.</i>: Rebbi Simeon ben Gamliel says, any human who lives for thirty days is not a still birth, “all redeemed you shall redeem at the age of one month<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:16" href="/Numbers.18.16"><i>Num</i>. 18:16</a>.</i>;” and an animal which lives for eight days is not a still birth, “from the eighth day and further it will be welcome as a sacrifice, a gift to the Eternal<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:27" href="/Leviticus.22.27"><i>Lev</i>. 22:27</a>.</i>.” There<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 136a" href="/Shabbat.136a">Babli <i>Sabbath</i> 136a</a>. The rabbis hold that any child born alive frees his mother from levirate and <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>, they say that practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. Rebbi Abba said, where do they disagree? If he was not born in his months<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">7 or 9 months. The disagreement is only about an 8 months’ child which does not have hair and fingernails. The Babli agrees.</i>. But if he was born in his months, even Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel will agree.
“If he injured one and then injured the other, or cursed one and then cursed the other, he cannot be prosecuted.”<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.7">Tosephta 12:7</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101a" href="/Yevamot.101a">Babli 101a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 16a" href="/Makkot.16a"><i>Makkot</i> 16a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 82b" href="/Chullin.82b"><i>Ḥulin</i> 82b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 91a" href="/Chullin.91a">91a</a>.</i> Rebbi Ḥanania asked, does that not disagree with Rebbi Joḥanan? Since they disagree about the second day of holidays in the diaspora. Rebbi Joḥanan said, one accepts forwarning in a case of doubt, Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, one does not accept forwarning in a case of doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is presented in detail in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 5:4:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.5.4.2-12"><i>Pesaḥim</i> 5:4</a> (fol. 32c), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 8:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.8.1.2-10"><i>Nazir</i> 8:1</a> (fol. 57a); derived from the point of view of R. Jehudah in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 16a" href="/Makkot.16a">Babli <i>Makkot</i> 16a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina said in the name of Rebbi, there is no disagreement. There, it would have been possible to make a determination, here it is impossible to make the determination.
“If he injured both of them at the same time or cursed them at the same time, he is guilty. Rebbi Jehudah frees him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babylonian tradition, the position of R. Jehudah is uncertain; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.7">Tosephta 12:7</a>, readings of Erfurt ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101a" href="/Yevamot.101a">Babli 101a</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan asked: Is not the argument of Rebbi Jehudah inverted? As we have stated there: <sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Chullin 7:3" href="/Mishnah_Chullin.7.3">Mishnah <i>Ḥulin</i> 7:3</a>, speaking of the sinew of the hip which is forbidden as food (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 32:33" href="/Genesis.32.33"><i>Gen</i>. 32:33</a>). He ate from both sides but did not know which piece was from what side. For the majority it makes no difference since the sinews on both sides are forbidden. For R. Jehudah, the singular used in the verse, “the sinew of the hip” implies that only one is forbidden; in the opinion of the Babli this must be the one on the right hand side. The Yerushalmi must hold that R. Jehudah holds that clearly one of the two sinews is forbidden but it is not decided which one it is. R. Jehudah holds that since he certainly ate a piece of the forbidden sinew, he is guilty. Then the question is why should the eater be prosecutable when the prosecution could not show which piece was the forbidden one?</i>“If he ate the volume of an olive of one of them and the volume of an olive of the other, he absorbs eighty [lashes]; Rebbi Jehudah says, he absorbs only forty [lashes].” Rebbi Crispus said, it is not inverted. There, it was in doubt what is forbidden. Here, it was certain<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">If his mother had waited the prescribed three months, there never would have been any problem.</i> but it became doubtful for him. Rebbi Judan asked: If it is so, in case carcass meat was mixed up with slaughtered meat, since it was certain but became doubtful for him, should he be free if he ate it<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Would R. Jehudah hold that a person who ate all of a portion of meat, of which it was known that it contained both kosher and non-kosher meat, could not be held responsible and would not have to bring a purification sacrifice?</i>? Rebbi Yose said, Rebbi Jehudah agrees for all other prohibitions that he is (free)<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">One has to read “guilty”. The text here is an erroneous copy from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.14">Halakhah 1 (Note 61</a>).</i>.
