But here, Rebbi Jehudah is interpreting verses: “His father,” certain but not uncertain, “his mother”, certain but not uncertain<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 9 8" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_9.8"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 9(8</a>), on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:9" href="/Leviticus.20.9"><i>Lev</i>. 20:9</a>.</i>.
“He may serve in the watch of either one”. He should not serve<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Why cannot each watch tell him that he does not belong?</i>. Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥinena in the name of Rebbi Yasa, because of the damage to the family<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">If it were known that a certain Cohen was not accepted for service in the Temple, nobody would marry any daughter of that family</i>.
It was stated: Only if they both belong to the same clan<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last statement in the Mishnah, that the son may receive part of the sacrifices if both putative fathers belonged to the same watch. Since each watch was divided into six clans of which one each was serving one day and received all the gifts of that day, he may receive a share only if the fathers belonged to the same clan. Only on the Sabbath they all served together but received no gifts.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101a" href="/Yevamot.101a">Babli, 101a</a>, agrees to this ruling.</i>.

Chapter 12



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The commandment of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is to be executed before three judges; all three may be lay people<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The procedure has to be executed in front of the town elders (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut.</i>25:7</a>); this implies that it must be in a judicial setting. Usually, the word “elders” in the Pentateuch is interpreted as “professional judges”; the admissibility of lay judges has to be justified in the Halakhah.</i>. If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a shoe<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Defined as leather shoe or boot enclosing the entire foot, sown together from several pieces of leather, some of it soft, and kept in place by leather shoelaces.</i>, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid, with a felt slipper<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>impilia, ium</i>, (plur.), “felt shoes”.</i> it is invalid. With a sandal<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Made of a single piece of hard leather covering the sole and some of the sides of the foot, held together with shoe laces fastened tightly over the foot.<br>Greek σάνδαλον, τό. The word might have been imported with the article from farther East.</i> having a heel it is valid, without a heel it is invalid. Below the knee the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">In the Halakhah the reference is to the way the shoelaces are wound around the leg. The straps may be wound around the lower leg but not around the thigh. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 103a" href="/Yevamot.103a">Babli (103a</a>) refers this part of the Mishnah to amputees.</i>, above the knee it is invalid.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The commandment of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is to be executed before three judges,” etc. It is written “elders”, and you say laymen? The commandment is on the elders. From where that even laymen [are acceptable]? The verse says, “stripped of shoe”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:10" href="/Deuteronomy.25.10"><i>Deut.</i> 25:10</a>. It seems that the argument refers to the entire verse, “His house shall be known <i>in Israel</i> as the house of the stripped of shoe.” Any three in Israel may make the fact known. (<i>Sifry Deut.</i> 291 may be interpreted as prohibiting a lay person to preside.) The quote from <i>Deut.</i> is an introduction to the next paragraph.<br>The language “the commandment is on the elders” should imply that levirate not before judges is improper but valid; cf. <i>Midrash Tannaïm</i> 25:8.</i>, in any case.
There are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid. And there are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 291 and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101b" href="/Yevamot.101b">Babli, 101b</a> (an Amoraic <i>baraita</i>), the reference is to a court composed only of converts. There is no proof that this is also the position of the Yerushalmi.</i>. He who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid follows him who says “in Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">There is no record of such a <i>baraita</i> in the parallel texts. In the Babli, those who admit a court composed of converts simply note that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:10" href="/Deuteronomy.25.10"><i>Deut.</i> 25:10</a> may be given another meaning. It is somewhat difficult to accept the validity of a court of converts who themselves are not under the rules of levirate (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:2:1-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.2.1-8">Mishnah 11:2</a>).</i>” to include converts. He who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is invalid follows him who says “in Israel” to exclude converts.
Here, you say, to exclude converts. But there<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:42" href="/Leviticus.23.42"><i>Lev.</i> 23:42</a>. “Every citizen in Israel has to dwell in huts.”</i>, you say, to include converts. There, “the citizen” to exclude converts, “in Israel” to exclude converts; an exclusion after an exclusion<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That an exclusion after an exclusion implies an inclusion is a fundamental principle of R. Akiba’s hermeneutics accepted in both Talmudim; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 6:7:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.6.7.3"><i>Peah</i> Chapter 6, Note 154</a>. For this particular example, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 28b" href="/Sukkah.28b">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 28b</a>; a more complicated argument, taking note of the inclusive “every”, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 17 9" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_17.9"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 17(9</a>).</i> to include converts. But here, “in Israel”, not converts.
There are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the presence of two men is invalid; there are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the presence of two men is valid. Does he who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the presence of two men is invalid, hold that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is invalid, and he who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the presence of two men is valid, hold that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid? Even he who holds that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid will agree that in the presence of two men it is invalid since judgments in civil matters are valid from converts but invalid from two [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">This is the position of the Yerushalmi, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:2-32" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.2-32"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:1</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 3a" href="/Sanhedrin.3a">Babli (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 3a</a>) follows Samuel in accepting judgments from a court of two; but such a court is called “insolent”.</i>.
There are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the night is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:2:1-3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.2.1-3.2">Mishnah 12:2</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:9" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.9">Tosephta (12:9</a>) reports that R. Ismael presided over an emergency <i>ḥalîṣah</i> as sole judge, in the night.</i>; there are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the presence of two men is invalid. Does he who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the night is valid, hold that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid, and he who says, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the night is invalid, hold that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is invalid? Even he who holds that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of converts is valid will agree that in the night it is invalid since judgments in civil matters are valid from converts but invalid in the night<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.5.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 4:6</a> states that civil proceedings have to start during daytime but may be concluded in the night. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.5.2">Yerushalmi (<i>Sanhedrin</i> Halakhah 4:6</a>) holds that this is only a desideratum but that civil suits may be adjudicated any time since it says (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:26" href="/Exodus.18.26"><i>Ex.</i> 18:26</a>) “they have to judge for the people at all times.”</i>.
Some Tannaim state, only if the judges know how to instruct what to say<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:9" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.9">Tosephta 12:9</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101a" href="/Yevamot.101a">Babli, 101a</a>: Only if they know how to instruct as a judge would do. לקרות is short for להקראת.</i>. Some Tannaim stated, even if the judges do not know how to instruct what to say. He who said, only if the judges know how to instruct what to say, before they found a hint in Scripture, but he who said, even if the judges do not know how to instruct what to say, after they found a hint in Scripture<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The hint that only one of the people present has to instruct the participants what to say since their recitation is called “answering”. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 3:4:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.3.4.8"><i>Bikkurim</i>, Chapter 3, Note 83</a>.</i>: “You shall answer and say;” one answers only to a single person. Rebbi Yose said, and only from the mouth of the judge, but one does not follow this.
“If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a shoe, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid.” For whom is this statement needed? For Rebbi Meїr, since Rebbi Meїr said, one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a shoe. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102a" href="/Yevamot.102a">Babli, 102a</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:11" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.11">Tosephta, 12:11</a>, the story is told to exclude shoes from <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>: Rebbi Yose said, it happened that I went to Nsebin<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In Greek sources, Nisibis; the important border town between the Roman and Persian Empires, seat of the rabbinic family Bene Bathyra for many generations.</i> and saw there an old man to whom I said, did you ever know Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra in your lifetime? He told me, Rabbi, I was a banker in my city and he was a constant customer of my bank. I told him, did you ever see him supervising a <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in your lifetime and what he did use for <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> a shoe or a sandal? He said to me, Rabbi, is there a sandal in our place<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">From antique statuary and pictures, it seems that the sandal was the usual Roman footwear and the shoe the Persian. The high boot was the Roman military footwear.</i>? I wondered, how could Rebbi Meïr say that one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a shoe<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">His position would create places where <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is not possible.</i>?
Rebbi Abba, Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102a" href="/Yevamot.102a">Babli, 102a</a>, the opinion of R. Abba is quoted in the name of Rabba (Rav Abba bar Naḥmani), that of R. Ze‘ira in the name of Rav Yosef. The Babli explains that in the opinion of Rabba, one uses a shoe only if one does not have a sandal whereas in the opinion of Rav Yosef one may use a shoe anytime.</i>: If Elijah<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">He was taken in a fiery chariot to be a member of the Heavenly Court and knows all rules how they should be by Heavenly standards.</i> came and said that one performs <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with a shoe, one would listen to him; that one does not perform <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with a sandal, one would not listen to him since most people use a sandal for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and usage supersedes practice. Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rebbi” given in the ms. cannot be correct since R. Jeremiah was the foremost student of R. Ze‘ira. The reference is to Rav Jeremiah (bar Abba), the colleague of Rav.</i> Jeremiah, in the name of Rav: If Elijah came and said that one does not perform <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with a shoe, one would listen to him; that one does not perform <i>ḥaliṣah</i> with a sandal, one would not listen to him since most people use a sandal for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and usage supersedes practice.
Rebbi Ze‘ira showed the bending<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of this paragraph is in doubt. It may either mean that the sandal used for <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is not a flat piece of leather but must be bent upwards to enclose heel, toes, and part of the sides of the foot [since the sandal must be “slipped <i>off</i> the foot” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>) which cannot be done if the sandal is just a flat piece of leather] or whether he bent to show how <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is executed.</i> to Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Most commentators emend to “Rebbi Abba bar Isaac” on base of the next paragraph.</i>. He said to him: Does one do this? He said to him, one does. He said to him, did not our teacher<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Probably R. Joḥanan.</i> bend?
Rebbi Ze‘ira showed Rebbi Abba bar Isaac how it is done. He binds [the shoelaces] that he can walk unaided. How is it done? Rebbi Ḥanania the son of Rebbi Hillel said, he laces it so that she will be able to untie it with one hand. How is it done? She unties with her right hand, grabs [the shoe] with her left hand, slips it off the heel and drags it away with her right hand, so that the slipping off and the unbinding should be done by the right hand<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli has no parallel to this paragraph. In <i><a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 24b" href="/Gittin.24b">Giṭṭin 24b</a></i>, it quotes R. Eleazar to the effect that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> not done by the right hand (or in the night) forbids the widow to the levir but must be repeated to free the widow for outside marriage.</i>.
Rav said, the essence of <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">As the paragraph shows, this needs a semantic clarification since up to now, the word <i>ḥalîṣah</i> designated the entire ceremony by which the widow is freed to marry outside the family. But here, the word designates the action by which the sister-in-law slips the levir’s shoe off his foot, which must be followed by her spitting in front of the levir (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>). Rav insists that the widow’s action is invalid if it does not start with untying the shoelaces.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102a" href="/Yevamot.102a">Babli, 102a</a>, Rav insists that the deciding act is slipping the shoe off the levir’s heel.</i> is the untying of the shoelace. Did not Rebbi Abba say in the name of Rav Jehudah, Rebbi Zeriqan turns to it in the name of Rav: The words of the Sages: If she slips off but did not spit, or spat but did not take off, nothing was done unless she slips off and spits<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:3:1-4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.3.1-4.2">Mishnah 3</a>.</i>. Even though Rav said “unless she slips off and spits” he agrees that the essence of slipping off is untying the shoelaces.
Rav said, the main point in acquiring squatters’ rights is the bringing in of the yield. Did not Rav say, only if one saw him hoeing and weeding? Even though Rav said, only if one saw him hoeing and weeding, Rav agrees that the main point in acquiring squatters’ rights is the bringing in of the yield.
Rebbi Yannai said, if he took off [his shoe] and she put it on again, or she took it off but he had untied, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid and if he wants to go back, he may not go back on it<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear what “going back” means. It may mean that if the levir changes his mind after the invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and wants to marry the widow that he is barred from doing so; or it may mean that the entire ceremony has to be cancelled and everything started anew. The next paragraphs seem to indicate that the first interpretation is the correct one.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102" href="/Yevamot.102">Babli, 102</a> a, the statement of R. Yannai is quoted without the last clause and the extent of the damage by invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is not discussed.</i>. Why? Is it since the two actions are not there together or because they are not in the right order? What is the difference? If she afterwards untied [the shoestrings]. If you say, because the two actions are not there together? They are there together! The reason therefore must be that they are not in the right order.
Rebbi Eleazar said, in some cases<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 24b" href="/Gittin.24b">Babli, <i>Giṭṭin</i> 24b</a>, states that in the cases discussed here, the valid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> implies the prohibition of the widow to the levir and the invalid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is a nonexisting <i>ḥalîṣah</i> which does not preclude the possibility of levirate marriage.</i> they said that her <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid and if he wants to go back he may go back. And in some cases they said that her <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid and if he wants to go back he may not go back. [If a woman] performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with felt slippers or for an underage boy, her <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid and if he wants to go back he cannot go back. If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a slipper, some Tannaim state that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid and some Tannaim state that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid. He who says that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid, with a leather slipper; he who says that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid, with a textile slipper<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102b" href="/Yevamot.102b">Babli 102b</a>, a statement of Rava (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.3">Chapter 1, Note 21</a>).</i>. A shoe in a slipper<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This case does not appear in the Babli.</i>, some Tannaim state that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid and some Tannaim state that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid. For him who holds that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid, the slipper is textile but the shoe leather<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The leather shoe with which the levir stands on the ground is removed from his heel.</i>. For him who holds that the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid, the slipper is leather but the shoe textile. Some Tannaim state that one may wear a slipper of the Day of Atonement<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102b" href="/Yevamot.102b">Babli 102b</a>, Yerushalmi <i>Yoma</i> 8:1 (fol. 44d), <i>Ta‘aniot</i> 1:6 (fol. 64c). It is held that wearing a textile slipper outside the house does not protect the foot from feeling the stones on the road and therefore does not violate the sanctity of the Day of Atonement as a day of deprivation.</i> and some Tannaim state that one may not wear a slipper. Rav Ḥisda said, For him who holds that one leaves the house [wearing a slipper,] a textile slipper, he who says that one may not leave the house [wearing a slipper,] a leather slipper.
“With a sandal having a heel it is valid.” There, they say, for example those קנסרוס<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">A kind of sandal. There is no convincing identification of this word either in Persian or in a Western language. The best so far is I. Löw’s Greek κόθορνος, Latin <i>cothurnus</i>, “hunting boot laced up in front; high Grecian boot, high shoe worn by actors” for which the first meaning is appropriate here. (Löw credits an author A. Löwinger; I have been unable to find a first reference.) D. Sperber (Sinai 82, 1977/78, p. 168) refers to Latin <i>cursorius</i> “belonging to running”.</i>. But the rabbis here say, like ours<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The common Roman sandals.</i>. Rav said, if I had not seen my uncle, the elder Rebbi Ḥiyya, performing<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., supervising.</i> a <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a sandal with plaited straps<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 102a" href="/Yevamot.102a">Babli, 102a</a>, סנדל דאית ליה שינצין. The word שורציפא is Semitic, from Syriac רצפא “sandal (to walk on a stone floor)”.</i>, I would not feel competent to do so. The maternal uncle of Rav Cahana performed<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., supervising.</i> <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the night, as single judge, on Friday night, with a cork sandal, and standing; (Rabbi Zeriqa said) and she did not spit. Rav heard that and said, who would ever do that<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Every single step being questionable. Since Rav Cahana I was a contemporary of Rav, his uncle belonged to the pre-Amoraic Babylonian scholars. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104a" href="/Yevamot.104a">Babli, 104a</a>, he is called Rabba bar Ḥiyya from Qaṭosap.</i> except the maternal uncle of Rav Cahana?
So is the Mishnah: “If he ties<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The shoelaces.</i> lower than the knee, it is valid, above the knee it is invalid.” It is written: “Aaron and his sons shall wash their hands and feet from it<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:19" href="/Exodus.30.19"><i>Ex.</i> 30:19</a>.</i>.” It was stated about this: The hand up to the wrist, the foot up to the calf; and here you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The “foot” of the priests refers only to the calf (in another interpretation to the shinbone) but not to the knee, but for the widow it extends up to the knee!</i>? There is a difference, since it is written “from above his foot”. In that case, even higher than the knee should be valid! There is a difference, since it is written “from above his foot”, and not from higher than above his foot<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 103a" href="/Yevamot.103a">Babli agrees, 103a</a>.</i>. Cahana objected: Is it not written, “and the afterbirth which comes out from between her feet<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 28:57" href="/Deuteronomy.28.57"><i>Deut.</i> 28:57</a>. Usually, one translates “between her legs”; then one also should translate that the widow has to remove the levir’s shoe “from his leg” and shoelaces bound above the knee should be permissible. The same question is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 103a" href="/Yevamot.103a">Babli, 103a</a>.</i>;” does it come out from between her feet? It looks as if it was between her feet; as we have stated there: “The water pit was between the Temple hall and the alter drawn towards the South.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Middot 3:6" href="/Mishnah_Middot.3.6">Mishnah <i>Middot</i> 3:6</a>. It was between the Southern edge of the hall and the altar.</i>” Was it put between the hall and the altar? Only it looked as if between hall and altar.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a sandal that was not his<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The levir’s.</i>, with a wooden sandal<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">For the Babli, a wooden (or cork) core covered by leather. The Yerushalmi notes that these restrictions are Babylonian.</i>, or with a left [foot sandal] on the right [foot], the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid. If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with [a sandal that was] too large but he could walk in it, or one too small which covers most of his foot<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The foot sole.</i>, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid. If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in the night, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid; Rebbi Eliezer declares it invalid. [If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i>] with her left hand, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid but Rebbi Eliezer declares it valid.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with a sandal that was not his,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">A partial copy of this paragraph is in <i>Sukkah</i> 3:1. R. Lazar mentioned here is a Tanna.</i> Rebbi Eleazar says, a ram’s horn<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The ram’s horn used on New Year’s Day.</i> belonging to idolatry<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The usufruct of any implements of idolatrous worship is forbidden. The horn is only permitted since Divine Commandments are not for enjoyment or use. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 28a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.28a">Babli, <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 28a</a>, agrees.</i> or to a “seduced city”<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">A city in the Land of Israel that was seduced to embrace idolatry and defected by a communal vote. This city must be burned to the ground (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:13-19" href="/Deuteronomy.13.13-19"><i>Deut</i>. 13:13–19</a>) with all its belongings, of which any usufruct is forbidden; a case that never happened and never will happen (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.1">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 14:1</a>).<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 28a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.28a">Babli, <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 28a</a>, disagrees in this case since a ram’s horn in a “seduced city” must be burned and therefore is considered to be ashes even if not burned. Arguments of this kind are absent in the Yerushalmi.</i> is valid. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated, it is valid. Rebbi Hoshaia stated, it is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, property of an idolatrous temple is undesirable, a dedicated gift to an idolatrous temple is prohibited, as is the shoe from a “seduced city”; 103b/104a.</i>. Everybody agrees that such a palmbranch is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 3:1:1-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.3.1.1-8">Mishnah <i>Sukkah</i> 3:1</a>. The palmbranch stands for the three kinds of branches and the fruit that are taken together on the Festival of Booths (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:40" href="/Leviticus.23.40"><i>Lev</i>. 23:40</a>).</i>. What is the difference between a ram’s horn and a palmbranch? Rebbi Yose said, for a palmbranch it is written: “You shall take for yourselves<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:40" href="/Leviticus.23.40"><i>Lev</i>. 23:40</a>.</i>,” from your own money. But here, “a day of horn blowing it shall be for you<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 29:1" href="/Numbers.29.1"><i>Num</i>. 29:1</a>.</i>,” from any source. Rebbi Eleazar said, there he fulfills his obligation with the article itself, but here with its sound. Is any sound forbidden usufruct<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar the Amora argues that without reference to Scripture it is obvious that palmbranches from idolatrous property are unusable since the essence of the commandment is the acquisition of the branches.</i>? Everybody agrees that a sandal from a “seduced city” is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the uncontested rule is promulgated that a shoe from a “seduced city” is invalid; 104a. In the opinion of the Yerushalmi, a shoe may be worn as long as it exists; for the Babli the shoe is legally nonexistent as soon as it has been condemned to be burned, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.2.2">Note 53</a>.</i>. For it is written “stripped of shoe,” from any source. Rebbi Mana said, as you say there, “a day of horn blowing it shall be for you,” from any source, so you say here, “stripped of shoe,” from any source.
“A wooden sandal.” The colleagues in the name of Rav: If only the edges<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Explanation of the Gaonic commentary to <i>Tahorot</i>, Mishnah <i>Miqwa’ot</i> 10:3, ed. Epstein: Arabic عرى “border, rim, brim”.</i> are wooden<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">But the remainder of the sandal must be leather.</i>. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav: If only the bottom of the sole is wooden. There, they say in the name of Rav: If only the loops<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Explanation of <i>Arukh</i>; Arabic שראך “loop, net”.</i> are wooden. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Even if it is entirely of wood it is valid. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan: “<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kelim Batra 4:2" href="/Tosefta_Kelim_Batra.4.2">Tosephta <i>Kelim Baba Batra</i> 4:5</a>. There, the addition “about impurity by stepping on it” is missing. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 66a" href="/Shabbat.66a">Babli, Sabbat 66a</a>, “a sandal of whitewashers” (who cannot wear leather sandals which would be destroyed by the whitewash).</i> A straw sandal becomes impure by being stepped on<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The impurity of the person with gonorrhea is transferred on anything he puts his weight on even if he does not touch it (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:5" href="/Leviticus.15.5"><i>Lev</i>. 15:5</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:6" href="/Leviticus.15.6">6</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:26" href="/Leviticus.15.26">26</a>) and even if same material impervious to impurity separates the person from the object. This is called “impurity by being stepped on.” Wooden implements that do not enclose any volume (“flat wooden vessels”) cannot accept impurity. R. Aqiba does not agree that flat straw sandals are flat wooden vessels.</i> and a woman may use it for <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, the words of Rebbi Aqiba, but the Sages do not agree about impurity by being stepped on<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This version implies that the Sages agree that a flat straw sandal may be used for <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. The Tosephta, which omits the last clause, follows the Babylonian tradition that a purely wooden sandal is inadmissible.</i>.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph and the next are from <i>Sabbath</i> 4:2. The paragraph is quoted here because it starts with a quote of the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> quoted in the preceding paragraph.</i>“<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Kelim Batra 4:2" href="/Tosefta_Kelim_Batra.4.2">Tosephta <i>Kelim Baba Batra</i> 4:5</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 112a" href="/Shabbat.112a">Babli <i>Sabbath</i> 112a</a>.</i> A sandal whose holes, edges, or loops are torn or one of whose soles fell off is pure. If one of its holes, edges, or loops is torn or most of it soles fell of it is impure. Rebbi Jehudah says, on the inside it is impure, on the outside it is pure.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Ritual impurity is restricted to Jewish persons, food, vessels and tools, and a leprous house. If a vessel or tool was damaged beyond repair, it becomes ritually pure. In this connection, “impure” means “a possible candidate for impurity” and “pure” “unable to become impure.” Rebbi Jehudah holds that people will repair even serious damage to their shoes if it can be done so as not to be noticed in public. The rabbis hold that even in such cases, people will not repair severely damaged shoes.<br>R. Jehudah holds that a person will repair sandals when the repair is not immediately visible from the outside. Therefore, if a strap or hole for the shoelaces is torn at the instep, towards the other foot, the shoe remains usable. The majority holds that one torn strap or a partially torn sole can always be repaired.</i>” Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Tevele, Ḥanin bar Abba in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Jehuda as far as the Sabbath is concerned<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 112b" href="/Shabbat.112b">Babli, <i>Sabbath</i> 112b</a>.</i>. A case came before Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac. He sent Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa to ask Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. He<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, following his teacher R. Joḥanan (in a first version in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 112b" href="/Shabbat.112b">Babli, <i>Sabbath</i> 112b</a>). The Babli holds that this tradition of R. Joḥanan is not trustworthy. It is possible that the Yerushalmi agrees since R. Joḥanan is not mentioned here, but only his students and later Amoraim.</i> said to him, just as they disagree about impurity so they disagree about the Sabbath, and instructed him following the rabbis. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac asked himself: One heard saying, practice follows Rebbi Jehuda, and he instructed him following the rabbis? A case came before Rebbi Aḥa bar Isaac. He sent to ask Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Ze‘ira asked Rebbi Immi. The latter said to him: Following the words of him who declares impure, it is permitted to go out on it on the Sabbath. Following the words of him who declares pure, it is forbidden to go out on it on the Sabbath. He did not get anything out of him<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">He refused to decide between Rav and the Galilean rabbis. Note that all persons mentioned here are Babylonians; those with the title “Rebbi” are immigrants to Galilee.</i>.
It was stated: But he may walk on it until he reaches the entrance of his courtyard<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph deals only with the rules of the Sabbath. Even if a sandal is torn and no longer is a piece of clothing that may be moved on the Sabbath, one may walk on it until one reaches one’s courtyard where it can be left and picked up after the Sabbath.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa and Rebbi Ze‘ira were walking on the highway. The sandal of Rebbi Aḥa was torn. When they came to the city gate, Rebbi Ze‘ira told him, that is the entrance of your courtyard<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">As a rabbi, you must be more strict than people in general.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa wound a fiber around. Rebbi Abbahu wound a bundle of Jew’s mallow<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Reading with I. Löw מלכניקי, Arabic ملو خيا “corchorus olitorius”, a kitchen vegetable, relative of jute. He derives the name from Greek μολόχη “mallow”. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 112a" href="/Shabbat.112a">Babli, <i>Sabbath</i> 112a</a>, R. Abbahu told R. Jeremiah to use textile fiber to lightly bind around a torn sandal.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu was of the opinion that a bundle of Jew’s mallow is ready to be used<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">As raw textile fiber, its use on the Sabbath would be forbidden. But as kitchen herb it is food and permitted to be used on the Sabbath.</i>. Rebbi Jonah threw them away before the fried food store<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The passage is difficult to understand; in the parallel in <i>Sabbath</i> the word לחנותא “in the store” is missing.Since the store is supposed to be closed on the Sabbath, it just indicates that R. Jonah took off his sandals far from his home when a shoelace broke on the Sabbath.<br>For the translation of חליטר cf. <i>Shevi‘it</i> <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.4.1">Chapter 7, Note 84</a>. It is not necessary to translate טלק “to throw away” (documented from the Targumim), most of the meanings of Arabic طلق will be acceptable, such as “to take off, let go, loosen”.</i>. That is little honor. The honor of Rebbi Eleazar obliged him to take it off<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Immediately when a shoelace broke.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Ze‘ira: May one switch<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">May one switch left and right sandal on the Sabbath if an outside ear was broken to hide the defect from sight?</i>? He said to him, it is permitted. Nevertheless, he told him: go and look for an Elder and rely on him. He went out and found Rebbi Abba bar Mamal, asked him, and he permitted. Rebbi Yose said, the Mishnah said that this is clothing, since we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah proves that sandal switching is practiced also on weekdays; therefore, it is permitted on the Sabbath since the switched sandals are legitimate pieces of clothing.</i>: “Or with a left [foot sandal] on the right [foot], the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid.” That means, in width. But in length it must cover most of the foot<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">This has nothing to do with the prior discussion; it shows what is meant in the Mishnah which states that sandals with torn soles are acceptable. The sentence also is copied in <i>Sabbath</i>, implying that sandals with partially torn soles may also be worn on the Sabbath.</i>.
What is the reason of Rebbi Eliezer? “Before the Elders’ eyes<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a>: “The sister-in-law shall approach him before the elder’s eyes”. R. Eliezer holds that one sees clearly only during daytime. This argument is not found in any of the parallel sources.</i>.” How do the rabbis uphold “before the Elders’ eyes”? That excludes a court of blind people. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the argument of Rebbi Eliezer seems to be inverted<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104a" href="/Yevamot.104a">Babli, 104a</a>.</i>. There<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The purification of a leper requires that blood and oil be put on the right hand thumb and the right big toe of the healed person, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:14" href="/Leviticus.14.14"><i>Lev</i>. 14:14</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:17" href="/Leviticus.14.17">17</a>. In Mishnah <i>Nega‘im</i> 14:9, R. Eliezer and R. Simeon disagree about the purification of a person missing his right hand thumb or right big toe; R. Eliezer insists that the right hand must be used in all cases.</i>, he says that the right hand is obligatory, but here, he says that the right hand is not obligatory. Rebbi Yose said, there it is written “the right hand”<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:14" href="/Leviticus.14.14"><i>Lev</i>. 14:14</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:17" href="/Leviticus.14.17">17</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104a" href="/Yevamot.104a">Babli, 104a</a>, this is the argument of the rabbis. In the Babli, R. Eliezer is defended by the argument that the leper has so many additional ceremonies that it is difficult to transfer any of his ceremonies to other cases.</i>, the right hand is obl;igatory, but here, where “the right hand” is not written, the right hand is notobligatory. Rebbi Yose from Sidon stated before Rebbi Jeremiah: “His ear”, “his ear”. Since “his ear” mentioned there refers to the right ear, so “his ear” mentioned here means the right ear<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">This compares the ceremony of the leper with that of piercing the ear of the Hebrew slave who refuses to regain his freedom, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:6" href="/Exodus.21.6"><i>Ex</i>. 21:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 15:17" href="/Deuteronomy.15.17"><i>Deut</i>. 15:17</a>. In the latter verses it is not spelled out which ear has to be pierced. The argument that the ear must be the right one is quoted anonymously also in Yerushalmi <i>Qiddušin</i> Chapter 1, fol. 59d, <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Mišpaṭim</i> 2, <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon bar Ioḥai Mišpaṭim</i> p.163, <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 122; in the name of R. Eliezer here and in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104a" href="/Yevamot.104a">Babli 104a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 15a" href="/Kiddushin.15a"><i>Qiddušin</i> 15a</a>.</i>. It also says “his foot”, “his foot”. He who infers from “his ear”, “his ear” infers from “his foot”, “his foot”; he who does not infer from “his ear”, “his ear” does not infer from “his foot”, “his foot”. But it was stated in the name of Rebbi Eliezer: “his foot”, “his foot”. That means, there are two statements about the words of Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah, R. Eliezer accepts the use of the left foot after the fact; in the <i>baraita</i> he declares use of the left foot as invalid.</i>. He who argues from “his ear”, “his ear” argues from “his foot”, “his foot”; he who does not argue from “his ear”, “his ear” does not argue from “his foot”. And this Mishnah accepts neither “his ear”, “his ear” nor “his foot”, “his foot”<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">That is, for R. Eliezer; but in the opinion of the Babli, the majority base their opinion on the comparison “foot, foot”.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she stripped off and spat but did not recite, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">All three actions by the widow, first stripping the shoe from the levir’s foot, second to spit out in front of him, third to recite: “So should be done to the man who would not build his brother’s house” are required in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a>.</i>. If she recited and spat but did not strip off, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid. If she stripped off and recited but did not spit, Rebbi Eliezer says, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid, but Rebbi Aqiba says, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid.<br><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah explains the positions of Rebbis Eliezer and Aqiba in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:3:1-4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.3.1-4.2">Mishnah 3</a>.</i> Rebbi Eliezer said, “so it shall be done<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a>: “So should be done to the man who would not build his brother’s house”. This is the required recitation by the widow. It is taken out of context for emphasis, <i>so</i> and not otherwise. This is meant to imply that no <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid if it is not executed exactly as written.</i>”, anything which is an action is preventing<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Preventing the validity of the procedure.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba said to him, is that a proof? “So it shall be done to the man”, any activity of the male [is preventing.]
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she stripped off and spat,” etc. Samuel said, if she stripped but did not spit, she shall spit<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The missing action can be performed belatedly; the original ceremony was not legally nonexistent.</i>. This follows Rebbi Eliezer. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If she stripped but did not recite nor spit, her <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid. Still that is Rebbi Eliezer’s. The words of the Sages? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Jehudah, Zeriqan turned to it in the name of Rav: If she stripped but did not spit, or spat but did not strip, she did not do anything<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">It is legally nonexistent and cannot be fixed belatedly.</i> until she strips and spits. Rebbi Abba asked before Rebbi Immi: If she spat before she stripped? He said, it is as if in the correct order<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Anything written in the verse has to be performed but the order in which it is written is not necessarily the order in which the ceremonies have to be performed. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105a" href="/Yevamot.105a">Babli, 105a</a>, this is a <i>baraita</i>.</i>. If he made a betrothal with a cluster of end-of- harvest [figs]? He said to him, with the figs hanging there he made the betrothal<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">R. Abba continued to address unrelated questions to R. Immi. The question here is not clear, the translation follows the interpretation of <i>Qorban Ha‘edah</i>. If somebody gave a woman a branch full of figs as betrothal gift (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.15">Chapter 1, Note 63</a>), how is the value computed? The betrothal is only valid if the value is at least a <i>peruṭah</i>, <sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup>/<sub>64</sub> of a silver denar. R. Immi specifies that only the figs are counted for the value, not the wood.</i>. May one open an Egyptian window<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Defined in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 3:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.3.8.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Batra</i> 3:8</a> as a hole smaller than a man’s head.</i> into a common backyard higher than four cubits<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">In general, people can object if a neighbor makes a new window that lets him see their activities that earlier he could not observe. This is called “damage by looking”, היזק ראייה; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 2:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.2.4.2"><i>Baba Batra</i> 2:4</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 2b" href="/Bava_Batra.2b">Babli <i>Baba Batra</i> 2b</a>. But a window higher than 4 cubits (about 2.2 m) is for air, not for looking.</i>? He said to him, so we are saying: He comes simply for the air. Rebbi Nasa said, that is what he said: If somebody wants to build his house in the form of a dovecot<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Where all openings are very high.</i>, does one not listen to him?

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid if performed for a deaf-mute man<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Since the deaf-mute (who does not understand sign language) cannot perform any legal act, the passive voice is required here.</i>, or by a deaf-mute woman, or for an underage male<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In v. 9 the male is called “man”, which means “adult”.</i>. The underage woman who performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> should repeat <i>ḥalîṣah</i> once she becomes of age but if she did not repeat it, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mishnah in the Babli: “invalid”. That version is explained in the Halakhah as representing the opinion of R. Meїr.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Eliezer said, “so shall be done to the man,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if they cannot fulfill “he shall say, and she shall say”<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">This does not refer to the discussion of the Mishnah but to the text quoted as required recitation by the widow. (The levir has to say “I do not like to take her”, v. 8). The statement that the verse excludes a person unable to speak from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is attributed to R. Yannai, R. Joḥanan’s teacher, in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104b" href="/Yevamot.104b">Babli (104b</a>).</i>. Does the recitation prevent [validity]? Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, for anybody able to recite, the recitation does not prevent [validity] but for anybody unable to recite, the requirement of recitation does prevent<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 104b" href="/Yevamot.104b">Babli (104b</a>, <i>Nedarim</i> 93a, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 25a" href="/Kiddushin.25a"><i>Qiddušin</i> 25a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 81b" href="/Bava_Batra.81b"><i>Baba Batra</i> 81b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 18b" href="/Makkot.18b"><i>Makkot</i> 18b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 83b" href="/Chullin.83b"><i>Ḥulin</i> 83b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 18b" href="/Menachot.18b"><i>Menaḥot</i> 18b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 103b" href="/Menachot.103b">103b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 66b" href="/Niddah.66b"><i>Niddah</i> 66b</a>) the rule is attributed to R. Ze‘ira: In general, the omission of a required action does not prevent the validity of the ceremony if it would have been possible to perform it as required; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.5"><i>Bikkurim</i> 1:6, Note 114</a>. This is the source of the next Mishnah.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 1:1:21" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.1.1.21"><i>Terumot</i> 1:2, Notes 94–102</a>.</i> There, we have stated: “Everybody is obligated for appearance except the deaf-mute, the insane, and the minor.” The colleagues in the name of Rebbi Eleazar (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 31:12" href="/Deuteronomy.31.12"><i>Deut</i>. 31:12</a>): “So they should hear and learn.” So far one who speaks but cannot hear; what about one who hears but cannot speak? Rebbi La in the name of Rebbi Eleazar (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 31:12" href="/Deuteronomy.31.12"><i>Deut</i>. 31:12</a>): “So they should learn,” so they should teach. Rebbi Jonah said, this means that the principles of Rebbi are no principles, since we have stated: “A <i>ḥereš</i> who speaks but cannot hear should not give heave,” and we thought that one who speaks but does not hear is <i>ḥereš</i>, one who hears but does not speak is<i>ḥereš</i>. But we have stated: “<i>Ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid if performed for a <i>ḥereš</i> man, or by a <i>ḥereš</i> woman, or for an underage male.” And Rebbi Joḥanan said, because they cannot say (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:8" href="/Deuteronomy.25.8"><i>Deut</i>. 25:8</a>): “he shall say”, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut</i>. 25:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9">9</a>) “she shall say.” We also have stated: “A <i>ḥereš</i> mentioned anywhere by the Sages is a deaf-mute.” This supports Rebbi Jonah, for Rebbi Jonah said that the principles of Rebbi are no principles.
Rebbi Ismael ben Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105b" href="/Yevamot.105b">Babli, 105b</a>, he is reported to say that the Yerushalmi version of the Mishnah is his father’s.</i> asked before Rebbi: What is the difference between underage males and females? He said to him, “a man<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a>. This argument is attributed to “the Rabbis” in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105b" href="/Yevamot.105b">Babli, 105b</a>.</i>” is written in the paragraph. But about her, “his sister-in-law shall come before him,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105b" href="/Yevamot.105b">Babli, 105b</a>, he is reported to say that the Yerushalmi version of the Mishnah is his father’s.</i>” in any case.
Rebbi Mana said it without attribution, Rebbi Isaac the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya came to it in the name of Rebbi Jonah: It is<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah which requires that the underage girl repeat the procedure once she grows up.</i> Rebbi Meїr’s who said that one does not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate with an underage girl because she might turn out to be a she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.25">Chapter 1, Note 65</a>. R. Meїr is reputed to take note of cases which occur only very infrequently. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:12" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.12">Tosephta, 12:12</a>, this is quoted as the opinion of R. Eliezer.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of two [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Which is invalid in the opinion of some authorities, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:1:2-17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.1.2-17">Halakhah 1</a>.</i> or of three when it turned out that one was a relative or unfit<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">According to everybody, a court of law is incompetent if it turns out that one of the judges is a relative of one of the parties or of another judge, or if he had been declared unfit to be a judge.</i>, the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is invalid; Rebbi Simeon and Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian declare it valid. If happened that she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> between herself and him in jail; the case came before Rebbi Aqiba and he declared it valid<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Since this is a report of an actual case, it represents practice (at least in cases of emergency).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> in front of two,” etc. The case happened in a jail and was resolved in a jail<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Reported by Amoraim in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105b" href="/Yevamot.105b">Babli, 105b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan the Alexandrian dressed up as a pedlar. One day, he passed in front of the place of confinement of Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">In the aftermath of the war of Bar Kokhba, when the teaching of Jewish law in Palestine was a capital crime. Therefore, the questions had to be couched in such terms that an Aramaic speaking Gentile would not understand question or answer.</i>, he cried aloud and said, “who needs needles, who needs hooks, what is if she performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> between herself and him?” Rebbi Aqiba pushed himself tightly to the hole and said: “Do you have spindles? You have valid!”

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The commandment of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>: He and his sister-in-law come to the court of law and they give him appropriate counsel, as it is said: “The Elders of his city shall call him and speak to him<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:8" href="/Deuteronomy.25.8"><i>Deut.</i> 25:8</a>.</i>”. She says: “My levir refuses to erect a name in Israel for his brother, my levir does not want;<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut.</i> 25:7</a>.</i>” and he says: “I do not desire to take her<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:8" href="/Deuteronomy.25.8"><i>Deut.</i> 25:8</a>.</i>.” They have to speak in the holy language<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The entire ceremony must be conducted in Hebrew. Since it is to be assumed that the parties do not know Hebrew, the text has to be read to them by the judges, for them to repeat.</i>. “His sister-in-law comes to him before the Elders’ eyes, strips his shoe from his foot, and spits out before him<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>.</i>,” spittle that is visible to the judges. She has to declare and say: “So should be done to a man who would not build his brother’s house.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>.</i>” Up to this sentence they were reading to them but when it was read for Rebbi Hyrkanos<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: When R. Hyrkanos was reading it under the oak tree at <i>Kefar ‘Etam.</i> In other places, the name appears as כפר עיכוס. The place is unidentified.</i> under the oak tree in Kefar Abus he finished the paragraph; they established to finish the entire paragraph, “his house shall be called in Israel the house of the one stripped of shoe<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:10" href="/Deuteronomy.25.10"><i>Deut.</i> 25:10</a>.</i>.” The obligation is on the judges, not on the students<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The law students who regularly attended court sessions. The judges themselves have to recite “house of the stripped of shoe”.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah said, everyone present has the obligation to say,” the one stripped of shoe, the one stripped of shoe<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the clause is repeated three times.</i>”.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The commandment of <i>ḥalîṣah</i>: He and his sister-in-law come,” etc. “They give him appropriate counsel”. What means, “they give him appropriate counsel”? If he is old, they tell her, what do you do with an old man like him? If she is old, they tell him, what do you do with that old woman? If she is a girl and he is an old man, they say to him, she is a girl and will bring you shame. If he is a boy and she an old woman, they say to her, he is a boy and will bring you shame. If he wants but she does not, one listens to her. If she wants but he does not, one listens to him. The principle: One listens to the one who wants to prevent. If both of them want, such a case came before Rebbi Yose and he said, throw her out<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The practice of his court was never to accept levirate. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 101a" href="/Yevamot.101a">Babli, 101a</a>, supports levirate for partners that are of similar age. The formulation of the Babli is also that of <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 290.</i>.
Rebbi Joḥanan asked, in the case of a sister in law, who runs after whom<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">If levir and widow live at different places, which court is empowered to deal with the matter?</i>? Rebbi Eleazar answered: “His sister-in-law shall come to the gate<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse requires the widow to take the initiative, the appropriate court is the one at the levir’s residence. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 31b" href="/Sanhedrin.31b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 31b</a>, this ia a statement of R. Joḥanan; it is a tannaïtic statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:8" href="/Deuteronomy.25.8"><i>Midrash Tannaïm</i> on <i>Deut.</i> 25:8</a>.</i>.” When Rebbi Joḥanan heard this, he said, Rebbi Eleazar taught us correctly.
Does the recitation prevent [validity]? Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, for anybody able to recite, the recitation does not prevent [validity] but for anybody unable to recite, the recitation does prevent<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.4.2">Halakhah 4, Note 100</a>.</i>. Rebbi Mana said, even though Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, the recitation does not prevent [validity], he agrees that if one recites, he recites in due order; in particular that it should not be said: “My levir refuses to erect, my levir does not want;” “I do not desire to take her”, but “my levir refuses to erect a name in Israel for his brother, my levir does not want;” “I do not desire to take her.”
There<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 39b" href="/Yevamot.39b">Babli, 39b</a>, the text of the <i>ḥalîṣah</i> document given to the widow is ascribed to Rav Jehudah. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:15" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.15">Tosephta, 12:15</a>, it is quoted as “old text”.</i>, they say: “She came before us, stripped his shoe from his right foot, spat before us spittle that was visible on the ground, and said: ‘So should be done to a man who would not build his brother’s house.’ ” Rebbi Abbahu said, since the spittle was visible when it left her mouth it is valid, even if the wind dissipated it<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">He disapproves of the formulation that the spittle has to be seen on the ground.</i>. If she spat blood? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Jehudah, Rebbi Zeriqan turned to it, Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Abba bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">He probably is Samuel’s father.</i>, Rebbi Ze‘ira turned to it in the name of Samuel: If it contains some liquid spittle, it is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105a" href="/Yevamot.105a">Babli, 105a</a>, no spittle is required since the verse simply says “she shall spit”, not “she shall spit spittle”.</i>. How does the handless [woman] perform ḥalîṣah? With her teeth<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Agreed to in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105a" href="/Yevamot.105a">Babli, 105a</a>, since the verse requires only that the shoe be stripped off but does not prescribe the way it should be done.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">A short version of this is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 105a" href="/Yevamot.105a">Babli, 105a</a>. There, Levi actually did not know how to respond. The Yerushalmi version is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 81:2" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.81.2"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 81(2</a>).</i> The people of Simonia came to Rebbi and told him, please give us a man who preaches, judges, runs the synagogue, teaches reading, teaches Mishnah, and looks after all our needs. He gave them Levi bar Sisi. They made him a big platform<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Greek βῆμα “speaker’s platform”.</i> and sat him on it. They came and asked him, how does the handless [woman] perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? He did not respond. If she spat blood” He did not respond. They said, maybe he is not competent in studies, let us ask him in homiletics. They came and asked him, what is that which is written: “Truly, I shall tell you what is traced in writing, it is true.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 10:21" href="/Daniel.10.21"><i>Dan.</i> 10:21</a>.</i>” If it is true, why is it traced, and if traced, why is it true? He did not respond. They came to Rebbi and told him, that required one we asked you for? He told them, by your lives, I gave you one who is my equal! He sent to bring him and examined him. He asked him, what if she spat blood. He said, if it contains some fluid of spittle it is valid. How does the handless [woman] perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? He said, with her teeth. What is that which is written: “Truly, I shall tell you what is traced in writing, it is true.” If it is true, why is it traced, and if traced, why is it true? He said, until the decision of the court is sealed, it is traced. After it has been sealed, it is true. He asked him, and why did you not give any answers? He said to him, they made me a big platform and sat me on it; by that my spirit became bloated<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">He forgot all he knew.</i>. He quoted about him: “If you became subject to contempt when you rose, if you planned, hand to mouth<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 30:32" href="/Proverbs.30.32"><i>Prov.</i> 30:32</a>.</i>”; why did you become contemptible in the words of the Torah? That you used them to aggrandize yourself.
It was stated: A mistaken <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:13" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.13">Tosephta 12:13</a>; quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 106a" href="/Yevamot.106a">Babli 106a</a> together with the disagreement of R. Simeon ben Laqish and R. Joḥanan.</i>. What is a mistaken <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, a case where one told him, perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and she will be permitted to you after some time. Rebbi Joḥanan said, yesterday I was sitting and learning that “if he has the intention but not she, or she has the intention but not he, <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is always invalid unless both of them have the intention!<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 12:13" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).12.13">Tosephta 12:13</a>; it is required that both parties act with the intention of freeing the woman for marriage outside the family.</i>” What is a mistaken <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for Rebbi Joḥanan? A case where one told him, perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and she will pay you a hundred talents. Rebbi Mana said, if this was stipulated as a condition, she has to pay<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">If it was a formal stipulation, not a vague promise. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 106a" href="/Yevamot.106a">Babli, 106a</a>, disagrees since the levir has the obligation to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if levirate is inappropriate in the eyes of the rabbinate and holding up the woman to extort her money is immoral.</i>. A case came before Rebbi Huna and he followed Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. When he heard that Rebbi Joḥanan disagreed, he changed his opinion and forced a second <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> A case came before Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. He told him, my son, this woman does not want to be married in levirate; therefore perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and remove your candidacy from her, then she will marry you in a regular marriage. After the <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, he said to him: Even if Moses and Samuel came, they could not permit her. He referred to himself as “they are wise to do evil; they do not know how to do good<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 4:22" href="/Jeremiah.4.22"><i>Jer.</i> 4:22</a>.</i>.”
There are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is shameful; there are Tannaim who state that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is praiseworthy. Rav Ḥisda said, he who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is shameful follows the early Mishnah, that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is praiseworthy follows the late Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 1:7" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.1.7">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 1:7</a>: “The obligation of levirate has precedence over <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> That was in earlier times, when people had the intent to fulfill the commandment, but now, when people do not have the intent to fulfill the commandment (but to enjoy the marriage) they said, the obligation of <i>ḥalîṣah</i> has precedence over levirate.”</i>. Rebbi Yose said, you might even say, in both cases one follows the early Mishnah, or in both cases one follows the late Mishnah. He who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is shameful, since he damaged one thing in the Torah he shall come and take his damage: “his house shall be called in Israel the house of the one stripped of shoe.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:9</a>.</i>” He who says that <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is praiseworthy, it mentions here “calling” and it is said there: “My name will be called about them<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 48:16" href="/Genesis.48.16"><i>Gen.</i> 48:16</a>. This verse is a blessing.</i>”. Since “calling” there is a praise, so here it is a praise.

Chapter 13



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say, one makes only betrothed girls repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">An underage girl can be married off by her father (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:16" href="/Deuteronomy.22.16"><i>Deut.</i> 22:16</a>). If the father is dead, the girl can be married off by her mother or her brothers under rabbinic rules. Since that marriage is not valid under biblical rules, if the girl dislikes the marriage she can walk out of it by a simple declaration, without formalities (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.1">Chapter 1, Note 118</a>). The House of Shammai restrict this possibility to the betrothed girl. They hold that a consummated marriage can be dissolved only by a bill of divorce, irrespective of how the marriage was contracted.<br>The active formulation, that one makes a girl repudiate, means that under certain circumstances, explained later in the Mishnah, one tells the girl to repudiate.</i>. The House of Hillel say, betrothed or married. The House of Shammai say, the husband, but the House of Hillel say, the husband or the levir<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Shammai and Sadducees restrict levirate to the widowed betrothed girl (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.6.2">Chapter 1, Note 192</a>). They consider candidacy for levirate as binding as marriage.</i>. The House of Shammai say, in his presence, but the House of Hillel say, in his presence or in his absence. The House of Shammai say, in a court of law, but the House of Hillel say, in a court or outside a court. The House of Hillel said to the House of Shammai: An underage girl may repudiate even four or five times<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">A girl married off by her father becomes an adult by the consummation of marriage. But a girl married off by mother or brothers is not married by biblical standards and, therefore, does not become an adult until she reaches her twelfth year.</i>. The House of Shammai said to them: The daughters of Israel are not abandoned property<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">That she can sleep with any man she chooses and then leave him without formality.</i>! But she repudiates, waits until she is of age, or repudiates and is married<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Since the House of Shammai do not permit repudiation by married girls, she may remarry as a minor if betrothal and marriage come together.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The House of Shammai say, one permits repudiation,” etc. There<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 6:1" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.6.1">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 6:1</a>. In most Mishnah sources, the tradent is R. Jehudah ben Baba.</i>, we have stated: “Rebbi Jehudah bar Abba testified to five statements: That one makes underage girls repudiate, … ” Does one disagree with testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Tractate <i>Idiut</i> is a collection of confirmed testimonies an attempt is made to reconstruct a history of early practice. These are recognized as authoritative.</i>? One disagrees about the essence of the testimony. So was the essence of the testimony: “The House of Shammai say, one makes only betrothed girls repudiate, but the House of Hillel say, betrothed or married”. It is difficult following the House of Hillel! Her marriage permitted her<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The husband’s sexual relations with her are meritorious as married sex and not sinful promiscuity.</i>, he has the right to what she finds and earns<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In exchange for the obligations the husband accepted by executing the <i>ketubah</i>, he by rabbinic convention acquires the right to the future earnings of his wife.</i>, to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The biblical prerogative of the husband (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 30:9" href="/Numbers.30.9"><i>Num.</i> 30:9</a>).</i>, and she is his wife in every respect. And you say so? They gave you of your own. By right, her marriage should not be a marriage. They<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The anonymous authors of the institutions of rabbinic Judaism, known as “the men of the great assembly”.</i> said that her marriage is a marriage and they said that she may repudiate him and leave.
What is the reason of the House of Shammai? If you say so, you make all intercourse he had with her intercourse of harlotry<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">An outside event would turn legitimate behavior retroactively into sin. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107a" href="/Yevamot.107a">Babli, 107a</a>, in a first explanation formulates that nobody would marry a fatherless underage girl since he does not want to run the risk involved.</i>. Rebbi Abin said, it turns out that the House of Shammai hold with Rebbi Eleazar as Rebbi Eleazar said, intercourse of an unmarried man with an unmarried woman not with the intent of marriage is intercourse of harlotry<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.5.4">Chapter 6, Note 108</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107a" href="/Yevamot.107a">Babli, 107a</a>, the House of Hillel hold that intercourse in a formal marriage can never be sinful.</i>. That means, for the House of Shammai her repudiation is nothing if she transgressed and repudiated after marriage. If she entered the bridal chamber but had no intercourse yet, what is her status? As betrothed or as married? If she is betrothed in Judea where he is familiar with her<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Where betrothed couples were permitted unchaperoned meetings. It is assumed that they slept together; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.5.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 1:5</a>.</i>, what is her status? As betrothed or as married<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The questions are not answered since practice does not follow the House of Shammai. The Babli holds that in all these cases, the House of Shammai would treat her as married.</i>?
If she had been in a situation that she could not repudiate, may she go and repudiate? Let us hear from the following: An underage girl who was married off by her father<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This is marriage by biblical standards and can be dissolved only by death or a bill of divorce.</i> but then was divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">She does not return to her father’s authority, she is “an orphan during her father’s lifetime”. Nevertheless, she cannot contract as an adult as long as she is underage. This means any marriage she contracts now, even if arranged by her father, is only rabbinic and subject to repudiation before she reaches the age of 12.</i>, if she went and married by herself she nevertheless can repudiate.
What is the reason of the House of Shammai<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Why do the House of Shammai forbid repudiation of the levir and the House of Hillel permit it?</i>? The husband she may repudiate since she married him with her consent. The levir to whom she was given by an act of God she cannot repudiate. What is the reason of the House of Hillel? If she can repudiate the principal, so much more the levir! <sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:10-6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.10-6.3">Chapter 1, Halakhah 2, Notes 121–139</a>, with small variations, mostly in spelling.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, she may repudiate the levir to invalidate the claim of the dead brother and to permit the co-wife to her father and the daughter-in-law to her father-in-law. Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, she may not repudiate the levir to invalidate the claim of the dead brother and to permit the co-wife to her father and the daughter-in- law to her father-in-law. Do Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish follow the house of Shammai, since the House of Shammai say “the husband”? Where do we hold? If she says, I can stand neither the marriage with your brother nor with you, everybody agrees that she invalidates. If she says, I can stand marriage with you but not with your brother? Rav and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, she says I cannot stand marriage with you but marriage with your brother I want. The Mishnah disagrees with Rebbi Joḥanan: “And all of these, if they died, or repudiated, or were divorced, or found to be she-rams, their co-wives are permitted.” Was she not divorced from him?
