Similarly, she repudiated him. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: If they repudiated or were divorced in the husband’s lifetime, their co-wives are permitted. After the husband’s death their co-wives perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate.
Rebbi Yudan, the father of Rebbi Mattaniah said: Explain it when they died and did not repudiate since there is a Mishnah: “If a woman could repudiate but did not do so and died, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but cannot be married in levirate.” Rebbi Eudaimon said, you may even say if she still lives; explain it if there is no levir besides her father.
Rebbi Jonah said, after <i>qiddušin</i>. Rebbi Yose said, even after final marriage. In the second repetition, Rebbi Yose changed his mind. Rebbi Phineas said to him, did the rabbi not teach us “after final marriage”? He answered him, is that fixed in you with a nail?
Rebbi Ze‘ira said before Rebbi Mana, did not Rebbi Yose say correctly before he changed his mind? Once a man’s daughter is married without being a she-ram, her co-wife is forbidden. If in addition she is a she-ram, does her co-wife become permitted? He said to him, the she-ram is as if non-existent. If there are two sisters-in-law, one a she-ram and one not a she-ram, if the levir comes and performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or has intercourse with the first, did he free her companion of anything? That shows that the she- ram is as if non-existent.
“His daughter”. How can his daughter repudiate, is she not married by Torah standards, “my daughter I gave to this man”? Rebbi Huna in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Explain it by a minor, who was married off by her father and divorced, who is like an orphan while her father is alive.
Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Ḥinnena, in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: This means that a minor cannot give birth; because otherwise she could wait until she grew up, repudiate her husband, and permit her co-wife to her son-in-law. The daughter-in-law of Rebbi Ismael repudiated while her son was on her shoulder.
Rav Hamnuna in the name of Assi: The Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The House of Hillel who approve of repudiation of the levir apply this even to the case when there is more than one.</i> speaks about a sister-in-law who has two levirs. If one of them “bespoke” her, she may repudiate his “bespeaking” and marry on the market place<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107b" href="/Yevamot.107b">Babli, 107b</a>, Rav Assi is reported that if she repudiates one of two levirs, she may even be married by the rejected levir himself since the Hose of Hillel will agree that the candidacy (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.5.1">Chapter 2, Note 9</a>) imposed by an act of God cannot be repudiated. What is reported here is in Babli the opinion of Rav, that a repudiation of the levir implies repudiation of the original marriage and elimination of the levirate.</i>. Why can she not repudiate his “bespeaking” and marry his brother? Explain it, if she says, I cannot stand you<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, neither you nor your deceased brother.</i>. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Yosina in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">R. Hila is mentioned in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107b" href="/Yevamot.107b">Babli, 107b</a>, as Ulla who holds that repudiation eliminates candidacy. R. Hoshaia holds there, 107a, that “bespeaking” can be repudiated but not candidacy.</i>: The Mishnah speaks about a sister-in-law who has five levirs<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">There is no difference in law between the case of 2 and that of 5 levirs.</i>. If one of them “bespoke” her, she may repudiate his “bespeaking” and marry his brother<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The same position taken by R. Hoshaia in the Babli.</i>. Why can she not repudiate his “bespeaking” and marry on the market place? Explain it if her father had married her off, this was a marriage by biblical standards<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This contradicts the position ascribed to R. Hoshaia in the Babli; the only candidacy that is not subject to repudiation is one based on the biblical validity of the previous marriage.</i>.
“<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted also in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107b" href="/Yevamot.107b">Babli, 107b</a>.</i> The House of Hillel said to the House of Shammai: It happened with the wife of the cameldriver Pison that the Sages repudiated for her in her absence<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: “That his wife repudiated him in his absence”. In the version of the Yerushalmi, the court acted as the guardian of the orphan.</i>. The House of Shammai said to them, is that a proof? Since he measured crookedly, the Sages measured crookedly for him<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli explained that he was dishonest in administering her property.</i>.” This is difficult. Because a man behaves incorrectly, does one permit his incest prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Since the House of Shammai hold that a married woman cannot repudiate, they seem to lift the prohibition of adultery from Pison’s wife. The Babli does not have this problem since it holds that “everybody who marries, marries under rabbinic rules” and that, therefore, a rabbinic court is empowered to annul a marriage as punishment for a severe infraction of the rules (e. g., <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 90a" href="/Yevamot.90a">Babli 90a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 110a" href="/Yevamot.110a">110a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 33a" href="/Gittin.33a"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 33a</a>). There is no such claim in the Yerushalmi.</i>? Rab Ḥisda said, that means that, if she transgresses and repudiated after marriage, the House of Shammai recognize her act of repudiation<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This disproves the earlier assertion to the contrary.</i>.
Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi: It happened that a girl went to wash at the river when they said to her, your betrothed is passing by. She said, let my mother go and marry him! When the case came before the Sages, they said that there is no repudiation stronger than that. Rebbi Ḥanina said, It happened that a girl went to buy flax from the flax dealer when they said to her, your betrothed is passing by. She said, let my mother go and marry him! When the case came before the Sages, they said that there is no repudiation stronger than that. It was stated in the name of Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.1">Tosephta 13:1</a>; a similar text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 108a" href="/Yevamot.108a">Babli 108a</a>.</i>: “Even if she went to buy something at the store and said, I cannot endure my husband X, there is no repudiation stronger than this.
Does a court convene for repudiation<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the requirement of the House of Shammai that the court be a party to any repudiation.</i>? Was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 93a, in the name of R. Ḥanina. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 109a" href="/Yevamot.109a">Babli, 109a</a>, a statement of Bar Qappara.</i>: Flee from three and cling to three. Cling to <i>ḥalîṣah</i>, annulling vows, and making peace. But flee from repudiations, from being a guarantor, and from receiving deposits. Rebbi Simeon bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Gen. rabba</i>, R. Berekhiah in the name of R. Simeon bar Abba.</i> said, its name is not פקדון “deposit” but פק דון “go to court”. Rebbi Berekhiah said, “My son, if you became guanrantor for your neighbor.” Does a court convene for repudiation? Explain it that they were sitting in another matter and the case came before them<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli applies the negative statement only to frivolous repudiations, not to necessary ones.</i>.
So is the Mishnah: Or she should repudiate him and marry. Therefore, she cannot get herself betrothed. That means, if she transgresses and repudiated after marriage, the House of Shammai recognize her act of repudiation<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion must read the statement of the House of Shammai as: If she repudiates, she may remarry in any case.</i>. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥiyya: A rumor spreads for a married woman but not for a betrothed one. A woman might hide herself and say, I was not betrothed, but she will not be able to hide herself and say, I did not marry<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">R. Abba reads the statement of the House of Shammai not as a requirement but as a counsel given to the husband to publicize the marriage in order to make his claim to her widely known. (While betrothal needs only two witnesses, a standard marriage ceremony needs at least ten invitees. They will make the fact of the marriage widely known.)</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Which underage girl needs to repudiate? Anyone whom mother or brothers married off with her knowledge<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">She has been informed that she is going to live with that man as his wife.</i>. If they married her off without her knowledge<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">If either she was not informed that she was a wife or she was too young to understand the implications, she may walk out without any formality. The minimum age for a girl to be married is three years and one day (Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:4).</i> she does not have to repudiate. Rebbi Ḥanina ben Antigonos says, any girl who is unable to watch over her marriage gift does not have to repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">If she is apt to give her marriage ring away as any other piece of jewelry, she is not married.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer says, in all legal respects, the underage girl is like one seduced<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Since the underage cannot legally enter a contract, her marriage has no legal consequences until she comes of age.</i>: The daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen may not eat heave; the daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel may eat heave.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Which underage girl needs to repudiate,” etc? What means “with her knowledge”? One makes for her a canopy, dresses her in jewelry<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοσμίδια “jewelry”.</i> and leads the man to her.
Do they disagree with Rebbi Ḥananiah ben Antigonos? From what Rebbi Joḥanan said, which is the underage girl that needs a bill of divorce? Anyone who is given her bill of divorce together with something else and she produces it after some time<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since a bill of divorce is needed if the girl is able to take care of that bill (which she needs as proof that she is unmarried and can enter a second marriage) irrespective of her maturity when she was married first, it proves that the majority does not require more than that she was made aware that she was being married and reasonably could understand what that meant.</i>. This implies that they disagree with Rebbi Ḥananiah ben Antigonos.
<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:3" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.3">Tosephta 13:3</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 108a" href="/Yevamot.108a">Babli 108a</a>.</i> Rebbi Eliezer says, the actions of an underage girl have no legal standing. He has no right to what she finds or earns, nor may he dissolve her vows; she is as if not his wife in any respect except that she needs repudiation from him. Rebbi Joshua said, he owns what she finds or earns, he may he dissolve her vows; she is his wife in all respects except that she needs a bill of divorce from him<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">In all parallel sources: “except that she needs repudiation from him.” That reading is required by the next sentence, since otherwise R. Joshua would be more logically consistent than R. Eliezer.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:4" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.4">Tosephta 13:4</a>; in the Babli, this is an Amoraic statement by Samuel.</i> Rebbi Ismael said, I looked around at all logical systems of Sages and did not find anybody who was consistent in the matter of an underage girl except Rebbi Eliezer, only that he requires repudiation from him.
Rebbi Abbahu said: It happened that Rebbi Eliezer’s mother was pushing him to marry his sister’s daughter. He said to [the girl]: go and get married, go and get married, until she said to him: Here I am your slave girl to wash the feet of my master’s servants<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly garbled version of Abigail’s speech, <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:41" href="/I_Samuel.25.41"><i>1S.</i> 25:41</a>.</i>. Even though he married her, he did not sleep with her until she had grown two pubic hairs<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Since for him, sleeping with an underage girl is tantamount to seducing her, even in a marriage.</i>.
According to Rebbi Eliezer, may she repudiate him and collect a fine from him<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Since for R. Eliezer any sex act with a minor girl is a seduction, may she repudiate him and go to court to collect the money due a virgin from her seducer?</i>? According to Rebbi Joshua, may she repudiate him and collect a fine from another man<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Assuming she was still a virgin; if she repudiated the man, may she claim never to have been married and therefore be entitled to all the payments the seducer or the rapist of a virgin has to pay?</i>? May she repudiate this one and invalidate her bill of divorce, a desecrated or a bastard<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">These are different questions taken together. If a Cohen married an underage girl forbidden to him and she repudiated him, does that retroactively free the Cohen from the guilt incurred in the marriage (and its eventual punishment)? Or if she repudiates a second marriage, may she return to the first husband even though for an adult that would be a transgression of a biblical prohibition; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:6:1-7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.6.1-7.4">Mishnaiot 4–6</a>.</i>? Rebbi Isaac asked, may she repudiate and return to her father’s food<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The daughter of a Cohen married to an Israel. This is no problem for R. Eliezer since she never stopped eating Cohen’s food.</i>? It is obvious that she does not return to her husband’s food<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">After he divorced her. The question whether the repudiating wife has any monetary claim on the husband is also asked in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 53b" href="/Ketubot.53b">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 53b</a>, and is left unanswared (In the absence of a legal ruling, the claimant cannot prove his case and cannot collect.)</i> since he writes for her: “You shall live in my house and be fed from my property,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.11.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:12</a>.</i>” and she is not in his house. Therefore, the only question is, may she repudiate and return to her father’s food?
<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 1:1:1-23" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.1.1.1-23"><i>Terumot</i> Chapter 1, Notes 105–135</a>, with minor differences.</i> There, we have stated: Rebbi Jehudah says, the heave given by a minor who has not yet grown two pubic hairs is heave. It was stated in the name of Rebbi Meïr: His heave is never heave unless he grew two pubic hairs. Rebbi Abin, Cahana in the name of the Rebbi Hila (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:32" href="/Numbers.18.32"><i>Num.</i>18:32</a>): “You should not carry guilt because of it.” He who may carry guilt can give heave, he who cannot carry guilt cannot give heave. They objected: But a Gentile cannot incur guilt, and he may give heave! Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Hila (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:27" href="/Numbers.18.27"><i>Num.</i> 18:27</a>): “Your heave will be credited to you”, (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:26" href="/Numbers.18.26">v. 26</a>) “and you shall lift”. Anybody for whom “thought” is written may give heave. But anybody for whom “thought” is not written cannot give heave. They objected: But “thought” is not written for Gentiles, and he may give heave! Rebbi Hoshaia stated: Gentiles have no “thought” whether for preparation or for heave.
Rebbi Aḥa bar Ḥinena in the name of Cahana: Following the opinion that someone who cannot give heave cannot dedicate to the Temple. Why did he not say: following the opinion that he can give heave, can he dedicate to the Temple? Because of Rebbi Jehudah, for Rebbi Jehudah says he can give heave but cannot dedicate. Rebbi Joḥanan says, even following the opinion that he cannot give heave, he can dedicate. What can he dedicate? Holocaust and well-being offerings. He cannot bring a sin sacrifice for fat because he is not obligated to a sin sacrifice for fat. He cannot bring a sin sacrifice for blood because he is not obligated to a sin sacrifice for blood. May he bring a sacrifice relating to gonorrhea and skin disease? Since it is obligatory can’t he bring it, or since he becomes impure by these can he bring it? If it is obvious for you that he brings, can he become an agent for these? Since he may become impure by these, may he become an agent, or since he cannot become an agent for anything else, can’t he become an agent for these? Rebbi Yudan objected: His produce is <i>ṭevel</i> from the Torah but he can<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Terumot</i>: “He cannot”. He can, following R. Jehudah; he cannot, following the majority.</i> free his <i>ṭevel</i> by Torah law! But here, even though he may become impure by them, he cannot become an agent. May he bring First Fruits following Rebbi Jehudah, for Rebbi Jehudah says that First Fruits have the status of territorial consecrated things? He may not bring following the rabbis who say they have the status of things consecrated to the Temple. May he bring a sacrifice of pilgrimage? Since it is obligatory can’t he bring it, or since he may change its name to well-being offering, may he bring it? May he bring a Passover sacrifice? Since it is obligatory can’t he bring it, or since Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia, a person may bring a Passover sacrifice any day of the year when he changes its name to well-being offering, may he bring it? May he bring tithes of cereals<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Terumot</i>: “Of animals”. The text following shows that the <i>Terumot</i> text is correct at this place.</i>? If he holds with Rebbi Meïr, since Rebbi Meïr said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:28" href="/Numbers.18.28"><i>Num.</i>18:28</a>): “From all your tithes,” that all tithes were bracketed together, then since he cannot bring tithes of grain he cannot bring tithes of animals. May he make substitutions? If Rebbi Meïr is of the opinion that all tithes were bracketed together, then since he cannot bring tithes of grain he cannot bring tithes of animals; since he cannot bring tithes of animals he cannot make substitutions. One may hold with Rebbi Simeon, since Rebbi Simeon says that tithes of animals teach you for all sacrifices about substitutions. That means, since he cannot bring tithes of grain he cannot bring tithes of animals; since he cannot bring tithes of animals he cannot make substitutions; since he cannot make substitutions for these he cannot make substitutions for any sacrifices. Is one guilty sacrificing for him outside the Temple? Cahana said, one cannot be guilty sacrificing for him outside the Temple. Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both say, one is guilty sacrificing for him outside the Temple. The statement of Cahana disagrees with Rebbi Jehudah, since Rebbi Jehudah frees his <i>ṭevel</i> as biblical law. And you say so? We can say he [Cahana] is following him who says they accepted tithes voluntarily.
Rebbi Yoḥanan had a difficulty with the words of Rebbi Joshua. Is her marriage valid by biblical standards? The dissolution of her vows must be by biblical standards<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This again proves that in the statement of R. Joshua early in the Halakhah, he must agree that the underage girl may walk out of the marriage by simple repudiation. This means that even according to him, the marriage of a minor is only valid by rabbinic standards. But since the annulment of the wife’s vows by the husband is a biblical law, it is difficult to see how a rabbinic marriage could confer biblical powers on the husband.</i>! And you say so! Rebbi Ze‘ira said, there is no dissolution of vows here, because of what Rebbi Joḥanan had against the words of Rebbi Joshua. Rebbi Nissa asked: Would it be the same for prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">If somebody privatly forbade himself certain things or enjoyments. These “vows and oaths of prohibition to deprive oneself” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 30:14" href="/Numbers.30.14"><i>Num.</i> 30:14</a>) are exactly what the husband may hinder his wife to bind herself to.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said, one does not whip for prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 1:1:2-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.1.1.2-9"><i>Nazir</i> 1:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 1:1:2-3:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.1.1.2-3.7"><i>Nedarim</i> 1:1</a>. Since the prohibition is purely by words, it is a “prohibition not implying an action”, for whose infringement no sacrifice of purification is needed or possible. But then there is no criminal act involved and the court will not get involved. It is well possible that R. Joshua holds that the powers of the husband to eliminate such a minor prohibition extends to rabbinic marriages. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 46b" href="/Niddah.46b">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 46b</a>.</i>. Would that be as we stated there: “Before that time, even though they said, we know for Whom we made a vow or to Whom we dedicated, their vows are no vows and their dedications no dedications. After that time, even though they said, we do not know for Whom we made a vow or to Whom we dedicated, their vows are vows and their dedications dedications<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Niddah</i> 5:6. The vows of a girl up to 11 years and a boy up to 12 years are null and void. The vows of a girl over 12 years and a boy over 13 years are valid. In the year in between the validity depends on the ability of the person making the vow to understand what he is doing.</i>.” What is the status of that Mishnah? For Cahana it is in dispute<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Who said earlier that he who cannot give heave cannot dedicate. For him, R. Jehudah will not agree to the lower time limit set by the Mishnah.</i>, for Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish it is everybody’s opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In the previous paragraphs they had denied the link between ability to tithe and ability to make dedications and vows.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said, every impediment that comes from the man makes her as if she were his wife; every impediment that does not come from the man makes her as if she were not his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">If the marriage of a man with an underage girl is dissolved by the initiative of the man, she is treated as a divorcee forbidden his relatives and forbidden to a Cohen, and he is forbidden her close relatives. But if she walks out on him, there never was any marriage, neither side is forbidden the close relatives of the other, and she is not forbidden to marry a Cohen. This is all explained in the next Mishnah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said,” etc. It was stated: “Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said, every impediment that comes from the man <i>by a bill of divorce</i> makes her as if she were his wife; every impediment that does not come from the man <i>by repudiation</i> makes her as if she were not his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">If the marriage of a man with an underage girl is dissolved by the initiative of the man, she is treated as a divorcee forbidden his relatives and forbidden to a Cohen, and he is forbidden her close relatives. But if she walks out on him, there never was any marriage, neither side is forbidden the close relatives of the other, and she is not forbidden to marry a Cohen. This is all explained in the next Mishnah.</i>.”

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If [a girl] repudiates a man, he is permitted [to marry] her relatives and she is permitted [to marry] his relatives; he did not disable her for the priesthood. If he gave her a bill of divorce, he is forbidden [to marry] her relatives and she is forbidden [to marry] his relatives; he did disable her for the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">If the marriage of a man with an underage girl is dissolved by the initiative of the man, she is treated as a divorcee forbidden his relatives and forbidden to a Cohen, and he is forbidden her close relatives. But if she walks out on him, there never was any marriage, neither side is forbidden the close relatives of the other, and she is not forbidden to marry a Cohen. This is all explained in the next Mishnah.</i>. If he gave her a bill of divorce and later took her back, then she repudiated him<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This repudiation is applied not only to the Second but also to the first marriage; then she is not divorced from him and may marry him anew after divorce or widowhood from another man.</i> and married another man from whom she became widowed or divorced, she is permitted to return to him. If she repudiated him and he took her back, then he gave her a bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">This divorce stands, and so stands the prohibition to take back the divorcee who was otherwise married (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:4" href="/Deuteronomy.24.4"><i>Deut.</i> 24:4</a>).</i> and she married another man from whom she became widowed or divorced, she is prohibited to return to him. That is the principle: By divorce after repudiation she is prohibited to return to him; by repudiation after divorce she is permitted to return to him.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If [a girl] repudiates a man, etc.” Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Her only problem would be aspersion on the priesthood, but the court will not tolerate aspersion<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.2">Chapter 10, Halakhah 7, Note 126</a>. Since the marriage was only rabbinic, the prohibition cannot be biblical.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If [a girl] repudiates a man and marries another who divorces her, another and she repudiates him, another who divorces her, another and she repudiates him, she is forbidden to return to anyone who had divorce her but permitted to return to those she had repudiated.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If [a girl] repudiates,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai: Her only problem would be aspersion on the priesthood, but the court will not tolerate aspersion<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.2">Chapter 10, Halakhah 7, Note 126</a>. Since the marriage was only rabbinic, the prohibition cannot be biblical.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody divorced his wife and later took her back, she is permitted to the levir but Rebbi Eliezer forbids her<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The second marriage annuls the prior divorce. R. Eliezer holds that she remains forbidden, even if the husband dies childless, since she was forbidden as his brother’s divorcee, as explained in the Halakhah. The same explanation is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 109a" href="/Yevamot.109a">Babli, 109a</a>.</i>. Similarly, if somebody divorced an orphan girl and took her back, she is permitted to the levir but Rebbi Eliezer forbids her<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The second marriage annuls the prior divorce. R. Eliezer holds that she remains forbidden, even if the husband dies childless, since she was forbidden as his brother’s divorcee, as explained in the Halakhah. The same explanation is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 109a" href="/Yevamot.109a">Babli, 109a</a>.</i>. If an underage girl who was married off by her father was divorced, she is like an orphan during her father’s lifetime<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">She is emancipated from her father’s power by her marriage. Since the father has the right to marry off his underage daughter, both betrothal and divorce are valid by biblical standards. But since the remarriage was by an underage girl no longer under tutelage but unable to perform legal acts by reason of her age, everybody agrees that her rabbinic marriage cannot lift the biblical prohibition of the brother’s divorcee.</i>. If she was taken back, she is prohibited to the levir.<br><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah is not in the Babli nor in most independent Mishnah mss.</i> The Sages agree with Rebbi Eliezer in case he divorced her as a minor and took her back as a minor, since her divorce is a total divorce but her return was not complete. But if he divorced her as a minor and took her back as an adult or she became an adult while married to him<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Since they live together with the idea of being married, the first intercourse after she reaches the age of 12 years makes her marriage valid by biblical standards.</i>, she is permitted to the levir.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The Sages agree,” etc. What is Rebbi Eliezer’s reason? That she was forbidden to him for an hour<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The second marriage annuls the prior divorce. R. Eliezer holds that she remains forbidden, even if the husband dies childless, since she was forbidden as his brother’s divorcee, as explained in the Halakhah. The same explanation is given in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 109a" href="/Yevamot.109a">Babli, 109a</a>.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:5" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.5">Tosephta 13:5</a>.</i> The Sages agree with Rebbi Eliezer about the underage girl who was married off by her father and divorced, that she is like an orphan during her father’s lifetime. Her betrothal and divorce were by biblical standards; her remarriage was not by biblical standards.
What is the status of her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The co-wife of the girl married off by her father, divorced, and remarried.</i>? Rav said, her co-wife is forbidden. Rebbi Joḥanan said, her co-wife is forbidden. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, her co-wife is permitted. Rebbi Eleazar said, I looked around at the rabbis here and at the rabbis there and did not find anybody agreeing with me except Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish who says, her co-wife is permitted.Rav Hamnuna was sitting before Rav Ada bar Ahava and said, what is the status of her co-wife? He said to him, she is permitted. He asked, divorce? He answered, forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">This is the case of the Mishnah.</i>. He said, go around<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Look for other opinions in the matter.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal said, it is reasonable following him who said that her co-wife is permitted. But following him who said, her co-wife is forbidden, as you take it: The aspect he acquired in her makes the corresponding aspect forbidden in her co-wife, the aspect he did not acquire in her makes the corresponding aspect permitted in her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">This text makes no sense. It seems that the correct text is the one quoted by Nahmanides (<i>The wars of the Eternal</i> on Alfasi, 37b in the Wilna edition): צַד שֶׁקָּנָה בָהּ כְּנֶגְדוֹ מוּתָּר בְּצָרָתָהּ וְצַד שֶׁלֹּא קָנָה בָהּ כְּנֶגְדוֹ הִתִּיר בְּצָרָתָהּ. “The aspect he acquired in her <i>permits</i> the corresponding aspect in her co-wife, the aspect he did not acquire in her was permitted in the corresponding aspect in her co-wife.” The argument is based on the doctrine that the marriage of an underage girl not arranged by her father results in partial acquisition of the girl by the husband. This doctrine is stated explicitly in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 110b" href="/Yevamot.110b">Babli (110b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 111a" href="/Yevamot.111a">111a</a>) but not in the Yerushalmi. If the girl was married, then the prior divorce was annulled and both she and her co-wife are permitted to the levir. Is the girl was not married, then she is not a widow; the co-wife is the only widow and as such subject to the levirate.</i>! Rebbi Shammai said, does one admit that kind of argument in matters of incest prohibitions? What about it? For any sister-in-law who is not totally outside [the family], the acquired aspect of her belongs to an incest prohibition and an incest prohibition forbids the co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">This argument supports the authorities Rav and R. Joḥanan. The Yerushalmi prohibits the levirate for the co-wife. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 109a" href="/Yevamot.109a">Babli disagrees, 109a</a>.</i>.
“Two brothers are married,” etc. Rebbi Yudan: One may ask what one asked there. Should he not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for the acquired aspect in her and free her co-wife? So here, should he not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for the acquired aspect in the underage girl and free her (co-wife) [sister]<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Would it not be possible (or required) to apply the argument of R. Eleazar and R. Abba bar Mamal in the previous Halakhah to the situation here? It is difficult to see why one should try to make the situation more complicated than it already is. The text is at least partially corrupt.</i>? Before you find Rebbi Eleazar difficult, you might find Rebbi Eliezer difficult! You cannot find this difficult for Rebbi Eliezer, since Rebbi Eliezer is a Shammaite<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ševi‘it</i> 9:9, <i>Terumot</i> 5:4, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 7b" href="/Niddah.7b">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 7b</a>. R. Eliezer became a student of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai; in no sense can he be considered an orthodox representative of the House of Shammai.</i> and the House of Shammai say, one lets only the betrothed [women] repudiate<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:1:1-2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.1.1-2.9">Mishnah 1</a>.</i>?

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two brothers are married to two underage orphan [sisters]<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The word “sisters” is missing but is in the Mishnah in the Babli and in the independent Mishnah.</i>. If the husband of one of them dies, the other one has to leave as wife’s sister. And so for two deaf-mute [sisters]<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Their marriages are only rabbinically valid.</i>. If one is adult and the other underage, if the husband of the underage girl died, she has to leave as wife’s sister. If the husband of the adult one died, Rebbi Eliezer said, one teaches the underage one to repudiate him<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eliezer holds that the biblical candidacy of the adult one forbids the rabbinically married one to her husband. If the underage girl repudiates her husband, her marriage never happened and the husband is free to marry his brother’s widow in levirate.</i>. Rabban Gamliel says, if she repudiated, she repudiated; otherwise she should wait until she becomes of age and the other one has to leave as wife’s sister<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Gamliel holds that candidacy has no effect on an existing marriage even if that marriage is only rabbinical. As long as the sister is underage, the older one cannot marry since she cannot get <i>ḥalîṣah.</i></i>. Rebbi Joshua says, woe to him for his wife, woe to him for his brother’s wife! He has to send away his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s wife by <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">He holds with R. Eliezer that candidacy of the older forbids the younger one to her husband. But he also thinks that one never tells an underage girl to repudiate. He will agree that if his wife repudiates him on her own, that he may marry her sister in levirate.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> Is the degree of acquisition of one equal to that of the other<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage of the underage girl is only rabbinic, the sister either was not married, then she can be married and divorced, or she was married, then she is freed by divorce after levirate.</i>? Did we not state “underage and deaf-mute”<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In the next Mishnah, also dealing with a case asymmetric in the rules.</i>? Rebbi Hiyya stated ““underage and deaf-mute”<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:6" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.6">Tosephta 13:6</a>.</i>: “If the husband of the underage girl died, the husband of the deaf-mute has to divorce her and the underage girl has to wait until she comes of age and perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Possibly the degree of acquisition of the deaf-mute by the husband is less than that of an underage girl. Then the biblical candidacy of the underage would prohibit the deaf-mute for her husband. Therefore, he must divorce the deaf- mute.</i>” Why can she not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> immediately? She cannot because of Rebbi Meїr, since Rebbi Meїr said that one does not perform levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with an underage girl, since she might be found to be a she-ram<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">But according to other authorities, she may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> immediately; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:4:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.4.4">Chapter 12, Note 105</a>.</i>. “If the husband of the deaf-mute died, the husband of the underage girl has to divorce her and the deaf-mute is permanently forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">She cannot be married in levirate since her sister’s marriage may have been valid. As a deaf-mute, she cannot perform <i>ḥalîṣah.</i> No man in the world is permitted to her.</i>. If he transgressed and had intercourse with the deaf-mute, he divorces her and she becomes permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage of the underage girl is only rabbinic, the sister either was not married, then she can be married and divorced, or she was married, then she is freed by divorce after levirate.</i>.” This follows what Rebbi Hila said, in order to fix her status<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">One permits the levir to transgress rabbinic rules since otherwise the deaf-mute cannot be helped. In the inverse case, that the underage girl became the childless widow, it is not necessary to permit infraction of the rules since everything can be done abiding by the rules. All this case shows is that <i>on the rabbinic level,</i> there is a difference between underage and deaf-mute.</i>.
So is the Mishnah: The underage girl should wait until she grows up, reaches puberty, and is being married<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement of Rabban Gamliel that in the absence of repudiation, the underage girl should wait until she becomes of age. The statement is modified slightly to make clear that the marriage of the former underage girl must acquire biblical validity in order to free her sister.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, there is no “being married” here, only “being betrothed.”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, 109b, that is very much in dispute.</i> Rebbi Joḥanban said, these are the words of Rabban Gamliel: If somebody gave <i>qiddušin</i> to his sister-in-law’s sister, his sister-in-law was freed from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate. It follows that what we had stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.10.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>. The complications of that Mishnah are irrelevant for Rabban Gamliel.</i>, “if somebody gave <i>qiddušin</i> to the sister of a woman waiting for her levir” does not follow Rabban Gamliel.
Rebbi Ḥaggai said before Rebbi Ze‘ira, Menaḥem in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Practice follows Rebbi Eliezer, if she repudiated, she repudiated. Rebbi Eliezer said, one teaches the underage one to repudiate him, and you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The statement in the name of R. Joḥanan is inconsistent: R. Eliezer says one teaches the girl to repudiate!</i>? Rebbi Ze‘ira, Rebbi Ḥiyya, in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Practice follows Rebbi Joshua, if she repudiated, she repudiated. Rebbi Joshua says, woe to him for his wife, woe to him for his brother’s wife! And you say so<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">The second formulation is also inconsistent.</i>? Rebbi Hila, Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Hila was one of the teachers of R. Yose, one has to read here: R. Yasa.</i> in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Practice follows Rabban Gamliel. Rebbi Joshua agrees with Rabban Gamliel, if she repudiated, she repudiated<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the first case, the problem took care of itself. If the women do not want to wait, Rabban Gamliel will agree with Rebbi Joshua.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 110a" href="/Yevamot.110a">Babli, 110a</a>, practice is stated to follow R. Eliezer without discussion.</i>; otherwise she should wait until she becomes of age. If not<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In the first case, the problem took care of itself. If the women do not want to wait, Rabban Gamliel will agree with Rebbi Joshua.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 110a" href="/Yevamot.110a">Babli, 110a</a>, practice is stated to follow R. Eliezer without discussion.</i>, he has to send away his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s wife by <i>ḥalîṣah.</i>

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody was married to two underage orphan girls and died, intercourse or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> of one of them frees her co-wife. The same holds for two deaf-mutes. An underaged girl and a deaf-mute: Intercourse of neither of them frees her co-wife.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last case in the Mishnah, an underage girl and a deaf-mute. It is again supposed that the underage girl was not married off by her father and the deaf-mute was already deaf-mute at the moment of marriage. In contrast to the Babli, the Yerushalmi does not try to determine the actual difference in the rabbinic status of the two marriages. The first part of the paragraph is exactly parallel to the preceding Halakhah, Notes 91–98.</i> Is the degree of acquisition of one equal to that of the other? What does he do? Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Rav: He marries the deaf-mute and divorces her; the underage girl has to wait until she can perform <i>ḥalîṣah.</i>” Why can she not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> immediately? She cannot because of Rebbi Meїr, since Rebbi Meїr said that one does not perform levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with an underage girl, since she might be found to be a she-ram. If he sleeps with the underage girl, he has to divorce her, and the deaf-mute is permanently forbidden. If he transgressed and had intercourse with the deaf-mute, he divorces her and she became permitted.” This follows what Rebbi Hila said, in order to fix her status. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Hila: What means, “in order to fix her status”? As you say there, he should perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for the aspect that was acquired in her and marry her co-wife; could he not perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for the aspect that was acquired in the underage girl and marry the deaf-mute<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the discussion in Halakhah 6 and supports the reading of Naḥmanides in Note 81. It is suggested there that in case of partial validity of a marriage there could be a partial <i>ḥalîṣah</i> which permits the co-wife for levirate; in our case there would be a solution which takes care of the deaf-mute without requiring the levir to commit a sin. {This also supports the position of Nahmanides that the Yerushalmi in Halakhah 6 choses R. Eleazar over R. Shammai.}</i>? He said to him, so says Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: We never find two sisters-in-law of whom one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one is married in levirate. Do we find two sisters-in-law of whom one performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one is divorced? He said to him, that happens. That is what we have stated there: “If he ‘bespoke’ one and performed <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with the other, the first one needs a bill of divorce”<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah 5:5, Note 73.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A hearing wife and a deaf-mute: The intercourse of the hearing woman frees the deaf-mute but the intercourse of the deaf-mute does not free the hearing woman<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">If a man married to a hearing woman and a deaf-mute dies childless, the execution of biblical levirate by intercourse with the hearing widow frees the deaf-mute but the execution of rabbinic levirate by intercourse with the deaf-mute does not free the hearing widow.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A hearing wife and a deaf-mute,” etc.: A hearing wife and a deaf-mute. The intercourse of the hearing woman frees the deaf-mute. The intercourse of the deaf-mute does not free the hearing woman but disables the hearing woman<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">She now is forbidden to the levir. But since the marriage of the deaf-mute was rabbinic only, the hearing woman cannot remarry without <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> An adult wife and an underage wife. The intercourse of the adult woman frees the underage girl but the intercourse of the underage girl does not free the adult woman<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">This and the corresponding Halakhah are the exact parallels to the preceding Mishnah and Halakhah. The Mishnah is required only because it is not known whether the rabbinic status of the underage wife is identical with that of the deaf-mute wife or not.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “An adult wife and an underage wife,” etc. An adult wife and an underage wife. The intercourse of the adult woman frees the underage girl. The intercourse of the underage girl does not free the adult woman but disables the adult woman<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">This and the corresponding Halakhah are the exact parallels to the preceding Mishnah and Halakhah. The Mishnah is required only because it is not known whether the rabbinic status of the underage wife is identical with that of the deaf-mute wife or not.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Somebody was married to two underage orphan girls and died. If the levir had intercourse with the first one<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">She then is married to him in levirate by biblical standards.</i> and then had intercourse with the second, or his brother had intercourse with the second<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">These acts are sinful, but since the first levirate was legitimate, the sins of others cannot influence the status of the blameless wife.</i>, the first one was not disabled. The same holds for two deaf-mutes. An underage girl and a deaf-mute. If the levir had intercourse with the underage girl and then had intercourse with the deaf-mute, or his brother had intercourse with the deaf-mute, the underage girl was not disabled<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">This is also the reading in the Babli of the Babylonian Gaonim and Maimonides. But the Western tradition, represented by Rashi, RaBaD, and the printed Babli text, reads: “the underage girl was disabled”. This is explained as a rabbinic decree to assimilate this case to the next one. Since the Mishnaiot are formulated to express the non-symmetry of the situations, the Eastern reading is to be preferred.</i>. If the levir had intercourse with the deaf-mute and then had intercourse with the underage girl, or his brother had intercourse with the underage girl, the deaf-mute was disabled<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">This Mishnah very definitely holds that the status of the deaf-mute is inferior to that of the underage girl. If the underage girl had not been an orphan, she could have been a wife by biblical standards. The marriage of the deaf-mute is a purely rabbinic institution to ensure that she should have a home and not be an object of public sexual abuse. Therefore, the almost biblical levirate of the underage girl annuls the purely rabbinic levirate of the deaf-mute, forbids the latter to the levir, and leads to the problem of the permanently forbidden deaf-mute discussed in the preceding Halakhot. As a consequence, both widows are forbidden to the levirs.<br>A totally different tradition is preserved in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 13:7" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).13.7">Tosephta 13:7</a>. There, it is held that if any levirate is not 100% biblical, any doubling forbids both widows for all levirs.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Somebody was married.” Even if he did not have intercourse with the underage girl, the deaf-mute is disabled<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">In the presence of an underage widow, the candidacy of the deaf-mute widow for levirate is not executable. As an earlier Mishnah stated, intercourse with the deaf-mute does not free the underage girl. The candidacy of the deaf-mute could be resurrected only if the underage girl died before she was married by the levir.<br>It is obvious that if the case involves a biblically married woman and a deaf-mute or an underage girl, the same situation applies.</i>. If he did not have intercourse with the underage girl and she died, he would have been permitted the deaf-mute. But now that he did have intercourse with her, even if she died he had disabled the deaf-mute.

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A hearing wife and a deaf-mute. If the levir had intercourse with the hearing woman and then had intercourse with the deaf-mute, or his brother had intercourse with the deaf-mute, the hearing woman was not disabled. If the levir had intercourse with the deaf-mute and then had intercourse with the hearing woman, or his brother had intercourse with the hearing woman, the deaf-mute was disabled.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A hearing wife and a deaf-mute. If the levir had intercourse,” etc. Even if he did not have intercourse with the hearing woman, the deaf-mute is disabled<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">In the presence of an underage widow, the candidacy of the deaf-mute widow for levirate is not executable. As an earlier Mishnah stated, intercourse with the deaf-mute does not free the underage girl. The candidacy of the deaf-mute could be resurrected only if the underage girl died before she was married by the levir.<br>It is obvious that if the case involves a biblically married woman and a deaf-mute or an underage girl, the same situation applies.</i>. If he did not have intercourse with the hearing woman and she died, he would have been permitted the deaf-mute. But now that he did have intercourse with her, even if she died he had disabled the deaf-mute.

Halakhah 13

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> An adult wife and an underage one. If the levir had intercourse with the adult and then had intercourse with the underage one, or his brother had intercourse with her, the adult was not disabled. If the levir had intercourse with the underage widow and then had intercourse with the adult one, or his brother had intercourse with her, the underage one was disabled. Rebbi Eleazar says, one teaches the underage girl that she should repudiate him<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Since the levirate of the underage girl would be almost biblical, her intercourse is incestuous and also forbids the adult co-widow. The situation can be remedied if the marriage of the underage girl is eliminated.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “An adult wife and an underage one” Even if he did not have intercourse with the adult one, the underage one is disabled<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">In the presence of an underage widow, the candidacy of the deaf-mute widow for levirate is not executable. As an earlier Mishnah stated, intercourse with the deaf-mute does not free the underage girl. The candidacy of the deaf-mute could be resurrected only if the underage girl died before she was married by the levir.<br>It is obvious that if the case involves a biblically married woman and a deaf-mute or an underage girl, the same situation applies.</i>. If he did not have intercourse with the adult woman and she died, he would have been permitted the underage one. But now that he did have intercourse with her, even if she died he had disabled the underage one.
“Rebbi Eleazar says, one teaches the underage girl that she should repudiate him.” After the fact<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Why does R. Eleazar (ben Shamua, the Tanna) not recommend that the underage girl repudiate the levir immediately before any complications can arise? The conclusion is that in practice one does not have to wait before one instructs the underage widow to repudiate the former marriage. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 111b" href="/Yevamot.111b">Babli, 111b</a>, concurs that one follows R. Eleazar</i>. Therefore, not from the start! Rebbi Mana said it without attribution, Rebbi Isaac the son of Rebbi Ḥiyya the Scribe in the name of Rebbi Yoḥanan: This is Rebbi Meїr’s, since Rebbi Meїr said that one does not perform levirate or <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with an underage girl, since she might be found to be a she-ram.

Halakhah 14

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If an underage levir had intercourse with an underage sister-in-law, they should grow up together<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">And stay married.</i>. If he had intercourse with an adult sister-in-law, she should raise him<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">And stay married.</i>. If the sister-in-law claims within thirty days<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">After he officially brought her into his house. The marriage ceremony of the levir is without meaning unless it is followed by the sex act.</i> that she was not copulated with, one forces him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that she cannot prove her claim by witnesses. But for the first thirty days, her claim carries a presumption of truth. Unless the levir can disprove her claim, she is not married in levirate and is freed by <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. After thirty days, one asks him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">It is not credible that a woman would stay more than thirty days with a man who does not sleep with her. If the levir denies her claim, she would have to prove it. In the absence of proof, the court may counsel a separation but cannot force it.</i>. But if he confesses, one forces him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her even after twelve months.<br>If a woman made a vow during her husband’s lifetime forbidding herself any usufruct from her levir<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">She made the vow when she did not think that her husband would die childless, but now she finds herself forbidden to marry the levir.</i>, one coerces him until he performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her. After her husband’s death, one begs him that he should perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">If she made the vow in order to prevent levirate, the court will not coerce the levir to abandon the biblical commandment of levirate. It is clear that the Mishnah became obsolete when preference changed from levirate to <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>. If she had [<i>ḥalîṣah</i>] in mind even during her husband’s lifetime, one begs him that he should perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If an underage levir,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The entire paragraph is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:4:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.4.2-5"><i>Ketubot</i> Halakhah 1:4</a>.</i> It was stated: A claim of non-virginity may be brought within thirty days, the words of Rebbi Meїr. But the Sages say, immediately<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 111b" href="/Yevamot.111b">Babli, 111b</a>, and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).1.4">Tosephta, <i>Ketubot</i> 1:4</a>: “A claim of non-virginity may be brought within thirty days, the words of Rebbi Meїr. Rebbi Yose says, if they were alone together, immediately; if they were not alone together, within thirty days (<i>Tosephta</i>), indefinitely (<i>Babli</i>).”<br>The husband goes to court to annul the marriage, without divorce and without payment, claiming that he was lead to believe the bride to be a virgin when he found that she was not.</i>. Where do we hold? If he copulated, immediately. If he did not copulate, even after a longer delay. But we must hold if it was not spelled out. Rebbi Meїr said, it is credible that a man may hold himself back for thirty days. But the Sages say, a man does not hold himself back even for one day<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 112a" href="/Yevamot.112a">Babli, 112a</a>, this is declared to be irrelevant for our Mishnah since a man will sleep with his bride immediately after the marriage ceremony but might be reluctant to touch his sister-in-law for some time.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah asked: According to Rebbi Meїr, would a man be believed to assert that he held himself back for thirty days in order to make the child fatherless<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">If his wife becomes pregnant immediately after the marriage ceremony, can he declare in court that the child is not his since he did not sleep with his bride for some time?</i>? Let us hear from the following: “If the sister-in-law claims within thirty days that she was not copulated with, one forces him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her. After thirty days, one asks him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> with her.” (After thirty days.)<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in <i>Ketubot</i>.</i> And Rebbi Eleazar said, this is Rebbi Meїr’s<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">But the majority will accept the widow’s claim only on the day after she entered the levir’s house.</i>. And Rebbi Eleazar said, that refers only to her, but not to her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">If the co-wife married an outside man based on the other’s levirate marriage, she cannot cast aspersion on the validity of her cowidow’s marriage without the testimony of two credible witnesse.<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 112a" href="/Yevamot.112a">Babli agrees, 112a</a>, at least in the interpretation of Rashi and Rabbenu Ḥananel.</i>. As you say there<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">“There” is here, <i>Yebamot</i>, “here” is there, <i>Ketubot</i>, cf. Note 122.</i>, she is not believed to damage her co-wife, so here, he is not believed to damage his son.
“If a woman made a vow forbidding herself any usufruct,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Halakhah refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.14.1">Mishnah 15</a>, not <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 13:14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.13.14.1">Mishnah 16</a>.</i> Consider the following: He said, I copulated, but she says, I was not copulated with. Even if he changed and then said, I did not copulate, he cannot be believed since from the start he had said, I copulated. But if from the start he said that he had not copulated, the two together can uproot the presumption<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The court must believe that they had no sexual relations and that she never became the levir’s wife while living in his house.</i>. The colleagues asked: What are we talking about? If following the early Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bekhorot</i> 1:7 stating that in early times, levirate was preferred, but today <i>ḥalîṣah</i> is preferred.</i>, we have understood that one may marry in levirate. If following the later Mishnah, we have understood that one may perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Where did we hear that one coerces<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–9</a> makes it clear that the levir can be compelled to appear in court but not that he can be compelled to do anything against his will.</i>? Rav Huna in the name of Rav: That is, if a bill of divorce has passed from his hand to her hand<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 112a" href="/Yevamot.112a">Babli, 112a</a>, this is the answer of Rav to the question why one does coerce him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if she already lives in his house, why does one not coerce him to sleep with her? Note that the colleagues prevented this question to be asked by referring to the later Mishnah.</i>. He says, it is the bill of divorce of a wife. But she says, it is the bill of divorce of a sister-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">As was determined earlier, in order to remarry she needs a bill of divorce for his “bespeaking” <i>and ḥalîṣah</i> for her candidacy of levirate.</i>. Within thirty days, the presumption is that he did not copulate; one coerces him to perform<i>ḥalîṣah</i>. After thirty days, one asks him to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. Rebbi Yose asked, after thirty days, the presumption is that he copulated and you say one coerces<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The only difference between the colleagues and R. Yose is the formulation of the question. Since after 30 days the presumption is that she became his wife, why should he be asked to perform a useless <i>ḥalîṣah</i>? The answer is that he already gave the bill of divorce but that might not be enough to let the sister-in-law remarry.</i>? But it must be the following: Rav Huna in the name of Rav: That is, if a bill of divorce has passed from his hand to her hand. He says, it is the bill of divorce of a wife. But she says, it is the bill of divorce of a sister-in-law. Within thirty days, the presumption is that he did not copulate; one coerces him to perform<i>ḥalîṣah</i>. After thirty days, one asks him to perform<i>ḥalîṣah</i>. The following: If he says, I copulated, and she says, I was not copulated with, it is obvious that he has to sustain her<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">He obligated himself since he asserts that she is his wife by biblical standards.</i>. It is obvious that he does not inherit from her<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">She asserts that she is not his wife.</i>. The problem is whether he inherits his brother’s property<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">If there are potential co-heirs, he inherits only if he is married to the widow.</i>. If she says, I was copulated with, and he says, I did not copulate, it is obvious that he does not have to sustain her<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">If he asserts that he did not copulate, it is obvious that there are no eyewitnesses to back up her claim for support as a wife. Since in money matters the proof is on the claimant, she cannot enforce her claim.</i>. It is obvious that he inherits his brother’s property<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">This is not obvious. In fact, all classical commentators amend the text to read “he does not inherit” and the editor of the Leiden ms. here notes a corruption. Their reason is that the coheirs can point to his denial of acquisition. There is little reason to accept the argument and the correction since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-6" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-6"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–6</a> makes it quite clear that the transfer of property is an automatic consequence of the transfer of the wife and her word is the only one that should carry weight in his family.</i>. The problem is whether he inherits from her<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">One the one hand, she asserts that he inherits from her. On the other hand, he renounces all his rights in any settlement with her family. No answers are given to the questions that never apply in practice.</i>.

Chapter 14



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A deaf-mute man who married a hearing woman or a hearing man who married a deaf-mute woman may divorce or stay married at will; just as he marries with sign language so he divorces with sign language<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The marriage is only valid by rabbinic standards; a divorce is possible by rabbinic standards.</i>. A hearing man who married a hearing woman who then became deaf-mute may divorce or stay married at will<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in the next Mishnah, a divorce is effective by the action of the husband alone; the divorce is possible even if the wife is not able to act in law.</i>. If she became insane he shall not divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">By rabbinic decree.</i>. If he became deaf-mute or insane, he can never divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">He is married under biblical standards. Even if he were able to communicate in sign language as a deaf-mute, he cannot execute acts under biblical standards.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A deaf-mute who married a hearing woman”, etc. How does he do it<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">How can he divorce? He has to tell the clerk to write the bill and the witnesses to sign and to witness the delivery of the documents. If the woman is deaf-mute, she has to be instructed to receive the documents in her hands. There is an opinion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:8:1-2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.8.1-2">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:8</a> that he may communicate by lip reading.</i>? He communicates in sign language and gives her the bill of divorce. In the same way he communicates with others, others communicate with him.
The Mishnah applies if he<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">If the deaf-mute became betrothed to a woman by giving her an object of value, he is imitating an act reserved for competent adults. His marriage is deemed valid only by special rabbinic enactment. If an underage (otherwise normal) boy became betrothed by money’s worth, his act does not have even a shadow of validity. But the betrothal of a woman by the sex act of a man, while impractical, is valid by biblical standards (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1"><i>Deut.</i> 24:1</a>). The marriage then can be undone only by an act valid by biblical standards, outside the reach of a deaf-mute.</i> became betrothed to her by money. But if he became betrothed to her by copulation, his betrothal is an action but his divorce is not an action.
Rebbi Eleazar asked Rebbi Joḥanan: The wife of a deaf-mute or an insane? He said to him, that does not even need a reparation sacrifice for a possible sin<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage has no biblical validity, adultery by the wife cannot be a biblical crime. There cannot be a sacrifice to atone for any transgression of rabbinic rules. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113a" href="/Yevamot.113a">Babli agrees, 113a</a> in the name of Samuel.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: It does not even need a reparation sacrifice for a possible sin. Since you say, it does not even need a reparation sacrifice for a possible sin; if another man came and gave her <i>qiddušin</i>, they take hold of her<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 5:2:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.5.2.3">Chapter 5, Note 43</a>. If the woman is not married by biblical standards, betrothal to another man needs a divorce.</i>. If he divorced, is she permitted to remarry the first [husband]? That is what Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: About the wife of a deaf-mute who after being divorced by the deaf-mute went and married a deaf-mute or a hearing person, I am reading: “Her first husband who sent her away cannot come to take her back.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9,</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 24:4.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rabbinic decree.</i> About the wife of a hearing person who after being divorced went and married a deaf-mute or a hearing person, I am reading: “Her first husband who sent her away cannot … ” If a deaf-mute’s husband went overseas and they came and told his wife, your husband has died, and she went and married a deaf- mute or a hearing person, and then her husband returned, she has to leave both of them<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Under the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 10:1</a>.</i>. If the husband of a hearing wife went overseas and they came and told her, your husband has died, and she went and married a deaf-mute, and then her hearing [husband] returned, we would think that the deaf-mute should divorce her but the hearing person can keep her<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Since she was not really married and unmarried sex in the erroneous belief that she was a widow does not prevent the woman to return to her husband.</i>. She is still under these disabilities<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The long list of disabilities of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 10:1</a> is rabbinic and the rabbis enforce them for marriages concluded under rabbinic rules only.</i>.
“If she became insane he shall not divorce.” In the House of Rebbi Yannai they said, because of the fence<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In the rabbinic literature (<i>Tosaphot</i> 113b <i>s. v.</i> יצתה, <i>Rašba</i> 113b, <i>Roš</i> 14:3, from where all later sources are derived) the reading is גְּרִירָה “towing, dragging”. According to that reading, R. Yannai says that the divorce is rabbinically prohibited because on her own the insane could not defend herself and might be dragged away by any man for sexual abuse. According to the reading of the ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> גְּדֵירָה, R. Yannai asserts only that it is a rabbinic decree that the husband is forbidden to divorce her (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Demai 1:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Demai.1.2.4"><i>Demai</i> Chapter 1, Note 89</a> for the equality גזירה = גדירה). The cases quoted by R. Nehemiah bar Mar Uqban support the ms. reading unequivocally.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113b" href="/Yevamot.113b">Babli, 113b</a>, R. Yannai is quoted as author of the statement attributed here to R. Ze‘ira and R. Hila.</i>. Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Hila both say, because she cannot preserve her bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:1" href="/Deuteronomy.24.1"><i>Deut.</i> 24:1</a> requires that the divorce document be <i>in the hand</i> of the wife, a wife without a legal hand cannot be divorced. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 113b" href="/Yevamot.113b">Babli, 113b</a>, agrees that a bill of divorce that cannot be delivered either to the woman or her representative is inactive.</i>. Rebbi Nehemiah bar Mar Uqban (the son) [in the name]<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Reading of <i>Roš</i>,<i>l. c.</i> The reading of the ms. is impossible.</i> of Rebbi Yose explained three cases. If he transgressed and divorced her. According to him who said because of a fence, he divorced<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">His action was a transgression but is valid.</i>. According to him who said because she cannot preserve her bill of divorce, it is forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Unless the woman understands that she is divorced, she is not divorced.</i>. If she has a son, or a father, or a brother. According to him who said because of a fence, it is forbidden. According to him who said because she cannot preserve her bill of divorce, she has a father and can preserve her bill of divorce. Sometimes she is insane and sometimes of lucid mind. According to him who said because of a fence, it is forbidden. According to him who said because she cannot preserve her bill of divorce, sometimes she can preserve her bill of divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">According to both Talmudim [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 1:1:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.1.1.12">Yerushalmi <i>Terumot</i> 1:1 (Notes 52–55</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 7:1:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.7.1.2-10"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 7:1,</a> fol. 48c; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 28a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.28a">Babli <i>Roš Haššanah</i>28a</a>] a sporadically insane person is treated as a normal person in his intervals of lucidity.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said, why can a deaf-mute woman be divorced but a deaf-mute man cannot divorce? They told him, a divorcing man is not comparable to a divorced woman since a woman can be divorced with or against her will<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">By talmudic standards. By an institution of R. Gershon ben Jehudah (Mayence, about the year 1000), European Jews were forbidden to divorce without the wife’s consent (except in cases where the law forces the husband to divorce).</i> but a man divorces only by his own will<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">If the court coerces a recalcitrant husband to give a divorce, they have to coerce him “until he says, I want to do it.”</i>.<br>Rebbi Joḥanan ben Gudgada<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">A Tanna, about one generation older than R. Joḥanan ben Nuri. His testimony is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 7:9" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.7.9">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 7:9</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 5:6:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.5.6.2-6"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 5:5</a>.</i> testified about a deaf-mute girl who was married off by her father<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">When she was a minor and was passive in the marriage. She is married by biblical standards.</i> that she could be divorced by a bill of divorce. They said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">To R. Joḥanan ben Nuri, that in principle, the biblical marriage of an incompetent person can be dissolved by divorce.</i>, that is an example.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">A scribal error.</i> testified,” etc. Rebbi Ḥananiah asked before Rebbi Hila. The matters seem reasonable for a hearing woman of sound mind, that she is divorced with or without her acquiescence. But a deaf-mute woman who has no will should not be divorced except with her acquiescence. But is it not testimony “that is an example”; does one add to a testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">If the Mishnah was included in <i>Idiut</i> it is proof that the testimony was checked and found truly to reflect old practice.</i>?
