But Rebbi Ḥanania is of the opinion that this deals with a hearing girl who was married off by her father and became deaf-and-dumb<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Since the marriage was valid by biblical standards, the divorce follows biblical rules.</i>. Rebbi Yose is of the opinion that this deals with an underage girl<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Already deaf-mute. Since she is not an orphan, she can be married off legally, not only if deaf-mute but even if insane.</i> who was married off by her father and became divorced.
Rebbi Joḥanan said<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">That is a note only on the order of the following Mishnaiot. R. Joḥanan notes that it would have been more reasonable to start in both series (sisters or unrelated women) with the totally unproblematic case and to introduce the complications later.</i>, there is nothing to be learned from the beginning, but there is something to be learned from the end. What is there at the beginning? If the deaf-mute [brother] was the husband of the deaf-mute [woman] and the hearing the husband of the hearing. But if the deaf-mute [brother] was the husband of the hearing [woman] and the hearing the husband of the deaf-mute, that should have been stated at the very end.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two deaf-mute brothers married to two deaf-mute sisters, or two hearing sisters, or two sisters of whom one is deaf-mute, the other hearing; or two deaf-mute sisters married to two deaf-mute brothers, or two hearing brothers, or two brothers of whom one is deaf-mute, these are free from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">A sister cannot become the co-wife of a sister, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a>.</i>. If the women are unrelated, they must marry them, and, if they want to, they may send them away<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Since they cannot perform a valid <i>ḥalîṣah</i> if one of the parties at least is deaf-mute, and the two marriages are of equal status, they must marry in levirate. But after the marriage, there is no general obstacle to a divorce.</i>.<br>Two brothers, one deaf-mute and one hearing, married to two hearing sisters. If the deaf-mute married to the hearing wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife do? [The widow] has to leave as the wife’s sister. If the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife died, what shall the deaf-mute married to the hearing wife do? He divorces his wife by a bill of divorce; his brother’s widow is permanently forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The widow was married by biblical standards. She now is a candidate for levirate with the deaf- mute brother by biblical standards. Her biblical claim to the levir is stronger than the rabbinic claim of her deaf-mute sister. Therefore, from the moment of the hearing brother’s death, the deaf-mute sister is forbidden to her husband as sister of a quasi-wife. The widow herself cannot be helped. She cannot be married in levirate since her levir is incapable of marrying by biblical standards. She cannot be freed to marry another man since her levir is incapable of performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two deaf-mute brothers,” etc. What about her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Since at least one party is deaf-mute, none of the marriages described in the Mishnah is of biblical validity (it is assumed throughout these Mishnaiot that the deaf-mute woman was not married to her hearing husband by her father during her minority.) It therefore is not self-evident that the exemptions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.1">Mishnah 1:1</a> apply in these cases.</i> ? Let us hear from the following: If his hearing daughter was married to his deaf-mute brother, her co-wife is free from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If the marriage was valid, then the co-wife of the daughter is free according to the House of Hillel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 14:3:1-5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.14.3.1-5.2">Mishnah 1–4</a>). If the marriage was invalid, then there is no place for levirate. In the latter case, the co-wife is forbidden to the hearing brother by rabbinic decree.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two hearing brothers married to two sisters, one deaf-mute and one hearing. If the hearing [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to a hearing wife do? [The widow] has to leave as the wife’s sister. If the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife do? He removes his wife by a bill of divorce and his brother’s widow by <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Here again, the claim of the biblically married widow is stronger than that of the rabbinically married wife; but since he had rabbinically married the sister, the widow is rabbinically forbidden to him.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two hearing brothers,” etc. What about her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to a co-wife of the deaf-mute sister married to a hearing brother.</i>? Let us hear from the following: If his deaf-mute daughter was married to his hearing brother, her co-wife performs <i>ḥalîṣah</i> but not levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">She cannot be freed automatically since her co-wife’s marriage was not valid by biblical standards.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two brothers, one deaf-mute and one hearing, married to two sisters, one deaf-mute and one hearing. If the deaf-mute [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to a hearing wife do? [The widow] has to leave as the wife’s sister. If the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife died, what shall the deaf-mute [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife do? He removes his wife by a bill of divorce; his brother’s wife is permanently forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The widow was married by biblical standards. She now is a candidate for levirate with the deaf- mute brother by biblical standards. Her biblical claim to the levir is stronger than the rabbinic claim of her deaf-mute sister. Therefore, from the moment of the hearing brother’s death, the deaf-mute sister is forbidden to her husband as sister of a quasi-wife. The widow herself cannot be helped. She cannot be married in levirate since her levir is incapable of marrying by biblical standards. She cannot be freed to marry another man since her levir is incapable of performing <i>ḥalîṣah</i>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two deaf-mute brothers,” etc. What about her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The co-wife of the deaf-mute wife of the deaf-mute brother. She has no claim on the hearing brother married to a hearing wife.</i>? Let us hear from the following: If his deaf-mute daughter was married to his deaf-mute brother, her co-wife is free from <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and levirate.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two brothers, one deaf-mute and one hearing, married to two unrelated hearing women. If the deaf-mute [brother] married to a hearing wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to a hearing wife do? He performs either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate. If the hearing [brother] married to a hearing wife died, what shall the deaf-mute [brother] married to a hearing wife do? He marries [the widow] and never can divorce her<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">His levirate is valid by biblical standards but his divorce would only be rabbinical.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two brothers, one deaf-mute,” etc. May she eat heave? Let us her from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 6, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.14.1">Halakhah 1, Notes 31–32</a>.</i>: “A hearing daughter of an Israel who married a deaf-mute Cohen does not eat heave. If he died and she came before the levir, if he is hearing, she eats, deaf-mute does not eat.”

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Two hearing brothers, married to two unrelated women, one deaf-mute and one hearing. If the hearing [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to a hearing wife do? He marries [the widow]<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow is unable to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. He may later divorce her since in that she is passive.</i>, and if he wants to divorce, he divorces. If the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife do? He performs either <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or levirate.<br>Two brothers, one deaf-mute and one hearing, married to two unrelated women, one deaf-mute and one hearing. If the deaf-mute [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife died, what shall the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife do? He marries, and if he wants to divorce, he divorces<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Since the widow is unable to perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i>. He may later divorce her since in that she is passive.</i>. If the hearing [brother] married to the hearing wife died, what shall the deaf-mute [brother] married to the deaf-mute wife do? He marries and can never divorce<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">His levirate is valid by biblical standards but his divorce would only be rabbinical.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Two hearing brothers,” etc. “Two brothers, one of them deaf-mute,” etc. May she eat heave? <sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 6, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 14:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.14.1">Halakhah 1, Notes 34–35</a>.</i> Let us hear from the following: “A hearing daughter of an Israel who became engaged to a hearing Cohen, who did not manage to bring her to the bridal chamber before he became deaf-mute or before she became deaf-mute, does not eat heave. If he died and she came before a levir she eats even if he is deaf-mute. In this He increased the power of the levir over that of the husband since the deaf-mute levir enables her to eat, but the deaf-mute husband does not enable her to eat.”

Chapter 15



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A woman went overseas with her husband. If there was peace between him and her and there was peace in the world and came and said, “my husband died”, she can remarry, “my husband died”, she can marry in levirate<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Not only can she remarry but the local court will oversee the liquidation of the husband’s inheritance on her word. Since the consequences of her remarrying while her husband is alive are so devastating (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 10:1</a>) we trust that she will not knowingly remarry if her husband is alive.</i>. If there was no peace between him and her but there was peace in the world, she cannot be believed<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and the independent Mishnah mss. there is another clause “if there was peace between him and her but no peace in the world.” Since the first sentence requires two conditions, peace between him and her and peace in the world, it is clear that the other clause was omitted by an oversight of the scribe. This is confirmed by the Halakhah, which discusses why in case of war she is not believed without supporting evidence.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, she is never believed unless she comes crying with torn clothes. They said to him, in any case she can remarry.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A woman went with her husband,” etc. Just as you say, <sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.4.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 2:4</a>. This belongs to a series of statements illustrating the principle that “the mouth that prohibits is the mouth that permits”. If nobody at that place knew that she had been married before, then if she asserts that she was married she forbids herself for every other male. If then she qualifies the statement that now she is no longer married because she is divorced, her testimony must be accepted since if one believes her that she was married one must believe her that she is divorced; if one does not believe her that she was married, one does not have to believe her that she is divorced but it makes no difference since as an unmarried woman she can contract marriage. But if there were witnesses who could testify that she was married, she has to prove her case by documents or witnesses if she wants to remarry as a divorcee.</i>“if there are witnesses that she is a married woman and she says, I was divorced, she is not trustworthy;” would I say it is the same here? There is a difference for witnesses of death since if he comes he disproves [the testimony]<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">But if the husband comes and claims that he did not divorce her, it is his word against hers; she is not automatically proven to be a liar.</i>. Then she should be trustworthy to say: “my levir died”! That is impossible since we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.9.1">Mishnah 15:10</a>. There is no relaxation of standards of proof before a court except in the case of testimony about a husband’s death.</i>: “A woman is not trustworthy if she says ‘my levir died’ to remarry, or ‘my sister died’ to enter her house<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">To marry her brother-in-law.</i>.” Rebbi Abba said, she is trustworthy for her husband whom she married out of her free will; she is not trustworthy about her levir on whom she was thrown against her will. Rebbi Hoshaia asked, think of it, then she should not be trustworthy if she was forced to marry him<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">If she was married off by her father while she was underage. There is no mention in the Mishnah of a restriction on women marrying on their own. No answer is given to the question.</i>!
Not only according to the current Mishnah that a single witness can permit her<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnaiot 16:7–8, a change in practice dated to the times of Trajan or Hadrian. In order to minimize the cases in which a woman is prevented from remarrying if the documentation of her husband’s death cannot be completed, the standards of proof have been extremely relaxed.</i>, but even according to the earlier Mishnah that a single witness cannot permit her, she permits herself. What is the difference between herself and a single witness? A single witness is suspected to want to cause trouble to her; she is not suspected to want to cause trouble to herself<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.1">Mishnah 10:1</a> requires her to satisfy herself that her husband is really dead. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 93b" href="/Yevamot.93b">Babli agrees, 93b</a>.</i>.
Is a single witness trustworthy in wartime? Let us hear from the following: A person was living in the times of Rebbi. They asked him about X; he said, he died. They asked him about Y; he said, he died. They asked him, are they all dead? He answered, if they were alive would they not have come<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that they were local residents.</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: The case came before Rebbi and he said, the ones married should stay married, the ones not married should not marry<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Those who remarried based on the unsupported testimony of one witness may remain married; those who want a ruling of the court in that matter will not get one.</i>. Rebbi Ayvo bar Naggari said, it happened in wartime. That implies that a single witness is trustworthy in wartime<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">If the wife accepts his testimony. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 115a" href="/Yevamot.115a">Babli, 115a</a>, there is an inconclusive discussion which may be interpreted (cf. <i>RIF, Nimmuqe Yosef</i>, in Wilna ed. 32b–33a; <i>Meïri</i>, ed. Albeck, p. 436) to follow the Yerushalmi.</i>.
What is the difference whether peace is in the world or war is in the world? If war is in the world, she might think that he died although he is not dead<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">If most of individuals in his group are known to have been killed. But her husband may have escaped or been taken prisoner. The same argument in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 114b" href="/Yevamot.114b">Babli, 114b</a>.</i>. So far if war was in the North and she came from the North, in the South and she came from the South. If there was war in the North and she came from the South; she says I am coming from the North, but I am arguing that you came from the South<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The court will argue that she has no knowledge of what really happened.</i>. If she says, I am coming from the South, it is because she thinks to free herself<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">She might lie to the court to make it appear that her husband never was near a dangerous place.</i>. If she says, he died on his bed, I am arguing that he went to war; it is because she thinks to free herself<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 114b" href="/Yevamot.114b">Babli, 114b</a>, accepts the testimony that the husband died in his bed even in a time of war.</i>.
What is a quarrel<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This wording shows that the reading in the Mishnah before the authors of the Yerushalmi was not אֵין שָׁלוֹם בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ וְשָׁלוֹם בָּעוֹלָם but קְטָטָה בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ וְשָׁלוֹם בָּעוֹלָם as in the Babli.</i>? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi. “You never gave me <i>qiddušin</i>, you did not divorce me, I never was your wife,” that is not a quarrel<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">If everybody knows that she is married to him, that is talk which is not serious.</i>. “You gave me <i>qiddušin</i>, you divorced me, but you never paid me what is owed me under my <i>ketubah</i>,” that is a quarrel<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 116a" href="/Yevamot.116a">Babli, 116a</a>, she is disqualified from testifying about her husband’s death only if the rabbinic court, which she pretends handled her divorce, denies the divorce ever took place. It is possible to read such an interpretation into the wording of the Yerushalmi.</i>. When Rebbi Abba said this before Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, he said to him, my son, even if she clearly requests to be divorced.
“Rebbi Jehudah says, she is never believed unless she comes crying with torn clothes.” They objected to Rebbi Jehudah: Think of it, if one came crying, the other did not cry. To this one you forbid, to that one you permit<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">In the language of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 116b" href="/Yevamot.116b">Babli, 116b</a>, the well-coached one will be permitted to remarry, the simple-minded one will be prevented.</i>. Rebbi Ḥananiah, the colleague of the rabbis, objected: Think of it, maybe her son went overseas and died there, she remembers that and cries<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">There are many causes that might induce a woman to cry, not necessarily her husband’s death.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Hillel say, we heard only about one who came from the grain harvest<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah is shortened in the Yerushalmi. In the Babli and the independent Mishnah mss. the text reads: “The House of Hillel say, we heard only about one who came from the harvest,<i>in the same district</i>, <i>and as it happened</i>. The House of Shammai said to them, it makes no difference whether she comes from the grain harvest, or from the olive harvest, <i>or from the grape harvest, or from another district</i>. The Sages spoke about the grain harvest only because what happened. The House of Hillel reversed themselves and taught following the House of Shammai.” It seems that the rule that the woman is permitted to testify on her own behalf was promulgated first in a case when the husband died of a heat stroke on the field and was immediately buried in place. {The cause of death was accepted as reasonable and the details of her testimony were subject to possible verification.} The House of Hillel restricts the precedent to exactly the circumstances of the first case.</i>. The House of Shammai said to them, it makes no difference whether she comes from the grain harvest, or from the olive harvest, or from overseas. The Sages spoke about the grain harvest only because of what happened. The House of Hillel reversed themselves and taught following the House of Shammai.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The House of Hillel say, we heard only,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 116b" href="/Yevamot.116b">Babli, 116b</a>.</i> The House of Shammai said to them: Is there not harvest the entire year? How is that? At the end of barley harvest starts wheat harvest. At the end of wheat harvest starts grape harvest. At the end of grape harvest starts olive harvest. That means, there is some harvest the year round. They accepted this argument. And why the grain harvest? Rebbi Mana said, because there accidents are frequent, for the sun only hits a person’s head at grain harvest time. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">2K.:18–20. He diagnoses the illness of the Sunamite’s child as a sun stroke. This is accepted by most modern commentators.</i>: “The child grew and some day it went to his father, to the harvesters. He said to his father, ‘my head, my head’; who said to the servant, ‘carry him to his mother’. He carried him and brought him to his mother where he sat on her knees until noontime, when he died.” But the rabbis say, because snakes are abundant. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 140:8" href="/Psalms.140.8"><i>Ps</i>. 140:8</a>. Usually, one would translate: “On the day of weaponry;” cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.2.2">Note 27</a>.</i>, “You shielded my head at the day of kissing,” at the day summer and winter are kissing<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">There are no other sources in talmudic literature that would declare the autumn equinox a dangerous day.</i>. Another explanation: “At the day of weaponry,” that is Gog’s weaponry<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 39" href="/Ezekiel.39"><i>Ez</i>. 39</a>, explained as prologue to the appearance of the Messiah, a descendant of David.</i>. Another explanation, on a day when two worlds kiss one another, when this world leaves and the future world enters<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The day of death.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The House of Shammai say, she should remarry and collect her <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Since the husband is declared dead, she collects the widow’s portion.</i>. The House of Hillel say, she should remarry but not collect her <i>ketubah.</i> The House of Shammai said to them, you permitted the stringent incest prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Adultery, which is considered incest. If the husband were alive, her second marriage would be adulterous.</i>, should you not permit the lenient money matters? The House of Hillel said to them, we find that the brothers cannot access the inheritance on her testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Nowhere do we find that the requirement of proof either by two witnesses or by certified document is abrogated in money matters. The leniency of informal proof applies only to the case of a woman who otherwise would have to stay unmarried for the rest of her life.</i>. The House of Shammai said, we can infer that from the text of her <i>ketubah</i> document in which he writes<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., he is required by rabbinical decree to write this sentence in her marriage document; if the sentence is missing it nevertheless is implied and enforced by the court; cf. <i>Ketubot</i> Chapter 4.</i>: “If you would be married to another man you shall take the amount I wrote for you.” The House of Hillel reversed themselves and taught following the House of Shammai.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The House of Shammai say, she should remarry,” etc. May the daughters claim upkeep based on her word<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">As will be explained later in the Halakhah, the standard text of the <i>ketubah</i> requires that “the sons will inherit and the daughters will be supported”. Since her testimony activates the <i>ketubah</i>, the daughters should be able to claim support (and a dowry in case they marry). But since the claim of the daughters is made dependent on that of the sons, and the sons cannot claim the inheritance on basis of her testimony, the daughters should be unable to claim support. The question is not answered (which <i>in praxi</i> means that the daughters cannot collect.) The problem is not treated in the Babli.</i>?
The House of Shammai insist on interpretation of the <i>ketubah</i>. As the House of Shammai explain, we can infer that from the text of her <i>ketubah</i> document in which he writes<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., he is required by rabbinical decree to write this sentence in her marriage document; if the sentence is missing it nevertheless is implied and enforced by the court; cf. <i>Ketubot</i> Chapter 4.</i>: “If you would be married to another man you shall take the amount I wrote for you.” The House of Hillel reversed themselves and taught following the House of Shammai. The House of Hillel insist on interpretation of the <i>ketubah</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:9" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.9">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:9</a>; a slightly different language in Babli <i>Baba Meṣ‘ia</i> 104a. In a slightly different arrangement the rest of the Halakhah is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:8:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.8.2-15"><i>Ketubot</i> 4:8</a>.</i> Hillel the Elder explained it, using the vernacular. In Alexandria they were writing that a man there became betrothed to a woman<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the usage in Judea, they did not execute the betrothal, <i>qiddušin</i>, by a gift but exclusively by contract.</i>. Another man abducted her from a public place<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">And immediately marry her.</i>. When this came before the Sages, they intended to declare [the children] as bastards<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>qiddušin</i> make the girl a married woman in all aspects of criminal law. If somebody abducts a betrothed girl he commits adultery and the children are bastards.</i>. Hillel the Elder told them, bring your mothers’ <i>ketubah</i>. They brough their mothers’ <i>ketubah</i>. They found written there: “When you enter my house you shall be my wife according to the laws of Moses and the Jews<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">This language makes the validity of the betrothal dependent on the fact of marriage, of the bride entering the groom’s house. If the prospective bride was abducted before entering the groom’s house, there were no <i>qiddušin</i> and the girl was free to marry any man.</i>.”
Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah insisted on interpreting the <i>ketubah</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.8.1">Mishnah<i>Ketubot</i> 4:8</a>. This Mishnah is rejected in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:8:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.8.2-15"><i>Ketubot</i> 4:8</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 49" href="/Ketubot.49">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 49a/b</a> accepts the Mishnah but holds that a father who does not support his children has to be shamed in public.</i>“Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah explained: ‘The sons shall inherit and the daughters shall be supported.’<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">A condition of the <i>ketubah</i>, incorporated in the text by reference even if not written.</i> Since the sons can only inherit after their father’s death, so the daughters can claim support only after their father’s death.”
Rebbi Meїr insists on interpreting the contract text. As Rebbi Meїr said<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:10" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.10">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:10</a>. Essentially this text, but without attribution, is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Metzia 9:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Metzia.9.3.1">Mishnah <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 9:3</a>.</i>, if somebody accepts a field as a contractor<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">He either works as a sharecropper or he leases the field for a fixed sum of money. In either case the contractor is required to keep the field in good condition so that at the expiration of the contract the owner can continue working the field as before without additional expense.</i>, one estimates how much it is expected to yield and give to [the owner]. Because the standard contract reads: “If I let it lie fallow and do not work on it, I shall pay as if from the best.”
Rebbi Jehudah insists on interpreting the contract text. <sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:11" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.11">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:11</a>; a similar text <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Metzora, Section 4 16" href="/Sifra,_Metzora,_Section_4.16"><i>Sifra Meṣora‘ Parašah</i> 4(16</a>). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 104a" href="/Bava_Metzia.104a">Babli, <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 104a</a>, presents a problem. The text of the <i>editio princeps</i> formulates the statement that he is responsible for “any other obligations that come to you from earlier times” as part of the <i>ketubah</i> document; this is R. Jehudah’s reason to require that the husband pay for all obligatory sacrifices due from his wife, even if the obligation predates the marriage. Rashi <i>ad loc</i>. changes the text to conform to the <i>Sifra</i> text; the changed text is that of the Munich ms. and all other Ashkenazic surviving mss.</i> It was stated in the name of Rebbi Jehudah: A person brings for his wife any sacrifice she is obligated for<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Nega‘im</i> 14:12. The majority hold that the husband has to pay only for his children and slaves. R. Jehudah holds that a wealthy husband has to pay for his wife’s sacrifices in the way prescribed for wealthy people even if the wife has no money of her own. But he does not have to pay for her voluntary sacrifices.</i>, even if she ate suet or desecrated the Sabbath. Also, Rebbi Jehudah says, once he divorces her, he is no longer obligated for her, for she writes to him<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">In the receipt she gives for full payment of her <i>ketubah</i>.</i> “any other obligations that come to you from earlier times.”
Rebbi Yose insists on interpreting the contract text. Rebbi Yose explained: In a place where one treats the <i>ketubah</i> as a loan<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">If the <i>ketubah</i> is treated as a mortgage on the groom’s real estate from the moment it is signed and due at the dissolution of the marriage, it relegates all mortgages executed during the marriage to secondary status. Any real estate sold by the husband after he signed the <i>ketubah</i> is potentially subject to foreclosure by the wife if there is not enough real estate left in the husband’s possession to satisfy her claim. Therefore, care must be taken in establishing the value of the <i>ketubah</i> in order to protect the innocent buyer. The value of the <i>ketubah</i> is the sum of three parts. (1) The basic sum of 200 <i>zuz</i> (defined in Mishnah <i>Peah</i> 8:8 as an amount which disqualifies its owner from public charity), (2) the voluntary amount added by the groom to that sum, and (3) the value of the dowry. It is stated here that the value of the dowry may be collected by foreclosure only if its value is correctly stated in the <i>ketubah</i> document. In places where the value of the dowry is routinely doubled, the document cannot be used against third parties for more than half the stated value.<br>A parallel text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 104b" href="/Bava_Metzia.104b">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 104b</a> and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:13" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.13">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:13</a>; in the latter text (all sources) in the name of R. Yose the Galilean.</i>, she collects the entire amount. Where one doubles, she collects only half the amount. Rebbi Eleazar [the caper grower] said, nobody is permitted to buy domesticated or wild animals or birds unless he has food prepared for them<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Ketubot</i>, this is also declared to be the interpretation of a document but the document is not indicated.</i>. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa insists on interpreting the contract text, since Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa said, a person lending money to another person should not take pledges from him for more than the value of the loan since he writes for him: “It will be paid by the property that came to my hand that I shall acquire corresponding to this [sum].”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Ketubot</i>, the text is slightly different: “He who takes a pledge from his debtor shall take it only in court; he may not enter the debtor’s house to take the pledge.” The parallels in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 104a" href="/Bava_Metzia.104a">Babli <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 104a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:12" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.12">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:12</a> follow the text given here. The text in <i>Ketubot</i> seems to require that the value of the pledge should be determined by an official of the court. The second clause in that text is a biblical verse (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:10" href="/Deuteronomy.24.10"><i>Deut</i>. 24:10</a>).</i>
Rav Huna insists on interpreting the contract text. Rav Huna explained: “The sons shall inherit but the daughters must be fed<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.6.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:6</a>.</i>.” Since the sons inherit movables<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Since the entire inheritance goes to the sons, it seems logical that the daughters should have a lien on the entire inheritance.</i>, the daughters also are fed from movables. Samuel said, the daughters are not fed from movables. A Mishnah supports Samuel: “The female children you shall have from me shall dwell in my house and be supported from my property.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.10.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:11</a>. This is one of the conditions stipulated in the marriage contract which does not have to be written down because the court will enforce it based on the existence of a <i>ketubah</i> alone. The obligation to support the daughters continues “until they are taken in marriage”.</i>” It was stated on this<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51a" href="/Ketubot.51a">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 51a</a>, this is stated in the name of the later Amora Rava and is undisputed. Rava himself rules in a practical case that if there was no real estate, the daughters must be fed in payment for the housekeeping duties they fulfill. {All these rules on the meaning of the <i>ketubah</i> contract are rabbinical and dependent on the circumstances. When the Jews lost their real estate after the Arab conquest of Iraq in the Eighth Century, the Geonim, the rabbinical authorities of that time, eliminated any mention of real estate in the rules of the <i>ketubah.</i>}</i>: From real estate but not from movables. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda said: Rav Huna follows Rebbi and Samuel follows Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 51a" href="/Ketubot.51a">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 51a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 4:18" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).4.18">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 4:18</a>. The version of the Babli is the most elaborate; probably it is the latest version taking into account the objections that may be raised against the Yerushalmi version. The Tosephta version differs in language from both Talmudim; S. Lieberman (<i>Tosephta kiFshuṭah,</i> part 6, vol. 1 (New York 1967) p. 254 shows that the Tosephta is compatible with the Babli version.</i>: “One uses both guaranteed property<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">“Property under threat of alienation”. Real estate is always sold with a warranty that if the buyer loses the property (it is alienated) because of a pre-existing lien or mortgage, the seller will indemnify the buyer. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 3:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.3.7.1"><i>Peah</i> 3:8, Note 121</a>.</i> and non-guaranteed property<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Movables.</i> for the support of the wife and the daughters, the words of Rebbi. Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, guaranteed property may be taken by sons from sons<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The court will adjudicate claims of unequal distribution of property between the heirs. (If there are no sons, the daughters legally have the status of sons.)</i>, by daughters from daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The daughters have a claim to a dowry which is fixed at 10% of the inheritance (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 6:6:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.6.6.2-4"><i>Ketubot</i>, Yerushalmi 6:6</a>, fol. 30d; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 68a" href="/Yevamot.68a">Babli 68a</a>). If there are ndaughters, for the first one has to reserve 1/<sub>10</sub> of the capital, for the second 1/<sub>10</sub>of the remaining <sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup>/<sub>10</sub>, etc. By the formula of the geometric progression, in all 1 - (<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup>/10)<sup class="footnote-marker">n</sup> of the inheritance has to be set aside for the daughters. The younger daughters may claim an equal share with the oldest one in the distribution of dowry.</i>, by sons from daughters<sup>59</sup><i class="footnote">If the inheritance is large, the sons may try to convince the court that the part reserved for the support of the unmarried daughters is too large.</i>, and by daughters from sons<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">If the inheritance is small, the daughters my apply to the court to reserve the entire inheritance for them. If the inheritance is large, the daughters may sue to invalidate any sale of real estate by the brothers which reduces the amount of capital available for their support. {This shows that the brothers have a monetary interest in marrying off their underage sisters.}</i>. But non-guaranteed property may be taken by sons from daughters<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">If they took from the inheritance.</i> but not by daughters from sons.” They said, Rav Huna reversed himself<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The silence of the Babli in this matter supports this claim in the Yerushalmi.</i>. They said, that was well done, <i>ketubah</i> is a biblical commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">This is the position of the Yerushalmi (for the marriage of a virgin), opposed by the Babli; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 7:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.7.3.3">Chapter 7, Note 63</a>.</i> but support of the daughters is from their words<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">It is part of the rabbinic <i>ketubah</i> text decreed by Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ in Hasmonean times which may show demotic Egyptian and Roman influences.</i>. May their words uproot a biblical commandment? It must be that they differ about the money contained in their mother’s <i>ketubah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">If there were sons of different mothers who predeceased the father, the original <i>ketubah</i> decree required that each set of full brothers first recover the full amount of their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> before the rest was divided among all sons.</i>. But is the money contained in their mother’s <i>ketubah</i> not also real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Since the entire <i>ketubah</i> must be satisfied by distribution of real estate (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:3:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.3.8">Note 53</a>).</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Ketubot (Lieberman) 8:2-3" href="/Tosefta_Ketubot_(Lieberman).8.2-3">Tosephta <i>Ketubot</i> 8:2–3</a>. The Tosephta contains additional statements, found in the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Metzia 28b-29a" href="/Bava_Metzia.28b-29a">Babli, <i>Baba Meṣi‘a</i> 28b–29a</a>.</i>“If somebody who works his wife’s property<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">His wife’s paraphernalia property of which he receives the usufruct as payment for his investment in and work on the fields. If he divorces his wife before harvest, he loses all rights to the crop. He therefore has an incentive to harvest as early as possible.</i> has the intention of divorcing her and goes and takes from the ground, he is quick and is rewarded. If somebody who works the property of prisoners<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Not only kidnap victims but a large class described in the next sentence. Both Talmudim, by endorsing Samuel’s definition, take position against the very wide definition of this Tosephta.</i> heard that they prepare to return, goes and takes from the ground, he is quick and is rewarded. These are properties of prisoners: In any case where his father, brother, or any person from whom he might inherit, went overseas, he heard that they died, and he went to work the inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">He had a reason to work the fields to keep them producing; he is rewarded by the possibility of acquiring the yield even if he has to return the real estate.</i>. But property of abandoning persons one takes out of their hands. These are properties of abandoning persons: In any case where his father, brother, or any person from whom he might inherit, went overseas, he did not hear that they died, but he went to work the inheritance<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">He started to work the field without authorization; if the owner returns before the harvest, he loses his investment. (In the Tosephta he may claim to be rewarded for his investment in money and time by being made a sharecropper. The Babli explains that this applies only if the farmer is appointed by the court to take care of his relative’s property. There is no hint of this in the Yerushalmi.)</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, I heard that there is no difference between prisoners and abandoning persons<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">He disagrees with the anonymous Tanna and assigns the yield to the person working the field.</i>. But property of broken persons one takes out of their hands. These are properties of smashed<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 10:14" href="/Hosea.10.14"><i>Hos.</i> 10:14</a>.</i> persons: In any case where his father, brother, or any person from whom he might inherit, went overseas, and his whereabouts are not known.” Samuel says, the prisoner is one who left involuntarily. If he had left voluntarily he would have given him instructions<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The relative who went to work the field may reasonably assume that he would have been appointed to care for the property if the kidnap victim had had time to communicate with him. Therefore, the courts will assign the yield to him.</i>. The abandoning person is one who left voluntarily. You should know that he had the intention of keeping [the relative] off his property since he left voluntarily and did not give him instructions<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel disagrees with Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel and refuses the harvest to the relative working the field.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa, Rebbi Abba, Rav Jehudah in the name of Samuel: Movables do not fall under the rules of smashed people<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The absent person cannot reclaim usufruct the unauthorized relative had from his movables.</i>. RebbiJacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rav Jehudah: Standing grain ready to be harvested and grapes ready to be harvested are movables<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 43a" href="/Shevuot.43a">Babli, <i>Šebuot</i> 43a</a>, theparallel statement is attributed to the Tanna R. Meїr; the anonymous majority declares any ripe crop to be under the laws of real estate until harvested. That means that the editors of the Babli rejected the attribution of the statement to Samuel, their highest authority in civil law.</i>. Rav Sheshet asked: Those date palms of Babylonia which do not need grafting<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">There, palm trees are so abundant that it is not necessary to take male flowers and hang them into the crowns of female trees. That means that the trees do not need hard work.</i>, is it not reasonable that we should treat them like standing grain ready to be harvested and grapes ready to be harvested<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">No answer is given. The problem is not treated in the Babli since it precludes the basis of the question.</i>?

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Everybody is accepted to be a witness for her<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 16:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.16.7.1">Mishnah 16:8</a>, even slaves and in certain cases people who attest to hearsay are empowered to declare that the husband died and that the woman is a widow free to remarry.</i> except<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that these hate her and that they might give wrong information in order to forbid her to her husband.</i> her mother-in-law, her mother-in-law’s daughter, her co-wife, her levir’s wife, and her husband’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">From another wife.</i>. What is the difference between a bill of divorce and death<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">It is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 2:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.2.7.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 2:8</a> that the women who are not empowered to testify to the husband’s death are empowered to deliver her bill of divorce and to testify to its validity.</i>? The document is the proof. If one witness says that he died and she remarried, then another comes and says that he is not dead, she shall not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Once she has remarried, her marriage can be invalidated only by the (biblically valid) testimony of two independent credible witnesses. But if she has not yet remarried, it is the word of one against the other and she should not remarry until the situation is clear.</i>. If one witness says that he died but two say that he did not die, even if she remarried she must leave. If two say that he died but one said that he did not die, even if she has not yet remarried she may remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Since the testimony of two witnesses is valid by biblical standards (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut.</i> 19:15</a>), the word of a single witness is disregarded.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Everybody is accepted to be a witness for her,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 117a" href="/Yevamot.117a">Babli, 117a</a>, agrees implicitly since it states that it is not necessary to note that the daughter-in-law cannot be trusted since the mother-in-law is on the list.</i>: “Just as they cannot be trusted for her, so she cannot be trusted about them.” Her mother-in-law’s son is like her mother-in-law’s daughter. Her husband’s son is like her husband’s daughter. Her co-wife, even if remarried<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">She no longer has any interest in her former husband’s marriage.</i>. Her levir’s wife, even [if she is] her own sister<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Who can never be married in levirate.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, a Mishnah says that they did not treat the males as they treat the females, as we have stated there: “because a woman is not trusted if she says, my levir died, that she should be free to remarry, nor that her sister died, to enter her house.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:10:1-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.10.1-3">Mishnah 12</a>. The Mishnah continues: “Nor can a man be trusted to say ‘my brother died’ in order to marry his wife, nor ‘my wife died’, in order to marry her sister.” That means that the levir can be trusted if he says that his brother died if the latter had children. But the statement of the Mishnah, that the levir’s wife is excluded from testimony, is absolute and not dependent on her being a candidate for levirate.</i>” Because she has no children. But if she has children, she is trustworthy.
Does the document prove? Do we not have to believe what she says? If she did not say ‘it was written in my presence, it was signed in my presence’, would you permit her to remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.1.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:1</a> states that abill of divorce brought from far away is accepted by the local court only if the person delivering the bill testifies that it was executed in his presence and, therefore, he can be queried about the details of the execution. Without such testimony, the woman to whom the bill is addressed cannot be declared to be a divorcee free to remarry.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, that parallels what Rebbi Abun said<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.1.2-11">Halakhah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:1</a>.</i>, one does not suspect him to vilify her in the eyes of Heaven; he is suspect to vilify her in the eyes of the court<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">If the husband would trick the messenger into delivering an invalid bill of divorce and the court would declare the woman free to remarry on that basis, the only consequence would be that the children of the divorcee from a second husband would be bastards in the eyes of Heaven. Since the divorce, once approved by a competent court, cannot be reversed, the second marriage will always be legitimate in the eyes of the public and the children will be legitimate and able to marry in the congregation. But the court has to be able to cross-examine him before it accepts the document to be sure that the husband had the bill signed by witnesses in good standing.</i>. Since he knows that if he were to come [and object, his objection] would not be accepted<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this is the argument of Rava (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.3">Chapter 1, Note 19</a>). Another opinion there holds that the excluded women may deliver a bill of divorce only locally since then their testimony is not needed, as the testimony is not directly mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 2:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.2.7.1">Mishnah <i>Giṭṭin</i> 2:8</a>. Since the Babli accepts Rava’s argument, it concurs that a bill of divorce duly accepted in a second court cannot be attacked by the husband.</i>, he has [the bill of divorce] signed by witnesses in good standing. And here, since she knows that her word does not count for the other woman, she will be truthful.
“If one witness says,” etc. “If one witness says that he died and she remarried, then another comes and says that he is not dead, she shall not leave.” Because he said that after she had remarried. Therefore if [the second witness came] before she remarried, if she remarried she has to leave. Rebbi Joḥanan said, these are the words of Rebbi Menaḥem ben Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>.</i>. But the words of the Sages [are], whether he testified after she remarried or before she remarried, she should not remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Since a woman remarrying on the testimony of a single witness does so at her own peril as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:1:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.1.2-12">Halakhah 10:1</a>.</i>, but if she remarried she shall not leave. Rav Naḥman bar Jacob said in the name of Rav, if she was married by the testimony of two witnesses, even if he returns, one says to him, “you are not he.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">In this version, the court tells the returning husband that they do not know him. In the earlier version (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:5:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.5.3">Chapter 10, Note 129</a>) the wife tells the returning husband that she does not know him.</i>” Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac asked, think of it, if he is a famous person like Immi? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, is there nobody who would look like Rebbi Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">The rule of Rav was also accepted in Galilee, with misgivings.</i>? There came a case before the rabbis there. They said to him, “you are not he.” Abba bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Samuel’s father. The story implies that Abba bar Abba did outlive Rav since “the students of Rav” only appear in cases after Rav’s death.</i> got up and whispered in his<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The second husband, who had married her on the testimony of two credible witnesses with the agreement of the court.</i> ear saying, by your life, give her a bill of divorce because of the doubt. Rav’s students got up and beat him. Somebody said, the whip is burning and the footstool is burning<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">It is difficult to understand what this means; probably one should translate אמר as third person plural: They (Rav’s students) said that Abba bar Abba should be whipped with a burning whip kneeling on a burning footstool because he denied the validity of their teacher’s decision.</i>. Samuel said, I was there, no whip was burning and no footstool was burning, but my father was hit<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">In the tumult.</i> and got up<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">He left without insisting that the matter of applying Rav’s teaching should come to a vote. The Babli knows nothing of Rav’s ruling nor of Abba bar Abba’s opposition.</i>. There came a case before Rebbi Immi. He said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">A man went overseas with his two wives; the wives return without the husband.</i>, yes, it is sure that she is permitted to you but you should know that the child of this man is a bastard before Heaven. Rebbi Ze‘ira was praising him because he made the situation clear.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One [wife] says<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">A man went overseas with his two wives; the wives return without the husband.</i>, he died, the other one says, he did not die. The one who said that he died can remarry and collect her <i>ketubah</i>; the one who said that he did not die cannot remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">According to her own statement, a second marriage would be adulterous. The <i>ketubah</i> is due only at the dissolution of the marriage.</i> nor collect her <i>ketubah</i>. If one said that he died, while the other one<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">According to the understanding of the Halakhah, this refers to two unrelated women who testify about their common husband who has disappeared.</i> said he was killed; Rebbi Meïr says, since they contradict one another, they<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The wives who contradict one another.</i> cannot remarry. Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Simeon say, since both agree that he is not alive they can remarry.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A woman who went overseas with her husband,”<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">A misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:7:1-8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.7.1-8.2">Mishnah 7</a>.</i> etc. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Rebbi Meïr agrees in the first case<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Of two co-wives giving conflicting testimony.</i>. It was found stated: That is also in dispute. What is the difference between the second and the first cases? In the first case, did they not consider her word as nonexistent for her companion<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Nothing a wife says has any legal consequences for her co-wife. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 118a" href="/Yevamot.118a">Babli, 118a</a>, quotes R. Joḥanan as holding that a quarrel whether the husband is dead or not is not a contradiction. That opinion is characterized as difficult to understand. The simple solution offered here is not mentioned; this implies that it is rejected.)</i>? Rebbi Eleazar said, Rebbi Judah and Rebbi Simeon concede in the case of witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Witnesses who contradict one another in details that have no essential bearing on the case before the court are nevertheless legally contradicting one another, making their testimony worthless. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 118a" href="/Yevamot.118a">Babli, 118a</a>, R. Eleazar and R. Joḥanan reject any distinction by R. Jehudah and R. Simeon between women and witnesses.</i>. What is the difference between witnesses and the co-wife? Did they not consider the co-wife’s words as nonexistent for her companion<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Nothing a wife says has any legal consequences for her co-wife. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 118a" href="/Yevamot.118a">Babli, 118a</a>, quotes R. Joḥanan as holding that a quarrel whether the husband is dead or not is not a contradiction. That opinion is characterized as difficult to understand. The simple solution offered here is not mentioned; this implies that it is rejected.)</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said, if Rebbi Eleazar said this, he heard it from me and formulated it<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">A frequent complaint of R. Joḥanan, that R. Eleazar should have formulated his statement for the permanent record as stating: R. Joḥanan says.…</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 3:7:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.3.7.2-3"><i>Nazir</i> 3:7</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:2:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.2.2-4"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 5:2</a>.</i> There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 3:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.3.7.1">Mishnah <i>Nazir</i> 3:7</a>.</i>: “If two groups of witnesses testified about him, one group testifying that he vowed two periods of <i>nezirut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The vow to abstain from grape products, from impurity of the dead, and from hair cutting, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 6:1-21" href="/Numbers.6.1-21"><i>Num.</i> 6:1–21</a>. If the person making the vow does not indicate the duration of the vow, it is for a period of 30 days (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 3:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.3.1.1">Mishnah <i>Nazir</i>3:1</a>).</i>, the other group testifying that he vowed five periods of <i>nezirut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">“The House of Shammai say, this is conflicting testimony, there is no <i>nezirut,</i> the House of Hillel say, two is included in a totality of five, he must be a <i>nazir</i> for two periods.”</i>” Rav said, they differ in the overall testimony. But in detail, everybody agrees that five contains two, that he has to be a <i>nazir</i> for two periods<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">What Rav calls detail, R. Joḥanan calls counting. Rav holds that the Houses of Shammai and Hillel disagree if one group of witnesses say that he vowed two periods and the other group say five periods. But if the first group testify that he vowed a first and a second time separate 30-day periods of <i>nezirut,</i> and the other group confirm this but add that he also vowed third, fourth, and fifth periods, then the testimony for the first two periods is concurrent and valid according to everybody. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nazir 20" href="/Nazir.20">Babli agrees, <i>Nazir</i> 20a/b</a>, in the names of Rav and the Galileans.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, they differ in counting. But in an overall testimony, everybody agrees that the testimonies contradict one another and there is no <i>nezirut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">R. Joḥanan holds that the testimony of 5 contradicts the testimony of 2 and the House of Hillel will agree that both testimonies are invalid. He holds that the House of Hillel consider a testimony on (1,2) to be contained in the testimony about (1,2,3,4,5), but the House of Shammai see the testimonies as contradicting one another.</i>. What is overall and what is counting? Overall, this one says two, the other one says five. Counting, this one says one, two, the other one says three, four, five.
Rav said, if testimony was contradicted in its essence, the testimony is not void<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The court may try to piece together an account of what really happened.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if testimony was contradicted in itself, the testimony is void in the opinion of everybody<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Both the testimony and the opposing testimony are eliminated from the record.</i>. If testimony was contradicted in some aspects that belong after the fact, the testimony is not void<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The example given below is concurrent testimony how the murder was committed but conflicting testimony as to the direction of escape of the murderer, which is testimony to what happened after the criminal act was committed.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan is consistent since Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Ḥiyya, said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, if it was agreed that he counted<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In some case before the court one needs to establish the fact that one party counted a certain amount of money.</i> but one [witness] said, he counted from a wallet and the other said, he counted from a bundle, that contradicts the essence of the testimony, and Rav will agree that the testimony is void. Where do they disagree? If there were two groups of witnesses, these say he counted from a wallet and the others say he counted from a bundle. That contradicts the essence of the testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Joḥanan, concurrent testimony by several witnesses is biblical testimony binding on the court only if it holds up under cross examination; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:18" href="/Deuteronomy.19.18"><i>Deut.</i> 19:18</a>: “The judges have to investigate thoroughly”.</i>, the testimony is void but according to Rav, the testimony is not void<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In the first case, there was no testimony. If both witnesses had testified in a coherent way, the fact would have been established by two independent witnesses and would be testimony by biblical standards which is binding on the court. In the second case, Rav holds that both testimonies are binding by biblical standards and can be used to establish any fact that is uncontested between the two groups; in that example that one of the parties counted money.</i>. These say, he counted into his bosom, the others say he counted into his money-belt; everybody agrees that is contradicting testimony after the main testimony, and the testimony is not void. If one [witness] said, he killed him with a mace, the other [witness] said, he killed him with a sword, that contradicts the essence of the testimony, the testimony is void and Rav will agree that the testimony is void<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">In criminal cases, the testimony of a single witness has no standing; if the two testimonies do not combine in a meaningful way, there is no testimony (this example is quoted by Rav Ḥisda in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30b" href="/Sanhedrin.30b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i>30b</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 41a" href="/Sanhedrin.41a">41a</a>). (In civil cases, a single witness also cannot testify but he can be used to ascertain circumstances.)</i>. Where do they disagree? If there were two groups of witnesses, these say he killed him with a mace and the others say, he killed him with a sword. That contradicts the essence of the testimony, the testimony is void but according to Rav, the testimony is not void. If these say, he ran away to the South and those say, he ran away to the North, everybody agrees that the testimony was contradictory in some aspects that belong after the fact, the testimony is not void<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The example given below is concurrent testimony how the murder was committed but conflicting testimony as to the direction of escape of the murderer, which is testimony to what happened after the criminal act was committed.</i>. The strength of Rav comes from the following: “Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Simeon say, since both agree that he is not alive they can remarry.” He did nor hear that Rebbi Eleazar said, Rebbi Judah and Rebbi Simeon concede in the case of witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Witnesses who contradict one another in details that have no essential bearing on the case before the court are nevertheless legally contradicting one another, making their testimony worthless. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 118a" href="/Yevamot.118a">Babli, 118a</a>, R. Eleazar and R. Joḥanan reject any distinction by R. Jehudah and R. Simeon between women and witnesses.</i>. What is the difference between witnesses and the co-wife? Did they not consider the co-wife’s words as nonexistent for her companion<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Nothing a wife says has any legal consequences for her co-wife. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 118a" href="/Yevamot.118a">Babli, 118a</a>, quotes R. Joḥanan as holding that a quarrel whether the husband is dead or not is not a contradiction. That opinion is characterized as difficult to understand. The simple solution offered here is not mentioned; this implies that it is rejected.)</i>? (Rebbi Joḥanan said, if Rebbi Eleazar said this, he heard it from me and formulated it<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">A frequent complaint of R. Joḥanan, that R. Eleazar should have formulated his statement for the permanent record as stating: R. Joḥanan says.…</i>.)<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The text in parenthesis is from ms. A only; probably it is copied from above by an unthinking scribe.</i> A Mishnah disagrees with Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.2.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 5:2</a>.</i>: “Both in investigations<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">The procedures before a Talmudic court are inquisitory. In a first stage the witnesses are queried about the alleged crime.</i> and in cross examinations<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">These are questions about matters of secondary importance put to each witness in the absence of the other to ferret out any prior understanding between the witnesses, which would invalidate the testimony, or inconsistencies in detail which would impair its standing.</i>, if they contradict one another their testimony is void.” Rebbi Mana said, Rav will explain that as referring to single witness against single witness. Rebbi Abun said, even if you say groups and groups. There is a difference in criminal cases: “Justice, justice you shall pursue”<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:20" href="/Deuteronomy.16.20"><i>Deut.</i> 16:20</a>. In criminal cases, proof beyond any reasonable doubt is required.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One witness said that he died, another witness said that he did not die; a woman said that he died, another woman said that he did not die; she may not remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Two witnesses testify to opposite facts and the court sees no reason to believe the one more than the other. In that case there is no testimony and the wife of the disappeared husband cannot remarry.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “if she says ‘my husband died’,” etc<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">A misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:7:1-8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.7.1-8.2">Mishnah 7</a>.</i>. Gidul bar Miniamin in the name of Rav: Anywhere they accepted the testimony of a woman parallel to that of a man, a man can contradict a woman and a woman can contradict a man. Then one should state: “A witness says that he died, and a woman says that he did not die; a woman said that he died and a witness said that he did not die.” In the House of Rebbi they stated it this way. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>; formulation as in ms. A and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 88b" href="/Yevamot.88b">Babli (88b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 117b" href="/Yevamot.117b">117b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 31b" href="/Sotah.31b"><i>Soṭah</i>31b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 47b" href="/Sotah.47b">47b</a>) against the reading of the Yerushalmi here and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 6:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.6.4.2-4"><i>Soṭah</i> 6:4</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 9:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.9.7.2">9:7</a>.</i> in the name of Rebbi Neḥemiah: One follows the majority of the testimonies. How is that? Two women against one woman they considered as if there were two witnesses against one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Two concurring witnesses have biblical status. One witness contradicting two witnesses has no standing, assuming that all are of the same reliability.</i>. What you say refers to a woman and women. But if there were a hundred women against one [male] witness, they are like one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli presents two opinions. Everybody holds that in the weight of testimony there is no difference between 2 and 100 witnesses. The first opinion holds that if the women came first, the single male witness has no standing. The other holds that any number of women against a male whose credibility is unimpaired (i. e., he never was found in violation of <i>any</i> biblical commandment) are like testimony split 50–50. This is accepted by Maimonides (<i>Gerušin</i> 12:20). Anywhere the text uses “witness” instead of “man” it means a male of impeccable standing.<br>The reading of the <i>editio princeps</i>, כעד אינון, is supported by R. Nissim Gerondi (Commentary to RIF <i>Ketubot</i>, §206): כעידי אינון.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman went overseas with her husband and she returns and says “my husband died”, she can remarry and collect her <i>ketubah</i>, but her co-wife remains forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Since the testimony of a wife cannot be trusted in matters of her co-wife.</i>. If she was the daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">And she has no son on whose behalf she remains in the priestly clan and continues to eat heave.</i>, she should eat heave, the words of Rebbi Tarphon. Rebbi Aqiba says, in this way one does not remove her from sin unless she be forbidden to remarry<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Since perhaps her co-wife is ready to put herself in a perilous position in order to damage her co-wife.</i> and forbidden to eat heave<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Since perhaps the testimony of her co-wife was true.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> She is suspected to cause trouble to herself in order to cause trouble to her co-wife<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">She is ready to forbid herself to her husband if it causes her co-wife to be equally forbidden.</i>. Then she should not be trustworthy even for herself! Since she knows that her word does not count for the other woman, she will be truthful<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 4:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.4.3.3">Halakhah 4, Note 94</a>.</i>. Then she should be trustworthy even for her co-wife! <sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Ms. A has an addition: . אָמַר רִבִּי הִילָא חֲזוֹר לְקִילקוּל הָרִאשׁוֹן חֲשׁוּדָה הִיא“Rebbi Ila said, go back to the first trouble; she is suspected …”.</i> She is suspected to cause trouble to herself in order to cause trouble to her co-wife.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a woman went overseas with her husband and she returns and says “my husband died and then my father-in-law died”, she can remarry and collect her <i>ketubah</i>, but her mother-in-law remains forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">This is a complete parallel to the preceding Mishnah and shows that the same rules apply to all women who cannot be trusted with the testimony about a husband’s death.</i>. If she was the daughter of an Israel married to a Cohen, she should eat heave, the words of Rebbi Tarphon. Rebbi Aqiba says, in this way one does not remove her from sin unless she be forbidden to remarry and forbidden to eat heave.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he was betrothed to one.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Wrong quote, belonging to the next Mishnah.</i>” Should she not be trusted to say “my father-in-law died”? Did we not hold that just as they are not trusted about her so she is not trusted about them<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yevamot (Lieberman) 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Yevamot_(Lieberman).14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 117a" href="/Yevamot.117a">Babli, 117a</a>, agrees implicitly since it states that it is not necessary to note that the daughter-in-law cannot be trusted since the mother-in-law is on the list.</i>?
